HEADLINE: OBJECTIONS MOUNT OVER VALDEZ PACT

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
Prompted by new studies on the damage to Prince William Sound and annoyed that scientific and economic information is being kept secret, lawmakers, environmental groups and many Alaskans are raising increasing objections to the $1.1 billion civil and criminal settlement of the Exxon Valdez oil spill.
In hearings this month held by a state House committee, hundreds of fishermen and native Alaskan villagers urged the panel to reject the proposed settlement, contending that $1 billion was neither enough money to pay for damage to the environment from the spill nor a severe penalty for the Exxon Corporation. 
 The House committee and a separate panel of the state Senate met in Juneau today to consider the comments and decide whether to recommend accepting the settlement arising from the 11-million-gallon spill on March 14, 1989. After the panels decide, the issue will go to the full Legislature.
 
Opponents in Washington
 Opponents of the settlement include Representative George Miller, a California Democrat who is acting chairman of the House Interior Committee. He has asked Federal District Judge H. Russel Holland in Alaska to reject the agreement made with Exxon to settle criminal violations.
Four other House Democrats urged the judge last week to postpone a decision on the settlement until scientific and economic studies on the condition of Prince William Sound are made public.
National environmental groups today also withdrew their earlier support, and officials from native Alaskan villages are pressing a court case in Federal District Court here aimed at scuttling the pact.
By far the largest settlement ever for damage caused by an environmental disaster, the agreement between the Justice Department, Alaska and Exxon calls for the company to pay up to $1 billion over the next 14 years to reimburse the state and Federal governments for scientific studies and environmental restoration projects. The pact also calls on Exxon and its shipping subsidiary to plead guilty to four criminal violations of environmental law and pay a fine of $100 million.
Lawyers for the Justice Department and the Alaska Attorney General, Charles E. Cole, have warned that any changes in the agreement could lead to its collapse. In an interview today, Mr. Cole said more Alaskans now appeared to oppose the agreement, but he said support for the pact was also strong in the state. A poll by an independent company commissioned by the Governor last week showed Alaskans supported the agreement by two to one, Mr. Cole said.
"What's happened is that as more people understand the settlement, they realize that $1 billion paid out over a decade is not enough to make up for the damages caused by the oil spill," Representative Miller said. "The people in Alaska have every reason to be concerned."
Mr. Miller complained this month in two letters to Judge Holland the agreement would immunize the Alyeska Pipeline Service Company, the owner of the Trans-Alaska pipeline and the Valdez oil terminal, from prosecution by the Government. Alyeska is owned by Exxon and seven other companies.
He said the protection for Alyeska was not in the public interest because documents his staff uncovered showed the company knew it was unable to respond to a major oil spill but misrepresented its abilities in documents it filed with the state.
 
Studies Remain Secret
 Opponents are also angry that scientific studies on damage to Prince William Sound, and economic studies that show how much the damage will cost, remain secret.
Earlier this month, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration released a summary of 58 scientific studies that said the oil spill killed hundreds of thousands of birds, thousands of otters and caused extensive damage to shorelines and tidal zones that will persist for years. Economists under contract to the state and the Federal Government said in interviews that in separate reports they estimated the damage at $3 billion to $5 billion.
Fishermen in Prince William Sound and Representative Gerry E. Studds, a Massachusetts Democrat who is chairman of a House Merchant Marine and Fisheries subcommittee, have asked Judge Holland to delay ruling on the settlement until the studies are made public.
 
'It's Made People Really Mad'
 "This is the big thing that caught everybody's attention," said Marilyn Leland, executive director of Cordova District Fishermen United, an association in Cordova, Alaska. "The state decides it is going to withhold the damage assessment data. We're the ones who bought this information the state says we can't get. We can't tell if the settlement is worth it because we don't know what the damages are. It's made people really mad."
Mr. Studds added: "The Federal and state governments and Exxon are essentially asking us to take on faith the fact this is a fair settlement. I hope it is. I would hate to see some of the procedures used in this case repeated elsewhere."
Native Alaskan villages are also seeking to bar the settlement in a District Court here. In February, the villagers filed suit against the Government, seeking to prevent the settlement from being signed. Lawyers for the native groups said the settlement would prevent the villagers from gaining damages from Exxon. District Judge Stanley Sporkin agreed to review the settlement and a hearing on the suit is scheduled for next Monday.
Exxon said through a spokesman today that it would not respond to questions about the settlement.
Amy Casner, a spokeswoman for the Justice Department, said, "We'll be addressing the court Wednesday and anything more we have to say we'll say there."

HEADLINE: Battle Lines Drawn in Sand As Las Vegas Covets Water

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS

 BODY:
This desert fantasy land of gambling casinos, lush lawns and fake lakes that is the fastest-growing major city in the United States will outstrip its water supplies by 1995 unless it soon finds new sources and conserves what it has.
Now Las Vegas is looking north to secure its future by harvesting water underneath vast, sparsely populated rural Nevada. The multibillion-dollar undertaking would pump water from an ancient aquifer in an area nearly as large as West Virginia and ship it south through more than 1,000 miles of pipelines. 
 Seventy years after the City of Los Angeles grabbed control of the water rights in the Owens Valley of California, with raw chicanery chronicled in the film "Chinatown," rural Nevadans say history is about to repeat itself. They fear that their land, like the Owens Valley, will become a dust bowl, its water diverted to build a vast city in an arid basin.
 
Reminder of Deeper Problem
 The move by Las Vegas exemplifies the growing problem of the West, where cities are beginning to confront limits to growth, limits set by the shortage of water, a commodity as scarce in the West as sun, land and optimism are plentiful.
The five-year drought that has gripped the Southwest has only hastened the day of reckoning that many experts said was inevitable. Four water districts in Southern California have stopped accepting new customers. Home construction in Lake Elsinore, a fast-growing city north of San Diego, has been halted, and many communities along the parched central coast of California have imposed limits on new water connections, as has Marin County north of San Francisco.
The angry accusations of a "water grab" by Las Vegas are being argued over four days ending Thursday as Las Vegas water officials hold a series of meetings around Nevada to explain why the city should have the water. It is a debate about the kind of growth wanted in the West, about whether water-profligate cities like Las Vegas deserve more water, and about fears that Las Vegas's thirst might destroy rare animal and bird species and wetlands hundreds of miles away.
"The way you hold on to the future in the West is to take control of the water -- that draws the political, economic and demographic landscape," said Stephen T. Bradhurst, a Reno planning consultant engaged by rural Nye County. Nye has formed an alliance with Lincoln and White Pine counties in Nevada, Inyo County in California and others to fight Las Vegas.
Southern Nevada's power in the State Legislature, and a state law that allows outside parties to claim any water not being used, give Las Vegas the upper hand in the dispute. But opponents hope that the complicated interests of the Federal Government, which owns the vast majority of land in the state, will push the issue into Federal courts, where Las Vegas may be at more of a disadvantage.
The Las Vegas Valley Water District, the agency that has applied for the new water, supplies most of the water in Clark County, which includes Las Vegas. Leaders of the agency say that they only want to tap unused water that is replenished every year and that the continued prosperity of Las Vegas, the largest city in the fastest-growing state, is essential to all Nevadans. "If Southern Nevada dies, Nevada dies," said Patricia Mulroy, general manager of the water district.
 
An Odd Alliance Against Las Vegas
 In their opposition to Las Vegas, the state's ranchers and farmers have found themselves in an odd alliance with their traditional foes, environmentalists and Federal agencies. The state water engineer, R. Michael Turnipseed, who must approve the Las Vegas proposal, has received more than 3,600 protests from groups and individuals, including the National Park Service, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, the Moapa Band of Paiute Indians and the Sierra Club.
Federal officials say the plan could endanger the Ash Meadows, Moapa Valley, Desert and Pahranagat Lakes national wildlife refuges, as well as the fragile life that clings to the 364 springs in Death Valley National Monument 125 miles away in California.
Paced by migrants from California and the East drawn by its desert climate and low prices, Clark County's population grew by an astonishing 62 percent between the 1980 and 1990 censuses, to 741,459 from 463,087. The newcomers have been wooed to this desert valley, which had only two inches of rain all last year, with water.
Until they were halted by a recent new law, developers used drinking water to build artificial lakes for new communities with names like The Lakes, Desert Shores and Lake Las Vegas, a resort with a 320-acre lake planned near Henderson that was approved before the moratorium. Seven miles west of the famed Strip, The Lakes development has a 30-acre lake, where residents of million-dollar homes even have a sailing club.
 
Torrents of Waste Flow Into Gutters
 Sprinklers send small rivers of water into the gutters daily all over Las Vegas. Acres of grass surround the new Citicorp Nevada building, a credit-card processing operation, on West Sahara Avenue. Huge sprinklers spray water during hot daylight hours into the air and, on a recent windy day, thousands of gallons drained into the streets. When questioned, Citicorp officials said they planned to replace half the lawn with desert plants soon.
Water is also the illusion that helps draw 20.3 million tourists a year to the gambling strip. The new $611 million Mirage Hotel, which describes itself as a "South Seas oasis," is set behind a 4.5-acre lagoon with 54-foot waterfalls and has a 1.3 million-gallon pool for its dolphins and a 20,000-gallon aquarium with more than 1,000 fish just behind the registration desk.
If it seems like water is wasted here, that is because it is dirt cheap. Until November, the district charged only 73 cents for 1,000 gallons. Last November, rates went up to 91 cents for the first 1,500 gallons a day and $1.01 above that, but even so water remains a huge bargain, less than a third of the $3.23 per 1,000 paid in Los Angeles.
Southern Nevada gets 80 percent of its water from Lake Mead, behind the Hoover Dam on the Colorado River. Seven states draw water from the river, and this region's allotment of 300,000 acre-feet a year will be used up by 1995. (An acre-foot, 325,850 gallons, is about enough to supply two typical families for a year.) By achieving 20 percent conservation and returning treated effluent to Lake Mead, Ms. Mulroy of the water district said the region could get to the year 2006 -- but no further -- if present projections for population growth hold true.
The district has enraged rural Nevadans by applying to drill 146 wells in 28 basins in four counties, some nearly 300 miles away from Las Vegas. The district applied for 840,000 acre-feet a year, but says now it really expects about 200,000 acre-feet, enough to permit Las Vegas and its suburbs to double in population by the year 2030. Under Nevada law, unused water belongs to the state, and it can be appropriated by any party that can put it to "beneficial use." The district has at least 20 years to demonstrate that it can use the claimed water before losing it, meaning that others cannot take the water in the meantime.
"The growth of rural Nevada is dead now because of Las Vegas," said Richard L. Carver, a rancher in the Smoky Valley about 200 miles northwest of Las Vegas. Mr. Carver is also a Nye County Commissioner. He said Nye, with only about 17,000 people, was poised to develop industry and recreational businesses because of its proximity to California, but could not do so without adequate water.
 
Nightmare Images Of Growing City
 Further, he said, Las Vegas is plagued with intensifying urban problems of smog, traffic, drug gangs and the like. "How are they going to clean up and bring in another million people?" he asked. "Nobody in Las Vegas wants growth except the county commissioners and the gaming industry."
Ranchers and farmers across a vast region fear that the pumping will lower the water table. They say they have husbanded a precious resource for years and are appalled at the waste they see in Las Vegas. Hank H. Records, for one, homesteaded the Amargosa Valley 90 miles northwest of Las Vegas 41 years ago. Though Las Vegas has proposed no wells in the water-rich valley, geological studies show that water flows toward it through the aquifer into which the wells would be drilled.
"This is our livelihood," Mr. Records, now 73, said as he looked out over the flat valley toward the Funeral Mountains in California. "Why don't they stop those golf courses before they stop our fields of green?" he said. "Let them conserve a little bit."
Mr. Bradhurst, the Nye County consultant, said Las Vegas's contention that it needed the water to maintain the gaming and tourist industry was specious because only 8 percent of its water went to casinos and hotels. Well over 60 percent, he said, goes to watering lawns and golf courses. "So there is not a lot of water used to support people who gamble," Mr. Bradhurst said, adding that he thought Clark County wanted to create a "dead zone" around it.
 
Two Wests Collide: The Old and New
 Ms. Mulroy said that Las Vegas intended to harvest only a "safe yield" of perennial water -- meaning water that is replenished through rain and snow annually -- and that it intended to give some of it to the rural counties to help them develop. "They do not want that opportunity," she said. "They want to maintain a rural life style. This is forcing rural Nevada to address an issue they never wanted to address. We have a colliding of the new and old West."
She pointed to figures showing that agriculture uses 90.3 percent of water but produced only 6,010 jobs and $168 million in revenue per year, while the remainder of the economy, mainly tourism and gaming, used 9.7 percent of available water and produced 547,100 jobs and $19.4 billion in revenue. "We are not asking for it all; we are not touching the 90 percent," she said. Gaming and tourism, she went on, provide half the state Government's income, relieving Nevadans of paying income taxes and other burdensome levies. "They are biting that hand that feeds them," she said of the rural counties.
Stephen A. Wynn, chairman of the board of Golden Nugget Inc., which owns the Mirage Hotel, said this one hotel, with 7,200 employees, generated a larger payroll, $180 million a year, than all the ranching and farming in Nevada. Water, he said, provided the essential "tension" between fantasy and reality that made Las Vegas what it is. He said any restrictions that slowed hotel building would "put an imaginative damper on the future of the place."
It is 125 miles from the watery glitter of the Strip to Death Valley in California. The park lies at the southern end of the vast aquifer under Southern Nevada, whose waters generally flow south. While studies are not conclusive, the park's superintendent, Edwin L. Rothfuss, said he feared that if Las Vegas tapped the aquifer, water would stop flowing out of the springs there.
 
Will Death Valley Live Up to Name?
 Mel Essington, a park service geologist, took a visitor to Naverres Springs, a typical oasis in the searing valley. For about 200 feet, a trickle of water fills a narrow wash, supporting a vast array of desert life -- native palms, sage, arrow weed, bighorn sheep, bobcats and reptiles. "The situation is roughly analogous to a bathtub," he said. "You remove only a small amount of water, and it no longer flows over the edge."
Just across the border in Nevada is the Ash Meadows National Wildlife Refuge, where numerous seeps support 26 plants and animals found nowhere else in the world, including such endangered species as the Ash Meadows speckled dace, a fish, and the Devil's Hole pupfish, an inch-long fish whose entire population is found in one water hole. It is protected by a 1976 ruling by the United States Supreme Court. Douglas L. Threloff, a biologist with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, called it the "American version of the Galapagos Islands," an irreplacable laboratory for the study of evolution in harsh environments.
Ms. Mulroy said the district would stop pumping if it caused any environmental damage to Federal lands. But Federal officials, asking for an environmental impact study, have asked the state water engineer to postpone making a decision on the Las Vegas request for 18 months. If he does not grant the delay requested by the Federal officials, he is expected to hold hearings later this year before making a decision.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A Maxwell Crusader In a Tabloid Wrapper

BYLINE: By SUZANNE CASSIDY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, April 22

 BODY:
The Daily Mirror's newsroom has a wall-sized reproduction of a front page that the newspaper published during Britain's last general election campaign. Two children stand on a rubble-strewn street in front of bricked-up houses. The big headline reads: "Whose Life, Whose Future?" A smaller headline accompanying a photograph of Margaret Thatcher, then the Prime Minister, reads: "She doesn't care for them. Do you?"
That front page tells a lot about The Daily Mirror, the 88-year-old mass-circulation tabloid newspaper that is the flagship of Robert Maxwell's Mirror Group P.L.C., whose holdings now include The Daily News in New York.
 
'Not Frightened of Anyone'
 The front page reveals the paper's deep disdain for Conservative governments, its penchant for the one-two punch and its unflinching embrace of crusade journalism. 
 "We are an aggressive, left-of-center, caring newspaper that is not frightened of anyone and that tells the truth, however unpalatable," said Richard Stott, editor of The Daily Mirror.
According to Mr. Maxwell, the paths of The Daily Mirror and The Daily News have converged in a "most uncanny" way. The Mirror was, according to Mr. Maxwell and others, the model for The Daily News. They share another link, Mr. Maxwell said: like The Daily News's founder, Joseph Medill Patterson, Mr. Maxwell is also "a socialist millionaire."
Mr. Stott is beginning his second stint as editor of The Daily Mirror, replacing Roy Greenslade, who left last month. In an interview that was granted only after Mr. Maxwell had approved it, Mr. Stott outlined his newspaper's editorial policy.
The editor said the paper was very pro-Europe. Mr. Stott also called the paper pro-royalty, which has something to do with the photo opportunities provided by the Princess of Wales. It is virtually alone among the British newspapers in calling for the British Army to leave Northern Ireland.
But The Daily Mirror's editorials oppose what the newspaper sees as the excesses of trade unionism. The paper is also vigorously against the Conservative Government's cutbacks in social spending, but it supports a nuclear deterrent.
Its political agenda and campaigning style is tempered by its devotion to soft features, like a recent long interview with the actor Mel Gibson.
"The whole secret of tabloid newspapers is a balance," Mr. Stott said, "between the heavy, the light, the funny and the sad." The Mirror's readers, the editor said, include a "fair smattering of people all the way up" the social scale. For the most part, however, its readers are members of the working class, albeit "the more liberal-minded ones as opposed to the red-necked ones who tend to read The Sun," Mr. Stott added, referring to the tabloid controlled by Rupert Murdoch. The Sun is The Mirror's chief rival.
While The Mirror may be the grandfather of the tabloids, Mr. Maxwell said The Daily News had little to learn from his British paper; rather, Mr. Maxwell said, The Daily Mirror could learn some things from the New York paper, like headline writing.
As for The Daily News, Mr. Maxwell said it was a "newspaper unique in the world" that needs "the unions to give it a chance." Editorially, he would like to see improved coverage of New York State government and the New York City boroughs. On the production front, he plans to make the same innovations at The Daily News that he made when he took charge of The Mirror, like high-quality color presses, machinery to insert supplements and regionalized advertising sections.
 
A Women's Publication
 When it was started in 1903 as a women's newspaper by the brothers Harold and Alfred Harmsworth, who later became Lord Rothermere and Lord Northcliffe, respectively, the editor of The Mirror was a woman and its title was chosen to appeal to women. Hand mirrors were given away as promotions.
A year later, Lord Northcliffe, having concluded from poor sales figures that "women can't write and don't want to read," made The Mirror a general-interest "picture newspaper."
In the 1930's, The Mirror was among the first of the Fleet Street newspapers to condemn the British Government's appeasment of Hitler. In the 1940's, the editorial director and chairman, Harry Guy Bartholomew, turned The Mirror into "the rather aggressive working-class paper" it is today.
By 1964, The Daily Mirror's circulation reached five million, but the paper's heyday was ending. In 1969, the International Publishing Corporation, owner of both The Daily Mirror and The Sun, sold The Sun to Mr. Murdoch, who captured the bottom of The Mirror's market, Mr. Stott said.
According to figures from the Audit Bureau of Circulations, The Daily Mirror's average circulation for the period from last October to March was more than three million, off about 2.3 percent from October 1989 to March 1990. The circulation figures at The Sun had a shaper drop. While it continued to maintain its lead over The Mirror, The Sun's circulation in the October-March period averaged 3.77 million, down 4.8 percent from the similar period a year earlier.
Mr. Stott said The Mirror's "dark days" ended in 1986 when Mr. Maxwell, having acquired Mirror Group Newspapers from Reed International, P.L.C., the parent of International Publishing, sharply cut the work force and introduced color presses. When Mr. Maxwell bought The Mirror in 1984, Mr. Stott said, the profits of the Mirror Group from its London papers were about $1.4 million. For 1990, Mirror's pretax profits were £88.3 million, or about $170 million under year-end exchange rates.
Mr. Maxwell said last week that a 45 to 49 percent stake in the newspaper group, which also includes The Sunday Mirror and The Daily Record, would be offered to the public.
Geoffrey Goodman, a former assistant editor at The Mirror, credited Mr. Maxwell for making some necessary changes, but added that the newspaper had "lost its edge, its credibility, largely because of Mr. Maxwell," whom he accused of interfering with editorial policy.
Mr. Stott denied that Mr. Maxwell's involvement was interference. "All proprietors are involved in matters of high newspaper policy," he said, adding that Mr. Maxwell left day-to-day operations to him.
In a telephone interview last week, Mr. Greenslade, whom Mr. Stott replaced in March, said he had an agreement with Mr. Maxwell not to discuss "the reasons for his departure. He added, however: "I wasn't fired, and I didn't resign. I left by mutual agreement -- Robert Maxwell's mutual agreement."
Tony Loynes, publisher and editor of the UK Press Gazette, a trade weekly, said The Mirror might recapture the lead in the daily tabloid market. But, he added, "the public is so besieged with soft material" that The Mirror may have to reassess its balance of hard news and features.
As for Mr. Stott, he says that only a slightly more aggressive style is needed. It is not only a "newspaper for the 90's," as The Mirror's banner proclaims, Mr. Stott said, "it is a newspaper for well into the 21st century."

HEADLINE: Moynihan Accuses Bush Of Scare Ploy on Elderly

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan accused the White House today of trying to frighten the elderly as part of its strategy to defeat his proposed cut in the Social Security payroll tax.
The New York Democrat released copies of what he said was a White House briefing memorandum he received over the weekend outlining points for the measure's opponents to use when arguing against it in Congress. The Bush Administration contends that cutting the payroll tax would drain the Social Security trust fund. 
 "Senator Moynihan argues that his goal is to make the tax code more fair," the memorandum stated. "Don't be fooled by the rhetoric. He promises a tax cut today and forces a series of major tax hikes on tomorrow's workers and their employers. This is nothing more than a shell game with Social Security."
The two-page memorandum was attached to a sheet of stationery imprinted with the logo and heading of the President's Office of Management and Budget. Its contents, Senator Moynihan said, misrepresent his proposal for gradual tax cuts over the next six years. He says the proposal would save more than $160 billion for wage earners.
 
Obstacle to Consideration
 He predicted the Senate would quickly approve an amendment to allow his bill to be considered this session. A similar measure was defeated late last year when it fell six votes short of the 60-vote majority needed to consider any measure that results in a drop in revenue.
Since then, Senator Jim Sasser, a Tennessee Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, has helped revive the measure by quietly changing the rules to allow the measure to be considered if it is approved with a simple majority.
The Administration and some leading members of Congress have opposed the plan, saying that it would bankrupt the Social Security system by 2005 and sharply increase the Federal deficit as soon as next year.
Mr. Moynihan defended his plan in a Capitol Hill news conference today, asserting that it would stabilize, rather than drain, Social Security surpluses that are now being used to mask the size of the Federal budget deficit. He said the White House strategy as detailed in the briefing memorandum was "pretty chilling, and not very seemly."
 
Charge and Countercharge
 "I mean, slash and burn is one thing," Senator Moynihan said. "But terrorizing and terrifying older people is another."
In response, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said, "People have a right to be afraid of his scheme."
The memorandum, dated April 15, cites reports by the General Accounting Office, the Congressional Budget Office and the Treasury Department to support its contention that a payroll tax cut is a bad idea.
The Administration says in the memorandum that the economy would be hurt by the tax cut and that future generations would pay for any tax cuts that benefit their parents today.
It concluded that the Moynihan plan "delivers a weakened Social Security system whose future solvency depends on a series of tax hikes on working Americans and businesses."
"These large tax increases may not be sustainable," it continued. "So, cutting Social Security benefits for disabled Americans, retirees and their families may become the only alternative to insolvency."
Senator Moynihan said the measure would eventually win approval, even though its immediate future appears bleak. Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, and Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, have opposed the tax cut proposal.
Mr. Moynihan said he did not know how he would overcome the force of such bipartisan opposition, adding: "And I don't know if I will be able to."
But he said election-year politics would change the outcome.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who said his proposed cut in the Social Security payroll tax would stabilize, rather than drain, Social Security surpluses. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Mobil Net Jumps 77.5% In Quarter

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, April 22

 BODY:
With huge profit increases in Europe and Asia resulting mainly from the Persian Gulf war, the Mobil Corporation said today that net income in the first quarter soared 77.5 percent, to $710 million, or $1.73 a share, from $400 million, or 94 cents a share.
Two other large oil companies also reported big gains for the period, but in their cases the increases came from financial procedures, not improvements in operations. Net income rose by 72.3 percent at the Amoco Corporation and by 25.9 percent at the Occidental Petroleum Corporation. 
 Ashland Oil Inc., a large refiner, said profits rose sharply, to $27 million, or 48 cents a share, from $913,000, or 2 cents a share, because costs for crude oil fell faster in the first three months than prices for refined products like gasoline and home heating oil.
 The reports provided the first detailed view of how varied oil industry profits were during the first quarter. In general, analysts expected that earnings from operations would be far stronger for refiners in Europe and Asia than in the United States.
Demand for kerosene, used by the allied military forces for jet fuel, kept Singapore refineries operating at high rates and, on some days, profits were more than double the level of refiners' costs. Mobil, for one, completed a major expansion of its Singapore refinery last year.
 
Plunge in Oil Prices
 But profits for exploration and recovery units were little changed worldwide because crude-oil prices, which started the year near $30 a barrel, plunged after the United States and its allies began bombing Iraq on Jan. 17.
Mobil said that during the quarter it was paid an average of $20.93 a barrel abroad and $17.18 in the United States for crude, compared with $19.68 and $18.30, respectively, in the corresponding period a year ago.
Chemical manufacturing operations were less profitable in the quarter than a year ago. Recession in the United States curbed profit margins, and costs for crude and other raw materials were higher than a year ago even though they declined throughout the quarter.
Bernard J. Picchi, managing director and senior oil analyst at Salomon Brothers, said the huge profit generated by international oil giants in Europe and Asia was a rare episode directly related to big military demands for jet fuel and diesel.
"Today, the international refining and marketing units are operating at a huge disadvantage" in those regions, he said. "Kerosene prices dropped by $20 a barrel in the last six to eight weeks. We calculate that 30 percent of the internationals' earnings has come and gone."
Following are the oil companies' results:
 
Mobil
The nation's second-largest oil company, after Exxon, said revenues rose 10.3 percent, to $16.58 billion, from $15.03 billion. International refining and marketing contributed most of the profit gain, with profits in that sector rising to $342 million, from $81 million a year ago. Worldwide profits for refining and marketing rose to $442 million, from $120 million.
Profits in exploration and production were little changed from the corresponding quarter last year, rising to $371 million from $369 million. Sales of natural gas fell 6 percent in the United States, but rose 9 percent worldwide because of increased buying and higher prices in Europe and Japan.
Allen E. Murray, the chairman of Mobil, which is based in New York, said that profit margins in refining had declined but remained strong. The profitability rates "should continue to support good earnings, although below first-quarter levels," he said. Mobil's shares fell 62.5 cents, to $67.75, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange today.
 
Amoco
The nation's fifth-largest oil company said it earned $803 million, or $1.60 a share, compared with $466 million, or 91 cents, in the period last year. Revenues of the Chicago-based company rose by 3.2 percent, to $7.3 billion, from $7.07 billion.
Nearly all of the higher profit came from a change in accounting methods, to Rule 96 of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, which allows companies to use a lower tax rate to determine the value of deferred taxes. Excluding that change and a restatement of last year's earnings, operating earnings rose 5.6 percent, to $492 million from $466 million.
Earnings from exploration and production declined, falling 11.7 percent in the United States and 9.5 percent abroad. Refining profits soared 65.9 percent, to $214 million from $129 million, and profits in chemicals fell slightly, to $85 million.
Amoco's shares gained 25 cents today, to $53.75, on the Big Board.
 
Occidental Petroleum
Net income was $136 million, or 45 cents a share, compared with $108 million, or 37 cents a share, in the period a year ago. Revenues rose 2.7 percent, to $5.3 billion.
A $53 million tax reduction in the quarter accounted for most of the higher profits. It was the first use of a portion of the $1.74 billion in future tax benefits accumulated last year when Ray R. Irani, chairman and chief executive of the Los Angeles-based company, wrote off $2.17 billion in an extensive revamping of the company.
Excluding the lower tax provision and other factors, earnings from operations rose 1.5 percent, to $404 million, from $398 million. Profits in oil and gas production increased to $122 million, from $100 million; the natural-gas pipeline unit, had profits of $126 million, up from $94 million. But chemical earnings fell to $139 million, from $186 million.
Occidental's shares rose 25 cents, to $19.25, on the Big Board today.
 
Ashland Oil
Revenues of the refiner, based in Ashland, Ky., were essentially flat, at $2.05 billion, compared with $2.1 billion in the 1990 quarter. John R. Hall, chairman and chief executive, said profit margins increased during the quarter as costs for crude and other refining raw materials fell and the nation's stocks of gasoline fell to unusually low levels.
Mr. Hall said refining profits remained strong and were likely to improve "as we approach the driving season." Profits in the chemical unit rose 35 percent in the quarter, to $23 million, but earnings from oil exploration fell slightly, to $11 million.
Ashland's shares rose $1.625 today, to $34.50, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

COMPANIES
The Government selected Fleet/Norstar, along with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts, to buy the failed Bank of New England and two affiliated banks that collapsed in January. Seidman said the bid was selected because it represented "the lowest cost" to the program that insures bank deposits. [Page A1.]
Mobil said its quarterly income soared 77.5 percent, citing gains in Europe and Asia. Amoco and Occidental also gained. [D1.] 
 Hewlett-Packard will sell a personal computer about the size of a calculator. The move is a challenge to the Japanese. [D1.]
The I.R.S. unexpectedly billed Executive Life Insurance $643 million for back taxes and penalties, further imperiling its ability to pay policyholders and other customers. [D1.]
Brandon Tartikoff is talking with Paramount Communications about becoming president and chief executive of Paramount Pictures, an NBC executive said. [D1.]
A Saudi investment group holds just over 5 percent of Chase Manhattan, according to an S.E.C. filing. [D2.]
NCR stock rose $5.25, to $102, after A.T.&T. said it would be willing to pay $110 a share in stock. [D4.]
A.T.&T. said it would join with NEC to explore better ways to make advanced semiconductors. [D4.]
Intel showed the first of a series of chips that it hopes will help it maintain its supremacy in microprocessors. [D4.]
I.B.M. "refreshed" its three-year-old midrange computer line, introducing 11 models that perform up to 60 percent faster. [D5.]
Hardwick Simmons is expected to be named Prudential Securities' chairman as soon as today, executives said. [D6.]
Champion International said profit plunged 79 percent. It cited lower prices for pulp and falling demand for lumber. [D7.]
Bankers Trust said earnings fell 19.2 percent, chiefly because of higher expenses and money set aside for bad loans. [D8.]
Capital Cities/ABC said its income fell nearly 45 percent. It said recession and war hurt broadcasting and publishing. [D9.]
McDonnell Douglas's chairman said China wanted to negotiate a deal that could lead to co-production of 150 more MD-80's. [D4.]
Anheuser-Busch said four unidentified ad agencies would compete for a new Michelob assignment. [D22.]
The settlement of the Exxon Valdez oil spill is facing objections from lawmakers and environmental groups. [A12.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
Large Japanese corporations have bought paintings apparently to conceal transfers of millions in cash or evade taxes. [Page A1.]
American Express is reportedly in talks with Sumitomo Bank to establish a company to issue charge cards in Japan. [D7.]
 
MARKETS
Interest rates jumped sharply in Government debt markets, amid rising concern about the large volume of Treasury debt scheduled for sale over the next three weeks. [D1.]
Stocks fell sharply, with investors uncertain about the economy and interest rates. The Dow fell 37.87, to 2,927.72. [D10.]
The dollar rose as traders expected stable U.S. interest rates and continued weakness in Europe. Gold prices rose. [D18.]
Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly lower amid uncertainty about whether the Soviets would buy U.S. crops. [D18.]

HEADLINE: Council Agrees to a Delay Of Two Weeks for Budget

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
After a prolonged standoff, Mayor David N. Dinkins reached agreement with the City Council yesterday on a two-week delay in submitting a budget mapping plans to cut city services in the fiscal year that begins on July 1.
The City Charter requires the Mayor to submit his budget by this Friday. But after the state failed to pass its budget on time and as the Mayor confronted difficulties in making deep cuts in city spending, he sought a delay of a month. 
 After weeks of brinksmanship and 40 minutes of negotiation by the Mayor and Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, the Council agreed yesterday to pass a measure delaying the deadline but only for two weeks, until May 10.
The negotiation in delaying the deadline shows some of the political and practical difficulties the Mayor faces as he struggles to balance the city's budget this year and to close a gap of more than $3.1 billion in the $29 billion budget for the next fiscal year.
 
Possible Measures
 City officials acknowledge that they will soon report that the $3.1 billion gap has already worsened by at least $100 million. Outside analysts say the gap could grow by as much as $500 million, but the city's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, discounted that. 
Yesterday, city officials released a list of possible measures that could be used to close the gap of $465 million for the fiscal year that ends June 30, ranging from freezing spending to furloughing city workers. If the city cannot close the gap and ends the year with a deficit of more than $100 million, the State Financial Control Board could take control of the city's finances.
The $3.1 billion deficit for next year represents total increases in spending and reductions in revenue forecast since last November, when the city first conceded it was facing deep fiscal problems because of the recession.
City officials already have plans to close $2.2 billion of this gap, mainly through tax increases and service cuts, and they are developing plans to cut an additional $910 million in city services. But critics, including the Council Speaker, Mr. Vallone, have questioned whether the Dinkins administration will be able to carry out the ambitious program it has made public.
 
Meeting Postponed
 Others have questioned whether the administration is moving quickly enough to make the additional cuts needed to balance next year's budget. Yesterday, the budget director postponed a City Hall meeting called to review $910 million in cuts to give his staff more time to prepare documents outlining their recommendations.
While the administration believed it should be allowed a month's delay as a routine courtesy, Mr. Vallone at first refused to grant any delay, arguing that such a delay would only postpone difficult decision-making.
Behind the dispute is a simmering political rivalry between the two leaders at a time when Council districts are being withdrawn, as well as a complaint by Mr. Vallone that the administration was not doing enough to consult with the Council on its fiscal problems.
Yesterday, city officials gave more details about this year's budget gap after meeting with Standard & Poor's to discuss plans to sell about $1 billion in short-term notes to make up for delayed state aid payments.
In all, they listed nine options that could provide the city between $500 million and $700 million to close the gap. Included were delaying subsidies the city pays to outside entities, like the Transit Authority, and asking the Municipal Assistance Corporation to turn over some surplus funds to the city.

HEADLINE: REGULATORS PICK BUYER TO OPERATE NEW ENGLAND BANK

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
The Government today selected Fleet/Norstar Financial Group Inc., a Rhode Island banking company, along with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the big corporate buyout concern, to buy the failed Bank of New England and two affiliated banks that collapsed in January.
L. William Seidman, the nation's senior banking regulator, said Fleet/Norstar's bid had been selected because it represented "the lowest cost" to the program that insures bank deposits. Officials acknowledged that as part of the deal, Fleet, which has a comparatively healthy capital base for a Northeast bank, would have to raise money to satisfy Federal regulations on its financial health.
 
Outlay of $5 Billion
 Mr. Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, also said the bailout would require an initial outlay of about $5 billion from the bank fund and would ultimately cost the sharply deteriorating fund that insures deposits as much as $2.5 billion. 
 Some of the initial outlay will need to be borrowed from the Treasury, Mr. Seidman said, because the bank fund is running so low. It had $8.4 billion at the end of 1990 after deductions for expected Bank of New England losses.
The takeover of the Bank of New England was the third-largest Government rescue in history, one that had been expected to cost about $2.3 billion ultimately. The 1988 collapse of the Republicbank Corporation of Dallas is expected to cost $2.9 billion, and the 1989 failure of Mcorp, also of Dallas, has been projected to amount to $2.7 billion.
 
Branches in Several States
 Fleet, which is based in Providence, has banks in several Northeast states including New York, Connecticut, New Hampshire and Maine. It has no banking institutions in Massachusetts, where the Bank of New England is based. Besides its flagship bank in Boston, the Bank of New England owns the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company of Hartford and the Maine National Bank of Portland.
The bidding for the Bank of New England was hotly contested because the bank represented a potentially lucrative banking territory once its loan portfolio was stripped of its worst loans. Also, the bank's fate has become a focal point in Washington as it has become apparent that the industry may ultimately need to rely upon taxpayer money to continue to operate successfully.
On Capitol Hill, the collapse and rescue of the Bank of New England, once the region's second-largest banking company, after the Bank of Boston Corporation, has heightened the sensitivity of lawmakers to the deteriorating condition of the bank insurance fund and has raised questions about the adequacy of the Government's supervision of banks. In the financial community, it has also prompted new concerns about the stability of the banking system.
A controversial proposal in the Bush Admistration's plan to strengthen the industry would permit industrial enterprises to own banks. While Kohlberg, Kravis is not expected to manage the Bank of New England, the fact that it controls such companies as RJR Nabisco recently prompted Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan and chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, to urge regulators to reject the Fleet/Norstar bid, with which it is a partner.
Kohlberg, Kravis is also the most visible of the powerful New York concerns that came to be identified with the corporate buyout binge in the 1980's. Much of its money comes from pension funds and its takeovers have included Safeway Stores as well as the Beatrice Companies. Henry Kravis, its most prominent partner, is a highly visible financier and philanthropist in Manhattan.
Fleet edged out bids from the Bank of Boston and the Bank of America, the San Francisco-based bank that is the nation's second largest. Citicorp is the country's largest banking company.
 
Widely Admired by Bankers
 Fleet, which merged with Norstar Bancorp of Albany in 1988, was widely admired by bankers and analysts during the 1980's because of its strategy of diversifying into areas many banks did not enter, like servicing home mortgages; factoring, which provides credit to merchandise suppliers, and consumer finance. J. Terrence Murray, 50, who is Fleet's chairman, president and chief executive, led the company's expansion, fashioned the Norstar merger and has built a bank that has successfully held down costs and generated profits.
At the end of last year, Fleet/Norstar had about $33 billion in assets, ranking it among the nation's top 25 banks.
In 1990, however, it stumbled, and reported a $48.5 million loss. The loss reflected the weakness of the Northeastern economy, which caused problems for its borrowers.
Some analysts said the selection of Fleet was a vote of confidence by bank regulators in the eventual recovery of the New England economy. But other experts said the Bank of Boston's bid was probably not chosen because of concerns about that bank's ability to operate with the capital needed to absorb the Bank of New England. Mr. Seidman said all of the bidders were qualified.
 
Scrutiny by Congress
 The deal proposed today will almost inevitably be scrutinized by members of Congress, who in a series of hearings have already been exploring the Bank of New England failure, charging that regulators moved too slowly to head off its collapse.
"The perspective that has to be applied is not who gets what, but who gets socked," said Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa and a member of the House Banking Committee. "The real issue is just how much it's going to cost the taxpayer."
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said tonight: "I am pleased that at least a bank in our region has prevailed. Massachusetts and New England are still in the grip of a painful credit crunch, and I urge the new owners to move as rapidly as possible to extend credit to strong firms and shore up our depressed economy."
Under the deal, the F.D.I.C. will receive $100 million in preferred stock from the new banking company and $25 million in cash from the purchasers. The insurance corporation will also purchase another $50 million in preferred stock of the Bank of New England.
 
$683 Million in New Funds
 The transaction requires Fleet to raise $400 million in new funds and Kohlberg, Kravis to raise an additional $283 million. The $683 million will be injected into both the Bank of New England and Fleet. Officials said that without the additional funds, Fleet would not be in compliance with Federal regulations on its own capital.
The deal gives Fleet three years to return to the Government all but about $1 billion of the assets that it has acquired. Mr. Seidman estimated that ultimately about $5.5 billion in assets, most of which are nonperforming or troubled loans, would not be held by Fleet.
Analysts said the deal was structured to give the winning bidder one of the healthiest banks in New England. Shortly after the bank was seized, the Government decided to hold onto the bad assets, including nonperforming commercial and consumer loans. The winning bidder will receive a fee to manage and sell these assets.
 
Corporation Not Involved
 The announcement today did not involve the Bank of New England Corporation, the company that had controlled the banks until January, when they were seized by the Government. Shortly after the regulators took control of the banks, the holding company filed for protection from its creditors in Federal Bankruptcy Court.
Mr. Seidman said that Kohlberg, Kravis, which will own about 15 percent of the Bank of New England, would be a "passive investor." He said the firm had assured regulators that it would not exert control over the bank's operations.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, said the decision to rely on Kohlberg, Kravis demonstrated that "regulators are reaching out to nontraditional sources for new bank capital."
In 1989, Kohlberg, Kravis made an unsuccessful bid for Mcorp, the second-largest bank in Texas, but lost out to the Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio.
The announcement of the winning bid for the bank had been scheduled for Wednesday. Mr. Seidman said the F.D.I.C. decided to make the announcement today, shortly after the winner was selected, because of concerns that the decision might be leaked to the press.
 
Fall Began in 1980's
 The fall of the Bank of New England began in the 1980's, as it aggressively expanded its lending for office buildings, hotels, shopping malls and condominiums that could not pay back their loans when the New England economy collapsed. Today it has $16 billion in assets and 320 branches in Massachusetts, Connecticut and Maine.
The Bank of New England seizure also marked one of the increasing number of instances in which the Government justified protecting all depositors, including those with accounts larger than $100,000. In exercising the "too big to fail" approach, Government officials said they had averted a possible ripple effect that would likely have brought down other institutions in the economically shaky region.
An investor group led by Marco F. DeSalle, an executive in Portland, Me., who is a former banker, offered to buy the smallest of the three banks offered for sale, the failed Maine bank, which has $1 billion of assets.
In the Senate, the resistance of regulators to a request for Government documents about their handling of the Bank of New England matter has led the chairman of the Senate banking committee, Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, to delay the confirmation proceeding for Robert L. Clarke, the Comptroller of the Currency and the primary regulator of all nationally chartered banks, to a second term.

HEADLINE: Birth Control Safer Than Unprotected Sex

BYLINE: By PHILIP HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
Contrary to popular opinion, using birth control is safer and healthier than not using it, according to a report released today.
"The average woman who has ever used the pill is less likely to get cancer and die as a result before age 55 than a woman who has never used the pill," the report said. 
 When the risk of death is set against deaths prevented, using contraception, including the pill, saves 120 to 150 lives per 100,000 women, the report said. Contraception also prevents about 1,500 hospitalizations per 100,000 women per year, it said.
Figures published today by the Alan Guttmacher Institute indicate that on balance the protective effects of contraception -- including prevention of at least two kinds of cancer, endometriosis, pelvic inflammatory disease and, of course, the health hazards of pregnancy -- far outweigh the danger of its side effects.
 
Doubt Over Breast Cancer
 The only doubtful case is that of breast cancer. Over all, it appears that the pill prevents breast cancer. But some studies have shown that women in their 30's and early 40's who have used the pill for many years may have an increased incidence of cancer. At the same time, women in their late 40's and early 50's who have been long-term users have fewer breast cancers than those who have never used the pill.
The Guttmacher report, a 129-page statistical picture of contraception in America, says that on balance, other methods also protect against disease. Use of spermicides and barrier methods like the condom and diaphragm prevent cervical cancer and pelvic inflammatory disease.
"One reason this book is important," said Dr. Jacqueline Forrest, vice president for research at the institute, "is that Americans, both men and women, seem to have a lot of misinformation about the effectiveness and the safety of methods. Most think using no method is safer than using a method, but the data show it's the reverse. The riskiest thing to do for your health, if you are sexually active, is to use no method."
Dr. Forrest said that in a 1985 random survey of 1,500 men and women by the Gallup Organization, 58 percent incorrectly thought that taking the pill was more dangerous than giving birth, and 23 percent incorrectly thought the risks were about the same.
The Guttmacher Institute is a private, nonprofit organization specializes in research on contraception, and this report is the first of its kind since the institute published a more limited version of the statistics in 1983.
Nine of 10 women who are 20 to 44 years old are sexually active, the study said, and three-quarters have had sex in the last three months. But most of these sexually active women, about two-thirds, are trying to avoid pregnancy and many are failing. Of the six million pregnancies in the United States annually, about 57 percent are unintended.
The book also lists the latest count, from 1988, of what contraceptives are most widely used. About 35 percent of women capable of becoming pregnant depend on sterilization, either their own or their partner's, while 28 percent take the pill, 13 percent use condoms, 10 percent use no method at all, 5 percent use diaphragms, 4 percent use withdrawal or periodic abstinence such as the rhythm method, and fewer than 2 percent use the intrauterine device.
The methods vary greatly in effectiveness. In the first year of sexual activity, 85 percent of women using no method become pregnant. With periodic abstinence, depending on how consistently it is used, 14 to 19 percent of women become pregnant in one year. Using condoms, 10 to 18 percent become pregnant. Using diaphragms or cervical caps, 12 to 39 percent become pregnant. Using a sponge containing spermicide, 16 to 52 percent become pregnant.
The most effective methods are the pill, with a pregnancy rate of 4 percent to 9 percent; intrauterine devices, 2.5 percent to 4.5 percent; sterilization and vasectomy, 0.2 percent to 0.5 percent; injectable contraceptives, about 0.4 percent, and implants, the most effective, with a pregnancy rate of 0.05 percent to 0.5 percent.
The report notes that some women have higher risks than average when using some methods, and those women should avoid using the riskier methods. For example, the pill should not be used by women 35 and older who smoke more than 15 cigarettes a day, or women 25 and older who smoke 25 cigarettes a day, because of a higher risk of heart disease or blot clots.
The report is available for $22 from the Alan Guttmacher Institute, 111 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10003.

HEADLINE: After the Ghetto

 BODY:
The ghetto, many Americans have come to believe, is forever. Frightened by crime and frustrated by seemingly intractable poverty, they grope for answers and settle for racial stereotypes: To give "them" welfare is to pour money down a rat hole . . . "They" are crime-prone and lazy . . . "They" know only childish instant gratification like sex and drugs . . .
These rationales proceed from profound ignorance, presuming that poor blacks somehow want the danger and squalor of central city enclaves. Blacks want to escape the ghetto. Indeed, thousands are succeeding. 
 The black movement outward noted by William Julius Wilson during the 70's continued in the 80's. Studies of 12 major metropolitan areas by Kathryn Nelson, an economist at the Department of Housing and Urban Development, show that better-off black families have been streaming out of the poorest central city areas.
The outmovement leaves behind an ever more concentrated distillation of misery. Even so, the lesson is powerfully positive: the ghetto is not a hopeless, unchanging fact of urban life. If comfortable citizens can only come to see how much even the poorest blacks want to escape, America can start making the ghetto disappear.
 That's why two new books, coincidentally published within weeks of each other, possess such a potential punch. Taken together, they have the power to educate America.
One is "The Promised Land," by Nicholas Lemann, an ambitious analysis of the tidal changes brought by the northward movement of black sharecroppers from the cotton fields of the South. The other is "There Are No Children Here," by Alex Kotlowitz, an intimately illuminating look at one such family in Chicago.
As Mr. Lemann's book shows, the useful word is not "blacks" but black sharecroppers. They lived for most of a century in conditions not much different than slavery. Just as the agricultural underpinning of their lives disappeared in the rural South, so did the manufacturing jobs that drew them to the North. Cotton-picking poverty soon turned into welfare poverty, in harsh ghettos of public housing.
Where this historical analysis addresses the head, Alex Kotlowitz's story informs the heart. His meticulous portrait of two boys in a Chicago housing project shows how much heroism is required to survive, let alone escape.
No less anxiously than Israelis or Saudis under Scud missile attacks, streetwise students in the projects slide off their chairs and huddle under their desks "when the powerful sounds of .357 Magnums and sawed-off shotguns" echo off the school walls.
On a rare trip downtown to see Christmas windows, Pharoah, one of the brothers, is amazed, first off, by the sight of clean window glass. One day, Pharoah, then 11, told a friend: " 'I worry about dying, dying at a young age, while you're little. . . . I want to get out of the 'jects.' "
Pharoah struggles to succeed in school, in spelling bees, in Upward Bound. He may yet find a future and a way out. Meanwhile others, no less than he, want a future; want a way out.
Will power alone hoists few bootstraps, and more children are born daily into lives short of either will or hope. But that's no justification for Americans to recoil in resignation and despair. Society knows a hundred ways to break down the ghetto walls.
Program after program shows that young women can be taught to defer childbearing until they are old enough to manage. Government knows how to give their babies a fair chance and a Head Start. Law enforcement knows how to search out the .357 Magnums and contain the violence that terrifies neighborhoods.
Most important, society knows how to capitalize on people's determination, given half an opportunity, to work, scratch and squeeze their way into the mainstream.
 The poor may always be with us, but it is not inevitable that so many poor black people, rooted in the same rural culture, must be herded into the same bullet-pocked projects. One day, all black Americans who want to will disperse themselves into the general population, just as many are doing now. One day the ghetto will be gone, and America's children, black and white, will look up and ask us: Why? What took so long?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Why Economy Pinches the College-Educated

 BODY:
To the Editor:
One cannot help feeling sorry for Julia Carlisle ("Young, Privileged and Unemployed," Op-Ed, April 4). Unfortunately, she is just one representative of a generation of college graduates who have been marginalized by our educational system. 
 The stress we, as a nation, have laid on a college education as a passport to a better life has had consequences that will haunt all of us for years to come.
A college education was always oriented to a career in the service sector -- law, medicine, banking, management, accounting and teaching. On the other hand, a good high school education was mainly a preparation for a trade career.
After World War II there was a vast demand for service professionals, as the American economy shifted to a service orientation. However, the stress on service careers siphoned people off from careers in industrial production. A career in trade or industry was regarded as a badge of inferiority, decreasing the supply of skilled workers and raising production costs.
But the demand for service skills had to dwindle as the service economy matured, at the same time that demand for skilled workers had to increase. Ms. Carlisle and others have now become expendable.
As college costs increase and our high schools deteriorate, we should begin to reallocate our dwindling resources to a rejuvenation of skilled work by increasing funds for high schools and vocational training, at the same time substantially raising academic standards at the college level, as suggested by W. Ann Reynolds, the new chancellor of City University.
This may have the salutary effect of providing the country with tomorrow's producers, who can build and maintain, for example, a videocassette recorder or even a decent automobile. The imbalance between supply and demand in the service sector will not soon abate, but better high schools and vocational training may restore the standing of the blue-collar worker to what it was before World War II. It may also keep a lot of unqualified time servers out of college classrooms.
 
RICHARD HYSE
St. Petersburg, Fla., April 11, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%);

HEADLINE: Why Economy Pinches the College-Educated;
Reagan Youth

 BODY:
To the Editor:
If I had to depend on your occasional "Voices of a New Generation" series for a glimpse into the minds of those younger than 30, I would write off the whole lot as incapable of harboring an honest thought (let alone an original one). This series seems devoted to the complaints of well-heeled Reagan youth. 
 Julia Carlisle's "Young, Privileged and Unemployed" (April 4) is a case in point. Ms. Carlisle was recently laid off as a news writer for CBS, and her article attempts to document her generation's suffering in the corporate purges of the 1990's. In one of the less comic passages she states: "We worked hard and we feel we deserved something. But we've learned an awful, preposterous truth -- that we are expendable."
Like every New Yorker, Ms. Carlisle walks past 10 to 20 people a day begging for money for something to eat; that it would suddenly dawn on her that people are expendable is a crime against maturity. What suddenly dawned on her is that she's expendable.
I do not wish to mock Ms. Carlisle; my beef is with you. If you are truly interested in publishing distinctly young perspectives, you'll have to dig deeper.
 
JOEL DINERSTEIN
Brooklyn, April 8, 1991

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
On Horse Farms, a Season of Distress Lingers

SERIES: Hard Times In the Bluegrass - First of two articles.

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LEXINGTON, Ky.

 BODY:
It is springtime in Kentucky, less than two weeks before the superstars of thoroughbred racing meet in the 117th Kentucky Derby, and as always there is excitement in the air and splendor in the bluegrass. But it is also reckoning time in Kentucky, and there is also trouble in the air and bankruptcy in the bluegrass.
As many as 150 of the 400 horse farms in central Kentucky are for sale. The cash flow at most of the others has been dragging for five years. The great stallion Nijinsky, reigning at Claiborne Farm at the advanced age of 24, fetches a $150,000 breeding fee instead of the $450,000 he once commanded. And princes from Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf emirates, who spent $250 million in the 1980's at the Keeneland sales here, have stopped spending big money to buy American horses for breeding and racing. 
 "We were in a fairyland and rolling in the 1980's, and now we're paying the price," said D. Wayne Lukas, the most successful trainer of horses in modern times and one of the major figures in the market. "The horse business was like oil and real estate. The banks were willing to lend; people were pouring in off the street to borrow and breed and sell horses. Guys came along and said, 'How long has this been going on?'
"Everybody had this false sense of security. You were certain you could always get your money back."
But as the decade ended, many people had learned that they couldn't get their money back. And now, the most startling sign of the times for the thoroughbred industry is this: Calumet Farm, for decades the reigning symbol of success in the horse business, is mired in debt, and racing people openly wonder if it is going broke.
Once the home of champions like Bull Lea, Citation, Coaltown and Whirlaway, Calumet Farm was among the biggest spenders in the big-spending years of the 1980's. Among its purchases were two stallions whose total price tag came to $55 million and who failed to return even a fraction of the investment.
Calumet officials deny that the farm will be forced into bankruptcy. Yet it has between $65 million and $75 million in outstanding mortgages; it recently sold 60 horses and 77 acres of land to raise money, and it executed a change in command two weeks ago when J. T. Lundy resigned as president and John T. Ward Jr. took charge.
Bertha Wright, the matriarch of the Calumet empire and the mother-in-law of Lundy, came out of what she called "a family meeting" at the farm the other day and said in a telephone interview: "I'd like the world to know we're standing together. It's an uphill course, but we're working on it. We're trying to see if we can work as a family together."
One stark indicator of the state of the horse industry was the January 1991 sale here at the Keeneland track, whose auctions produced an amazing run-up in the price of horses in the mid-1980's. This January, 1,384 horses were auctioned at an average price of $16,050, and only two went home with Arab royalty.
Three years ago, the average price was more than $50,000. And horse people have no trouble remembering the day in July six years ago when Warner Jones, who is based at Churchill Downs, the Louisville home of the Derby, sold the yearling Seattle Dancer at Keeneland to British buyers for $13.1 million.
"We went to the Keeneland horse sale in January," said Lyle Robey, Calumet's lawyer and the chairman of the Kentucky State Racing Commission. "We brought 96 horses to sell. We figured to get $15 million that week. But the very day we put them up at auction, the air war in the Middle East broke out.
"How's that for timing? It put a brake on the horse business. Calumet went home with only $6 million and with 30 horses nobody bought."
 
Gambling Glut
 In addition to war and recession, the thoroughbred industry has been under growing pressure from various other forms of legal gambling, from the new casinos in Atlantic City, to the exposion in state lotteries, to the latest gimmick, riverboat casinos.
On top of all that, the bloodstock business suffered a series of setbacks in the last two years when several elite stallions died unexpectedly within months of one another. They were an all-star team: Alydar, 15 years old and still going strong; Secretariat, racing's superstar; Roberto, Fappiano and Northern Dancer, the senior hero of the breeding business.
When he died, Alydar was being bred 70 to 80 times a year at fees ranging up to $250,000 and generating close to $20 million a year in business for his owner: Calumet Farm.
The result of all these factors has been a general losing streak for the industry, and it shows no sign of letting up.
"We still haven't hit bottom," said Seth Hancock, president of the Claiborne Farm, long renowned as a leader in the breeding business. "We're maybe 20 percent from reaching the bottom. It's a time of great change. We really don't know where we're going in this business."
"There's a cash-flow problem in all horse farms," Robey said. "Every one of them has a cash problem."
"There certainly is a great malaise," said John Gaines, longtime master of the scientific breeding farm Gainesway. "The breeding industry has never been an economically sound investment, and never will be. If you take the total purses and divide them by the total number of horses, you come up with a number that doesn't even pay their training bills."
 
Back on the Farm
Before the Betting, Foals Are Born
Horse racing may be a way of life or a livelihood or maybe just a $2 bet, but it draws nearly 60 million people to tracks in 36 states every year. They bet $10 billion a year, and $3.5 billion more is bet at offtrack parlors.
"Everything starts and ends at the parimutuel window," Gaines said.
But in fact the business really starts on the horse farms, where 48,000 foals are born each year.
Situated primarily in five counties in central Kentucky, the farms stretch for hundreds of acres behind white or brown board fences along the Paris Pike and Iron Works Road, in elegant country towns like Lexington and Paris and Versailles. But Calumet is not the only great horse farm to have been transformed in the last 10 years.
 
Series of Sales
 Spendthrift, once the home of the stallions Nashua, Seattle Slew and Affirmed, went public and sold stock to raise money. Gainesway was sold two years ago to Graham Beck of South Africa. Elmendorf Farm, owned for more than 30 years by Maxwell Gluck, was sold after his death six years ago to Jack Kent Cooke, owner of the Washington Redskins football team, but has never approached its past rank as a major winner.
The Bunker Hunt holdings were dispersed after the Hunts got into financial straits over dealings in the silver market. North Ridge Farm was sold by Franklin Groves after he suffered other losses in other business. Hamburg Place, for generations a family breeding and racing farm, was leased out by Preston Madden.
The future of the Darby Dan Farm became uncertain after a series of real-estate reversals that wiped out the $250 million fortune of the Galbreath family.
But the slide has been the steepest for Calumet.
That farm was established as a thoroughbred farm in the 1930's by Warren Wright after he had sold his family's Calumet Baking Company for $60 million during the Depression. He took a giant stride forward one day in August 1939 when he and his wife invited a celebrated Midwest trainer to breakfast at the Drake Hotel in Chicago.
Warren Wright said, "We want you to be our trainer."
Lucille Wright said, "We want to win the Kentucky Derby."
The trainer, Plain Ben Jones, said, "O.K."
The Wrights didn't have to wait long. In 1941, Calumet not only had a Derby winner but also a Triple Crown champion after Whirlaway also took the Preakness and the Belmont Stakes. Three years later, Pensive won the Derby. And four years later, Citation swept the Triple Crown with the legendary Eddie Arcaro on his back. More Derby winners followed: Ponder in 1949, Hill Gail in 1952, Iron Liege in 1957 and Tim Tam in 1958.
 
After Bull Lea
 Jones set the stage for this runaway success by buying Bull Lea as a yearling in 1940 and later sending him to the breeding barn to help establish an empire. Citation was Bull Lea's son, as were Hill Gail and Iron Liege. Bull Lea became the No. 1 sire, Calumet the No. 1 farm. At its peak, the farm won eight Kentucky Derbies, two Triple Crowns and hundreds of stakes races.
Warren Wright died in 1952, leaving the farm's fortunes to his wife, Lucille. When she died in 1982 the farm passed to her daughter-in-law, Bertha Wright, and her four children. Mrs. Wright then named son-in-law J.T. Lundy as president.
Some horse people say that Lundy headed the farm back toward its old success; others say he became part of the problem, not the solution.
Either way, he was there as the bloodstock market took its tumble. When he left two weeks ago, he said only: "I'd rather be out of it. I'd rather have a little peace and quiet."
 
Uneasy Analysis
Calumet Magnified General Malaise?
 Why did the bloodstock business, including that at Calumet, plunge in the last half-dozen years?
"It seems to me every business is on its back, and the breeding business is one of them," Hancock said. "Nobody knows what's real. Five or six years from now, people may be saying, 'Remember when Roger Clemens was making $5 million a year?'
"We're also facing challenges for the entertainment dollar: riverboat gambling, casino gambling, offtrack betting parlors, state lotteries. Someday you'll be able to sit home and flip on cable Channel 103 and get Aqueduct and make your bets."
But one of the top executives in the racing business, who spoke on the condition that he not be named, said that Calumet's downfall may have been caused by more than just a bad economy or increasing competition from other gambling enterprises.
"You have to ask how a farm with the richest land in Kentucky and the richest record of success in the past and with three Eclipse Awards last year, how could a farm like that get leveraged into $75 million in debt," he said. "You have to ask if it was mismanaged."
Other racing people suggested that Calumet had yielded to the mania of the 1980's and overspent for horses that did not produce. The farm spent $30 million to buy Mogambo and $25 million to buy Secreto as stallions.
"But both horses bombed sensationally," another racing executive said. "That was a $55 million investment totally out of character for Calumet. They traditionally bred their own, like Alydar, bred and raced by Calumet and a great sire. Vintage Calumet.
"In the 80's, they got into the same swivet as the come-latelies, and their race production fell to zilch. The factory turned out the foals, but the foals never won. And the overhead expenses continued. They were honest mistakes. But that's management. It's like oil. Everybody was punching holes in the ground in Texas and Oklahoma, too."
The questions about Calumet's management have led to speculation on Lundy's departure as farm president earlier this month. Lundy did not respond to several telephone requests for an interview, but Robey, Calumet's lawyer, denied that he had been forced out of his job because of the farm's financial problems.
"J.T. wasn't shaken out," he said. "He was just burned out. This is a farm that won three Eclipse Awards last year. The farm was voted breeder of the year, and Criminal Type was voted best older horse and horse of the year. Yes, Calumet took out a mortgage last year, but compare it to the value of the assets. Yes, Calumet lost money last year. But there's no bankruptcy.
"Calumet Farm is sitting on 800 or 900 acres of prime land across the road from the Lexington Airport and next to Keeneland, bounded on three sides by four-lane highways. It's a highly valuable resource. If the economy goes to hell, Calumet is still a farm. The family has no desire to change it or to lose it."
 
A Safer Route
Claiborne Strategy Looks Wise Now
Robey and many other horse people see broader reasons for the financial plunge on the farms.
"First, the Tax Reform Act of 1986 wasn't reform," he said. "It was a tax penalty act. It took away incentives in depreciating horse and in capital gains.
"Second, no effort was made by the Commerce Department to influence the Japanese and Arabs to come in and do business. Trade embargos were applied by the Japanese on purchasing our horses.
"Third, the recession. It happened, and the money just wasn't there.
"And fourth, the war in the Middle East. It kept the Arabs home, and it made everybody wary."
But there are many farms that are weathering the financial storm. And many people in horse country point to Claiborne Farm as the best example.
"They didn't strain to find studs," said one racing executive. "They used homebreds. They dealt with the same customers as in generations past. They didn't try to compete with the Arabs in the marketplace. They didn't finance."
"I'm a conservative person," Seth Hancock of Claiborne said. "If the boom of the 1980's had kept going, I'd have been left in the dust. But it didn't."
 Next: Selling racing to the public.

HEADLINE: Net Off 14.4% At Monsanto

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, April 23

 BODY:
The Monsanto Company reported today that it had a 14.4 percent drop in first-quarter net earnings, in part because of the recession's effect on its chemical business.
The company reported net earnings of $166 million, or $1.31 a share, on revenue of $2.22 billion in the three months ended March 31. A year ago, Monsanto said it earned $194 million, or $1.47 a share, on revenue of $2.29 billion. The company's stock rose by $1.125, to $62.75, on the New York Stock Exchange today. 
 "Given a much weaker U.S. economy compared with a year ago, we expected that we would have a tough time matching last year's first-quarter earnings," said Richard J. Mahoney, Monsanto's chairman and chief executive.
He said that although the chemical unit's results suffered during the first quarter, strong showings in other businesses and the company's cost-control efforts made him confident that year-end earnings would exceed last year's.
The company also makes pesticides and animal feed supplements, owns a pharmaceutical subsidiary and sells Nutrasweet, an artificial sweetener.
