HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The 'No Regrets' Greenhouse Fix

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
THE latest word on the greenhouse effect, from a National Academy of Sciences panel headed by Daniel Evans, a former Governor of Washington, will surely not be the last. But the panel's report, somnolently titled "Policy Implications of Global Warming," is surely a breakthrough -- the first to bridge the canyon between alarmist science and what-me-worry economics.
The academy's synthesis can be summed up briefly as concluding that human adaption to warmer weather will likely be relatively painless. Outlined in 113 reader-friendly pages, the argument won't quite convince end-of-nature types to bed down with those looking forward to palm trees in Buffalo. Still, it is a safe bet that the report's approach, which one Bush Administration analyst dubbed a "no regrets" policy, will carry the establishment's imprimatur for some time to come. 
 Reduced to its journalistic essence, "no regrets" goes something like this:
Atmospheric levels of greenhouse gases (carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, CFC refrigeration chemicals) are rising rapidly; projecting current trends, concentrations will be double their pre-industrial level by the year 2050. That virtually guarantees the planet will trap more solar energy and the earth will grow warmer.
But the plausible range of temperature change is as little as 2 degrees Fahrenheit to as much as 9. And even if the figure could be pinned down, it would not tell us much about the ensuing environmental and economic damage or the difficulty of adaptation. In agriculture, for example, hard-to-predict shifts in rainfall are likely to have far greater consequences than the direct effect of hotter summers.
Gradual weather change would probably prove only an expensive headache for humans. Tens of millions of Americans, after all, have coped with far more dramatic shifts in their voluntary move to the Sun Belt. But there is some possibility of discontinuous, catastrophic change -- for example, a huge release of methane from the melting Arctic tundra that turned the cornfields of Iowa into a desert in a single generation. And there is little doubt that thousands of marine and plant species would be decimated by even a gradual warming.
What to do? The panel's "no regrets" strategy starts with emissions-reducing initiatives that would pay for themselves in greater economic efficiency. High on this list is energy conservation for buildings, vehicles and industrial processes.
But the panel, which included experts ranging from Stephen Schneider, a Government climatologist, to William Nordhaus, a Yale economist, would go further, buying a little insurance against an unexpectedly rainy (or, more likely, a very dry) day. This would surely include spending money to develop greenhouse-benevolent energy technologies that will be on the shelf and relatively affordable if they are needed. And it would probably also include reducing greenhouse emissions where there are only modest net costs. Prime targets: an accelerated phase-out of CFC's, which are damaging the ozone layer as well as warming the planet; a big effort to save tropical rain forests, which support diverse life forms as well as storing carbon.
"No regrets" looks like good politics as well as good policy. While every politician wants a piece of the righteous turf on this biggest of all environmental causes, few are eager to ask the voters to take the bus to work or shiver in their sweaters until the dangers are much clearer. But the approach may not prove as uncontroversial as it first appears.
Much of the energy-saving that the panel believes would pay for itself would require a fairly heavy regulatory hand. The report, for example, calls for higher mileage standards for cars -- a move the Bush Administration has already declared to be veto bait. One must wonder, too, how the idea of testing a new generation of nuclear reactors would appeal to Congress.
But the panel's most problematic recommendations may be those it treats most lightly: the imperative for international cooperation. At very least that translates as aggressive support for population control in the third world. But it could also take money -- lots of money -- to induce poor countries to think greenhouse when they think economic development.
China, for example, now emits just 7 percent of the greenhouse gas created by human activity. But it emits six times as much the United States per dollar's worth of G.N.P. and a remarkable 18 times as much as Japan. Thus if Chinese living standards ever approach those of the West without radical improvements in energy efficiency and a technological overhaul of agriculture, the greenhouse game will be as good as lost.

HEADLINE: Bank Funds And C.D.'s Are Down

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were down for the eighth straight week, but the declines in the week ended yesterday were not as large as those in the previous week.
Analysts at The Bank Rate Monitor, say the end of the recession is still not in sight, as savings yields continue to fall, particularly for certificates of deposit. 
 Yields on C.D.'s with shorter maturities are falling at a faster pace than those with maturities of more than one year, the analysts said. Big Yields Are Harder to Find
Also, the number of banks and savings institutions with a one-year certificate that yields 7 percent or more has dwindled to 13, from 19 the previous week, making longer maturities more attractive, analysts said.
At the Treasury's weekly auction on Monday, the average discount rates rose, after three straight weeks of decline. The results of the bill auction often indicate what many banks may eventually pay on money market accounts and certificates of deposit.
The rate on three-month bills increased by 12 basis points, to 5.69 percent, and the six-month bills rose a similar amount, to 5.79 percent, its highest since the beginning of the month. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
In The Bank Rate Monitor's weekly survey of the New York area, the declines in yield were similar at the commercial banks and the savings insitutions.
The largest yield changes in the New York area this week were recorded at Chase Manhattan, which cut its money market account by 10 basis points, to 5.34 percent, and Marine Midland, which cut its three-month and six-month certificates each by 21 basis points, to 5.76 percent and 5.97 percent, respectively.
The yield on the average money market account at commercial banks was unchanged at 5.39 percent, but three-month certificates were down by 3 basis points, to 5.81 percent, and the sixth-month C.D. was off 4 basis points, to 5.97 percent.
At savings institutions, the average money market account was down a basis point, to 5.75 percent, while three-month and sixth-month certificates were cut by 5 basis points each, to 6.20 percent and 6.44 percent, repectively.
Yields at 20 large banks outside the New York area show the average yield on money market accounts down 3 basis points, to 5.38 percent, and the average yield for a six-month certificate down 4 basis points, to 5.99 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Moves Downward As Some Traders Cash In

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended lower yesterday in foreign exchange trading as dealers cashed in on the currency's recent strength and the Government reported that orders for durable goods plunged in March.
Gold prices slipped after rising in Asia. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold settled at $357.10 an ounce, 80 cents lower than Monday's close. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid of $356.50 an ounce, off 70 cents. 
 The dollar started out lower in Tokyo and continued in that direction in Europe after a round of dollar-selling by central banks, led by the Bundesbank of Germany.
Currency dealers said the decline accelerated after the Government reported that orders for durable goods in March were weaker than had been expected. In addition, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, made comments that currency traders interpreted as suggesting interest rates could ease further since the economy remains sluggish. Lower interest rates in the United States generally make the dollar less attractive to foreign investors.
Ronald H. Holzer, vice president and chief dealer for Harris Trust and Company in Chicago, said some dealers might have been looking for an excuse to sell dollars after the currency's recent upswing.
The Commerce Department reported yesterday that factory orders for durable goods fell a seasonally adjusted 6.2 percent last month, to the lowest level in four years. Many economists had expected a slight gain in orders in March, supporting the view of the Bush Administration that the economic recovery would begin in the current quarter.
The dollar fell in New York trading to 137.64 Japanese yen, down from 139.49. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 138.45 yen, down 0.25 from Monday. It stood at 137.90 yen in London.
The dollar was weaker against the British pound. A pound cost $1.6925 in London and $1.7130 in New York, up from $1.6955 late Monday.
Against the German currency, the dollar fell to 1.7415 marks from 1.7645.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday quotes, included: 1.4525 Swiss francs, down from 1.4700; 5.8730 French francs, down from 5.9455; 1,286.00 Italian lire, down from 1,301.25, and 1.15685 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15875.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $355.80 an ounce, from $357.25 Monday. In Zurich, it was down 50 cents, to $355.50. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose 96 cents to close at $358.20.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
NEC May Acquire Stake In Ailing Bull of France

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 23

 BODY:
The NEC Corporation, one of Japan's largest computer makers, said today that it was negotiating with Compagnie des Machines Bull about buying shares in the faltering French computer giant.
NEC offered few details, but a spokesman said that if an agreement was reached NEC would acquire no more than 10 percent of Bull. It would be the second Japanese investment in a major European computer company in less than a year. Bull is mostly owned by the French Government. 
 In Paris, a spokesman for Bull said the Tokyo talks were aimed at "accommodating" the stake that NEC already has in a Bull subsidiary based in the United States after recent shifts in Bull's corporate structure. He refused to say whether fresh money would also be involved.
Bull, France's largest computer maker, is among the hardest-hit of Europe's computer and electronics makers. A selloff of part of the company has been considered all but inevitable.
Bull lost $1.2 billion in 1990, and has grown increasingly dependent on NEC for its most critical mainframe computer technology. For months, French officials have been urging Bull's management to seek help from abroad, chiefly from NEC.
NEC said that it had "not yet decided" how to respond to Bull's request for an equity investment. But there seems little doubt that NEC -- in its effort to assure that Fujitsu, Japan's largest computer maker, does not gain too large a lead in the European market -- will take a stake.
Bull's economic condition is so severe that France recently pledged more than $1 billion to shore up the company and pay for its research. But computer industry experts say that money will barely scratch the surface. To try to broaden its product line in the 1980's, the company bought the computer businesses of Honeywell Inc. and the personal computer business of Zenith Electronics.
NEC and Bull have long had technical agreements, and in the United States they operate a venture to sell NEC supercomputers. NEC owns about 15 percent of Bull HN, which controls Bull's overseas operations. The Italian and British operations, previously attached to this American subsidiary, have been transferred to Bull's European division. As a result, the Bull spokesman in Paris said, it was necessary to "accommodate" NEC's stake in Bull HN in the company's new structure.

HEADLINE: Regan Says City Economy Will Still Be Weak in '92

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
New York City's economy will probably continue to falter next year as a deep recession presses all sectors of the local economy, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said yesterday.
Mr. Regan released figures showing that a local recession that is already two years old continued to worsen during the first few months of 1991. 
 A report issued by the Comptroller said that retail sales, which slipped by 1.5 percent in 1990, fell by 5.1 percent in January and February compared with a year earlier. And during the first quarter of this year, as the local unemployment rate reached its highest level in five years, 8.1 percent, the number of jobs in the city fell by 75,000 compared with the same period a year earlier.
The report showed that job losses, once concentrated in the financial industries of Manhattan, had spread to other boroughs and to service businesses, with 10,300 fewer restaurant jobs in the city in December 1990 compared with a year earlier.
"New York City -- well into the second year of its own severe recession -- should not count on any relief from this in coping with its financial burdens," Mr. Regan said.
He noted that one of the major imponderables was whether poor economic opportunities would induce New Yorkers to move out of the city in large numbers, which could further erode the possibilities of economic recovery. In the 1970's, a time of economic retrenchment in New York, the city lost almost 1 million people, he said.
The Comptroller's forecast is somewhat more pessimistic than other local economic forecasts, including the forecast that the Dinkins administration is using to predict tax revenue, and less pessimistic than a forecast by by City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman.
While the State Comptroller is forecasting a net loss of 65,000 jobs in 1991, the City Comptroller is predicting a loss of 110,000. The Dinkins administration's forecast predicts a decline of 55,000 jobs in the same period.
City budget officials said they too were considering whether to take a more pessimistic view, especially after an unexpectedly deep decline in sales and income tax revenues reported earlier this month. But they declined comment on yesterday's report, saying they had not had a chance to study it.
Mr. Regan's report said the quick end to the war in the Persian Gulf, a stronger stock market, a rebound in real-estate prices, and lower interest rates were raising expectations that the national economy was beginning to improve.
 
Large Debt Burdens
 But he said recovery in New York from a local recession that dates back to retrenchment in financial services after the October 1987 stock market collapse could be delayed further.
The report cited large debt burdens by both private industry, particularly the city's financial institutions, and government, and expectations that this would translate into further reductions in the financial industries, particularly for back office employees.
In 1990, the report noted, the local economy lost 44,700 jobs, the worst annual lost of jobs since the 1970's, including 24,700 jobs in the service trades, especially department stores and restaurants.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Bond Prices Rise Moderately

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of long-term Treasury bonds posted a moderate recovery yesterday, pushing interest rates down slightly, while the shorter maturities had smaller gains.
Dealers attributed the modest improvement to some bargain-hunting by retail buyers who had been largely absent from the market during the sharp price declines of the last three trading sessions. 
 Late in the session, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 7 7/8 percent issue maturing in February 2021, were being offered at 95 21.32, up by 10/32, which caused the yield to fall to 8.26 percent from 8.29 percent the day before. The Treasury's long notes, the 7 3/4 percent issue of February 2001, rose 7/32, to 97 19/32, as the yield fell to 8.10 percent from 8.14 percent the day before.
 
Not Overly Aggressive
 But the dealers were quick to add that the retail buyers, a trade euphemism for large institutions like pension and mutual funds, were not overly aggressive. Most retail buyers preferred to stay on the sidelines until the auctions of Treasury notes today and tomorrow.
Today the Treasury will auction $12 billion of two-year notes, with $9 billion of four-year notes scheduled for sale tomorrow. The two-year notes traded on a when-issued basis to yield 7.03 percent, off three basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, while the yield on the four-year notes fell four basis points, to 7.77 percent.
"One indication of the malaise that has enveloped the market is that the retail buyers only appeared hours after the bond market received its best news of the day," said Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief financial economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities.
 
Thrives on Negative News
 The "good news" for investors in fixed-income debt was that orders for durable goods in March fell 6.2 percent, to the lowest level since August 1987. The bond market thrives on negative economic news because it lessens both inflationary pressures and reduces the pressure for higher interest rates on future debt offerings. A rise in interest rates tends to lower the value of existing issues carrying lower yields.
"The positive impact of the durable goods numbers was diluted by the fact that much of the decline was in orders for aircraft and military hardware," Mr. Ricchiuto said. "It was also apparent that the supply of new Treasury debt facing the market remains a major concern."
Testimony by the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, before the Senate Banking Committee yesterday was largely ignored by the credit markets because, dealers said, his remarks gave no clear indication of the central bank's intentions regarding interest rates. He reiterated his view that while the economy was declining, it was doing so at an ever slower pace.
 
Reserves Drained by Fed
 The shorter end of the Treasury market came under some pressure after the Fed once again drained reserves from the banking system. The move was apparently aimed at pushing up the key interest rate that banks charge each other for temporary loans. Although the Fed does not disclose where it prefers this pivotal lending rate to be, credit market analysts believe it has been at 6 percent since early February.
In any case, the draining of reserves was followed by a rise in the funds rate from 5 13/16 percent to 5 15/16 percent at the close. Normally, the discount rates on the longer Treasury bills, which are most heavily influenced by the funds rate, would have risen. But they did not, several bill dealers said, because of fading expectations that the Fed will soon act to reduce interest rates.
Thus, late trading found the rate on the six-month bills down four basis points, to 5.74 percent, and the rate on the one-year bills off two basis points, at 5.89 percent. The discount rate on the 90-day bills rose a basis point, to 5.70 percent.
In the corporate debt market, meanwhile, the Chrysler Financial Corporation offered $528.98 million of asset-backed securities through Merrill Lynch & Company, which is acting as sole underwriter. The two-part Chrysler offering of certificates backed by domestic home equity loans include $486.7 million of class A certificates, due in 2001, that carry an 8.5 percent coupon and are priced at 99 24/32 to yield 8.616 percent. The securities are expected to have a life of 8.7 years.
The class B part of the Chrysler offering consists of $42.32 million of subordinated debt that carries a 9.5 percent coupon and was priced to yield investors 9.243 percent.
Also, Champion International priced $200 million of notes, due in 2003, at par to yield 9.70 percent. The noncallable notes are rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Is Cautious On Easing

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today that the economy's slide was drawing to an end and that the central bank needed to be especially cautious before deciding to try to hasten recovery through another round of interest-rate cuts.
"The evidence suggests that the economy is still modestly moving lower, but moving at a reduced rate," Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee. "We do expect the bottom to occur within a reasonably short period ahead," he added. "Week by week, the daily numbers still indicate that there is a modest decline."
 
Sign of Economic Weakness
 Mr. Greenspan's comments came shortly after the Commerce Department reported that new orders for manufactured durable goods tumbled 6.2 percent in March, a considerably worse decline than expected. This was the fourth decline in five months and the biggest since an 11.2 percent plunge in November.
The drop in orders for durables -- goods from bicycles to bombers that are expected to last at least three years -- was widespread. When military orders, a volatile category, are excluded, the decline was still a steep 5.4 percent. Shipments and order backlogs also fell.
Mr. Greenspan, appearing before the committee to discuss banking and deposit insurance issues, was not asked specifically about the durable goods figures, which he presumably had seen.
 
'Our Options Are Open'
 But when asked by Donald W. Riegle Jr., a Michigan Democrat who heads the committee, whether interest rates would fall further, Mr. Greenspan, shunning direct comment, said, "We're looking at the economy on a day-by-day basis -- and I would say our options are open."
At another point, he seemed to hint at the possibility of lower rates in response to a question about inflation, which ran at a relatively rapid pace early this year before subsiding in March. "Do I see inflationary pressures in price levels and wage levels? I think we're doing rather well in that respect," he said.
On the other hand, Mr. Greenspan warned that the risks of a wrong monetary policy decision are magnified at economic turning points, implying it would take more than poor durable-goods orders to prompt another rate cut. "The issue of inflation is that it never surfaces visibly until it is well advanced," the chairman said.
In sharp contrast to the guarded statements of Mr. Greenspan, some private analysts used strong language to characterize the latest drop in durables orders, which have fallen to the lowest point since August 1987.
Douglas P. Handler, manager of economic analysis at Dun & Bradstreet, called the figures "a horrible setback" to those who believe the economy has already begun to revive, based mainly on some housing data. "The magnitude of this drop-off is usually associated with the beginning of a recession rather than the end," Mr. Handler said.
 
$110.3 Billion Annual Rate
 At an annual rate of $110.3 billion, which is adjusted for seasonal variation but not for inflation, orders for durables stand $7.3 billion, or 6.2 percent, below the February pace. The negligible February decline was revised to two-tenths of 1 percent from three-tenths of 1 percent.
Among major industries, the biggest loss was a 10.8 percent drop in transportation equipment, with orders weakest for aircraft and parts. Electronic and other electrical machinery dropped 11.8 percent, roughly offsetting a February advance, while primary metals fell 2.6 percent. The exception was industrial machinery and equipment, which edged up seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Within capital goods industries, new orders for nonmilitary goods fell 10.3 percent -- 5.5 percent not counting aircraft and parts. New orders for military capital goods fell 16.9 percent, the Commerce Department report also showed.
 
Shipments Also Decline
Meanwhile, shipments of durables fell for the fifth straight month, the 2.4 percent decline, to $114.7 billion, dragging them to the lowest level since February 1988. All major industries posted declines, the biggest a 3.9 percent drop for transportation equipment.
Unfilled orders, a particularly good economic predictor, fell nine-tenths of 1 percent in March, to $502.3 billion, with all major industries declining here as well.
New durables orders last month were 15.4 percent lower than in March 1990, the department also said.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
U.S.-Iraqi Standoff Hinders Kurd Relief at Camp

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: IN IRAQ, April 23

 BODY:
Iraqi and United States forces continued their wary standoff today in Zakho, the main town near the site of the first proposed American-built haven for Kurdish refugees in northern Iraq.
The impasse is frustrating efforts by relief officials to coax the Kurds down from the mountains and back to their ancestral lands. 
 Carrying machine guns and sidearms, the Iraqis patrolled the sidewalks as United States Marines moved through the streets in military convoys. Some stood behind and observed residents of Zakho as the local towspeople tried to speak with Western journalists.
The authorities in Baghdad say that the men are police officers and that their presence does not violate the accord under which the United States has begun to set up tent cities for the Kurds in northern Iraq.
 
'They Will Kill Us'
 American officials disagree, and the issue has caused a standoff not just between the Americans and the Iraqis but between relief officials and the hundreds of thousands of Kurds who fled for the hills last month from Zakho and other cities and villages here in northern Iraq.
"Saddam's soldiers, 2,000 of them, are there," said Sayed Daruish Abdullah, a Kurdish refugee who said he was asked to join a caravan that officials want to send to Zakho. "They wear Kurdish clothes and police clothes. We are afraid. If we go there, they will kill us."
Townspeople in Zakho said the Iraqis were listing the names of those who had fled the town for the nearby mountains after the smashing of the Kurdish revolt. And word of their presence spread quickly to leaders of the Kurds mired in misery along the jagged border with Turkey, leaving the kurds still unconvinced that they will be safe from retribution if they leave their mountain refuges for the camps below.
"The leadership on the mountain, it's as if they are on another end of a phone line," said Gordon Murchie, a spokesman for the Agency for International Development. "They seem to know everything going on. They are worried about the Iraqi military. The question is, 'Are they really police and do they really need that many?' "
 
Iraqi Armed Contingents
 Col. Dick Naab of the Marines, a liaison officer to the Iraqi Army, also said the presence of the Iraqis in Zakho was frightening the refugees.
"The Iraqis say they want to cooperate," he said. "This is not cooperation, this is threatening. We are making certain demands. I'd rather not go into that, but we have options."
Iraq has pledged to cooperate in relief efforts, but it condemns the allied plan as interference in its internal affairs and insists that the United Nations oversee the care and protection of the Kurds.
The armed Iraqis arrived in Zakho on Sunday after contingents of the Iraqi Army abandoned a division headquarters, barracks and outposts and left in compliance with the American withdrawal demand.
 
'These Aren't the Police'
 But the issue of whether paramilitary forces could stay was not addressed when the commander of the relief effort, Lieut. Gen. John Shalikashvili of the Army, outlined the agreement with the Iraqi authorities on Friday.
"My interpretation of his statement in that meeting was that he wanted them to start pulling back immediately," said Staff Sgt. Lee Tibbets, spokesman for the 24th Marine Expeditionary Unit, who was at the meeting. "Let's get one thing straight. These aren't the police, these are Iraqi soldiers with AK-47's. The generals are working on why there are people walking around in green uniforms with AK-47's."
Kurdish clan chiefs, who hold sway over families ranging from 100 to several thousand, have told American officials that they will not order their kinsmen out of the mountains unless President Saddam Hussein falls or the allies give absolute assurances that the Kurds who return to northern Iraq will be indefinitely protected from the Iraqi Army.
Washington has stressed that its military presence in northern Iraq is a short-term humanitarian operation, although it has set no time limit for it. The United States hopes to turn over the relief operation to the United Nations and private aid organizations.
 
Recruiting Kurds for Camps
 The United Nations has said that it is not equipped to cope with the huge undertaking.
Journalists saw members of the Kurdish rebels in the tent city at Zakho this afternoon, and clan chiefs are supposed to tour the site on Wednesday. American officials hope to recruit Kurds to help build the camp and want to begin moving people into tents in the next few days.
"There is nothing wrong with a police force to help restore civilian authority in a town," said Mr. Murchie, the relief official. "But now there are so few people that when you bring in this many police they almost outnumber the inhabitants."
The Iraqis "are going to keep on playing games," he said, adding, "Right now they are trying to see how far they can go."

HEADLINE: Oregon Literacy Test Shows Many Lag in Basics

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SALEM, Ore., April 23

 BODY:
In what is being called the nation's first comprehensive statewide survey of adult literacy, Oregon has found that 97 percent of adults can read at some level, but only a small percentage can interpret a poem, use a bus schedule or determine correct change from a lunch bill.
The survey results, announced today by Gov. Barbara Roberts of Oregon, offer the first preview of what a national adult literacy survey is likely to show when it is conducted next year. 
 The national survey will use the same test as was used here, one administered by the Education Testing Service of Princeton, N.J. The test used a random sampling of 2,000 people.
Some Oregon educators and political leaders were surprised at the large number of people who could not perform basic tasks.
"I didn't realize that a bus schedule could be so difficult to read," Governor Roberts said.
The survey broke the reading test down into three basic categories: prose literacy, or understanding information in a basic text; document literacy, or the comprehension of maps, graphs or technical information; and quantitative literacy, the ability to follow and apply simple mathematics.
In the prose category, 78 percent of those surveyed were classified as reading at the basic, or lowest level, 41 percent were intermediate, and 8.7 percent were classified as master.
When asked to locate specific information in a sports article, 97 percent could do so. But when asked to find information that the columnist Tom Wicker of The New York Times used to support an argument made in his essay, only 47 percent correctly answered the question.
 
Trouble With a Bar Graph
 In testing for document literacy, the survey found that 95 percent could determine the due date for payment of a bill; 84 percent could find the year-to-date gross pay on a payroll stub; 35 percent could determine the correct dosage of medicine using a chart of a child's age and weight; 18 percent could use a bus schedule to find the time of departure, and only 4 percent could read a bar graph well enough to determine economic recovery.
The quantitative section found that 96 percent of adults could tabulate two entries on a bank deposit slip; 60 percent could use an advertisement to determine the least costly product; only 37 percent could determine the correct change from $3 after purchasing two items from a lunch menu, and only 5 percent could correctly figure out which sort of investment, from a table comparing monthly to weekly returns, would be the most beneficial.
Those tested ranged from 16 to 65 years of age, and were selected as a scientific sample of the adult population. The test was conducted in their homes and lasted an hour. In a previous, smaller survey, Oregonians tested slightly higher than the national average.
Adults 21 to 25 years old were tested in 1985 nationwide, but no comprehensive literacy survey of all age levels has yet been conducted.
Robert Silvanik, director of state literacy programs for the National Governors' Association in Washington, D.C., said estimates of adult illiteracy in the United States range from 25 million to 70 million people. But he said the definition of illiteracy had changed dramatically in the last 25 years.
The survey in Oregon and the nationwide test scheduled for next year will be used to determine how many people are not responding to basic communication demands in an increasingly complex society.
"It's a mistake to measure literacy by grade level, or whether somebody can read their name," Mr. Silvanik said. "The meaning of illiteracy is much broader than ever before. We have high school and even college graduates who cannot comprehend their functioning level."
 
Answering the Basic Demands
 The Oregon tests indicate that educators should be doing more testing on how well people can answer the basic demands of society, and less on right and wrong academic questions, said Matthew Prophet, superintendent of schools in Portland.
Governor Roberts said Oregon would use its survey as a tool to help the displaced and the poor.
"How can an unemployed woman get to a job interview on time if she can't read the bus schedule?" the Governor asked. "How can a father care for his sick daughter if he can't tell how much medicine to give her?"
President Bush has made improvement of adult literacy one of the four planks in his recent education program. Two bills in Congress would also promote education of adults who cannot read at a functioning level.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
3 Media Companies Report Large Declines

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Times Mirror Corporation, the Tribune Company and the Washington Post Company yesterday reported large declines in their first-quarter earnings, reflecting the added costs of covering the war in the Persian Gulf and the impact of the recession on advertising revenue.
Times Mirror said earnings fell 49 percent; Tribune reported a 37 percent decline, and Washington Post a 65 percent decline. 
 Following are the media companies' results:
 
Times Mirror
Times Mirror, based in Los Angeles, earned $23.3 million, or 18 cents a share, in the three months ended March 31, down from $46 million, or 36 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue fell about 1 percent, to $864 million from $875.2 million. The decline would have been greater except for a gain of 5 cents a share this year from sales of a cable television system investment.
The company said advertising volume dropped at its newspapers, magazines and television operations. Also contributing to the lower results were higher costs related to circulation growth at The Los Angeles Times and Newsday, said Robert F. Erburu, the chief executive.
Despite higher newspaper circulation revenue, newspaper publishing revenue was down 7 percent and operating profit fell 73.4 percent.
Broadcast television revenue fell 15.1 percent, while operating profit tumbled 87.8 percent because of reduced advertising and higher program costs.
But revenue rose 8.2 percent in the book, magazine and other publishing groups as operating profit rose 17.2 percent. The cable television division had increases of 21.3 percent in revenue and 94.2 percent in operating profit.
Times Mirror's shares gained 12.5 cents, to $30.25, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Tribune
Tribune, based in Chicago, earned $21.1 million, or 26 cents a share, in the first quarter, down from $33.5 million, or 43 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue fell 20 percent, to $467.6 million from $583.6 million.
The company attributed the drop to lower operating profit from its three lines of business -- newspaper publishing, broadcasting and entertainment, and newsprint operations -- as well as higher interest expenses and higher income-tax rates.
Operating profit in the newspaper division fell 18 percent as revenue fell 31 percent, reflecting a sharp decline in ad revenue.
The latest results exclude any contribution from The Daily News, which was sold in March to Robert Maxwell. Operating losses for The News were reflected in Tribune's 1990 results.
Broadcasting and entertainment's operating profit fell 39 percent, to $3.8 million, on a 4 percent revenue decline because of fewer shows in syndication and lower ad levels.
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Tribune shares were unchanged at $45.50.
 
Washington Post
Washington Post said earnings in the first quarter fell to $13.6 million, or $1.15 a share, from $39 million, or $3.16 a share, in the corresponding period in 1990. Revenue declined 7 percent, to $317 million, from $341 million a year earlier.
Newspaper division revenue fell 13.5 percent, as ad volume tumbled 22.5 percent at The Washington Post.
Revenues at Newsweek magazine fell 3.5 percent. Revenues at the broadcast division dropped 11 percent, while cable division revenue rose 12.5 percent.
Washington Post's share price fell $6 yesterday, to $220, on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
RJR Posts Small Profit For Quarter

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
In a surprise to analysts, RJR Nabisco announced a small profit for the first quarter yesterday, its first since going private in 1989 in history's largest leveraged buyout. It posted net income of $5 million, compared with a loss of $222 million in the comparable period last year.
Despite sluggish domestic cigarette sales, quarterly sales for the company over all rose 8.4 percent, to $3.47 billion from $3.2 billion, largely because of foreign cigarette sales and higher sales of food, like Oreo cookies and Grey Poupon mustard. 
 Earnings before interest, taxes and other charges totaled $800 million, up 6 percent from $754 million. But interest and other costs dropped by a quarter, to $637 million from $846 million, largely because of refinancing and swapping debt for common shares. The $209 million drop in such costs nearly equaled the loss in the 1990 period.
 
Stock Up 12.5 Cents
 The stock of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation rose 12.5 cents yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, to $11.75. The issue was the Big Board's most active, with a volume of 3.8 million shares.
Analysts were quick to reduce their estimates of interest expense sharply, a crucial factor for leveraged buyouts, from about $2.5 billion to $2 billion this year. "For any company," said John C. McMillin of Prudential Securities Inc., "$500 million is a lot of cookies."
Last week, RJR Nabisco successfully sold $1.5 billion in new "junk bonds," double what it once thought it could sell, at an interest rate, 10.5 percent, just above that of investment-grade issues.
Mr. McMillin said the quarter was helped by the end of the Persian Gulf war, which increased cigarette sales in the Mideast, where RJR Nabisco has a relatively strong presence.
"But Nabisco knocked the cover off the ball" with strong sales and profits for food, he said, partly by moving sales of certain grocery products to independent brokers rather than Nabisco's own sales force. The shift cut overhead and enhanced profits.
 
Losses Peaked in '89 Period
 The tobacco-and-food giant's previous seven quarters of losses peaked in the third quarter of 1989 at $447 million. The losses resulted from RJR Nabisco's huge and expensive debt, $29 billion at its peak and costing 17 percent for some of the bonds, which the company accumulated when it went private in the $25 billion buyout.
RJR Nabisco's crucial cigarette business, which accounted for more than half the company's sales and 80 percent of operating profit, posted a rise in operating profit, to $648 million from $637 million. Cigarette revenues rose 5 percent, to $1.96 billion from $1.86 billion.
But the improved cigarette performance resulted mainly from foreign gains, especially in Europe and Asia, rather than in the United States, where unit sales are declining by about 3 percent a year. The figures include part of the 14 billion cigarettes scheduled to be sold to the Russian republic from October 1990 to December 1991.
RJR Nabisco said its domestic decline was "larger than trend," but did not have an immediate estimate.
 
Lower Cigarette Volume
 RJR Nabisco acknowledged lower unit volumes in cigarettes for the first quarter, as well as a more than 12 percent increase in marketing expenditures, for advertising and promotions like contests and discount coupons. The strategy is in line with the company's heavier investment in its full-price cigarettes, which are declining in unit sales, like Winston and Salem, rather than the growing but less profitable discount brands like Doral and Sterling.
RJR Nabisco's food business posted a 21 percent rise in operating profits, to $171 million, from $141 million in the 1990 period. Quarterly revenues increased 12 percent, to $1.5 billion from $1.34 billion.
But excluding sales for the Baby Ruth/Butterfinger candy business, which was sold last year, RJR's food sales rose only 3 percent and operating net about 22 percent.

HEADLINE: M.I.T. to Repay $731,000, Including Lobbyist Fees

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
The Massachusetts Institute of Technology announced today that it would pay back $731,000 to the Government, including $27,000 it used to pay Washington lawyers to lobby the Government on M.I.T.'s behalf, university officials said.
The lobbying was intended to dissuade a Congressional committee from investigating fraud allegations in a research paper signed by Dr. David Baltimore, then affiliated with M.I.T. and now president of Rockefeller University. 
 M.I.T.'s decision was preceded by a similar action last week by an affiliated research laboratory, the Whitehead Institute, which agreed to repay $69,000, also in lobbying expenses incurred in the investigation of the research article signed by Dr. Baltimore.
The announcement by M.I.T. combines two issues that have recently given science a black eye. One is the issue of overhead expenses that universities may properly charge to the research grants received from the Government. The other is the five-year-long furor over charges of scientific fraud in an article prepared by a research colleague of Dr. Baltimore.
M.I.T. says the $731,000 figure it has said it will repay is less than 1 percent of the $482 million in overhead costs the university billed to the Federal Government over the last five fiscal years.
The charges being withdrawn included $1,500 for a trip to Barbados; $13,750 for a party, and $27,300 in expenses it was billed by the Washington law firm of Kirkpatrick & Lockhart to aid three M.I.T. officials in testifying on questions of scientific fraud before the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations.
The university had billed the Government for the charges and had already received reimbursement for some of the total.
M.I.T. made its announcement at a hearing today by the House Science, Space and Technology Committee.
"We have a responsibility to American taxpayers, including ourselves, our own faculty and employees, to make sure that scientific research in the non-profit university environment is being conducted economically," M.I.T.'s president, Charles Vest, said today. "M.I.T. has a long history of cooperation with the Federal Government," he added. "And such a cooperative situation mandates a sense of fairness and a sense of responsibility."
Mr. Vest said M.I.T. was withdrawing charges that are now considered inappropriate but that were allowed under regulations that existed at the time. Most of the expenses withdrawn were "in the allowable but inappropriate category, such as receptions, functions, memorabilia or gifts, flowers, and catering charges," he said. Other claims were not intended as charges to be billed to the Government but were billed through a bookkeeping error, he added.
M.I.T. reviewed its overhead charges after the unfavorable public attention given to Stanford University, which had the Federal Government pick up as overhead on research grants items like a yacht, fresh flowers and cedar closets in the President's residence. Stanford, the California Institute of Technology and Harvard's Medical School have each withdrawn about $500,000 in such charges.
Other universities' accounts are also under scrutiny, and this week the Office of Management and Budget listed expenses that universities may not charge to the Government as part of the overhead costs of scientific research.
The repayments by the Whitehead Institute, first reported in The Boston Globe on April 17, included money that was used to pay for the services of several Washington lawyers, including Joel Jankowsky of Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld.
Mr. Jankowsky is a registered lobbyist who, Congressional aides said, lobbied various members of Congress before a hearing by the Energy and Commerce oversight committee, headed by Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan.
Representative Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, said today that Mr. Jankowsky had met with him to raise concerns about the hearing and about whether Dr. Baltimore would be treated fairly.

 
Assertions About Research
 The lobbying by the Whitehead Institute also concerned the investigation by Mr. Dingell's panel. The committee was looking into an article based on work by Dr. Thereza Imanishi-Kari and signed by Dr. Baltimore. Since 1986, Dr. Baltimore has persistently repudiated charges of fraud in Dr. Imanishi-Kari's work.
He and scientists supporting him conducted a campaign of writing and speaking to defend Dr. Imanishi-Kari and what they felt was the integrity of science. He said Congress should not be involved in such matters.
Last month, a draft report written by the Office of Scientific Integrity at the National Institutes of Health concluded that Dr. Imanishi-Kari's work was not in error, but was intentionally faked.
Now, critics have begun to question details of Dr. Baltimore's campaign, including the use of Whitehead Institute funds to lobby the Congress. Until recently, Dr. Baltimore was director of the Whitehead Institute.
Officials of the institute said that at least $196,000 was spent in 1988 and 1989 for legal fees in the defense of the 1986 research paper.
Dr. John Sawhill, chairman of the board of the Whitehead Institute, today said the money had been approved by the board of directors at Dr. Baltimore's request "to retain counsel to help Dr. Baltimore deal in an adversarial environment with the N.I.H. and the Congress."
He said: "We felt it was appropriate to pay some portion of the legal fees because he was director. I don't think we'd change our decision, because at the time, we didn't think fraud was involved. We felt Dr. Baltimore had done a wonderful job in building the institute."
John Pratt, associate director of the institute, said that Dr. Baltimore had asked that those legal fees not be charged to the Government, but that the fees for 1988 were forwarded through an error of the accounting department.

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Profits Up 6.6% At McDonald's

 BODY:
The McDonald's Corporation, the world's largest fast- food chain, said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose 6.6 percent, to $168.5 million, or 46 cents a share, compared with $158.1 million, or 43 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago.
Revenues rose 3.3 percent, to $1.56 billion from $1.51 billion. 
 But its core business, restaurant sales in the United States, continued to be sluggish. Foreign sales, which account for more than half of McDonald's business, were strong, despite the fact that overseas outlets make up only about one-quarter of its 11,800 restaurants.
Currency translations favored McDonald's. If first- quarter currency values had stayed at 1990 levels, McDonald's said, earnings would have been lower by $3 million.
Like other fast-food restaurants, McDonald's has had to cope with a sluggish United States economy that has chilled customers' willingness to eat out, even at inexpensive fast- food outlets. While the nation's population has grown only 1 percent or so a year, burger, chicken, pizza and other chains have grown far faster.
McDonald's share price slipped 12.5 cents yesterday, to $34.875.

HEADLINE: LATIN QUAKE TOLL PUT AS HIGH AS 70

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMON, Costa Rica, April 23

 BODY:
An international relief effort began delivering assistance to Costa Rica today, a day after a severe earthquake struck a broad area of Costa Rica and Panama.
A Costa Rican Government official said that "no more than 20" had been killed by the quake in this country, but an official of the Costa Rican Red Cross said that at least 50 people had died. Reuters reported 23 killed in Panama. Reports from both countries indicated that at least 500 had been injured. 
 United States, United Nations and Latin American relief workers said they had evacuated about 200 of the most seriously injured Costa Ricans to hospitals in San Jose, the capital.
Costa Rica's President, Rafael A. Calderon Jr., said in an impromptu news conference at the Limon airport that damaged bridges and roads threatened the delivery of relief supplies, but that the medical effort had gone well.
"The first stage is completed," he said. "We have saved lives. The second stage is food."
 
Loan From the World Bank
 Mr. Calderon announced that he had received a $60 million loan from the World Bank for emergency road and bridge repair, and he appealed for more aid. He said he feared a cholera outbreak unless sanitation could be rapidly improved.
In Limon, thousands of residents who slept in the streets, parks and fields Monday night remained there today, afraid to return to sagging houses that continued to be rattled by strong aftershocks. In one neighborhood two miles north of the city center, young children held plastic soda bottles up to passing cars and trucks, begging for water.
Power and water supplies were restored to some neighborhoods in Limon by nightfall, however.
American diplomats said no Americans were injured.
One group of Americans said they were cruising on a river several miles north of Limon when suddenly the channel shook and the river reversed its course, nearly swamping their two boats. "The river banks exploded," said Ronald Greek, a member of the group. "The trees fell in."
Limon, a Caribbean port of 65,000 people that handles 80 percent of Costa Rica's exports, was the city closest to the epicenter of the quake, which was measured at 7.4 on the Richter scale of ground motion.
It was the worst quake in Costa Rica since 1910, when 600 died in the city of Cartago.
Rodolfo Rojas, the customs administrator for Limon, said that the Caribbean Sea receded 100 yards after the quake, beaching an American container vessel that was loading bananas. As he toured the collapsed customs building, he said that the water had returned far enough this morning to allow the ship to depart.
The oil refinery in Limon was badly damaged in the quake, and Costa Rican officials said that it might take months to repair it.
The main road into Limon from San Jose was severed, with two bridges severely damaged. President Calderon said 10 trucks with relief supplies were backed up on the highway. His aides said they hoped to reopen the road in one or two days.
Officials offered differing estimates of the number of casualties. Eduardo Sanchez of the Costa Rican Red Cross estimated that 50 had died and 500 had been injured in Costa Rica because of the quake, but Gerardo Fernandez, the operations director of the Costa Rican National Emergency Commission, said that there were "no more than 20 dead and 200 injured."

HEADLINE: Fleet's Big Bet on New England

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
In one fell swoop, J. Terrence Murray, Rhode Island born and Harvard bred, is turning the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group into New England's biggest bank at a time of one of the region's worst economic downturns.
His $625 million bet for the assets of the failed Bank of New England will give his operation hundreds of new branches, billions in new deposits and loans and a presence in Massachusetts, where Fleet does not operate. It will also make Fleet, based in Providence, R.I., the clear banking leader in New England -- toppling the venerable Bank of Boston and putting Fleet among the 10 biggest banks in the nation. 
 But this is not a riskless proposition. And Mr. Murray, Fleet's 52-year old chief executive, is counting on an aggressive cost-reduction plan and an eventual turnaround in the New England economy to make it pay off. On the day after the acquisition was announced, Mr. Murray conceded that he expected to lose money on the deal initially, and he warned not to expect quick profits of the kind that occured in Texas when failed banks were sold by the Government to healthy bidders like the NCNB Corporation of Charlotte, N.C.
"This is a very strategic move for us," said Mr. Murray, who started at Fleet as an $85-a week trainee in 1962. "It fills holes we have in our franchise, and will make us the region's best-capitalized bank. The key is not what happens in the first 12 months, but realization of real returns in the subsequent periods."
On Wall Street, Fleet's stock rose $3.625 a share on the New York Stock Exchange to close at $21.50, one of the day's biggest gainers.
Fleet, along with Kohlberg, Kravis Roberts & Company, the Wall Street buyout firm, was selcted by the Government on Monday to buy the failed bank. The acquisition increases Fleet's assets -- primarily its loan portfolio -- by about $15 billion, to $46 billion. It adds 12,000 employees to its payroll of 18,000 and it brings its branches to 837, of which 474 are in New England and 363 are in upstate New York. And it thrusts Fleet, a hybrid institution that is half bank and half financial services company, more deeply into traditional banking.
Many analysts see the deal as an opportunity that Fleet can ill afford to pass up. They point out that the agreement with Federal regulators gives Fleet up to three years to transfer bad loans back to the Government. This means Fleet is acquiring a bank unencumbered by the bad real estate loans that have cut profits at so many other New England banks. And they note that Fleet has had a history of effective cost-cutting as it snapped up local New England banks in the last several years and engineered the acquisition of the Norstar Bancorp, based in Albany, in 1988.
"It's not a big risk," said David S. Berry, vice president at Keefe Bruyette & Woods, which analyzes the banking industry. "The real risk is operational -- if they don't get the cost savings. But that's a manageable risk. And they are in good shape, barring a total downturn in the New England economy, because they have three years to put bad loans back to the Government."
 
Bostonians Are Relieved
 Bankers in Boston are relieved that the Bank of New England, once the region's second largest, is finally sold. It will bring certainty to the region's banking scene and eliminate a wounded institution whose aggressive lending once put pressure on other banks to fall into increasingly risky ventures. Fleet's arrival means that the Bank of New England is still in local hands -- Fleet traces its history back to 1791.
The possible presence in the region of the BankAmerica Corporation of San Francisco, the rival bidder, was feared by local bankers because of its unfamiliarity and size -- it is the nation's second-largest bank, after Citicorp. "The real fear was that players would come in from out of the region and knock people around," said Gerard S. Cassidy, an analyst with Tucker, Anthony in Portland, Me.
William Crozier, president of the BayBanks in Boston, said: "We can return to stability. Bank of New England was like a wounded whale thrashing around. Now we have a vigorous competitor and one we know."
Charles Peabody, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody, said that for Fleet, "the rewards are quite substantial." The risk, he added, is "to get a real return on their investment, since a considerable piece of their capital is now infused in Bank of New England."
Mr. Peabody said that Fleet was getting a $14 billion bank with asset protection. "We think this acquisition can earn $140 million in 1993 and generate upward of $200 million a year by the end of the decade," he said. "This acquisition makes Fleet the dominant player in New England banking."
John W. Flynn, Fleet's chief financial officer, estimated that Fleet would lose about $20 million in the first six months after the acquisition and expected to save about $350 million in expenses in the first year. Given the poor state of the New England economy, returns for the acquisition will come more from cost savings than from making loans. "We don't expect to get the full benefits for at least 18 months," Mr. Flynn said.
When asked about cost reductions, Mr. Murray specifically declined to estimate the number of Bank of New England employees to be laid off. But, he said that in the last nine years Fleet had acquired more than 49 banks and was skilled at the delicate task of bank consolidation.
Fleet, which takes over Bank of New England on Monday, said it had not yet decided whether it would change the acquired bank's name.
"The consolidation process is complicated," Mr. Murray said. "We have parallel back-room operations and product lines and we will have to pay escape bonuses to people to phase them out."
 
Merger Experience
 He said that when Fleet and Norstar merged, 12 data centers were reduced to 1, and 16 operation centers were cut to 3. "So you can see the magnitude of consolidation, and this has implications for Bank of New England," he added. "We haven't made any definitive decisions, but we are looking at overlapping branches and redundant functions in two large independent organizations."
Fleet/Norstar is an unusually diversified bank, both geographically and in its services. Among its non-bank operations are a California-based student-loan processing operation, the nation's largest non-bank equipment leasing operation, a Milwaukee-based mortgage-brokerage firm with more than $52 billion outstanding and a municipal securities dealer with branches in New York and New England.
The revenues from these operations, along with a strict policy against lending to New England condominium developments and a $50 million limit on loans to any one borrower, have created a healthy bank in a region littered with troubled institutions.
The earnings from its non-New England operations have more than offset the downturn in Fleet's New England banking. In 1990, the financial services group earned $125.6 million and the New York Banking Group earned $78.2 million, while the New England Banking Group lost $195 million. Combined with the rest of the company, Fleet as a whole had a 1990 net loss of $48.5 million.
In Providence, depositors at the bank's 26-story Art Deco headquarters hailed the acquisition. "This place is a symbol of strength," said Charles Pasqualetti, a retired salesman, in the bank's lobby, which has 32-foot-high columns of black marble. "You know this place is going to be here tomorrow."

HEADLINE: As Crime Drops in Midtown, Even Criminals Credit Police

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY

 BODY:
New York's citywide crime statistics have not been especially encouraging lately, but there is good news about the streets and subway stations at the core of Manhattan. Crime in midtown, like so much else there, seems to be in a severe recession.
The number of reported felonies, which range from purse-snatching and pickpocketing to murder, began dropping in midtown last summer and is still declining this spring. Since July the number of reported robberies, considered the best gauge of overall street violence, is 18 percent lower than for the same period a year earlier. 
 The muggers' economic slump might be partly related to the city's, since there are fewer workers and shoppers to rob in midtown. But many observers -- criminologists, local merchants, street criminals -- believe the decline is chiefly due to extra police officers on foot patrol, and some experts think the success of the police in midtown augurs well for the rest of the city.
 
'Unsafe for Bad Guys'
 For years criminologists have debated the effectiveness of putting more police on foot patrol, a policy that is gradually being adopted citywide. Extra officers were added in July around Times Square and Pennsylvania Station, and in the fall more officers began patrolling northern midtown.
"We made it unsafe for the bad guys, and the robberies dropped right away," said Assistant Chief Thomas P. Walsh, the commander for all the precincts in Manhattan below 59th Street. "I'm very excited about the results. I've never seen such a sharp decrease in robbery anywhere in the city before."
All other common felonies have also declined in midtown since last summer, compared with the same period a year earlier. The three midtown precincts include most of the area between 29th Street and 59th Street.
Although the police had feared that the extra officers in midtown would simply divert criminals to adjacent neighborhoods, Chief Walsh said that apparently did not happen.
"We're not sure where they've gone," he said.
Some of them could still be found yesterday outside the Port Authority Bus Terminal at 42d Street and Eighth Avenue, where they were offering to sell drugs and telephone credit-card numbers. They generally agreed, regretfully, with the police's statistical picture.
"Too many cops in sight -- it's intimidating," said a 28-year-old man from Brooklyn who declined to give his name but described himself as a former convict and current street hustler.
"They're tightening the bolts, and crime is definitely down," he said. "People are saying, 'Damn! How am I going to get paid?' It's still going on -- the folks smoking that crazy stuff will do anything -- but most people are going other places or sticking to small hustles. I wouldn't try to rob anyone. Well, I might if I saw they had a lot of money, but I'd follow them out of midtown to do it away from these cops."
Dan Biederman, the president of the Grand Central Partnership, said the number of crimes reported near the train station had been dropping since 1989. He attributed this partly to increased patrolling by the city police, and partly to the force of 53 private security guards hired by his organization, a coalition of local property owners and businesses.
 
Crime Down in Subway
 "It used to be that five or six times a year I'd see a thief running down the street with someone's purse," Mr. Biederman said. "I haven't seen that in the last year and a half. There's also been a decline in shoplifting. We've created an atmosphere where criminals know they're going to get caught."
Crime has also been declining in the subway stations at Grand Central, Times Square and Pennsylvania Station. From July through the end of March, the number of felonies fell 19 percent from that period a year earlier. The number of robberies in those subway stations was down 32 percent.
In the Times Square stations, for instance, reported felonies dropped to 362 from 450. At Penn Station, the number of reported robberies fell to 71 from 95.
"One reason for the drop is that we've had a lot more transit cops on patrol," said Albert W. O'Leary, a spokesman for the transit police. "By paying overtime, we've had the equivalent of 200 additional officers a day on the subway, and we've also changed our paperwork procedures so that a lot more officers can stay on patrol after making an arrest."
Another reason for the drop in crime, both above and below ground, might be the smaller crowds in midtown. Since July, the number of commuters using the midtown subway stations has been about 6 percent below the previous year. But this difference is smaller than the drop in crime, and some observers doubt that it would have much impact on the crime rate anyway.
"A guy going to commit a crime doesn't care if there are 10,000 people using a subway station or 9,200 -- the opportunity is still there," said Frank McLoughlin, a former deputy city police commissioner who is now director of government relations for the New York Telephone Company, at 42d Street and Avenue of the Americas. "I think an increased number of cops is the reason that crime is down. I've noticed a lot more officers on 42d Street, and I haven't heard many of our employees complaining about mugging in the past six months."
That view was shared by Lee Silver, a spokesman for the Shubert Organization, which owns 17 Broadway theaters.
"We haven't heard any complaints about pickpocketing or purse-snatchings at any of our theaters the last couple of months," he said. "The cops have been doing a great job, and we're seeing the results."
Thomas Reppetto, a criminologist who is executive director of the Citizens Crime Commission, a private group that monitors crime, also credited the additional officers in midtown for helping reduce crime. "I expect this trend to continue and expand citywide, because the police are planning similar programs in other areas," he said.
The redevelopment of West 42d Street may be another factor in the midtown crime drop, said William H. Daly, director of the Office of Midtown Enforcement, a branch of Mayor David N. Dinkins's office working to clean up the area around Times Square. He said the closing last spring of several action-movie theaters had reduced crowds on the notorious block between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.
 
Combination of Factors
 "In some ways 42d Street is the great engine that drives crime in midtown," Mr. Daly said, "and some of the activities that brought in criminals have been closed. The combination of the redevelopment and the added police has brought a decline that's unique in the 15 years I've been working here. Right now 42d Street is in the best shape I've ever seen it."
Still another apparent factor in the crime drop, cited by Mr. Daly and others, was the presence of a police Tactical Narcotics Team in midtown starting last July. The team made more than 2,600 arrests in the nine months ending March 31, and its presence was well known to the men standing outside the Port Authority bus terminal yesterday.
"T.N.T. has been everywhere," said the 28-year-old self-described hustler. "You see the van going around, you see them undercover, you see them in uniform. They're making it hard for us, but we'll survive.
"As long as those Jersey boys are getting off the buses looking for drugs and I.D.'s and switchblades, we'll figure a way to get over."

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
$39.2 Million Loss Posted By Bethlehem

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's No. 2 steel producer, reported a first-quarter loss of $39.2 million yesterday, saying the recession had diminished demand for steel sheet products that go into automobiles and appliances.
Bethlehem's loss compares with income of $21.3 million, or 20 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1990. Sales fell 13.2 percent, to $1.05 billion, from $1.21 billion in the period a year earlier. 
 The company, like others in the industry, has been battered in the last year by falling demand and bitter price competition among the leading steelmakers and the smaller minimill producers. But analysts said the company was also heavily tied to the construction industry and that it might be hurt less by the slowdown than many of its competitors.
The company said its steel business had an operating loss of $26 million for the quarter, compared with operating income of $29 million in the period last year. Bethlehem said its steel shipments were 7 percent lower and attributed the decline to weak demand from the automotive and light construction markets.
 
Higher Labor Costs
 The company said its non-steel operations, which include ship-repair and freight-car producing operations, had a $7 million operating loss, compared with an operating loss of $4 million in the quarter last year. The deeper loss was a result of lower volume and costs of a feasibility study on a joint venture with British Steel on a structural steel plant. Bethlehem also said its labor costs were higher because of a labor agreement that went into effect three years ago. Under the agreement, wages increase at the beginning of each year.
"While there are some signs of stability and potential recovery for the economy from the current recession, the outlook remains uncertain because of high unemployment, credit constraints and the recent strengthening of the dollar," said Walter L. Williams, the company's chairman and chief executive. "Even with a general economic recovery that is expected to start midyear, we do not expect a meaningful rebound in our business until later this year," Mr. Williams said.
Mr. Williams also said he remained optimistic about the prospects of talks with British Steel on establishing a joint venture in the United States to produce structural steel.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Bethlehem Steel's stock closed yesterday at $13.875, down 37.5 cents.
 
'Worse Than We Expected'
 Charles Bradford, a steel analyst with UBS Securities Inc., said that the earnings were in line with his predictions. "However, the non-steel business came in worse than we expected," Mr. Bradford said. "We expect that among all the majors Bethlehem will have performed the best. They will lose money in the second and third quarter and a lot of this has to do with equipment outages because they are doing a lot of modernization."
Mr. Bradford said that the cost of those temporarily idled operations might reach $60 million this year. "And that's over and above what the recession will cost them," he added. "But coming out of it, they will be a much stronger company with better products."

HEADLINE: Audit Disputes F.D.I.C. Fund's Value

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
The nation's senior auditor has found that the fund that protects bank deposits is in substantially worse shape than has been reported and may be worth only about half of the $8.4 billion that regulators previously calculated, a top banking official said today.
L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said today in an interview that the General Accounting Office's annual audit of the bank insurance fund, to be released on Friday, would show that the fund might be worth only about $4 billion to $5 billion. Unaudited figures presented by the F.D.I.C. at the end of 1990 indicated it was worth about $8.4 billion. 
 The F.D.I.C. stands behind its unaudited net worth figure of $8.4 billion. That figure already accounts for the $2.5 billion expected cost of the failure of the Bank of New England and two affiliated banks that were sold yesterday to the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group and Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.
While details of the two agencies' disagreement remain sketchy, Mr. Seidman said that the F.D.I.C. had been trying to persuade auditors from the General Accounting Office to revise their results in an attempt to persuade them that their estimate was too pessimistic.
He said the G.A.O. had come up with a substantially lower net worth figure for the fund than the F.D.I.C. had computed, because the G.A.O. found much higher liabilities. He said the accounting office had come up with the larger figure because it concluded that many more banks were already effectively insolvent than the F.D.I.C. had found.
The insurance fund, created in 1934, after many banks collapsed in the Great Depression, is financed through bank premiums and protects depositors when institutions fail. The number of failures of big banks in recent years has left the fund in its worst condition since it was created, and some Government economists have predicted that it could become insolvent within two years.
The G.A.O., the investigative arm of Congress, is required by law to audit many Government agencies. Its auditors have often disagreed with agencies' leaders and accountants. In the past, it has painted a more negative picture of the F.D.I.C. than the insurance corporation's officials have presented, and its assessments have generally been proved correct.
The accounting office is a nonpartisan organization headed by Charles A. Bowsher, the Comptroller General. Mr. Bowsher commands significant respect on Capitol Hill for his thorough and candid assessments, but he is at times considered a thorn by the Bush Administration. Last month, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady criticized Mr. Bowsher for often taking critical positions. Mr. Bowsher had said the Administration's plan to fix the bank insurance fund concealed the magnitude of the fund's problems and failed to tackle its problems head-on.
 
'Below the Safety Level'
 Mr. Seidman said the G.A.O. figures could push Congress to act more quickly to address the problems of the fund and the banking industry.
"I don't think it will change our view that we'll need a recapitalization by the end of the fiscal year," he said, referring to this fall. Earlier in the day, he said in testimony before the Senate Banking Committee that the bank insurance fund was "down below the safety level" and that only about $7 billion of its resources was in cash. Another $1.4 billion is in other assets.
The Bush Administration is proposing that the the bank insurance fund be refinanced by increasing the borrowing authority of the fund by $70 billion, $25 billion of which would be lent by the Federal Reserve.
But Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, who also testified before the Senate Banking Committee today, made clear that the central bank did not see itself as a lender of last resort for the bank fund. There is "no sound economic reason" to use the Fed instead of the Treasury, he said.
 
Greenspan Sees Bad Precedent
 Mr. Greenspan said that the proposal, by itself, would not inhibit the Fed's ability to conduct monetary policy by changing interest rates, but that it would set a bad precedent, which if followed for future borrowings would substantially reduce the Fed's liquidity and ultimately "create concerns" about its ability to change interest rates.
Treasury Under Secretary Robert R. Glauber took issue with Mr. Greenspan's assessment.
"Recapitalizing the bank insurance fund is a liquidity issue," he said. "Providing liquidity to the banking system is one of the primary traditional responsibilities of the Federal Reserve."
The chairman of the House Banking Committee, Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, said today that he expected to have legislation to recapitalize the insurance fund through his committee and onto the House floor by the end of May.
Mr. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, said he thought an increase in borrowing authority of $25 billion would be enough to "meet immediate needs." He also said he would propose that the borrowing be done through the Treasury "rather than back-door borrowings through the Federal Reserve, or other gimmicks."
 
Computer Analysis of Banks
 Precise details of the differences between the F.D.I.C. and its auditors on the worth of the fund remain unclear. Mr. Seidman said the General Accounting Office had based its results on a computer analysis of insured banks that had failed to meet reserve requirements, based on the banks' confidential financial reports filed quarterly with the F.D.I.C.
"They applied the reserve requirements, figured out how much it would cost to put them in compliance, and then, based on that, decided ipso facto which banks would be insolvent," he said. "Our argument is that generally accepted accounting principles only require us to count losses that are definitely ascertainable, and the use of an economic model is not definitely ascertainable."
He added that the F.D.I.C. had recently retained Arthur Andersen & Company to review the audit results and that the accounting firm had not yet reached any conclusions.
Cleve E. Corlett, a G.A.O. spokesman, said auditors had been relying upon generally accepted accounting principles, which require them to account for all contingent liabilities.
 
'Highly Significant' Testimony
 Mr. Bowsher was out of Washington today and could not be reached for comment. In an interview last week, he declined to discuss the audit of the F.D.I.C., but said his appearance this Friday before the Senate Banking Committee, when he would discuss the figures, would be "highly significant."
Mr. Corlett of the G.A.O. confirmed that auditors from the two agencies had been in discussions over disagreements in the audit reports, but he declined to say how far apart they were.
In a report delivered to Congress today, the G.A.O. found that many bank failures could have been anticipated, and possibly averted, had accounting standards been stronger and reports to regulators more comprehensive.
The accounting office said the system of quarterly reporting by banks to regulators was "seriously flawed" and often failed to provide adequate warnings of troubles at many banks.
G.A.O. officials called upon the organizations that set standards -- the Financial Accounting Standards Board and the American Institute of Certified Public Accoutants -- to come up with more accurate measurements of problem assets at banks.
The report was based on an examination of 39 bank failures in 1988 and 1989. The banks accounted for 87 percent of the total assets of banks that failed during those two years and $8.9 billion of the $11 billion of costs incurred during 1988 and 1989 by the bank insurance fund.
