HEADLINE: Dow Rises 2.73, Ending a Three-Day Slide

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
After what looked much like another poor day on Wall Street, stock prices moved slightly higher late yesterday, ending a three-day losing streak.
"What we've seen here is a short-term selloff," said Kenneth M. Spence, director of technical analysis for Salomon Brothers. "The market is now trying to stabilize around 2,920." 
 The Dow Jones industrial average shot ahead 16 points at the opening bell but quickly faded, dropping close to 30 from its high and ending the day at 2,930.45, ahead 2.73.
 
Volume Up to 167.8 Million
 Pushed ahead strongly by a last-minute flood of bargain hunting, Big Board trading rose to 167.8 million shares, from 164.4 million the day before. But advances narrowly led declines, 830 to 794. Still, while 7 stocks slid to new 52-week lows, 57 rose to new highs.
One was Fleet/Norstar, the winner in the bidding for the failed Bank of New England. One of the best Big Board gainers of the day, it rose to 22 1/4 before ending at 21 1/2, up 3 5/8, in heavy trading.
Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said that heavy computerized selling clipped the Dow almost 8 points but that none of the late recovery in the blue chips appeared to come from program buying.
Analyzing the Dow's movements from a technical standpoint, Mr. Spence said that when the Dow dropped to 2,920 on Monday, it bounced back as bargain hunters moved in. Then yesterday, it climbed to 2,945, dropped again but again moved up easily through 2,920 to close somewhat higher.
"That's where the market will be stabilizing," he said.
 
'Treading Water'
 Asked what it was telling clients, Abby Joseph Cohen, co-chairman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said: "We're telling them the market for the time being is nervous and treading water and that investors are worried that economic recovery and profit recovery isn't here yet.
"At the same time, investors are worried that the Federal Reserve may become less friendly. Some investors are unhappy that the Fed has done nothing recently to cut rates or expand money growth."
Mrs. Cohen said the market was "bouncing all day because investors aren't quite sure whether they should be buying at this point."
But when asked what Goldman, Sachs was saying, she replied, "We're telling clients the bull market is still intact."
She gave these reasons:
*The Fed is still following an easy money stance.
*Central banks in other countries will be providing money stimulus to their economies, which in turn will help the American economy.
*When the American economy recovers from the recession, growth will be "modest" and "unlikely to push inflation up."
Explaining the close relationship between the United States and foreign economies, Mrs. Cohen said that if foreign growth in money supply was faster than economic growth, the excess money supply there "tends to boost stock prices" here. Moreover, she said, a rise in foreign money supply means higher American exports.
 
Takeover Stocks Active
 Besides the Fleet/Norstar deal, the takeover front was busy yesterday. Square D climbed 2 1/2, to 81 1/4, in heavy trading after the electrical equipment producer said it was still considering a proposal by Groupe Schneider of France to raise its $78-a-share bid. It added that it was also "pursuing a full range of alternatives," including "discussions of some of these alternatives with commercial banks."
NCR, target of a $110-a-share takeover bid, fell 1/8, to 101 7/8, after a new high of 102 1/4. Showing he was receptive, NCR's chairman, Charles E. Exley Jr., said he would recommend the offer if A.T.& T. guaranteed $110 regardless of its own stock price.
After the market closed, the Air Force said a team headed by Lockheed, Boeing and General Dynamics won a $65 billion Stealth fighter contract over a group headed by McDonnell Douglas and Northrop. Except for General Dynamics, which rose 1 7/8, to 36 7/8, the others changed little, but bigger moves are expected today.

HEADLINE: CUNY Protest Frustrating Even Students Who Agree

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES

 BODY:
Ask Mario Rodriguez, a 36-year-old father of four from the Bronx, why he became a student leader at the City University of New York and he talks about what would happen if student aid was cut and tuition was raised by $500 a year. A lot of students -- poor New Yorkers, many of them single mothers -- would have to leave school, he says.
With protests against the proposed tuition increases and budget cuts in their third week and no solution in sight, there is a growing sense of frustration and tension among the students throughout the 21-campus system. 
 In interviews at several campuses over the last few days, most students agreed that proposals for the City University would be devastating: in addition to the tuition increase, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposals call for $52 million in cuts in student aid, staffing and several programs. Many said thousands of students would not be able to absorb the double blow of $1,950-a-year tuition and less financial aid. But more and more students are questioning the use of strikes as a protest, wondering if keeping students out of school is the best way to keep them in school.
 
'Certainly Justified'
 "The protests are certainly justified," said James Butler, a 25-year-old senior in mechanical engineering at City College. "But the students should realize how many lives they're disrupting."
Mr. Butler transferred three years ago to City College, in Manhattan, where the protests began on April 8, after he graduated from Fordham University with a degree in biology. To pay for school, he tutors nursing students in biology at Hostos Community College in the Bronx, another campus embroiled in protests.
"Now I'm out of school," he said, "and out of work."
And Joseph Tosto, a 23-year-old senior at City College, also majoring in engineering, said, "What about our right not to protest?"
About 300 students have seized buildings at 12 of CUNY's 21 campuses, halting classes at 6 campuses and forcing 52,000 students out of school. Protesters agreed yesterday to release one building, the Graduate Center in Manhattan, at noon tomorrow. And today, student representatives are to take their case to Albany, where they plan to meet with the Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller of Brooklyn.
The university administration, struggling with how to handle the impasse, has been seeking temporary restraining orders barring the students from occupying buildings.
Yesterday, students at Bronx Community College were ordered by Justice Alice Schlesinger of State Supreme Court in Manhattan to release the buildings by 8 A.M. today, university officials said. Students at Borough of Manhattan Community College defied a similar injunction last week. Students at Lehman College in the Bronx are to appear this morning at a hearing before Justice Schlesinger.
The students entrenched in campus buildings say the takeovers are the most dramatic way to force attention on the devastation that would be wrought by the proposed cuts and on how the proposals would destroy the once-free university's historic mission to educate the city's poorest students.
Like Mr. Rodriguez -- raised by working-class parents from Puerto Rico and the first in his family to go to college -- many are the children of the city's immigrant poor. Others are immigrants themselves, most often from the Caribbean. Most striking, the majority of the two dozen protesters interviewed over the last week said they could endure a tuition increase but were protesting to protect the thousands of students who could not.
Mr. Rodriguez, who is president of the Student Government Association at Hostos, is one of those. A former doorman for a Park Avenue building, he enrolled in Hostos partly because he could manage the $1,225-a-year tuition with loans. His wife, a parking-fine collector, supports him and their two children on $27,000 a year (his other two chidren live with his ex-wife most of the year).
 
'Here for the Duration'
 That makes him rich, he said, compared with the more than 80 percent of the 4,150 students at Hostos Community College who earn less than $8,000 a year. "So we're here for the duration," he said, sitting in the student cafeteria, which is housed in a garage-like classroom building on the Grand Concourse.
But there are other students, with similar backgrounds and similar dreams, who have reached very different conclusions.
Susan Jacob, an 18-year-old freshman at Hunter College, where students have taken over the administration building and library, said she could not condone their methods. "Everyone has a right to peaceful protest," said Ms. Jacob, who was raised in the Bronx by parents who moved here from India. "But it's not fair to students to not let them go to class."
Ms. Jacob receives full financial aid, as does her sister, a senior at Lehman College. But she said her father, an unemployed factory worker, struggled to pay for her books. "I know that my parents will pay for my education if they have to," she said.
 
'You Work Harder'
 Mr. Tosto, who lives in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn with his parents and plans to become a mechanical engineer like his father, received a full four-year scholarship to attend City College. Now in his fifth year there, he said he works full time to pay his tuition.
"If the tuition goes up, you work harder," said Mr. Tosto, who works as a computer software consultant at a Wall Street firm. He is also captain of the college's swim team and president of its mechanical engineering club. "I don't agree with the increase, either," he said. "But I offered the protesters another way to do it and they didn't want it." He said he suggested that the students hold protest rallies on and off campus instead of seizing buildings.

GRAPHIC: Photos: "We're here for the duration," said Mario Rodriguez, center, of the protest against CUNY tuition increases. He was joined at Hostos Community College in the Bronx by fellow students, Hector Sanchez, left, and Arsinio Devares. Mural depicts Eugenio Maria de Hostos, the Puerto Rican patriot for whom the school is named. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times) (pg. HEADLINE: Thousands, Doing Without, Make Do in Apartment Strike

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
On its third day, the strike by 30,000 building service workers in the New York City region settled into a pattern yesterday. Deliverers, repairers, cable television workers and city garbage collectors generally honored picket lines, forcing hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers to devise creative ways to perform ordinarily simple tasks like having a package delivered or taking out the trash.
Even so, striking workers at dozens of buildings in Manhattan said residents had remained cordial and even supportive. Striking porters, handymen and doormen outside several buildings on the Upper West Side were treated to homemade cookies, doughnuts, coffee and other goodies from tenants in what, superficially at least, may be among the most amiable strikes in the city's recent history.
 
Difference Over Wages
 "The strike had better stop soon or I'm going to gain weight," said Danny Rodriguez, a striking concierge at Sofia condominium apartments at 43 West 61st Street. He had received coffee, bagels and cookies from sympathetic condo owners by early afternoon. 
 But all the good-luck wishes and expressions of sympathy by residents -- many of whom have known the striking workers for years and consider them a vital part of their building's extended family -- did not disguise the fundamental economic issues that caused the strike. The union is proposing a wage increase of about 5 percent a year for three years, a union representative said, and the owners' representatives are offering 2 percent. That means that about $14 a week separates the two sides.
Doormen, elevator operators, porters and other service workers receive $462.73 a week under the contract that expired Sunday, according to the management's bargaining agent, the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations. Handymen make $503.
Many of the same cooperative and condominium owners who are expressing solidarity with their striking service workers on the sidewalk picket lines will have to pay for any wage and benefit increases that are eventually won.
 
Owners Cite Higher Costs
 Their representatives insist that substantial wage increases are not feasible when maintenance costs are already soaring because of huge increases in property taxes and water and sewer costs.
The strike is affecting all boroughs except the Bronx, where workers are represented by another union, and Suffolk and Nassau Counties on Long Island. A repre sentative of the striking union -- Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union -- broke nearly two days of silence yesterday to discuss the union's position with a reporter.
Ronald Raab, a lawyer representing the union, said the board, representing the owners of 2,800 buildings, and the union were divided chiefly over the size of a wage increase when talks broke down early Sunday.
The Realty Advisory Board characterized the dispute slightly differently at a news conference on Monday; it included proposed increases in benefits. The gap between the two offers, as stated by the realty board, was also 3 percentage points.
 
Lower Entry Wage
 Other issues also cloud the negotiations, Mr. Raab said. The building owners' representatives are seeking to create a new entry wage for service workers -- 70 percent of the general union wage. Under the proposal, new workers would be brought up to the full wage over three years. In addition, new workers would not receive consecutive days off, which is guaranteed to current employees.
These proposals "are something that the members couldn't possibly tolerate," Mr. Raab said.
James F. Berg, executive vice president of the Realty Advisory Board, said the owners needed such concessions "because costs across the board have been escalating very rapidly."
Management is seeking other changes, Mr. Raab said, including a reduction from 10 paid sick days to 5, a weakening of job-security provisions and the right to replace full-time workers with part-time employees.
The owners' representatives said some provisions sought by the union were particularly troublesome, including a demand to double sick pay and another to shorten the workweek from 40 hours to 35.
Many buildings where the owners want the front doors attended 24 hours a day would have to hire additional workers if the workday was cut an hour -- to seven from eight hours. Three shifts of eight hours each now provide the service.
Mr. Raab said the union has dropped that demand.
Even so, no new talks are scheduled as each side waits for the impact of the strike to be felt. "Nothing lasts forever, so I'm sure we'll be back together," Mr. Raab said.
On the streets yesterday, both sides made accommodations to ease potential disruptions. Drivers from United Parcel Service avoided crossing the picket lines at some buildings by giving lists of people for whom they had packages to security guards, who then notified the recipients. The residents had to go to the U.P.S. trucks to claim their packages.
The Sanitation Department began acting on health emergency complaints and announced that beginning today, its trucks would pick up refuse at 51 sites on the East and West Sides of Manhattan. Sanitation workers have refused to cross picket lines except in health emergencies.
Reporters surveying parts of the Upper East Side and Upper West Side found more than 20 apartment buildings that had reached separate agreements with the union, ending the strike. Union and management officials say the wage increases in these agreements are similar to those proposed by the union.
Mr. Raab said about 150 buildings had reached separate agreements. That would be about 5 percent of all buildings covered by the strike.
Overall, residents of buildings with workers on strike appeared to chip in yesterday without much complaint. The residents "are taking it pretty good," said Tom Southwick, a striking concierge at 710 Park Avenue, at 70th Street.
"But it's early yet," he added. 'Give them a week and come back and ask me."

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Damning a President With Fairness

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

President Reagan
The Role of a Lifetime
By Lou Cannon
948 pages. Illustrated. Simon & Schuster. $24.95.
By being eminently fair, Lou Cannon has written a devastating account of Ronald Reagan's Presidency. Try as he does to be even-handed, and he is so almost to a fault, the conclusion of "President Reagan" is best summed up in the apt subtitle of his book: "The Role of a Lifetime." 
 It's a phrase that can be interpreted without rancor by Mr. Reagan and his admirers; of course being President of the United States is the most important event in anyone's life, ex-actor or ex-anything else. But by the end of this exhaustive 948-page Presidential biography, Mr. Cannon leaves the reader with a decidedly negative assessment: that while Mr. Reagan may have been qualified to play the part of a President in Hollywood, he was unqualified to be the President in Washington.
The author, now the Western correspondent for The Washington Post, covered Ronald Reagan for more than 25 years in California and Washington and interviewed him and Nancy Reagan several times for this book. He delivers his judgment in temperate language:
"Because of his ability to reflect and give voice to the aspirations of his fellow citizens, Reagan succeeded in reviving national confidence at a time when there was a great need for inspiration. This was his great contribution as President. But because he believed in happy endings obtained with too little sacrifice, this revived confidence became an end in itself that Reagan rarely sought to focus on higher goals. He aged little in the Presidency and took his role too lightly. In the end, it proved too big for his talents."
Mr. Cannon's book is a very solid piece of work. While it touches upon Mr. Reagan's life, its main focus is on his performance in office. He gives Mr. Reagan good marks for the intangibles -- inspiring confidence in the American system, showing friendship and leadership in his foreign dealings, being what his critics called a "Dr. Feelgood," a calumny that Mr. Reagan took as a compliment.
But on the tangibles, Mr. Reagan comes off in the book as a sincere incompetent, who sometimes actually snoozed on the job and whose vision for Americans followed the starry-eyed scenarios of old movies. The author says Mr. Reagan often exaggerated for the sake of a story, confusing real life with reel life. As others have written, Mr. Reagan told world leaders that he had seen the concentration camps in Europe when, in fact, he did so only on film in Hollywood, where he spent the war years.
One of the highlights of the author's analytical reporting is that he looks closely at the numbers during Mr. Reagan's two terms; in the best tradition of investigative journalism, he follows the money. Measuring the scripted campaign rhetoric against the Federal Government's bottom line, he shows that while Mr. Reagan promised to balance the budget, his policies led to the largest national debt and worst foreign trade deficit in American history. In this respect, the author quotes a pungent comment about the legacy of Mr. Reagan and Reaganomics by Walt Rostow, a special assistant to President Lyndon B. Johnson and a history professor at the University of Texas: "He's been a good-time Charlie. Nothing bad's going to happen on my watch."
Mr. Cannon properly devotes two powerful chapters -- which he calls "Darkness at Noon" and "Struggle at Twilight" -- to the Iran-contra affair. It was the nadir of Mr. Reagan's style of governance, when a military and intelligence sub-government illegally defied Congress and secretly ran the nation's foreign policy. How much did the President know and when did he know about the diversion of Iran arms-sales proceeds to the Nicaraguan contras? Mr. Cannon is no potted palm when he questions the President's convenient forgetfulness. He writes:
"Reagan has consistently denied knowledge of the diversion -- a denial he repeated to me for this book and in his memoirs. But such denials can hardly be regarded as conclusive, even by those who believe Reagan is telling the truth as he remembers it. As has often been observed in these pages, Reagan long ago learned to accept as the truth whatever version of events he used to explain things."
The author doesn't always slam-dunk his points. For example, he uses such euphemisms as "ethical insensitivity," "ethical embarrassments" and "ethical impropriety" for the plain corruption of some of Mr. Reagan's closest aides and Cabinet members, including those at the head of the Justice, Labor, Interior and the Housing and Urban Development departments. Yet he does score with unsensational outside shots at the Presidency when he gets down to the specifics of such things as the courts, the environment and the regulatory agencies. "Overall," he says, "Reagan left a ruinous regulatory legacy."
"President Reagan: The Role of a Lifetime" is the second book by a Washington Post writer to appear in the last few weeks in which the former President is found not to have been up to the job. In "Sleepwalking Through History: America in the Reagan Years" ( W. W. Norton ), Haynes Johnson concludes that the country is now paying for the Reagan legacy with lowered ideals and a debtor economy. Both books are on the same wavelength, with Mr. Johnson's taking a broader look at the social history of the nation and Mr. Cannon's concentrating more on the Reagan Presidency itself. It's noteworthy that Simon & Schuster is the publisher not only of Mr. Cannon's serious book about the President but also of Kitty Kelley's scandal-filled book about the First Lady.
Inevitably, Mr. Cannon also mentions the opulence of the White House under the regal Reagans. But the main value of his well-documented Presidential biography is his evidence that Mr. Reagan's Oval Office too often was out to lunch.

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
To Lessen Malaise, Industry Looks to Up The Purse for Promotion

SERIES: Hard Times In the Bluegrass - Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LEXINGTON, Ky.

 BODY:
After a five-year economic free fall that has wiped out scores of horse farms and sent breeding fees plunging, many people in the thoroughbred industry say its best bet is to launch a national campaign to glorify and advertise the industry's ultimate product: the race horse.
They predict that if they do not do this, the racing business will be decimated by competition from casinos, state lotteries and even the new riverboat gaming operations that several states have instituted to grab a share of the gambling dollar. 
 And they warn that the runaway production of race horses that caused a crash in prices in the 1980's must be replaced by more selective breeding, and that there must be more unified leadership in a fragmented business largely peopled by rugged individualists.
"No industry in America spends less on advertising its own product," said John Gaines, former owner of the Gainesway scientific breeding farm here, and the man who created the Breeders' Cup series of championship races. "You see what national advertising has done for basketball and baseball. Even the meat industry. If this industry can't come up with $50 million and the leadership to spend it wisely, it's going nowhere."
"But," he added, "the industry is so fragmented that it needs leadership. It needs to sell itself as an industry."
Fred Pope, whose agency in Lexington handles advertising for much of the thoroughbred industry, said he was astounded three years ago when he looked into what the racing business was spending on advertising.
"All the race tracks in North America were spending $8 million on advertising," he said. "I had figured it was $100 million. The entertainment industry spends 5 percent of its sales on advertising. Racing, 1.5 percent. In the last five years, attendance fell 11 percent at Santa Anita in California, 12 percent at Aqueduct in New York, 17 percent at Del Mar in California, 18 percent at Belmont Park in New York and 23 percent at Gulfstream Park in Florida.
"How long can you go? Do you want 5,000 people at Belmont on a summer afternoon? We've got to get together before race tracks start closing."
 
From Taxes to 'Product'
 The industry is also clamoring for relief from Federal laws that eroded depreciation allowances and increased taxes on capital gains, and it is searching for ways to bring Arab and Japanese investors back into the horse market. Those are the factors most often cited in explanations of the breeding industry's decline.
But some leading figures in the business, seeking a cure, are shifting their emphasis to the "product," the race horse, and the role the horse might play as the link to the public's pocketbook.
"We no longer have a monopoly on the entertainment dollar or the betting dollar," Gaines said. "Everything starts and ends at the parimutuel window. Racing needs to go where the people are. It must create a whole new fan base."
Gaines said the industry should aim its message to a wider audience, particularly those people already receptive to gambling. "We need to go to the TV audience," he said, "to Disneyland, where 25 million people go each year, to Atlantic City, also 25 million visitors on a hard-core betting basis."
Seth Hancock, president of the Claiborne Farm near Paris, Ky., pointed out that an example of the threat to the business might be found next door to horse racing's most famous site, Churchill Downs in Louisville, home of the Kentucky Derby.
"There's a big river that runs within five miles of Churchill Downs," he said, referring to the Ohio. "People can say, 'I'd like to take that nice gambling cruise on a riverboat.' "
He added: "We've got to find reasons for them to come to the race track and watch the horses run. We've got to have purses high enough to attract horses good enough to attract people as big entertainment."
How would that help the breeding, or bloodstock, business revive?
"It would restore logic to the whole system," Gaines said. "In the 1980's, it was all very exotic. The business attracted large numbers of people who wanted to get on the bandwagon and make a killing. Players were entering, trying to breed and sell yearlings; the market was doubling every two years. And all of a sudden, we were running out of people who could buy those horses."
 
Back to the Race
 "It was like real estate," said the prominent trainer and horse owner D. Wayne Lukas. "Guys didn't have the expertise to stay for the long haul. It was an era when we went through plan A, which was raising horses, and skipped plan B, which was racing horses, and went straight into plan C, which was breeding horses. The horse would have a couple of races, and they'd say, 'Breed him.'
"That's why we need to go back to the race horse in order to revive the whole system. High purses induce you to race your horse."
Lukas probably knows, and works, the system better than anybody else. As an owner, in 12 years, he spent $90 million to buy 280 horses at the Keeneland sales in Kentucky. And as a trainer, he has saddled 13 champions, including Criminal Type, who won the Eclipse Award as the Horse of the Year in 1990.
In a recent telephone interview from the Oaklawn Park race track in Hot Springs, Ark., Lukas said that he saw signs that plan B was already coming to the rescue of plan C.
"Actually, the horse economy is becoming strong again," he said. "Our purse structure has become strong. We simulcast races to other tracks; we put on the Breeders' Cup series with million-dollar purses; we've started the new American Championship Racing Series for older horses; we've got high purses in the Kentucky Derby and the other classic races.
"In fact, now is probably the best time to get into horses. Horse flesh is cheaper than it's been in 15 years, and the purses are higher than ever. Look, the house of cards in the bloodstock market tumbled when race horses couldn't go out on the track and win back the money they cost."

GRAPHIC: Photo: D. Wayne Lukas, who spent $90 million on horses in 12 years: "Now is probably the best time to get into horses. Horse flesh is cheaper than it's been in 15 years, and the purses are higher than ever." (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
China Ties About To Snap

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Beijing and Washington soon will mark the 20th anniversary of Henry Kissinger's secret journey of reconciliation to China. Only there is nothing to celebrate. In a drama barely noticed, Chinese actions are tearing apart ties with the U.S.
 China no longer matters much strategically as Soviet-American rivalry recedes. Its tired leaders cruelly clutch on to power. They flout American concerns in shady trade practices and huge trade surpluses, slave labor camps, Tibet, human rights violations and sales of particularly dangerous weapons.
 
 Congress is fed up with China's performance and seems poised to impose trade sanctions. President Bush, micromanager of policy toward the Middle Kingdom, fought fiercely and prevented Congressional retaliation last year. Beijing is obviously hoping he will rescue it again. But it is far from clear that he will or can -- or should.
 China's leaders had almost two years to shape up since their bloody crackdown in Tiananmen Square. Yet they threw Mr. Bush, their great protector, only a few bones: an abstention in the U.N. vote to authorize force against Iraq, and the release of political prisoners (though providing no list).
 Bones aside, Chinese exporters brought on a trade crisis. They refused to protect U.S. patents and copyrights and resisted American access to their markets. They transshipped goods through Hong Kong to hide their origin. They continued to use prisoners and "ex-prisoners" as slave labor to lower the price of exports.
 By such means, they overcame years of modest U.S. surpluses. But in 1990, China's trade surplus with the U.S. leaped to $10.4 billion. This year experts predict that gap will jump to at least $15 billion, ranking China's trade advantage over the U.S. behind only Japan and Taiwan.
 Meanwhile, Chairman Li Peng and associates meted out harsh sentences to student democratic leaders. They also continued to execute workers demanding political rights, while Westerners hardly raised a murmur compared with their outrage over jailed intellectuals.
 The old gang went on with the systematic destruction of Tibetan identity. Mr. Bush, to the chagrin of Chinese leaders, broke recent precedent and met with the Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader and national symbol. Mr. Bush may have been aiming at Americans charging him with insensitivity about the Kurds, but Beijing got the message anyway.
 Chinese leaders also startled Washington by secretly helping Algeria to build a nuclear reactor. Like North Korea's, it is too small to generate electricity profitably and too large for research, but just right to make material for nuclear weapons.
 Pressured to explain, Beijing announced that the reactor would be for "peaceful uses" and subject to international inspection. But Chinese leaders still have not honored a months- old Administration request for a thorough private explanation.
 China also persisted in playing games with missile sales. U.S. intelligence recently found that Pakistan has started constructing mobile launchers apparently for the Chinese M-11 missile. Its range falls short of agreed international limits, but could be extended. China has not signed on to these limits, but has indicated it would comply with them.
 While Administration officials are unhappy about all these subterfuges, they are loath to slap down China hard. They do not quite know what their boss in the White House wants. So, their inclination is to stress quiet diplomacy and a long-term process of rebuilding relations.
 To Senator Joe Biden, a key player in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, that is not nearly tough enough. He calls China "a rogue elephant on weapons proliferation" and threatens to take away what China needs most from America -- its trading privileges as a most favored nation.
 It would be foolish to isolate China as Washington did from 1950 until the fateful Kissinger trip of August 1971. But strong action along the lines of the Biden approach, perhaps a conditional extension of trading status, is called for.
 Mr. Bush should have learned one thing from his experience with Saddam Hussein and with Chinese leaders: Coddling dictators to moderate their behavior does not work. Better for the U.S. to vehemently defend its interests, and let diplomatic contacts and trade slip to lower levels -- until new and more promising leaders gain power in Beijing.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Let the City College Strikers Take Their Protest to Albany

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Some students at City College, CUNY, protesting proposed tuition increases and financial aid cutbacks, have shut down the North Academic Center, a building where the majority of classes is held. As a City College student, I am both frustrated and outraged by this action.
What is the good this strike is designed to serve? It does not relieve this student's financial burden; I work 20 hours a week, in addition to taking six courses, and each day that I am prevented from taking classes threatens the investment in time and money I've put into my education. 
 Does this strike send the right message to the right people? The professors and on-campus administrators have no say about tuition rates or whether students will receive more or less financial aid from the state. Preventing the professors from teaching and the administrators from taking care of nuts and bolts does not reduce student financial burdens.
Although the education I receive at City College is a steal (and I mean grand larceny, for its quality is tremendous) at $725 a semester, it is very hard for me to support myself in New York City and attend school full time. I therefore sympathize with anyone despairing over a greater financial load. But New York City and New York State are suffering a financial crisis, and everyone will have to give something up, including students at public universities.
It will be a challenge to come up with $900 more a year, if it comes to that. But if there are things worth a little blood, sweat and tears, isn't a college education one of them?
The strikers' demands are not those of every student at City College. Yet every student at City College, on strike or no, is being kept out of the classroom. Albany is the source of the strikers' woes, not Convent Avenue. Let the strikers take their protest to Albany.
 
PAULA HALL
New York, April 8, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (94%);

HEADLINE: Let the City College Strikers Take Their Protest to Albany;
Only Path for Many

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Uncivil Disobedience" (editorial, April 12), your criticism of the striking City University of New York students, suggests they are neglecting other means of heading off the stunning tuition increases that promise to devastate their finances -- indeed, their educational aspirations. The alternatives you offer, however, betray the hypocrisy of law-and-order liberalism in the post-Reagan era.
There have been peaceful demonstrations: nobody noticed. Meetings with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo have been suggested and sought: he has indicated that he is actively uninterested in any such meeting or in alleviating the dire financial situation of these thousands of students. 
 More than half of CUNY students are from households of less than $22,000 yearly income; however, come August, they are going to be asked to find about $700 more to attend college. I wonder how many readers understand what this means in human terms. Throttling the CUNY system is among the most short-sighted of economizing measures imaginable, for it is almost the only path by which many young citizens of this troubled city can escape the tragic circumstances of the urban underclass, the waste and pointless suffering to which their childhoods have been witness.
Cutting budgets will hurt primarily the have-nots among us. This nation is sinking, sinking into self-impoverishment because we are not investing in ourselves.
 
BEN DICKINSON
New York, April 13, 1991
 
The writer is a part-time tutor at the City College Writing Center.

HEADLINE: Book Notes

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell

 BODY:

'Nancy Reagan'
 Kitty Kelley's "Nancy Reagan" is still the best-selling book in the United States, but the rate of sale last week plummeted by almost two-thirds compared with the week before. It will still be No. 1 on the hard-cover nonfiction list in The New York Times Book Review on May 5, reflecting sales through April 20, but it is no longer selling several times faster than every other best-selling book. 
 The falloff is not unexpected, after the buying frenzy that followed the book's publication, by Simon & Schuster and the initial news accounts two weeks ago. In fact, some booksellers said sales also fell last week because they had pretty much sold it out during the first week of sales. This was said to be true at the B. Dalton/ Barnes & Noble chain, where sales "dropped substantially," a spokeswoman said, but largely because many stores in the chain were out of stock.
 
Pictures From the Gulf
 Two photographic records of the Persian Gulf war are in production for publication in the next few months.
"Triumph in the Desert," which Random House plans to publish on Memorial Day, May 27, will contain a foreword by Gen. Colin L. Powell, theChairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. The foreword will represent General Powell's first written appreciation to those who served in the Persian Gulf.
The book, a photographic record of the war, was conceived by Harold Evans, the publisher of Random House adult-trade books. He arranged for General Powell to write the foreword, and arranged for the main text to be written by Peter David, the international editor of The Economist in London, who supervised his magazine's coverage of the war in the Persian Gulf.
 Mr. Evans also assembled much of the art and the production team that has been working on an accelerated schedule. And he chose Ray Cave, a former managing editor of Time magazine, and Pat Ryan, former editor in chief of Life, to select and edit the 200 or so photographs, from photojournalists around the world.
Many suppliers for the $25 hard-cover book have reduced their fees, and Random House to pledge 50 percent of the net proceeds from its sale to the Gulf Crisis Fund of the American Red Cross.
Harry N. Abrams, the art publisher, and the professional photography division of the Eastman Kodak Company will co-publish "In the Eye of Desert Storm," a book with more than 180 color photographs of the gulf war by 25 photographers from Sygma, the international photo agency. The book is to be published in July ($24.95 paperback, $39.95 hard cover) and is to be edited by Eliane Laffont, the president of Sygma.
The introduction to the book is by C. D. B. Bryan, the author of "Friendly Fire." Mr. Bryan also contributed a short profile of Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf to the "Triumph in the Desert," the Random House book.
 
Will He or Won't He?
 General Schwarzkopf himself has apparently not yet made up his mind whether to write a book, or he is not yet willing to say whether he will write one. While publishers and agents say the General could pretty well write his own ticket and while some acknowledge having approached him with offers, they say he has said only that he has not yet made a decision.
 
Books by Booksellers
 Most book awards are chosen by writers or librarians, but the $5,000 Abby Award is chosen by booksellers -- specifically, the members of the American Booksellers Association.
Early this year, each member bookstore was asked to nominate five books they enjoyed selling during the previous year, regardless of subject matter or publication date.
 "With this award we wish to focus attention on the so-called midlist books of quality, in hopes that they will achieve the recognition they deserve," said Bernard Rather, executive director of the association.
The winner is "The Little Tree," by Forrest Carter, the autobiographical account of its author's boyhood in the 1930's with his Eastern Cherokee Hill country grandparents. Published by Delacorte Press in 1976, three years before the author's death, it was reprinted in trade paperback by the University of New Mexico Press in 1986 and has since sold almost 250,000 copies -- making it one of the biggest selling books in that press's history.
Runners-up for the Abby award were "The Civil War" by Geoffrey Ward with Ric Burns and Ken Burns (Alfred A. Knopf), "Cold Sassy Tree" by Olive Ann Burns (Ticknor & Fields and Dell), "The Shell Seekers" by Rosamunde Pilcher (Thomas Dunne/ St. Martin's Press and Dell) and "When I Am an Old Woman I Shall Wear Purple," edited by Sandra K. Martz ( Papier-Mache Press ). "When I Am an Old Woman," an anthology of stories, poems and photographs about growing old, has sold 150,000 copies since its publication three years ago by Papier-Mache, a small press in Watsonville, Calif.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 26, 1991, Friday

 CORRECTION:
The Book Notes column on Wednesday misidentified the book that won the Abby Award from the American Booksellers Association this year. It is "The Education of Little Tree" by Forrest Carter, not "The Little Tree."

HEADLINE: Peter Arnett Wins Special Press Club Award

 BODY:
The Overseas Press Club of America honored foreign correspondents, editors and photojournalists for their work in 1990 at its 52d annual awards dinner last night at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Manhattan.
In keeping with the evening's theme, "The Media and the War," a special President's Award was given to Peter Arnett of the Cable News Network in recognition for lifetime achievements in foreign reporting. 
 The winning awards were presented by Tom Brokaw of NBC News. Ted Turner, the founder of CNN, and Bob Simon, the CBS correspondent who was held by the Iraqis for 40 days, were the featured speakers.
These were the other winners were:
Hal Boyle Award ($1,000, sponsored by American Telephone and Telegraph), for best daily foreign print reporting: Geraldine Brooks and Tony Horwitz, The Wall Street Journal, for the gulf crisis. Citation to Serge Schmemann, The New York Times, for Germany.
Bob Considine Award ($1,000, by King Features Syndicate) for best daily print interpretation of foreign affairs: Michael Dobbs, The Washington Post, for the collapse of the Soviet eEmpire.
Robert Capa Gold Medal (plus $1,000 from Life Magazine) for best photographic reporting or interpretation from abroad requiring exceptional courage or enterprise: Bruce Haley, Black Star, for U.S. News & World Report, for "Burma's Ethnic War."
Olivier Rebbot Award ($1,000 and a plaque from Newsweek) for best photographic reporting from abroad, in magazines and/ or books: Christopher Morris, Black Star, for Time, for "London Poll Tax Riots and Liberian Civil War." Winner for newspapers and/or wire services ($1,000 from Eastman Kodak Professional Photography Division) to Greg Marinovich, The Associated Press, for "A Violent Death in Soweto."
Ben Grauer Award for the best daily spot radio news from abroad: Rich Lamb, WCBS Radio News, New York, for "Rich Lamb in Saudi Arabia."
Lowell Thomas Award ($1,000 from Capital Cities/ABC Inc.) for best radio interpretation or documentary on foreign affairs: Alex Chadwick, National Public Radio, for "Natasha Dudinska: Hope and Courage in Czechoslovakia." '
Winnners for best TV spot news reporting from abroad: Bob Simon, CBS, "Reports from the Frontline," and Brian Ross and Ira Silverman, NBC, for "Nuclear Trigger."
Edward R. Murrow Award ($1,000 from CBS News) for best TV interpretation or documentary on foreign affairs: Ted Koppel and Phyllis McGrady, The Koppel Report/ABC News, for "Death of a Dictator."
Ed Cunningham Award ($500 from the O.P.C. Foundation) for best magazine reporting from abroad: Peter McGrath and team, Newsweek, for the Gulf crisis.
Hallie & Whit Burnett Award for best general magazine story from abroad: Louise Lief, U.S. News & World Report, for "The Most Dangerous Man in the World."
Best Cartoon on Foreign Affairs Award ($500 from the New York Daily News): Mike Peters, Dayton Daily News.
Morton Frank Award ($1,000) for best business and/or economic reporting from abroad in magazines: Fiammetta Rocco, Institutional Investor, for "The Banker in the Bunker." For newspapers and/or wire services ($1,000, sponsored by Forbes), the award for business reporting: James Risen, The Los Angeles Times, for "The Quality Gap: Why Japanese Auto Makers Are Still Winning."
Cornelius Ryan Award for best book on foreign affairs ($1,000 from The Anita Diamant Literary Agency): Tad Szulc chulz for "Then and Now: How the World Has Changed Since World War II (William Morrow & Company).
Madeline Dane Ross Award ($1,000) for the foreign correspondent in any medium showing a concern for the human condition: Tom Jarriel and Janice Tomlin, ABC's 20/20, for "Nobody's Children: The Shame of a Nation."
Eric and Amy Burger Award ($1,000) for the best reporting dealing with human rights: Jon Sawyer, The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, for "After Apartheid."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New York Fed Official Takes No. 2 Job in Boston

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Cathy E. Minehan, the official who has been responsible for the nerve center of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York -- its electronic payments system -- has been appointed first vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, effective July 1. In her new position, she will be the second-highest officer of the Boston bank, in charge of all of its affairs except for helping to formulate monetary policy, a job reserved for the bank's president, Richard F. Syron.
If New York is the crossroads of American financial markets, then the electronic payment system of the New York Fed is clearly the middle of the intersection. Its computers and phone lines are the heart of a system through which New York banks send or receive more than $1 trillion each day in more than 100,000 transactions with other American banks. At the same time, payments are made through the system for another $1 trillion of foreign currency trades. 
 In her 23 years at the New York bank, Mrs. Minehan worked in the budgeting, check processing and planning departments. Since 1987 she has been in charge of the accounting and electronic payments group. That group includes the operation of the "Fed wire," which is used to execute large transactions. Quick, reliable service on the Fed wire is crucial to banks and securities firms, which need to send and receive funds that will be immediately available for spending or investment.
As the Fed has pushed banks in the last few years to change their use of the payments system to avoid overdrafts during the day on their Fed accounts, Mrs. Minehan has emerged as a national expert on the subject. "Banks are now taking steps to control their intraday risk, though the concept still needs refining," she said.
Another matter receiving more attention, she said, is the danger of mechanical failures, especially since a fire last summer cut off power to parts of Manhattan's financial district, including the New York Fed, for several days.
After a burst water-cooling pipe disabled two of its three emergency generators, the New York Fed managed to avoid declaring a bank holiday by shifting its payment system operations to a backup operation in Pearl River, N.Y. Mrs. Minehan said the experience was serious enough to prompt consideration of a third backup system, beyond the emergency generators and the Pearl River operation.
Mrs. Minehan is also hopeful that moves will be made to eliminate, or at least reduce, the physical handling of billions of checks a year. "I was hearing about the coming of the checkless society more than 20 years ago," she said, noting that the Boston Fed now has a pilot program for recording the information on checks by computer and electronically forwarding the information.
Mrs. Minehan and her husband, Gerald, who is in charge of examiners for multinational banks at the New York Fed, plan to relocate to the Boston area.
"We love Montauk, and I expect we will learn to love the Cape," she said. She enjoys downhill skiing, but says she spends much of her free time transporting her 8-year-old son and 11-year-old daughter to soccer matches.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cathy E. Minehan, Federal Reserve Bank of Boston (Antar Studio)

HEADLINE: White House Details Flights by Sununu

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
Under pressure to account for John H. Sununu's use of Government airplanes, the White House today released documents showing that it paid for 49 flights by the chief of staff over the last two years, including four trips to mountain resorts where he made speeches and also went skiing.
But the documents also showed that Mr. Sununu or Republican Party organizations were charged for 28 other trips by Mr. Sununu that were listed as political or personal business. 
 The White House released the documents at President Bush's personal order in an effort to back up its assertions that Mr. Sununu had followed Federal policy on using military airplanes. That policy allows him the use of a military plane so he can be in constant, secure voice contact with the White House, but that payment must be made for all non-official flights at the going commercial rate for a coach-class ticket, plus $1.
 
Criticism on Capitol Hill
 In one case, Mr. Sununu paid $167 for a flight on April 20, 1990, from Key Largo, Fla., where Mr. Bush was staying, to West Palm Beach, to visit Mr. Sununu's parents. The airplane had to be flown from Washington to pick him up. From West Palm Beach, the plane flew him at goverment expense to New York, where he was interviewed by CBS News and spoke at a police breakfast, and then flew him back to Washington. The price tag for the trip, at the rate the Air Force calculates the cost of his airplane: $23,670.
The expense of Mr. Sununu's trips has stirred strong criticism on Capitol Hill and has vexed Mr. Bush because it involves the head of a Presidential staff that is under strict orders to avoid even the suggestion of impropriety.
 
Inquiry Begun by Democrats
 Democratic lawmakers have begun an investigation to review, on economic and security grounds, the practice of having the White House chief of staff and the national security adviser fly on Government planes. From an ethical standpoint, lawmakers want to know whether Mr. Sununu has billed Washington for trips whose official function might be debatable.
"I don't think that anybody inside or outside of the White House can help but be distressed at the use of Government equipment in this fashion," said Representative John Conyers Jr., the Michigan Democrat who heads the House Committee on Government Operations, which asked for the inquiry.
"On the face of it, it raises serious questions of judgment," Mr. Conyers said, citing among other things the trips to ski resorts.
Mr. Sununu's flights have become especially controversial in Washington because they involve a man whose unyielding management techniques and abrasive negotiating style have left him with a stock of ill will and without many willing defenders on the White House staff and on Capitol Hill.
 
The Flights Hit a Nerve
 Nationally, interviews on television in recent days suggest that it has hit a nerve with ordinary travelers who have been forced to deal with delays caused by congestions, travel disruptions from failing airlines and security measures prompted by the Persian Gulf war.
So far, the documents showed that Mr. Sununu has paid $14,391 for non-official flights, including four listed as personal, and tickets for his family on political and official trips. Party organizations have paid $32,653 more and still owe the Federal Government nearly $21,000 for airplane trips in the past six weeks, the documents show.
The documents do not say when the payments were made. Mr. Sununu's office said there had "never been a backlog" and that none of the payments had been made after the articles on his traveling first appeared.
The White House also documented about 45 flights by Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, who has made classified trips that were not listed. The list included missions abroad, trips to brief former Presidents and an official trip to New York for a dinner at which the host was Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State and a former colleague of Mr. Scowcroft.
There was one personal trip, an eight-day skiing vacation in March with his daughter, for which Mr. Scowcroft paid $1,052.
Mr. Scowcroft's office said he was involved in negotiations on the unification of Germany and preparations for a NATO summit at the time and needed to stay in contact with Mr. Bush during his flights.
 
Appearance a Consideration
 The Federal policy, as released today by the White House, says that when officials plan a vacation "for a period of time which makes their immediate return unlikely, the travelers should evaluate the use of military air transportation on the basis of appearance or impropriety."
Mr. Scowcroft's trips have not been at issue, but the White House released a list of them because he is the only other official authorized to use military planes on non-government business.
According to the documents, Mr. Sununu has not paid for any of several trips to his home state of New Hampshire, all of which were billed as official or party business. Most recently, Mr. Sununu flew up on Friday to address the Manchester Republican Party's Robert Frost Award Dinner and spend the weekend, returning to Washington on Monday.
The White House pays for Mr. Sununu's official trips from its travel budget.
At the $3,945 hourly rate that the Air Force assigns to the modified Gulstream jet that Mr. Sununu uses, and figuring flying time of two and a half hours, that trip was worth $9,862. The party organization was billed $519, the going rate for a coach-class ticket on that route.
 
Comparisons Called Distorted
 The White House argued that such comparisons were distorted. Officials said the far larger sum did not actually leave the Federal coffers at that rate since the airplanes are rarely idle; they carry other officials and dignitaries and go on training and maintenance flights.
The documents showed that Mr. Sununu and his wife, Nancy, traveled to Vail, Colo., in December 1989. Mr. Sununu flew at Government expense to address a Ski Magazine conference and The Times-Mirror newspaper organization. He also went skiing.
Last December, he made a similar trip to Aspen and flew to New Hampshire in February 1990 and February 1991 for a fund-raiser at a ski resort for a foundation named for Christa McAuliffe, one of the Challenger crew. Mr. Sununu spoke at both events and went skiing, his office said.
 
Trips to Boston Dentist
 According to the documents, Mr. Sununu went to Boston to visit his dentist twice. His office said they were follow-up visits to continue work started earlier.
Official explanations of the policy on military flights have been contradictory.
At first, the White House said Mr. Sununu and Mr. Scowcroft were required to use military aircraft at all times. On Monday, Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's press secretary, said they were "authorized" to do so.
The documents today include an Aug. 4, 1987, memorandum from then-Secretary of State George P. Shultz to President Ronald Reagan in which he said the national security adviser and chief of staff "should always travel on Air Force planes."
"I agreed with your reaction that they should be told to do it this way and not to be given an option," Mr. Shultz wrote.
Accompanying documents spelling out the policy do not say whether the officials should or must use military aircraft.

LENGTH: 701 words

HEADLINE: Collector Is in Line To Head Modern

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK

 BODY:
Agnes Gund, a collector, art educator and vice president of the Museum of Modern Art, is expected to be named president of the Modern in June, when Donald B. Marron, the current president, steps down after a five-year term.
Museum officials would not confirm reports that Ms. Gund will be elected when the board meets on June 12. "I've heard the rumors," is all Mr. Marron would say. 
 Richard Oldenburg, director of the museum, said, "Obviously, she's a leading possibility, but the election won't be until June, and the trustees will make the decision." A secretary in Ms. Gund's office in New York said she was out of town and could not be reached for comment. But others close to the museum said Ms. Gund was an odds-on favorite for the nonpaying job, one of the most prestigious in the world of cultural volunteerism.
"Sure, she's going to get the job, if the trustees elect her," said Philip Johnson, the architect, who is a longtime trustee of the Modern. "And why shouldn't they? She's done great work at the museum, she has a wonderful eye for art, and she's extraordinarily energetic, strong and able to cope."
 
Financial Ups and Downs
 Whoever takes the post will do so in an era of strong financial gain for the museum, but also of problems. The Modern has not had one of its best years. It will announce a substantial deficit for the fiscal year that ends June 30. In recent months attendance, membership and bookstore sales have dropped, a decline officials attribute to the impact of the recession and the war in the Persian Gulf, which has affected tourism. The museum has also lost $200,000 in state aid. "We are in the same boat as other museums," Mr. Oldenburg said yesterday. "It's a disturbing trend around the country, but particularly true in New York."
But the longer-term picture is encouraging, museum officials say. Under Mr. Marron's stewardship, the endowment has increased significantly, from $26 million in 1985 to $59 million in 1990. The museum's annual fund, supported by donors every year, has also increased from $2.5 milli0n to $3.8 million, contributing to an operating budget of $46 million a year. And the Modern has initiated a chairman's council, under the leadership of David Rockefeller, its chairman, aimed at increasing corporate and personal donations.
Overall, the new president will have the continuing fiscal concerns "of most museums," Mr. Oldenburg said. Another problem is the Modern's urgent need to expand its space for contemporary art, which has had officials considering the possibility of digging under the its famous sculpture garden to provide additional exhibition areas.
Another long-range goal, Mr. Oldenburg said, is the expansion of the museum's audience "in terms of the multi-cultural world around us, through education and other means."
He praised Ms. Gund as "a very important and effective person at the museum" for her "deep commitment to contemporary art, as a major collector and generous donor of works," and for her "belief that museums have a significant role to play in art education." And he added, "She likes and respects artists and enjoys their company and has been very good for the museum as an ambassador and interpreter of that world."
In the art world, Ms. Gund, who is married to Daniel Shapiro, a lawyer, is known not only as a major collector of contemporary art but also as the founder, in 1977, and president of the innovative Studio in a School Association. A nonprofit organization that brings artists into New York City public schools to work with children and teachers, the association has also helped re-establish art programming curtailed in the 1970's by financial strictures.
In 1988, Ms. Gund and the Studio in a School Association won the Governor's Art Award, an honor conferred annually by the Governor of New York on individuals who have made the most significant contributions to the art life of the state.
Ms. Gund, who is 52 years old, was born and raised in Cleveland, where her father was a prominent banker. A brother, Graham Gund, a leading architect in Boston, is also well known as a collector of contemporary art and a patron of the Museum of Fine Arts there.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Aboard the Persian Gulf Bandwagon

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
If their only clue to Senator Barbara A. Mikulski's stand on the use of force in Persian Gulf were the 1992 fund-raising appeal they recently received, thousands of women around the country would be in the dark.
"As I write this letter," the Maryland Democrat said, "Americans are rejoicing that our military men and women have defeated a deadly challenge in the Persian Gulf." 
 Without reference to the way she or 46 colleagues had voted -- against the use of force -- Ms. Mikulski wrote, "Women filled an unprecedented role in facing the military challenge in the Persian Gulf" and now "have a new role in facing economic and social challenges at home."
All the talk about domestic policy notwithstanding, the hot issue on Capitol Hill is still the Persian Gulf. Everyone is indignant at the suggestion that they would use matters of war and peace for political gain. But everyone wants a piece of it.
The posturing began with last month's bidding war on benefits for Persian Gulf veterans. Now the gulf is turning up in fund-raising pitches, in stirring passages in floor speeches and on agendas of obscure subcommittees that normally have nothing to do with military affairs. The House Committee on Government Operations, for instance, has suddenly taken great interest in the export of high-tech equipment to Iraq.
"To have a variety and mix of experts on defense matters suddenly develop all around the Congress is evidence of not just cynical but how even arrogant the process has become," Jerry Lewis of California, the House Republican whip, said Tuesday.
In her letter, Ms. Mikulski used the war as an attention grabber, then moved on to her record on domestic issues and the need for women in Congress. Insisting the Senator was not using the war for political purposes, Mike Morrill, her spokesman, said, "You can't send out a letter immediately following the war and not acknowledge there was a war."
Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee is also making the issue a tool to raise money. His twist is that his vote for the use of force hurt him.
"Now the war is over," he wrote to potential donors. "And the political aftershocks are being felt. The personal cost of my decision has been high. As I write to you this evening, I find myself a political target of those who opposed American involvement in the gulf conflict."
In a recent report, the Democratic Study Group, an organization of liberal Democrats in the House, told lawmakers that many Republicans had "taken partisanship well beyond the water's edge." But it went on to advise Democrats to remind the public that many weapons successfully used in the gulf "had their origins in Democratic Administrations."
Lawmakers do risk running into political danger when they seize on the war issue, as happened with Senator Connie Mack, a Florida Republican. In the aftermath of a fund-raising letter in February that made prominent mention of his support for the war, he was attacked by Republicans at home for exploiting the crisis.
As the afterglow of the war has diminished with reports of starving Kurdish refugees, Democrats have become particularly vocal in attacks on the President Bush's policy in the gulf.
Senator Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, accused the Democrats of pressing the Kurdish issue in "a desperate search for cover for having been on the wrong side of one of the most critical votes of the post-World War II period."
One Democrat who made the rounds on the television talk shows this week, discussing the Kurds, was Representative Tony P. Hall of Ohio, chairman of the Select Committee on Hunger. Mr. Hall, back from visiting Kurdish refugee camp, said he resents Republicans who question his motives.
"It's amazing that they would try to bring a political issue into a situation in which there is a tremendous amount of malnutrition and death occurring, especially among children," Mr. Hall said. If his critics saw what he and others in his bipartisan group saw, he added, "I don't think a political word or phrase would ever come out of their mouth."

HEADLINE: Decline in U.S. Sales Pushes Du Pont Earnings Down 4%

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company reported yesterday that its earnings declined 4 percent in the first quarter. The company said declines in its domestic chemicals-based business more than offset increased earnings from sales of petroleum products.
Net income fell to $590 million, or 88 cents a share, from $615 million, or 90 cents a share. 
 Despite the decline, the Du Pont Company's results exceeded the expectations of analysts, who had been predicting earnings ranging from 75 cents to 85 cents a share. Du Pont stock closed at $41.125 yesterday, up 62.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Petroleum Earnings Rise 63%
 Sales for the period totaled $9.7 billion, an increase of 3 percent from $9.4 billion, largely attributable to petroleum sales by the company's Conoco Inc. subsidiary. Sales in other segments declined 2 percent, the company said, primarily because of a 6 percent drop in sales in the United States.
Edgar S. Woolard Jr., Du Pont's chairman, said the company's diversity prevented "dramatic downswings" in earnings while some segments of the business were depressed. He said the company expects to report increased profits "as the world economies recover."
Earnings attributed to petroleum operations rose 63 percent, to $322 million, as a result of a 15 percent increase in sales and higher prices. Earnings from chemicals declined 39 percent, to $78 million, because of the costs of withdrawing chlorofluorocarbons from the market and developing environmentally safer substitutes.
Fibers earnings declined 49 percent, to $85 million, as a result of charges to close plants and a decline in sales of carpet fibers worldwide. Polymers earnings were down 17 percent, to $68 million, because of what the company termed "the severe slowdown" in the automotive and construction industries in North America.
High inventories at electric utilities and generally warm weather were cited for a 20 percent decline in coal operations, to $48 million.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Keeps Police Hiring While He Cuts Budget More

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that New York City would press ahead with plans to expand the police force and crime prevention programs for youth, even as he called for deeper cuts in other city agencies to cope with worsening city fiscal probems.
"In tough economic times, it is especially important that we recruit and train these grass-roots guardians of public safety so that we can prevent crime, insure the safety of our people and rebuild our community of pride," Mr. Dinkins said in a statement released yesterday. 
 By affirming his commitment to the police, Mr. Dinkins ended a debate in his administration and authorized the Police Department to go ahead with hiring a new class of 2,000 officers who are to report next week.
But his announcement came on the same day that city commissioners were called to City Hall and handed lists of detailed budget cuts prepared by the Mayor's budget office, including thousands of possible layoffs, that go far beyond any cuts disclosed earlier by the administration.
 
2 Frantic Exercises
 The decision to go ahead with the police class came as the Dinkins administration was in the midst of two frantic budget exercises.
It is racing to close an unexpected $465 million gap in the remaining weeks of the current fiscal year, which ends on June 30, through a series of temporary measures, like furloughs and speeded-up state aid payments.
At the same time it is preparing deep spending cuts and seeking concessions from unions as part of a plan to slash city spending next year. The Mayor is to present next year's budget to the City Council on May 10.
Mr. Dinkins has put next year's gap at $3.1 billion and has said the city has developed plans to close two-thirds of it, mainly through tax increases and spending reductions. To make up the difference, the city is seeking another $810 million in cuts in services.
But yesterday City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman predicted that this gap had grown by $500 million, to a total of $3.6 billion. The administration stuck to its gap figures but disclosed that it was seeking far deeper cuts from city agencies.
 
Commissioners Get the Word
 Instead of $800 million in cuts, the administration is developing contingency plans to cut as much as $1.3 billion in city services if it is unable to get concessions from city unions, officials said. These cuts will probably mean less street cleaning, slashes in hospital services, and deeper cuts in libraries and other cultural institutions.
And while in the past city commissioners were asked to draft cuts that were later negotiated with budget officials, this time budget officials, disappointed with the cuts proposed by some commissioners and agencies, drafted the latest round of cuts after little consultation with them.
Like patients at a dentist's office, commissioners and their aides sat on a hard wooden bench in the basement of City Hall before entering the City Hall chapel, where the Mayor's aides and budget officials presented each with a budget-cutting plan. The commissioners were given a chance to return today to raise objections.
 
Commitment to the Police
 The city's worsening fiscal plight was reflected in another critical way in the last few days. Yield, or the effective interest rate earned by investors, rose by two percentage points on short-term city notes in the last few weeks, to 6.5 percent. That occurred just as the city was preparing to sell $1.2 billion in additional notes because of a delay in state aid payments caused by a delay in the adoption of a state budget.
Traders attributed the change, in part, to overall market trends. But at least a percentage point, they said, was due to concern over the city's finances and worry about the state's budget problems.
But despite the worsening news, Mr. Dinkins affirmed his commitment to an expensive plan, financed through property- and income-tax increases, to add 3,500 police officers over the next six years, expanding the criminal justice system and providing funds for services for youth and the elderly.
Under an agreement with the State Legislature, the city promised to continue to expand the police force or risk losing a portion of the tax increase.

HEADLINE: Soviet Excerpts: Accord With the Republics

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a joint statement by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and leaders of nine Soviet republics, issued yesterday and translated by Tass, the Soviet press agency:
The crisis of our society continues to intensify. Society is being torn asunder by social and interethnic conflicts. Production is plummeting. People's living standards decline, posing a threat to the provision of people with basic necessities. Law and order and discipline in the country have been seriously disrupted. Acute problems that have been piling up for decades and painful difficulties of the transitional period and errors made during perestroika have complemented one another. 
 The President of the U.S.S.R. and leaders of top state bodies of the union republics -- the Russian federation, the Ukraine, Byelorussia, Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan, Azerbaijan, Tadzhikistan, Kirghizia and Turkmenia -- upon having discussed the situation in the country at their meeting on April 23, 1991, deemed it necessary to take concerted actions without delay.
Participants in the meeting believe that taking resolute measures to restore the constitutional order everywhere and strict compliance with current laws, pending the adoption of a new union treaty and a constitution of the union, is an indispensable condition to stabilize the situation in the country. . . .
 
A New Treaty
Concluding a new treaty among sovereign tates, with an eye to the results of the recent all-union referendum, is top priority for overcoming the crisis. In this connection participants in the meeting regard the following as necessary:
*To finalize work on a draft new union treaty soon so that an agreed-upon document could be signed by delegations from the above-mentioned republics.
*Not later than six months after the treaty is signed, a new constitution of the U.S.S.R. based on the provisions of the treaty on the union of sovereign states should be prepared and brought up for adoption at a congress of the U.S.S.R. people's deputies.
*Following the adoption of a new constitution, the election of union power bodies, provided for by the treaty and the constitution, should be prepared and held.
*The normal functioning of the power bodies of the union and republics and councils of people's deputies of all levels should be insured throughout the transitional period.
*The top leaders of the union republics taking part in the meeting, while recognizing the right of Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia, Moldavia, Georgia and Armenia to independently decide on the question of accession to the union treaty, at the same time consider it necessary to establish the most-favored-nation treatment for republics signing the union treaty, within the framework of a single economic space formed by them.
 
Limits on Sales Tax
Recognizing that all factors that have a negative effect on the living standards of the population were not taken into account during the reform of retail prices, participants in the meeting consider it necessary to take a number of additional measures for the social protection of citizens, particularly small-incomed ones. The measures are as follows in particular:
*Cancel the 5 percent tax on the sale of goods that are in everyday demand. The U.S.S.R. Cabinet of Ministers and the governments of republics shall determine a list of such goods within a week.
*The U.S.S.R. Cabinet of Ministers and the governments of republics within two weeks shall consider the real prices situation and take coordinated decisions on issues that heighten social tension most of all.
*To take measures to make up for price increases in student dining-rooms and school snack bars and reconsider new tariffs on railway and air transport with an eye to lowering them.
*To make a decision within a month on the indexation of incomes.
With due regard for the above-mentioned agreed-upon decisions, the leaders of the union and republics are calling on miners and all workers to call off strikes from economic and political motives and catch up on production shortfalls soon.
Taking into account the exceptionally acute crisis situation in the country, the leaders of the union and republics regard as intolerable any attempts to attain political ends through incitement to civil disobedience, strikes, or calls for the overthrow of the existing lawfully elected state power bodies.
Participants in the meeting are aware that all these measures to stabilize the situation and overcome the crisis are inconceivable without radical enhancement of the role of union republics.
