HEADLINE: Judge Rejects $100 Million Fine For Exxon in Oil Spill as Too Low

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
A Federal district judge in Alaska today rejected a plea agreement the Exxon Corporation negotiated with the Justice Department in March, saying the $100 million criminal fine in the Exxon Valdez oil spill was too small.
The judge, H. Russel Holland, said his decision was partly in response to growing protests from Alaskans, members of Congress and prominent environmental groups. The ruling jeopardizes the separate $1 billion agreement Exxon reached with the Government and the state of Alaska to settle civil violations of environmental law stemming from the nation's worst oil spill on March 24, 1989. 
 "The fines that were proposed to me were simply not adequate," said Judge Holland. "They do not adequately achieve deterrence. I'm afraid these fines send the wrong message, suggesting that spills are a cost of business that can be absorbed."
He added, "There is no question that the Exxon Valdez oil spill was off the chart."
Exxon has done well recently, announcing today that it made $2.2 billion in the first quarter of the year, its highest quarterly profits since it was founded in 1882. [Business Day, Page C1.]
The judge's action, which cannot be appealed, throws into doubt the $1.1 billion agreement arrived at by the Government, Exxon's chairman, Lawrence G. Rawl, and Gov. Walter J. Hickel of Alaska. Divided into civil and criminal sections, the agreement was the largest ever proposed for an environmental disaster, and second in value only to the $1.25 billion the Government received in 1988 from Texaco Inc. to settle charges that the company set excessive prices for petroleum products in the 1970's.
While judges routinely accept plea bargains, a highly unusual provision of the arrangement was the chance for the public to express its views to Judge Holland as he decided whether to approve the plea agreement on the criminal charges. Judge Holland noted today that the letters he received criticizing the size of the penalty proved persuasive. The fine, he said, did not "adequately punish the defendant for the crime for which guilty pleas are offered."
 
Exxon's Options
 Judge Holland gave the company 30 days to decide whether to withdraw its guilty pleas to four criminal misdemeanor violations of Federal environmental law and face a criminal trial.
A Justice Department lawyer said today that if the company decides not to withdraw its guilty pleas, Judge Holland has the option of issuing a sentence, which could include fines of up to $700 million. The Justice Department also said there was a slim chance that Exxon and the Government would open negotiations to reach another criminal plea agreement.
A provision in the civil settlement allows Exxon to withdraw from that agreement within 10 days if a court rejects the criminal plea. Exxon's executives now must decide whether it wants to abide by the separate $1 billion civil settlement.
Both houses of the Alaska Legislature, whose approval is required for the civil settlement, have already expressed dissatisfaction with many of its main provisions. "The question is how does the Legislature now accept the settlement when a part of it has now been rejected," said Terence O'Malley, a spokesman for a special House committee considering the settlement.
Given the legal, economic and political uncertainties introduced today in the case, Federal lawyers who helped negotiate the settlement and Charles E. Cole, Alaska's Attorney General, said they feared the pact would collapse.
 
'A Lot of "Ifs" Now'
 "We have to await further developments," Mr. Cole said in an interview today. "There are a lot of 'ifs' now. If Exxon terminates the civil settlement, or if the State Legislature disapproves, it's going down the drain."
Negotiated over 57 daysJuneau, the $1.1 billion agreement was novel in almost every respect. The civil agreement called on Exxon to pay $900 million over the next 10 years to reimburse the state and Federal governments for scientific studies of Prince William Sound and to restore shorelines, tidal zones and animals harmed by the 11-million-gallon spill. If additional damage was found after 2001, the agreement also had a clause that required Exxon to pay $100 million more over four years for environmental restoration.
Completed in Washington before midnight on March 12, the pact was hailed the next day by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner, and the Environmental Protection Agency administrator, William K. Reilly. They said the pact was the strongest message ever sent by the Government that pollution violations would be aggressively investigated and prosecuted.
Prominent national environmental groups, including the Sierra Club, the National Audubon Society and the Natural Resources Defense Council, also initially praised the agreement.
 
Rawl's Damaging Remarks
 But hours later, in a separate news conference at Exxon's headquarters in Irving, Tex., Mr. Rawl announced that the $1 billion settlement and the $100 million fine would "not have a significant effect on our earnings." Mr. Rawl expressed little regret over the spill, and said in the two years he had had to deal with the effects of the oil spill, his most painful moments were usually caused by bad publicity.
"Mr. Rawl's comments were incredibly arrogant," said Hope Babcock, the general counsel of the National Audubon Society. "In setting a tone for the company, he completely failed to acknowledge any culpability or responsibility for the damage that occurred. There was a total lack of remorse for what happened and that is a basic tenet of the criminal justice system."
Pressure to undo the agreement increased earlier this month when the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration released a summary of 58 scientific studies conducted in Prince William Sound that showed the spill took a much greater toll on wildlife, shorelines, tidal zones and the valuable herring and salmon fisheries than previously suspected. Hundreds of thousands of birds died after the spill, thousands of otters drowned in the oil, and fish fry exhibited abnormally high rates of birth defects.
The new data upset many Alaskans, who became even more angry when they learned that the complete scientific studies, paid for by Federal and state taxpayers, would remain secret, along with studies of the value of the damage. In interviews, the economists who conducted the studies say the spill caused $3 billion to $5 billion in damage to Prince William Sound. Public hearings earlier this month in villages around the sound attracted hundreds of opponents.
In the last 10 days, disatisfaction with the agreement spread out of those villages, reaching Anchorage, Juneau, Washington and New York. In 1989, the Exxon Valdez spill came to represent more than a terrible soiling of the water, becoming a lasting and transcendant symbol of environmental destruction. Many Alaskans believed the penalties for Exxon should achieve a similar symbolism, sending a powerful message to all who cause ecological harm.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Wang Loss at $48.9 Million

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LOWELL, Mass. April 24

 BODY:
Wang Laboratories Inc. said today that it had lost $48.9 million in its third fiscal quarter. The computer company blamed the sluggish economy for hindering efforts to turn around its finances.
The results for the three-month period ended March 31 compared with a loss of $146.6 million in the quarter a year earlier. 
 Revenue for the period was down significantly to $499.7 million, compared with $593.5 million during the quarter a year earlier.
Wang, which has been hurt by a computer market downturn that has hit other companies as well, has been struggling to rebound for more than a year.
Wang's chairman, Richard W. Miller, said that while his company was able to report a $2.6 million profit in its first fiscal quarter, "economic and industry conditions have slowed the momentum which the company had achieved through its turnaround programs."
While Wang has introduced products and strategies to generate new revenue, these sales have been outpaced by drops in the company's traditional businesses, Mr. Miller said.
Despite the losses, Mr. Miller said, Wang was in its strongest cash position in 18 months. In the most recent quarter, Wang had $194.1 million in cash or cash equivalents.
Wang, which has laid off thousands of workers in recent years, said it was considering further steps to control costs but declined to say whether more layoffs might be needed.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Report Forecasts 3% Growth

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund predicted today that the world's economies would rebound briskly in 1992 after weak growth this year -- but the rebound might never materialize if the United States recession fails to end soon.
The I.M.F., in its semiannual outlook report, said worldwide economic growth was likely to slow to an average of 1.2 percent in 1991 -- barely enough to avoid recession -- from 2.1 percent last year. But the fund predicted an average growth rate of nearly 3 percent next year, mainly on the strength of recoveries in the United States, Britain and Canada. All are now in recession. 
 "If the United States recession lasts longer than we anticipate, then, yes, the whole world will be adversely affected," Ernesto Hernandez-Cata, director of the outlook report, said at a news conference. "But I think the recession will be a short one. You can say you heard that here."
The fund attributed the 1991 slowdown, involving virtually every region of the world, to disruptions resulting from the Persian Gulf crisis, the North American and British recessions and sharply falling output in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
 
Recovery Expected Soon
 Economic growth in the United States will average only two-tenths of 1 percent this year, down from 1 percent last year, the fund estimated. But with a recovery starting this summer, the nation's gross national product, covering all of the goods and services produced each year, would rise to an average of 2.7 percent in 1992 -- a forecast roughly in line with the Bush Administration's projections and those of many private forecasters.
Indeed, as the basis for its optimism about the United States, the monetary fund cited many of the reasons that American economists have put forward to support a widely held view that the recession will end by this fall, roughly a year after it began. Interest rates have fallen sharply in recent months, encouraging consumers to borrow and spend again, and inflation is easing, the fund said.
Fund officials also noted that inventories in the United States are low, which means that production to restock shelves can resume almost as soon as consumers step up their buying. American exports, key to a recovery from the recession, are also likely to remain strong, the fund said, even though the economies of two major importers of American goods, Japan and Germany, are weakening a bit.
American exports fell in March, partly because of weakening overseas economies. "There is a slump in Europe," Mr. Hernandez-Cata acknowledged. "But these countries are still strong enough to absorb enough American exports."
 
Endorsement of Fed Policy
 Expecting an upturn, the Federal Reserve Board has become reluctant in recent weeks to continue pushing down interest rates as a means of stimulating the economy and insuring the expected upturn. Jacob Frenkel, the I.M.F.'s research director, in effect, endorsed the American central bank's monetary policy.
"This is not the time for an activist monetary policy," Mr. Frenkel said. He said the Fed should take its cue from the marketplace. If rates fall naturally because the American economy weakens unexpectedly or inflation becomes less and less of a problem, "then the Fed should not resist also lowering rates," he said.
The report said the currencies of the United States, Germany and Japan were roughly in the proper alignment. The report suggested that none of the three should alter interest rates to change the value of their curriences. "The dollar has recovered markedly since February, and this has alleviated concerns about the weakness of the dollar," the report said.
The report also included these major points:
*World trade will shrink this year because of the economic slowdown, and rebound strongly next year. The United States' share of total world output has declined, partly as a result of the recession, "while the shares of Japan, West Germany and the newly industrialized countries of Asia, where growth remains robust, have increased."
*The shifting growth rates are expected to reduce the United States trade deficit and also the trade surpluses in Germany and Japan -- in effect, narrowing the differences among these countries, not only in trade but also in their current accounts, which cover all international transactions, including trade.
*Oil prices, which averaged $16 a barrel last July, before the Persian Gulf crisis, and rose to as much as $40 a barrel in September, will average just over $17 a barrel in 1991, eliminating a source of inflation.
*Foreign debt among all of the developing countries rose by 6 percent in 1990, to a total of $1.3 trillion, and is likely to rise again this year and next, in every region of the world except, perhaps, the Western Hemisphere.
With Germany, Eastern Europe, and the Mideast drawing capital to rebuild, the developing world might have difficulty getting loans.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
$90.1 Million Loss Posted By Goodyear

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, battered by intense price competition and deteriorating demand from auto makers, yesterday reported a first-quarter loss of $90.1 million. The company attributed the results to the downturn in the economy, special charges against earnings for costs associated with the layoffs of employees and the decision to abandon plans to establish a plant in South Korea.
In the first quarter of last year, the company reported net income of $20.9 million, or 36 cents a share. Sales for the quarter were down 7.3 percent, to $2.5 billion, from $2.73 billion in the quarter a year earlier. The results from the first quarter of this year include $65 million in pretax charges related to the furloughing of employees and the decision to discontinue efforts to establish a South Korea tire factory. 
 On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Goodyear shares were up 50 cents, closing at $21.50.
In March, Goodyear announced that it was eliminating 1,100 salaried jobs by the summer of next year. The giant tire company also announced at the time that it would take a pretax charge against earnings. Goodyear, which is based in Akron, Ohio, has eliminated thousands of salaried and hourly positions in the last two years, slashing its work force by about 9 percent in that period.
Like other major international tire companies, Goodyear has been bruised by a number of difficulties, including intense price competition, a sluggish automobile market and narrow margins. Goodyear has also suffered from operating an unprofitable 1,750-mile crude oil pipeline between California and Texas, which it bought in 1985 as a way to diversify. Although the pipeline is designed to carry more than 400,000 barrels of oil a day, it is now handling only about 100,000 barrels, a result of low customer demand.
In the tires and related segment of Goodyear, operating income for the first quarter fell to $62.8 million, from $129.9 million in the period a year earlier. The company attributed the decline to $46.9 million in unusual charges. The company said sales in that segment fell 5.7 percent, to $2 billion.
Goodyear said that, on a unit basis, global sales declined 7.5 percent. The company said the decline was primarily a result of sluggish demand in the United States from automobile makers and a soft market for replacement tires.
The company reported an operating loss of $25.1 million in its oil transportation segment, which includes the pipeline. That compares with an operating loss of $14.6 million in the first quarter of 1990. "Oil purchase costs exceeded oil sales and pipeline tariff revenues, resulting in negative sales," the company said.
Harry W. Millis, an independent tire analyst based in Cleveland, said that if all the non-recurring items were excluded "the company would only have had a $5 million loss. That tells me that the actual operating numbers were better than the reported numbers and that we should be looking at black ink, based on seasonal factors, in the second quarter." Mr. Millis said he expects second-quarter earnings to reach about $20 million.
Tom H. Barrett, Goodyear's chairman and chief executive, said the company is focusing its attention "on quality, service, cost reduction and other fundamentals so that it will come out of this recession a stronger company."

HEADLINE: Chores? Strike Gives Celebrities an Opening

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
Barbara Taylor Bradford, who writes best-selling romance novels, is storing empty bottles and cans in a spare bathtub of her luxurious apartment on the East Side of Manhattan. They do add up, especially the cans of dog food for her bichon frise, who eats a special brand of diet food suggested by the veterinarian. "I don't know if you know the bichon frise," she said, "but they are prone to gain weight."
Eventually, Mrs. Taylor and her housekeeper will drag the bottles and cans to the street, a task normally done by striking building-service workers. But, like many privileged New Yorkers who are doing some of their own dirty work during the walkout, she makes light of the inconvenience. "I've lived through worse things," she said, "being English." 
 In an era when the rich seem to understand that they could be poor tomorrow, or perhaps in talks with bankers, there is a great deal of sympathy for the striking workers. Like everybody else, many prominent New Yorkers who live in the affected buildings are standing guard in their lobbies, running elevators and carrying garbage even as they talk about the workers' rights to have better salaries. For now, less than a week into the strike, their new burdens still seem like fun.
"It's early," said Jonathan Hadary, the co-star of "Gypsy." "Hopefully, it won't go on long." Late yesterday afternoon, he was planning to deliver mail to everyone else on his floor, a task that now falls to the first person who arrives home. "I should be in a longer show, I guess," he said. Many buildings have already decided to maintain security by keeping out people who don't absolutely need to get in. Like decorators. Like contractors. Like partygoers.
Mario Buatta, a decorator who has many rich clients, said the disappearance of doormen was creating a work stoppage in his field. "I spoke to an architect who is spending his time in the library," he said.
Tim Zagat, publisher of guides to restaurants and hotels, said no parties are allowed in his building on Central Park West for the duration of the strike. But slightly to the west, David Halberstam, the writer, was expecting 150 people to descend on his home last night for a party in honor of Alex Kotlowitz, author of the new book, "There Are No Children Here."
Mr. Halberstam, who ran the elevator in his building for two hours yesterday after noon, admitted that the volunteer who was scheduled for night duty would have quite a bit of work. But the 40 people who live in his West Side cooperative had not yet complained about doing their share, he said. There were, however, some suggestions that their compatriots be summoned back to town to do their duty. "Jonas Salk has an apartment here," said Mr. Halberstam, "but he's in San Diego."
 
More Familiar Than Neighbors
 While there is much joking about playing doorman and sorting garbage, there is also sadness for workers who are out on strike in a bad economy. Alexander H. Cohen, the theatrical producer, was planning to picket yesterday for two hours with the workers and then zip back into his building to run the elvator from 6 P.M. to 8 P.M., prime time in any building as the occupants come home.
Mr. Cohen, who lives on the West Side, said the small wage increase offered to the workers was "inhumane." After 25 years in the same building he said, the doormen he sees several times a day are more familiar to him than most of his neighbors. Unfortunately, he said, they should be doormen in fake life, not the real world. "I pay $2,800 for three days to be an elevator man in a movie for TV," he said.
In many buildings, residents volunteer to spend time in the lobby, checking visitors to make sure they are legitimate. Peter Jennings, the ABC anchor, has been doing his share of sitting in the lobby of his West Side building.
 
'I'll Bet They Would Help'
 So has Faith Stewart-Gordon, owner of the Russian Tea Room. "It's kind of a friendly atmosphere," she said. "Everyone is chatting away." In her East Side building, she said, the residents seem very sympathetic to the strikers. "Everybody is so concerned about New York right now, we would like not to have any more ill feeling. We would like to look forward, rather than be divisive." Although she has done a turn in the lobby, her shift yesterday was being taken by her housekeeper, Patricia Fredes, while she worked. "A lot of people are doing that," she said.
Richard Heffner, producer and moderator of "The Open Mind," an interview show on public television, said he has signed up, with his wife, for the 10 P.M. to midnight session this Friday, before the temporary security guard arrives to protect the building.
Asked what he would do if a mean-looking person showed up, he seemed surprised by the question. "What are you trying to do, scare me?" In an emergency, Mr. Heffner said, he would probably turn to the picketing workers. "I'll bet they would help," he said.
Not all doormen in the city are on strike. Wendy Wasserstein, the playwright, said the workers in her building at 1 Fifth Avenue are not on strike, although she was not sure how she would know if they decided to have a stoppage. Doormen in downtown buildings are not always as rigid in their ways as their uptown counterparts. "They're always giving me my dry cleaning as I'm leaving," she said.
In some residential buildings, employees have already settled with management. Sylvia Miles, the actress, said the owners of her building on Central Park South had signed an agreement with the workers, apparently fearing that if services declined, they would have to refund rent money. But some preparations for a strike were made. "I was going to do the mail," she said. "Thank god I didn't. I would have had to wear my glasses."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alexander H. Cohen, right, the theatrical producer, joined striking workers yesterday on the picket line outside his apartment building at 25 West 54th Street. He spoke with Alex Walkowich, an elevator operator at the building, behind a pile of trash. (Najlah Feanny for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 3-Star Comment on 'Fast Track' Plan

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
Congressional committee hearings on important issues often star a Cabinet official. But a chorus of three Cabinet members turned up for today's hearing by the House Agriculture Committee on the Administration's authority to negotiate trade pacts.
Secretary of Agriculture Edward R. Madigan, Labor Secretary Lynn M. Martin and the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, sat shoulder to shoulder for more than two hours this morning, defending the Administration's position in an unexpectedly bitter domestic dispute over international trade policy. 
 The Bush Administration wants the authority to negotiate two international trade agreements over the next two years and submit each one to a special Congressional ratification process in which no amendments would be allowed.
 
Some Opposition
 While one of the two, a proposed pact to liberalize world trade, has drawn little opposition, organized labor and environmental groups have fought granting the so-called fast-track authority for the other agreement, a free-trade pact with Mexico.
The Administration has had trouble responding to critics because it has not yet negotiated an agreement with Mexico and so cannot point to specific clauses intended to allay American concerns. "Quite honestly, we are handicapped in quieting the fears raised," Mrs. Hills said yesterday.
She said the United States could not obtain good trade agreements without the ability to guarantee that Congress would not undo a trade pact by adding many amendments. "No negotiating partner will give its bottom line knowing the bargaining can be reopened," she added.
Opponents of fast-track authority have put the Administration on the defensive by suggesting that American companies will move factories and jobs to Mexico to take advantage of lax enforcement there of worker safety and environmental laws. Some of the testimony in support of this argument has been lurid.
A Mexican woman testified before a Senate panel on Tuesday that her son was killed last autumn when his head, throat and right arm were destroyed by a mechanical grinder in an American-owned windshield factory in Ciudad Juarez. The factory did not provide safety training or equipment, she said.
A free-trade agreement with Mexico would allow multinational companies in the United States to move their factories south and "pay their laborers slave-labor wages," said Representative John J. LaFalce, Democrat of upstate New York. He favored the free-trade agreement with Canada that went into effect at the start of 1989 but now opposes fast-track authority for a pact with Mexico because the two economies are so dissimilar and because it involves the surrender by Congress of considerable influence to the Administration over the final shape of the agreement.
Under an unusual legislative mechanism created by Congress, the Administration's fast-track authority is renewed automatically unless either house passes a resolution of disapproval by June 1. A simple majority is needed for passage.
 
Growing Support for Cancellation
 "If the vote were taken today, I suspect you would not get disapproval," Rep. LaFalce said. But testimony in recent weeks has produced growing support for canceling the fast-track authority, he added.
The Administration and many economists insist that the best way to improve conditions in Mexico is through the prosperity that a free-trade agreement could bring. And Mrs. Martin testified that wages, employment and economic output in the United States would rise slightly if a free-trade pact could be reached.
When two congressmen said most of the auto-parts and food-processing factories in their districts had moved to Mexico, Mrs. Hills replied that this demonstrated that businesses most suited to operating there have already moved, regardless of any free-trade agreement.

HEADLINE: Cabbies Come Out Swinging as Riders Get Scarce

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
When New York boomed in the 80's, getting a taxicab was a fight. Now it is the taxi drivers who are fighting -- and swerving and speeding and crashing -- to get ever-scarcer fares.
While hardly models of decorum in the best of times, cabdrivers are responding to the increased economic pressure with an increase in reckless driving and violent confrontations between cabbies, say taxi officials, passengers and the drivers themselves. 
On the other hand, judging at least by the complaints filed, the drivers seem to be nicer to passengers. And it is easier to get a cab.
Sometimes dangerously easy, as when a man wearing a dark business suit stepped from the curb at 81st Street and Columbus Avenue to flag down a taxi last week. Two yellow cabs immediately raced toward him, narrowly avoiding a collision before screeching to a halt.
As the drivers honked their horns and hurled obscenities, arguing over who had reached the man first and thus whose customer he was, the man, looking bewildered, jumped into a third cab whose driver had stopped to watch the melee.
 
Aggressive Driving Reported
 "You can be killed just getting a cab in this town," the man said as the cab he chose sped away.
Since 1987, when the stock market plunged, the number of customers complaining that taxi drivers are speeding, running red lights and violating other traffic rules has been steadily increasing, according to the Taxi and Limousine Commission, which licenses the industry's 40,000 drivers. At the same time, the total number of complaints against drivers, including verbal abuse, cheating and poor vehicle conditions, has been dropping, the commission says. While the commission's figures trace these twin trends over at least the last four years, industry and commission officials and drivers said it was their impression that in the last few months accidents had increased.
 
Some Rides Hard to Get
 Despite the hard times, it still can be tough to get a ride to Brooklyn, or for some non-white riders to catch a ride.
The taxi commission still receives a substantial number of complaints from passengers who say that some drivers refuse to stop for them or to take them to destinations in Brooklyn, upper Manhat tan, Queens and the Bronx.
Ronald Stoppelman, president of the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade, which represents the owners of 2,500 medallion taxis, said the board had received a flood of complaints from drivers who say they are not making enough money because of the recession.
"When there is less money out there, drivers have shorter tempers and naturally are more aggressive in going after fares," Mr. Stoppelman said.
Healy Teppin, a taxi dispatcher at Grand Central Terminal, said that in recent weeks he had seen at least 10 fights between drivers over fares. Three involved collisions between drivers vying to pick up passengers who went out to the street to hail a cab because they did not want to wait in line.
 
'So Few Customers'
 "It's like a jungle out there, because there are so few customers during most of the day and night," Mr. Teppin said. "But it really gets crazy about 5 P.M., when a lot of people are coming from the train station, looking for cabs. I would advise people not to go out to the street to get a cab. The safest way is to wait on line."
Rebecca Bowser, a spokeswoman for the Taxi and Limousine Commission, said that while she had no way of knowing if cabbies were driving unsafely, the commission had received reports in recent weeks from fleet owners and passengers that drivers were "more anxious" to get fares.
And while there are no official statistics on taxi ridership or revenues, dozens of fleet owners, drivers and taxi regulators said they had seen a decline in fares in the last two years.
The price of a taxi medallion has dropped to $125,000 from a record high of $144,000 in 1989, in part because of the economy but mainly because new regulations require new medallion owners to drive their own cabs.
Munwer Sayer, 40, who has been driving his own taxi for seven years, said that business had never been worse. "We are having to work so hard just to make ends meet that drivers have a very short fuse these days," Mr. Sayer said. "I saw a driver pull out a baseball bat the other day and threaten to hit another driver because he had cut him off."
Mr. Sayer said business was so slow that he now worked 16 hours a day instead of the 10 he put in a year ago to make the $200 he needs to cover costs and earn a decent profit. He said he paid $2,000 a month in mortgage fees for his medallion, $150 a month for gas, $300 a month for insurance and other costs.
"This is a tough business where drivers have to work very hard for every penny," said Mr. Stoppelman, who also owns a fleet of taxis, "It's not like they get a fixed paycheck every week. They get what they earn on the street."
Taxi drivers say that a 12 percent fare increase last year had been more than offset by increases in leasing rates and motor-vehicle taxes at a time when the economy is slow and fewer people are going out to restuarants and nightclubs.
As a result, Mr. Stoppleman estimates that for the last nine months, at least 20 percent of the 11,787 medallion cabs in the city have been idle at night because owners cannot find drivers to lease them.
"You just can't make enough at night because New York City's night life has all but died, and the taxi business is going with it," said Fared Dawat, who has been driving a fleet cab for 10 years. "During the 1980's you could always find a fare at the nightclubs and discos, but no one's going out anymore."
But Frank Mercado, a 28-year-old television producer, said he often was unable to get a cab late at night to take him from midtown Manhattan to his home in Harlem. Last Saturday, for instance, he tried. "I was dressed very nicely in a suit," he said, "but the driver said to me: 'I'm not going there. Period.' I had to get out in the pouring rain and look for another cab."
The number of complaints to the taxi commission that drivers refused to pick up some customers or take them to their destination increased to 1,467 in 1990 from 1,396 in 1989. Ms. Bowser, the commission spokeswoman, said most customers who were turned down were of darker skin color or wanted to go to places in northern Manhattan or the other boroughs.
But Mr. Stoppelman of the taxi trade board said: "Reality dictates that the driver's safety comes first, and nothing is worth a driver's life, even if it means passing up fares in these hard economic times.'
He called on the taxi commission to increase fares. Ms. Bowser, the taxi commission's spokeswoman, said the agency planned to conduct a fare review this summer to determine whether the driver's increased costs and decrease in revenue warranted a fare rise.

HEADLINE: For Remodelers, The Time Is Now

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
IF there is a silver lining in the recession and the sluggishness of the real-estate market in the Northeast, it may be that this is the moment to do long-postponed renovations. A buyer's market for houses is also a buyer's market for contractors who do remodeling jobs.
"It's the time to do something," said Linda Case, who heads Remodeling Consulting Services of Silver Spring, Md. 
 For one thing, prices have plummeted as contractors struggle to find something, anything, to see them through the recession.
"More contractors are sharpening their pencils and giving much better prices and much better value than in previous years," said Sandy Haft, the executive director of the chapter of the National Association of the Remodeling Industry that covers New York City and Long Island.
Douglas Peix, a Manhattan architect, said prices were 30 percent less than they were 18 months ago, and Richard Baronio, a Manhattan contractor, said supply houses had cut prices for lumber and hardware at least 20 percent. "And most labor has dropped, I would say, 25 percent," he said. "Maybe more."
Nationally, the recession's hit on the remodeling business has been erratic. Ms. Case said the East Coast had been hardest hit, the West Coast somewhat less affected and the Midwest virtually unscathed. In the New York area, architects say the drop in prices reflects the cautious mood of owners who no longer feel they can afford the ambitious, top-to-bottom home-improvement projects that were a kind of ritual in the 1980's.
"The thing that's hit remodeling is the fact that people's confidence in their house value is shaken," Ms. Case said. "In my memory, that's not been a factor before. We've lived with ever-rising house values, getting more and more valuable. That meant investing in remodeling allowed you to enjoy it and receive further return when you sold it."
Homeowners are doing only "the essential stuff," said Alan Lindenfeld, a Manhattan architect. "If it's a matter of doing a large project or just certain essential things, they'll do the essentials and say they'll do the rest next year," he said.
But contractors and trade associations say consumers can benefit from the lower prices and contractors' eagerness to keep work crews busy. Mr. Haft of the remodeling association said business had dropped 30 percent in the last two years.
"If you are in just the repair-replacement line, such as roofing, your business probably didn't suffer as much as contractors geared toward the upscale master bath and kitchen renovation work," said Alan J. Campbell, the executive director of the remodeling association. "Those were the types of purchasing decisions consumers could put off much more easily than repairing a leaky roof."
How different the remodeling business is from a couple of years ago, when people moving into new quarters were happy to pay the going rate and their only hope was that they could find a contractor who would complete the job and do it well. Now homeowners are no longer swapping stories of jobs abandoned in a shower of plaster dust by a contractor who left for more lucrative work. Instead, the talk is of contractors fighting to give the lowest bid and the earliest completion date.
But there are concerns that some homeowners are hiring unlicensed or unreputable contractors whose work will not measure up to building codes or fire laws. Customers should hire only licensed contractors and should not pay too much of their projected remodeling bills in advance, said a spokeswoman for the New York City Consumer Affairs Department, Linda Sachs.
 "It's hard to tell what the psychology is out there," said Vahe Tiryakian, a spokesman for the New York City Department of Buildings, which issues permits for renovations. "I personally would hazard the guess that smaller jobs are now coming to the fore."
Mr. Peix said he had estimated that a renovation in a three-bedroom apartment in Greenwich Village would cost $210,000, but the bids came in at $150,000. The job involved redoing three bathrooms, gutting the kitchen and taking down the walls between the living and dining room.
Mr. Baronio told of a job in an apartment on Fifth Avenue at East 67th Street. "Had this been three years ago, it would have been $130,000," Mr. Baronio said. "In light of everything that's happened since then, I cut the price and came in around $100,000. Somebody else got the job for about $85,000."
Another of Mr. Peix's clients wanted to expand a Cape Cod-style house in West Islip, L.I. Mr. Peix sought five bids and accepted one for $160,000, $40,000 less than he had expected.
"It took this man 45 minutes to get there," Mr. Peix said. "That's a sign of the times, that he'd go that far." In the boom years of the 1980's, Mr. Peix said, contractors did not have to venture far from home base to find work.
The National Association of the Remodeling Industry estimated that consumer spending on renovation projects across the nation increased 10 to 15 percent a year in the 1980's. In New York City, Buildings Department officials say the value of renovation work declined from 1989 to 1990, and they expect the downward trend to continue in 1991.
Although the dollars spent on renovations are no longer increasing, the number of contractors seeking work is. The remodeling association attributes this to the slowdown that began with the stock market collapse in 1987. The New York City consumer affairs agency says it has granted 1,182 new licenses for contractors in the last year; on Long Island, Nassau County has 2,000 more contractors than a year ago and Suffolk 750.
Some are new-home builders who are trying their hands at remodeling because the recession put a dent in their primary line of work. Some contractors have been trying to drum up business by knocking on doors they would like to replace. A contractor in Maryland pulled out old estimates and called the prospective customers to see if the projects had a chance. That approach landed a $28,000 job that had been put on hold.
And sometimes no one gets the job. Mr. Baronio told of one nonprofit organization that was considering renovating the director's offices.
"They started with a budget of about $50,000," he said. "After several months of negotiations and back and forth, trying to figure out what they wanted to do, they call me to say their stocks had not performed as well as they had hoped, and they had $10,000 to spend, and what could we do for that. In the end, we did about $7,000 worth of work."
When business began to soften, Mr. Baronio said, most contractors hoped they could survive with the same prices they had charged in the 80's.
"As things continued to weaken," he said, "they slowly came around to the realization that they would have to charge less and cut down on whatever expenses they had."
The downward trend accelerated, many contractors said, in the weeks before the Persian Gulf war.
"I had clients with children who were verging on draftable ages," Mr. Peix said, "and they couldn't focus on improving the quality of the space they lived in. People are still a bit skittish, but they're beginning to talk more seriously."

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
Preventive Medicine

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
In the beginning, Sister Barbara Moran felt a little as if she'd been hit over the head with a board. She had the cubbies ready, the tiny tables and chairs, the cots for naptime, all the miniaturized impedimenta of the preschool. And then the children came.
Some of them had never owned a toy. 
 Some of them had never held a book.
Some of them had never sat at a table, or used a fork.
"I was thinking about reading stories," said Sister Barbara, looking back, "and we were dealing with kids who were not even socialized. They had been born and raised in welfare hotels where there were no tables and chairs. They had eaten all their meals with their hands. They had the quickest hands you've ever seen."
If you want to make a case for the importance of early childhood intervention in the lives of poor children, you can make it here, at The Nurturing Place. The staff graduated their first class last year, four kindergarteners who went out the door and into the public schools. All are doing well. Two made the honor roll.
The children who first arrived here 18 months ago, 2-year-olds with virtually no language, who hit and kicked and spit at anyone who tried to touch them, now introduce themselves to a visitor and try to palm off their lunchtime spinach. "It's a vegetable," says one little girl. A 5-year-old shows off by painstakingly printing his name. When he finishes the procession of tiddly letters, he looks up. How did I do? his eyes ask.
Some of the children here were lifelong residents of the hotels where the homeless were warehoused. Some had homes but lost them, and wound up with their mothers in the transitional housing at St. Joseph's Home. Some are the children of students at Kenmare, a high school for female dropouts. The home, the school and the child development center make up the York Street Project.
We are deeply dissatisfied with many of our social programs, if for no other reason than that they do not work. Education, welfare, crime have all come to seem like bottomless pits. Beneath them all is the dark sea of poverty.
There are lots of good programs that work with social ills, but at The Nurturing Place you see preventive medicine. The landmark study in this area was done in Michigan by the High/Scope Educational Research Foundation in 1984, and its results are staggering. It followed the progress of poor children who had been enrolled in a good early childhood education program at age 3. The dropout, teen-age pregnancy, arrest, unemployment and welfare statistics -- all were substantially lower for 20-year-olds who had been in the program.
Today a panel of experts is meeting to consider recommendations to the National Education Goals Panel, created after the 1989 Presidential education conference to chart the future of this country's kids. They will hear an updated High/Scope report that concludes: "Because we do not now spend enough tax dollars to provide all poor children with good early childhood programs, we wind up spending three times as much as the programs would have cost on largely ineffective responses to school failure, crime and unemployment."
There's been some debate about preschool programs, about the question of robbing children of childhood. That's an academic question at The Nurturing Place, where most of the children experience childhood for the first time. The biggest problem in the beginning was that the staff insisted on hugging and cuddling them. The mothers didn't like it. "My kids have to go back on those streets and survive," they would say. "They have to be tough." The kids in question were under the age of 4.
For some of these children, this all may be an oasis in a desert of a life. A few of the kids at The Nurturing Place have already disappeared into the nomadic migration of the urban poor, from shelter to shelter, from city to city. For a few months they began to blossom, to know Curious George, Big Bird and the feelings of security and stimulation. Then it was gone. Others are flowering still. "So smart, some of them," said Sister Barbara. "If we didn't have this, society would lose out on their talents." The High/Scope report says this is high yield for the taxpayers. And I believe it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Not the Best Census Ever

 BODY:
An embarrassed Commerce Department at last admits that far from "the best census ever," its 1990 enumeration missed more Americans than the 1980 census did. It's the first time in recent memory that a national headcount has been shoddier than its predecessor.
Instead of a nation of 249 million people, the department concedes after a follow-up survey, we number somewhere between 253 and 255 million. A uniform undercount involving all population groups would pose no special problem, but out of as many as six million uncounted, more than half are black or Hispanic Americans. They live in crowded cities, many refusing to cooperate out of poverty, ignorance or distrust. Whatever the reason, the failed census is an outrageous theft of power and economic benefits from those pockets of undercount. 
 That pledge of best ever was a weak answer to large cities and states demanding adjustment to the tally using the best statistical methods. The Bush Administration, still resistant, has until mid-July to decide whether an adjustment is feasible.
The decision, though technical, ought to begin with a sense of injustice. The miscount drains political strength and billions in population-based Federal benefits from the populous areas where uncounted poor people live. It robs states like New York, which already stands to lose seats in Congress, and California, the big population gainer for the decade. It stands to deprive the great cities of their fair representation in state legislatures.
The Commerce Department shows no sign of being moved by this injustice, but it frets openly about a cure. Officials wonder whether their survey data are accurate enough to apply at the local level across the land. The technical questions are not frivolous, but even if they can be solved, the department vows to cling to the miscount unless the adjustment is easy to explain and not politically disruptive.
That puts special pressure on Robert Mosbacher, the Secretary of Commerce, to allow some adjustment or come up with a very good explanation for not doing so. His position is especially delicate because he is expected to resume Republican fund-raising for the 1992 Bush re-election campaign, and census adjustment is an issue pressed primarily by Democrats.
So few states would gain or lose a House seat that the feared political disruption could be minimal. Meanwhile Congress can pass a law requiring an adjustment or at least disengage some categorical benefit programs from slavish reliance on an unadjusted, undercounted census.

HEADLINE: Don't Jump the Fast Track

BYLINE: By Lloyd Bentsen ;Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It seems inconceivable that the U.S. would deny itself the ability to negotiate the elimination of barriers to foreign trade. But that will happen if Congress derails the "fast track" authority for conducting trade negotiations.
Since 1974, fast-track procedures have been an effective mechanism for approving trade agreements. They require the President to consult with Congress during trade negotiations and Congress to accept or reject the agreement, with no amendments, when it is submitted for approval. 
 Why the fast track? We don't want a rerun of the problems of the 1960's. After Congress in 1968 rejected parts of an agreement reached in the so-called Kennedy Round of trade negotiations, our trading partners refused to come to the table until assured that any deal the President struck would be approved or disapproved by Congress, not amended unilaterally. For six years, progress in eliminating foreign trade barriers ground to a halt.
The immediate issue is whether we will disarm our negotiators at a crucial time. (The fast-track procedures will be automatically extended for two years unless the House or Senate votes by June 1 to discontinue them.) Killing this authority would doom the current Uruguay Round negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Today, GATT covers no more than one-third of world trade. The European Community spends more than $12 billion on agricultural export subsidies annually; international counterfeiters copy U.S. inventions with impunity; U.S. products face 100 percent tariffs in some foreign markets. These barriers might be eliminated or reduced in the Uruguay Round, but not if fast-track authority is revoked.
Eliminating the fast track would also prevent us from seizing the opportunity to reach a free-trade agreement with Mexico. Since 1986, Mexico has lowered its maximum tariffs from 100 percent to 20 percent, and scores of other restrictions have been lifted. As a result, our exports to Mexico have more than doubled since 1986, creating more than 400,000 new jobs for U.S. workers.
Free-trade negotiations provide an opportunity to build on that foundation. And free trade with Mexico can also keep and create good jobs in the U.S. Since 1979, 2.6 million U.S. manufacturing jobs have been lost to lower-cost operations, especially in the Pacific Rim countries. Companies that move there often relocate all of their production. By contrast, sharing production with Mexicans creates jobs in the U.S. In 1990, American-owned companies operating in Mexico bought $9 billion in components and other supplies made in the U.S.
Many members of Congress worry that the Uruguay Round and the negotiations with Mexico might wind up hurting important domestic constituencies.
That's why chairman Dan Rostenkowski of the House Ways and Means Committee and I wrote the President asking that he submit an action plan to Congress by May 1, telling us how he intends to address issues relating to potential U.S. job losses, Mexican labor standards and the effect on the environment. That response will be critical in determining whether the U.S.-Mexico (and GATT) negotiations proceed.
But let's keep one point in mind: Support for fast-track procedures does not commit anyone to vote for the final agreement.
Congress cannot afford to pass up any opportunity to boost U.S. exports. Last year, 88 percent of the nation's economic growth was attributable to increased sales to foreign countries. Exports offer the best chance to pull the U.S. out of the recession -- and to position us for the economic challenges of the 1990's and the next century. Negotiations offer our best hope to reduce trade barriers and increase U.S. exports. Let's keep them on track, the fast track.

GRAPHIC: Drawing

HEADLINE: Rent Regulation Essential to Preserve New York's Middle Class

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Tap the Treasure in Rent Control" (editorial, April 9) is naive and one-sided. 
 Yes, by removing rent regulations, building owners and New York City would derive more revenue. And it is also true that some tenants pay less in rent than their incomes suggest they can afford.
Housing economists report that the allocation of about 25 percent of disposable income is the proper proportion to pay for housing. However, thousands of tenants pay in excess of 40 percent or even 50 percent of disposable income for rent. Would it be fair to raise their rents, without restrictions, or force their eviction because an owner can find someone willing to pay more?
How many more people would be rendered homeless or indigent if we lifted restrictions on an owner's avarice? Have we forgotten the bitter experience of vacancy decontrol in 1971-74, when rents and harassment of tenants both skyrocketed? In that period of precipitous rent increases, there was little recorded reinvestment of profits into the buildings.
Rent regulation and tenant protection are essential to protecting the endangered, middle class of New York.
 
STEVEN SANDERS
Member of Assembly, 63d Dist.
Albany, April 9, 1991

HEADLINE: Tokyo Voters Sent a Message to Washington

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Tokyo Election Defeat Stuns Japan's Governing Party" (news article, April 9), you unfortunately missed an important political statement by the voters who overwhelmingly defeated Hisanori Isomura for Governor of Tokyo against the 80-year-old incumbent, Shunichi Suzuki. 
 Mr. Isomura was backed by the ruling Liberal Democratic Party national leadership, led by its general secretary, Ichiro Ozawa, and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. Mr. Suzuki was backed by the Liberal Democrats' Tokyo regional groups, defying their national leadership.
Behind the internal party struggle lay the Japanese public's festering resentment against high-handed Ozawa power politics and President Bush's humiliating treatment of Japan in the Persian Gulf crisis. Tokyo voters were merely registering their protest against the United States and the national leaders of the Liberal Democrats, whom they consider too subservient to Washington.
Last fall and again early this year, President Bush pushed Mr. Ozawa to circumvent the Japanese Constitution and send "noncombat" military forces to the gulf. Mr. Ozawa seized on America's push to establish the precedent of dispatching Japan's military personnel to a war overseas. His schemes were repeatedly rejected by the Japanese public.
However, the Liberal Democrats and the Government had agreed to pay $13 billion to the war costs of the United States-led allies, against the will of the majority of the Japanese (half of male adults and two-thirds of female adults were clearly opposed). Even those Japanese in the minority who grudgingly approved of the monetary contributions to the gulf war saw the payment as colonial taxes without representation levied by the United States.
To pass Japan's monetary contributions through the upper house of the Japanese Parliament, Prime Minister Kaifu and Mr. Ozawa needed the support of the conservative opposition parties, Komeito and the Democratic Socialists. Since these parties were opposed to Mr. Suzuki, the incumbent Governor of Tokyo, Mr. Ozawa hurriedly put up Mr. Isomura as a candidate of a Liberal Democrats-led coalition.
When the gulf war ended, President Bush invited the foreign ministers of Britain, France and even Germany to Washington for postwar consultation. Germany had pledged half as much in monetary contributions as Japan. But President Bush did not even go through the motions of inviting Japan. He even canceled his planned trip to Japan.
These political slights occurred when Mr. Ozawa and his candidate were gearing up for the campaign against Governor Suzuki. Suddenly, Mr. Suzuki, who had been written off as a lame duck, was revived by the strong sentiments of Tokyo voters for anybody but Mr. Isomura. Tokyo voters knew that Mr. Isomura's defeat would force Mr. Ozawa to resign as party general secretary and weaken the Kaifu Administration. At the same time, it would express their anger at United States diplomatic slights of Japan.
Mistakenly, Prime Minister Kaifu accepted President Bush's summons to California for a photo opportunity three days before the Tokyo governor election. Mr. Kaifu's subservient posture further fueled anti-Isomura sentiment among Tokyo voters.
Ichiro Ozawa got the message and resigned from his leadership position. Mr. Kaifu's days are numbered. For the first time in Japanese political history since the end of World War II, the closeness of Japanese politicians with the United States President became a political kiss of death. However, the Bush Administration does not yet grasp the serious diplomatic blunders that have unraveled United States-Japanese relations.
The United States and Japan need each other more than ever, now with the United States forced to tackle many economic, political, military and technological problems at home and abroad. The United States cannot afford to continue treating relations with Japan as if the United States dictates and Japan obeys. The United States must consult Japan fairly and seriously to put some substance into the new political and economic order of the world.
 
YOSHI TSURUMI
Professor of International Business
Baruch College, CUNY
New York, April 11, 1991

HEADLINE: TRUMP DISCUSSING EMPIRE'S BREAKUP TO PAY OFF BANKS

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
The empire that Trump built is about to be dismantled.
Less than nine months after signing a sweeping rescue package for Donald J. Trump, the banks that lent him nearly $2 billion to build his empire have abandoned the original agreement and are now close to signing tentative agreements that would give them some of his key properties. 
 In exchange, the banks, including Citicorp, Manufacturers Hanover and Bankers Trust, would release him from some of the hundreds of millions of dollars in loans that he personally guaranteed. Being released from these obligations reduces the prospect that Mr. Trump would have to file for personal bankruptcy if the loans soured and he had insufficient cash to make good on the guarantees.
Mr. Trump confirmed that tentative agreements were close.
"The negotiations are going very well," Mr. Trump said yesterday. "We've established excellent relationships with our lending institutions."
The new plan would effectively begin the unwinding of one of the largest and most visible financial empires built in the 1980's.
 
An Aura of Great Wealth
 Although Mr. Trump exuded an aura of great wealth, his empire was built largely on borrowed money. This has proved to be his undoing. Because he paid such high prices for many of his properties, many did not generate enough money to pay the interest on the loans underlying them. Although the banks allowed him to restructure his finances last summer in the hopes the arithmetic would work better, the sharp downturn in the economy that resulted from the Persian Gulf war, dashed those hopes.
According to bankers and confirmed by Mr. Trump, those agreements, as they stand now, would give almost all of his 50 percent interest in New York's Grand Hyatt Hotel to Bankers Trust. Citicorp would get his 27 percent stake in Alexander's, the department store chain. The Trump Shuttle airline would be taken over by NWA Inc., parent of Northwest Airlines, with several dozen banks getting an equity interest in the shuttle.
His 282-foot yacht would go to the Boston Safe Deposit and Trust Company, a subsidiary of American Express. And his Regency Hotel in Atlantic City would be put on the block, with most of the proceeds to go to Manufacturers Hanover.
Final terms on all of these arrangements are still being worked out, but the general outlines are expected to hold. The disposition of other properties, including the Plaza Hotel, has not yet been decided. It is possible that if Mr. Trump is not able to reach an agreement with one of the banks, he might throw one of the properties into bankruptcy and tie it up for several years. But the other transactions could still move forward.
One banker said yesterday that when the new agreements on the assets were completed, Mr. Trump's holdings would largely consist of equity in three Atlantic City casinos and in properties like the undeveloped Penn Central railroad yards on the West Side of Manhattan and commercial and residential space in the Trump Tower.
Last summer's plan gave Mr. Trump $65 million in new money and an agreement that revised nearly all his obligations and gave the banks new liens on his assets. Bankers said yesterday that that plan had been proved useless because even the assets that were expected to pay their own way had not met projections.
 
Collateral Was Put Up
 As part of the plan signed last summer, all of Mr. Trump's assets were put up as collateral for his outstanding loans. Before then, many of his loans carried little or no collateral, and had been granted on his signature alone. The rescue package gave Mr. Trump three to five years to sell or otherwise refinance the properties so the bank debts could be paid off. None of Mr. Trump's leading assets has been sold since the rescue plan was set up.
"That plan is dead," one of Mr. Trump's bankers said. "It was predicated on a lot of things like cash flow from the casinos, cash flow from the shuttle, and cash flow from the hotels. None of those cash flows have materialized."
Bankers in the talks said that with the recession and the rise in oil prices, the performance of Trump assets like the casinos in Atlantic City, the Trump Shuttle, and the Plaza Hotel had been hurt. Even without the overall economic turmoil, bankers openly doubted the valuation of many of the Trump assets.
According to the tentative plan, NWA would take a controlling equity stake in the Trump Shuttle. The senior and junior bank lenders, both led by Citicorp, will also get equity interest in the Shuttle in exchange for releasing Mr. Trump from his personal guarantees. The Trump Shuttle has a $245 million first mortgage on it and another $135 million that was borrowed with Mr. Trump's personal guarantee.
The Regency Hotel in Atlantic City would continue to be operated by Trump Plaza Casino, which leases it, but Manufacturers Hanover would have the right to sell it if the bank could find a buyer. The proceeds from the sale would then go to the bank to cover loans.
The Plaza Hotel in New York is one of the few big assets on which little has been agreed. Mr. Trump has plans to turn much of the hotel into condominiums, but no agreement has been reached yet on that property with Citicorp, the main lender.
 
Keeping a House in Palm Beach
 Mr. Trump says he is planning to subdivide his Palm Beach estate into something he will call The Mansions at Mar-a-Lago, which will feature eight large, adjacent developments. He also says he is planning to keep the 118-room main house for himself.
Mr. Trump and his chief financial officer, Stephen F. Bollenbach, are also negotiating to get the banks to pay the necessary operating expenses on many of the assets until the various restructuring plans are completed.
The banks are expected to finance not only the expenses of many of the properties, but also to provide additional extensions on many loans and to accept pieces of equity in the various assets in exchange for more lenient repayment terms on outstanding debt. The maturity of the $65 million loan that helped the developer escape bankruptcy last year is also likely to be extended.
 
Restrictions Flouted
 Bankers also say Mr. Trump regularly violated restrictions of last summer's agreement.
The bankers say Mr. Trump violated the terms of the rescue package within weeks of its signing. One proviso prohibited the developer from paying anyone more than $200,000 in a single year without the approval of the banks. Only weeks after the agreement was signed, Mr. Trump agreed to pay his wife, Ivana, whom he later divorced, $350,000 to run the Plaza Hotel. Last month, bankers said, he violated the agreement again by paying Mrs. Trump $10 million as part of the divorce settlement. In neither case, however, did the banks take any action against Mr. Trump.
 
Some Potential for Profit
 Two assets that Mr. Trump is retaining for now seem to have potential for future profit: the West Side railroad yards and the space he owns in the Trump Tower. The Trump Tower is current on its debt, and unless there is a drastic change over the next few months, it will begin to generate a profit when Galeries Lafayette, the French retailer, begins to pay rent in September on space it has leased there.
Prospects for the railroad yards are also better now that Mr. Trump and several civic groups have reached an agreement about the scale of the development for the more than 70 acres of empty lots. But a lengthy and expensive zoning process has yet to begin. If that, too, is favorably completed, the zoning will greatly enhance the value of the acreage. Chase Manhattan Bank, the leading lender on the property, is expected to cover most of the cost of the zoning process and may receive some equity for doing so.
 
New License for the Taj Mahal
 As for his biggest Atlantic City property, Mr. Trump last week won relicensing for the Taj Mahal casino, a billion-dollar, candy-colored giant that dominates the gambling business in that city. The New Jersey Casino Control Commission granted the extension of the license, but expressed great reluctance because it concluded that Mr. Trump did not prove that he was financially stable.
The commission told the developer to return on June 17 with conclusive proof that his finances and those of the Taj Mahal are stable. Mr. Trump and holders of the "junk bonds" that financed the Taj are preparing to file papers with the Securities and Exchange Commission that would give the bondholders 50 percent of the equity in the Taj in exchange for reducing the interest on the bond debt and extending the maturities of the bonds.

LENGTH: 1165 words

HEADLINE: Bold and Nimble Banker With Few Flops in Past

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
With a wall of television cameras facing him and a bevy of aides at his side yesterday, J. Terrence Murray, chief executive of the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group, looked more like a politician on the campaign trail than a banker.
At a Manhattan news conference, Mr. Murray fielded questions about his bank's latest acquisition, the purchase of the failed Bank of New England, an audacious and controversial move. 
 The purchase is bold because of its size -- the Bank of New England's collapse could ultimately cost the Government more than $2.5 billion. And it is bold for the precedent of allowing a powerful industrial conglomerate, the buyout firm of Kohlberg, Kravis & Roberts, to own a stake in what will be one of the nation's largest banks.
 
A Well-Respected Company
 But breaking precedent and making bold moves are nothing new for the 51-year-old Mr. Murray, who has built a well-respected and innovative financial-services empire. "Terry Murray is a businessman rather than a banker," said James Moynihan, an analyst with Advest Inc. in Boston. "He has more entrepreneurial instincts than any other New England banker."
Since the announcement Monday night that Fleet, based in Providence, R.I., had beaten out the Bank of Boston and the BankAmerica Corporation to gain the $15 billion in assets of the Bank of New England, Mr. Murray has been traveling the region preaching the gospel of the deal. "We're buying a clean bank and we think we can grow it," the stocky, redheaded Mr. Murray told the gathering yesterday.
The morning after the announcement, Mr. Murray was in the office of Lawrence K. Fish, the Bank of New England's departing chief executive, meeting with him and other senior officers of the bank. That day and the next, he shuttled from Boston to Hartford, New York, Portland, Me., and Providence, meeting with employees, analysts and reporters on a schedule calibrated by the half-hour.
"He's direct, he's smart and has a clear understanding of how you run a successful bank," said Mr. Fish, who will continue in his job for two to three months. "He's a very dynamic guy who has a lot of brains and a little luck."
With a salary of $755,000 and frequent travels, often in chartered jets, Mr. Murray has come a long way from blue-collar Woonsocket, R.I., where he worked as a newspaper carrier and a waiter as a youth. The son of a factory worker, Mr. Murray's first real job was in a textile mill, but when he saw how tedious the work was, he quickly went back to high school -- and finally to Harvard.
Upon graduation in 1962, already married and with two children (he now has five), Mr. Murray took a trainee position at Fleet's predecessor bank, the Industrial National Bank, and never left. After a decade of putting together complex deals, particularly bailing out troubled real estate projects, Mr. Murray, then in his 30's, became the bank's No. 2 officer. In 1982, he became chief executive upon the death of John Cummings Jr., who had held the No. 1 position. Today, he and his wife, Suzanne, live in Narragansett, R.I., and he spends his free time golfing and adding to his collection of Presidential letters.
 
Up Through the Bank
 "Terry's a roll-up-the-shirtsleeves kind of manager and a very down-to-earth guy," said Gerard Cassidy, an analyst with Tucker Anthony in Portland, Me. "He did go to some good schools that can create a certain pretention. But, he's not like that. He came up through the bank and really learned his job in the trenches."
Mr. Murray is perhaps best known for his strong vision and his belief in diversification. So far, his agressive approach to acquisitions has brought only a few mistakes. In the early 1980's, he began to diversify away from banking and into non-banking financial services by buying leading companies in a variety of areas outside New England -- a consumer finance company, a mortgage banker and a student-loan servicing company. In 10 years, he acquired 46 companies and saw Fleet grow from a $3.5 billion company in 1981 to a $32 billion one today. It will grow to more than $40 billion with the Bank of New England acquisition.
Even Mr. Murray acknowledges that Fleet prides itself on being nimble and opportunistic. "Our company is very entrepreneurial," he said at the New York news conference. "It's required a lot of resourceful entrepreneurial thinking. We're always looking outward and even in bad times, there is opportunity. And, the Bank of New England is one of them."
The $625 million that Mr. Murray and his investors are paying for the Bank of New England has, for the first time, brought him recognition beyond New England. In one big move, he is creating one of the nation's top 10 banks and breaking the historic barriers between banking and commerce. It was Mr. Murray's decision to approach Kohlberg, Kravis for funds and now, when talking to the press on telephone conference calls or in conferences like the one in Manhattan today, it is the issue he is asked most often to address.
 
Bank-Commerce Mix
 Many fear that the mixing of banking and commerce will lead to concentrations of power and could lead to loans being made on a favorable basis to the industrial concern that owned the bank. At the same time, in today's capital-starved banking system, such industrial concerns are being eyed as sources of fresh funds.
"We called K.K.R.," Mr. Murray said. "We were sitting in Providence and looking at the prospect of bidding on the Bank of New England. We couldn't bid without creating incremental new capital. We needed a unique, sophisticated investor with lots of capital. We knew that K.K.R. has large pools of capital, so we went to them." That was Mr. Murray's first and only stop for funds.
He defends the arrangement, saying that K.K.R is only a passive investor seeking an "attractive rate return." K.K.R. will have "no board responsibility, no voting rights and no management say," he emphasized.
And he readily concedes the deal is not riskless -- the biggest unknown is the speed of any rebound in New England's economy. But, if Mr. Murray's record is any sign, luck is generally on his side. In 1986, he was outbid by the Bank of New England for the Conifer Group in Worcester, Mass. -- by less than $1 a share. Although a disappointment then, Conifer later turned out to be riddled with bad real estate loans. Mr. Murray instead bought the Albany-based Norstar Bancorp, a New York franchise that has helped Fleet weather New England's bad times. Still, a few of his acquisitions -- particularly the Indian Head Bank in New Hampshire -- have been flops.
In a brush with disaster, in early 1990, Mr. Murray once briefly considered merging with the troubled Bank of New England, but passed. "That would have been the ultimate disaster," said Mr. Cassidy of Tucker Anthony. "He was lucky that merger never took place. But he can't go on luck all the time, which is where smarts and hard work comes in, and he has both."

GRAPHIC: Photo: J. Terrence Murray, Fleet/Norstar Financial Group's chief executive, spoke at a news conference in New York yesterday. (Neal Boenzi/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Kennedy Center Names a Top Executive

BYLINE: By BARBARA GAMAREKIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
James D. Wolfensohn, the chairman of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, announced the appointment of Lawrence J. Wilker as chief operating officer today. Mr. Wilker, president and chief operating officer of the Playhouse Square Foundation in Cleveland, is to join the center on July 1.
The appointment to this newly created position comes after a four-month search and a review of some 130 performing arts institutions. 
 "Larry Wilker combines rare financial, general management, fund-raising and leadership skills," Mr. Wolfensohn said today. "He has the drive, energy and enthusiasm, and a personal style to help keep the Kennedy Center in the forefront of the performing arts in the United States."
In the new position, Mr. Wilker will operate as the center's second in command, responsible for the day-to-day operation.
The appointment is part of a management reorganization plan being put in place by Mr. Wolfensohn, who assumed the chairmanship a year ago. It is a departure from the Kennedy Center's tradition of having a single top executive. The plan is based on a five-month study conducted by the management consulting firm of Cannon Devane and it reflects an administrative trend at arts institutions across the country.
Additional appointments, including that of an artistic director for theater, are expected during the next few months.
Mr. Wilker, who has an undergraduate degree in economics, a master's degree in acting and directing and a Ph.D. in theater administration, joined the Playhouse Square Foundation in 1982, where he has overseen a $40 million theater restoration project. From 1977 to 1980 he was vice president of the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Foundation. Before joining the Playhouse Square Foundation, he was the director of properties for the Shubert Organization for two years.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Decline in Sales At Rolls-Royce

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LONDON, April 25

 BODY:
Sales of Rolls-Royce luxury cars are down sharply in Britain and the United States, the parent company's chairman said today.
David Plastow, chairman of the industrial conglomerate Vickers P.L.C., said at the annual shareholders meeting that the first three months of 1991 "have been extremely difficult for Rolls-Royce motor cars." 
 Mr. Plastow said Rolls- Royce's first-quarter sales had fallen markedly in both countries in line with a slump in sales of other luxury cars.
He did not give any specific figures, but analysts were forecasting that Rolls-Royce's worldwide sales would fall to 2,760 in 1991 from the 3,333 recorded in 1990.
Mr. Plastow said Vickers would continue to invest in Rolls-Royce to insure that the car maker was well placed to take advantage of an economic upturn.

HEADLINE: Home Resales Are Up 0.6% For 2d Consecutive Increase

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
Sales of existing homes rose in March for the second consecutive month, a real estate trade group said today. The advance of six-tenths of a percent was new evidence, analysts said, that the housing recession has bottomed out.
"It's another sign that we've reached the bottom of the general real estate or ousing recession," said Daryl Delano, an economist with Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass. But he and other analysts do not expect any big improvement in the near future. 
 "It will move forward, but very, very slowly," Mr. Delano said.
The National Association of Realtors said sales of existing single-family homes totaled 3.18 million at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, up from 3.16 million a month earlier. February's 8.9 percent advance was the first since November.
Other recent signs of a resurgence in the housing industry have included a 16.2 percent jump in new-home sales and an increase in housing starts in February, some of which analysts said was attributed to good weather. But applications for building permits -- often an indication of future activity -- also posted their first gain in eight months.
The president of the realtors group, Harley E. Rouda, attributed the sales increases to favorable mortgage rates and to growing consumer confidence in the economy. "Buyers in all income ranges are going ahead with their purchases," he said.
The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said fixed-rate mortgages averaged between 9.40 percent and 9.59 percent in March, down at least one-half of a percentage point from a year earlier.
The median price of an existing home rose to $96,500, up 2.7 percent from February and four-tenths of a percent from March 1990. The median means half of the homes cost more, half less.
The resale rate in the Midwest jumped 10.2 percent, to 970,000 units. The median price there was $76,200, down three-tenths of a percent from February.
For the second month, sales rose in the Northeast, up 4 percent, to a 520,000 rate. The median price was $142,300, up 3.7 percent.
But sales plunged 7.3 percent in the South, to a 1.24 million annual rate. The median price of $87,500 was up 5.2 percent.
And in the West, the resale rate slipped 1.9 percent, to 530,000 units. The median cost there was $137,000, up four-tenths of a percent.
