HEADLINE: Knight-Ridder Net Drops; Viacom Narrows Its Loss

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Knight-Ridder Inc. reported a 39 percent decline in its first-quarter profit yesterday, blaming an advertising slump related to the recession and the Persian Gulf war for its "toughest quarter in memory."
Viacom Inc., meanwhile, said its loss for the first quarter narrowed from a year earlier, as its earnings from operations rose 42 percent. 
 Following are details of the media companies' results:
 
Knight-Ridder
Knight-Ridder, the Miami-based newspaper and information-services giant, said it earned $15.8 million, or 32 cents a share, in the quarter ended March 31, compared with $25.8 million, or 50 cents a share, in the comparable quarter last year.
Revenue fell 2.7 percent, to $540.1 million, from $554.9 million a year earlier.
The company reported 4.4 percent decline in overall first-quarter newspaper revenue, to $456 million, the first such drop since Knight-Ridder was formed in a merger in 1974, said Robert Singleton, chief financial officer.
The drop in overall revenue included an 8.4 percent decline in newspaper advertising revenue, to $340.4 million, and an 8.8 percent rise in circulation revenue, to $106.6 million.
Revenue from business-information services rose to $84.1 million, from $77.8 million a year earlier.
Prospects for the rest of the year are guarded. "We have a chance of a flat to slightly up year, although the second quarter is currently projected to be flat to down slightly," Mr. Singleton said.
Knight-Ridder publishes 29 daily newspapers, owns electronic retrieval, news, graphics and photo services as well as cable television outlets, and manufactures newsprint. Its stock fell 75 cents on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to close at $53.50 a share.
 
Viacom
Viacom, a New York-based cable-television and entertainment company, said it lost $3.7 million in the three months ended March 31, in contrast to a loss of $17.1 million a year ago. Revenue edged up 3.6 percent, to $407.2 million from $393.2 million.
The company said earnings from operations at its cable-television division, which includes the MTV Networks and the pay-television Showtime channel, more than doubled, to $39 million, while earnings from operations at its cable television systems rose 66 percent, to $25 million.
Operational earnings in Viacom's entertainment segment rose 5 percent, to $28 million. But earnings from operations in broadcasting fell 69 percent, to $2 million, because of softness in the advertising market and the cost of recent radio station acquisitions.
Viacom is 84 percent owned by National Amusements Inc., a closely held company controlled by Sumner Redstone with 675 movie screens in 14 states and Britain. Viacom's stock fell 25 cents, to $31.875 a share, on the American Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Earnings Rise 71.3% At Johnson

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Johnson & Johnson, the world's largest health-care-products company, said yesterday that first-quarter profits jumped 71.3 percent, to $418 million, or $1.25 a share, from $244 million, or 73 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago.
The increase reflected a write-off of $125 million last year because of economic turmoil in Argentina and other Latin American countries. Adjusting for the extraordinary charge, earnings rose 13.3 percent, from $369 million, or $1.11 a share, a year ago. 
 Sales increased 12.1 percent, to $3.15 billion from $2.81 billion, with about 3.1 percent coming from weakness in the dollar overseas, where the company has half its sales.
Johnson & Johnson, which is based in New Brunswick, N.J., announced its 27th-straight annual dividend increase: to 40 cents a quarter from 34 cents.
Ralph S. Larsen, the company's chairman, said sales results were "outstanding" in pharmaceuticals, which increased by 20.8 percent worldwide and 24 percent in the United States. He also reported "solid gains" of 14.5 percent in hospital supply sales.
Consumer products like Tylenol were hurt by economic problems in Brazil, rising only 4.1 percent. Kenneth S. Abramowitz, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, said the company's sales were "better than it looks, because consumer products in Brazil were down at least $50 million."
"New-product launches fueled strong domestic growth" in all three business units, Mr. Larsen said. The company said its new prescription drugs were headed by an anti-anemia drug, Proscrit; an anti-bacterial drug, Floxin, and a blood-pressure drug, Vascor. It also introduced an over-the-counter version of Monistat, a widely prescribed remedy for women's yeast infections.
Mr. Larsen said other products with sales increases included Acuvue disposable contact lenses, diagnostic tests for hepatitis-C, and the antihistamine Hismanal. Ethicon surgical sutures continued to gain market share, despite a recent challenge by the United States Surgical Corporation. He added that Ethicon is also pressing to become the market leader in endoscopic products that are increasingly used in "less invasive" surgery.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Johnson & Johnson's share price rose $1.125 yesterday, to $95.

HEADLINE: Xerox's $116 Million Profit

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., April 25

 BODY:
The Xerox Corporation reported a first-quarter profit of $116 million today, compared with a loss in the 1990 period that mostly resulted from a discontinued real estate investment.
The company said its first-quarter income, excluding 1990's $367 million loss from discontinued operations, rose 3 percent from $113 million a year earlier. 
 The increase reflected a doubling to $6 million in profits in Xerox's insurance and financial services operations, which were increased by insurance underwriting results.
Income from Xerox's document-processing business, hurt by the recession and the Persian Gulf war's effect on consumer spending, was the same as last year's $110 million.
Including discontinued operations, Xerox said its net income for the three months that ended on March 31 was $1.01 a share, compared with a loss of $254 million. Its revenues totaled $4.2 billion, up slightly from $4.15 billion in the 1990 period.
Thomas Abbott, a spokesman, said Xerox was able to maintain profits in document processing despite sluggish consumer spending because of continued growth in service and rentals, supplies and in the financing of equipment.
Revenues from Xerox's document-processing business, aided by favorable currency exchange rates, grew to $3.2 billion, up 5 percent from $3.05 billion.
The company's revenues from insurance and other financial services totaled $1 billion, versus $1.16 billion. Xerox said the drop in revenues primarily reflected the withdrawal from writing personal lines of property and casualty insurance, including the sale of the Navco Corporation, an automobile insurance specialty unit.
On the New York Stock Exchange today, Xerox's stock rose $1.875, to $58.125.

HEADLINE: New Claims for Unemployment Insurance Rise by 47,000

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
Reversing a two-week decline, the number of people filing new claims for state unemployment insurance climbed by 47,000, to 498,000, in the week ended April 13, the Labor Department announced today.
The report pointed to continued economic weakness, a subject seized upon by President Bush today. He took the occasion of a photo session with former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita of Japan in advance of a Group of Seven meeting here to reiterate the Administration's desire for lower interest rates to help spur economic growth. 
 "We want to see these interest rates down a little bit," the President said, "including our own." Mr. Bush was presumably directing his message mainly at Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and other Fed policy makers, but he did not specify them. The Bush Administration has been more persistent in its admonitions to the central bank than previous Administrations, but its tone has been less aggressive.
The report on initial jobless claims received particular scrutiny this time because the April 13 week was the same one in which the Government conducted its monthly survey of employment and unemployment.
 
Downward Trend Overall
 But even though initial claims are considered a predictive indicator for the economy at large, analysts said they were not particularly discouraged by the latest increase.
"It doesn't mean you should get real pessimistic," said Maury N. Harris, the chief economist at Paine Webber Inc. For one thing, Mr. Harris said, initial claims traditionally provide only short notice of economic turns. For another, he said, claims were still reflecting a downward trend when gauged on a four-week moving average -- 491,250 in the latest period compared with 494,250 on April 6 and 511,250 on March 30.
Analysts also said that recent figures may have been somewhat skewed by seasonal adjustment problems around the Easter holidays and by an inability to adequately adjust for a recurring shift in claims around calendar quarters. Because some states peg jobless payments to earnings in the preceding quarter, some people defer applications until the new quarter begins, when their base for calculations will tend to be higher.
For these and other reasons, claims figures are subject to wide weekly gyrations, prompting economists to average them over longer periods.
Alan C. Lerner of the Bankers Trust Company was another analyst not distressed by the latest claims data. Agreeing with comments on the economy by Mr. Greenspan earlier this week, Mr. Lerner said, "There is evidence that the rate of decline is slowing."
 
Payroll Figure Awaited
 He predicted that figures to be published by the Labor Department May 3 would show that payroll employment fell in April by a relatively modest 100,000.
Today's report of initial claims rising 47,000 followed declines of 70,000 and 22,000 in the two preceding weeks and left the total well under the peak of 543,000 recorded for March 23. Some 10,000 of the latest rise in claims were in Michigan, where automobile makers have been cutting payrolls.
Without seasonal adjustment, claims in the April 13 week numbered 461,700, or 14,600 more than the week before, the report also showed. In the comparable 1990 week, 315,600 new claims were filed.
The seasonally adjusted rate of insured unemployment remained unchanged at 3.3 percent for the week ended April 6, with 3,496,000 people collecting benefits, down 36,000 from the last week in March.
But while the latest figures did not portray any significant worsening of the labor market, they did provided little grounds for optimism.
"The recession is definitely still going on," said Carol Ann Hamilton of National Westminster Bancorp in New York. "Unemployment is going to rise for some time."

HEADLINE: White House Lists 22 Critical Technologies

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
Departing from a longstanding policy, the White House today listed 22 areas of technological development that should be nurtured as "critical to the national prosperity and to national security."
Until now, the White House had opposed efforts to identify and nurture critical technologies as unwarranted governmental interference. Aides to President Bush had said such lists involved picking winners and losers, were counterproductive and undermined the Administration's commitment to free trade. 
 The change was signaled in a letter to President Bush that accompanied the list released today. In it, William D. Phillips, chairman of the National Critical Technologies Panel and associate director of the White House Office of Science and Technology, said: "We most recently have been reminded, by the spectacular performance of U.S. coalition forces in the Persian Gulf, of the crucial role that technology plays in military competitiveness. It is equally clear that technology plays a similar role in the economic competitiveness among nations."
 
Report Required by Congress
 Congress, in passing the Defense Authorization Act, required that the White House consider and issue such a report.
The report cited technologies involving materials and manufacturing, information and communications, biotechnology and life sciences, aeronautics and surface transportation, and energy and the environment.
Dr. Phillips said that almost all of the critical technologies cited were essential to the military as well as to economic prosperity and that he saw "a considerable overlap" between today's list and one prepared by the Defense Department in 1990.
The broad list of technologies is also similar to one issued last month by the Council on Competitiveness, a nonprofit organization of leaders in business, education and labor, but the White House study places more emphasis on technologies involving surface transportation and the environment.
 
Commercial Use Urged
 The report urged greater commercial use of new technologies. "The key to future U.S. competitive success involves a fundamental change in the way U.S. industry competes in the marketplace," the report said.
"This is the first time that the White House has identified priorities in technology for the country to pursue," said Senator Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico, chairman of the Armed Services Committee's Subcommittee on Defense Industry and Technology. "But there is still a raging dispute between those who put out this report and others in the White House over the Government's role in meeting this challenge."
Included in the surface transportation technologies section of the report were the development of "Intelligent vehicle/highway systems," often referred to as "smart cars" and "smart highways," and electrically powered vehicles, which rely on advances in batteries and fuel cells.
The environmental section involved minimizing pollution; recycling, and the treatment, storage and disposal of pollutants.
The report also listed technologies in these areas:
 
Materials processing.
Electronic and photonic materials.
Ceramics.
Composites.
High-performance metals and alloys.
Flexible computer integrated manufacturing.
Intelligent processing equipment.
Micro- and nano-fabrication.
Systems-management technologies.
Software.
Microelectronics and optoelectronics.
High-performance computing/networking.
High-definition imaging and displays.
Sensors and signal processing.
Data storage.
Computer simulation.
Applied molecular biology.
Medical technology.
Aeronautics.
Energy technologies.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Push for Lower Rates At Group of Seven Meeting

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The United States will emphasize the need to lower world interest rates when it meets in Washington this weekend with its chief economic allies in the Group of Seven, a top Treasury official said yesterday.
But even before this public acknowledgement of what the United States has been quietly lobbying for in recent weeks, Karl Otto Pohl, the president of the Bundesbank, said the German central bank was not considering lowering interest rates. 
 In other comments, the Treasury official, David C. Mulford, the Under Secretary for International Affairs, indicated that the United States was not overly concerned about the recent sharp rise of the dollar, which has climbed about 20 percent since February against the mark and some other major currencies.
The debate on interest rates will undoubtedly take up a lot of time this weekend and will be watched closely because of the impact interest rates have on the foreign exchange market.
But analysts said yesterday that they expected no significant onslaught against the rising dollar because the level of the dollar has not become worrisome to finance officials. Also, they said, German resistance to lower rates there, combined with Bush Administration pressure for lower rates here, is the blend of policy needed to slow the dollar's rise.
"This may be a weekend that nothing definitive will happen," said Neal M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation in New York. He said he did not think the current level of the dollar was a big concern as long as the rally subsides. But he said there was a worry that the speed of the rally this year might mean the dollar would continue to move higher.
The dollar closed yesterday in New York at 1.7495 marks, up from 1.7460 on Wednesday, and 137.85 yen, up from 137.80.
John Lipsky, the director of international bond trading at Salomon Brothers in London, said: "In the end it seems likely that the G-7 focus in the communique is likely to be cautious. If there is a promise to prevent unjustified dollar appreciation or over rapid appreciation, but no one is willing to undertake the policy moves to do that, that would undermine the G-7 process."
Mr. Mulford made his comments at a news conference in Washington. He said that interest rates around the world were "too high," especially in Europe. Because of these interest rate levels, he said, "the prospect for growth is less good." He said that policy makers should concentrate on stimulating growth rather than fighting inflation at a time when the world economy is slowing down.
 
Dollar's Rapid Rise
 Mr. Mulford added that despite the dollar's rapid rise since February, the increase had been orderly and stable.
On Tuesday and Wednesday central banks in Europe, led by the Bundesbank, sold dollars in an effort to slow the rally. But traders said the Federal Reserve Board did not participate. This dollar selling helped stop the rally.
Mr. Mulford's comments echoed those that Secretary of the Treasury Nicholas F. Brady had made in recent meetings with members of the Group of Seven, which consists of the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada.
And yesterday, President Bush added his voice to the chorus, calling for lower interest rates in the United States. At a White House meeting, the President said, "We want to see these interest rates down a little bit, and I think that would be good for the world economy, including our own."
But at the same time, Mr. Pohl made clear in an interview with The Financial Times that the Bundesbank, Europe's key central bank, was not thinking of lowering rates. "A cut in interest rates in Germany is not on the agenda," Mr. Pohl said. "Calls for Germany to cut interest rates are, from our point of view, difficult to understand."
United States lobbying for lower rates comes at a time when it suddenly appears that key central banks have stopped the lowering of interest rates that had begun earlier this year.
The Bank of Japan was thought to be near easing but apparently has now put it off. And the Federal Reserve, which eased aggressively earlier this year, has apparently put any further moves on hold. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chariman, told Congress on Tuesday that he was being cautious about any further lowering of interest rates. And a tax increase in Germany had seemed to open the possibility of lower rates there or, at the least, no further increases.

HEADLINE: Compaq Net Up 24 Percent For Quarter

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Compaq Computer said yesterday that its first-quarter profit rose 24 percent, and Data General posted its second profitable quarter after a string of losses. But struggling Unisys said its loss had widened sharply.
Compaq's stock price dropped sharply, apparently because it warned that the next quarter's profits could suffer. 
 Following are details of the companies' results.
 
Compaq
The Compaq Computer Corporation said it earned $114.3 million, or $1.26 a share, in the first quarter, compared with $92.2 million, or $1.07 a share, in 1990's first quarter. Revenue was up 11 percent, to $970.8 million, from $872.2 million in the 1990 period.
"Our financial results for the first quarter were very good, especially given all the uncertainties surrounding the war in the Middle East, slowing global economies and the effect of major strategic programs," said Joseph R. Canion, president and chief executive of the Houston-based company.
Mr. Canion said sales were strong worldwide. Foreign sales were 16 percent above the 1990 period and accounted for 59 percent of revenue.
But Compaq warned that its second-quarter profit could be hurt by price cuts this month on many of its products as well as by the stronger dollar, which hurts the results of sales abroad.
Because of these factors, "it is likely that second-quarter earnings will be below those of the second quarter of 1990," Compaq said in a statement.
Compaq's stock plunged $9.375 yesterday, or 15 percent, to $52.50 on the New York Stock Exchange.
One analyst, Eugene Glazer of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said the drop resulted mainly from Compaq's warning about the second quarter. In addition, he said, the first-quarter earnings were at the low end of analysts' estimates.
 
Data General
The Data General Corporation said it earned $19.2 million, or 60 cents a share, in its third quarter ended March 30, continuing to rebound from a string of losses.
The Westboro, Mass., company had a loss of $8.6 million in the comparable period a year ago. Revenue for the 1991 period rose almost 2 percent, to $320.4 million from $314.8 million.
The company's president, Ronald L. Skates, said Data General's results improved despite the weak economy and the impact of a strong dollar, which makes its products more expensive abroad.
During the previous quarter, Data General reported a $12.4 million profit after nearly two years of quarterly losses.
Data General had losses in its proprietary line of computers as customers increasingly demanded "open systems" computers that can more easily work with other brands.
Mr. Skates said the company remained cautious because of the worldwide economic slump, but he added that Data General was well positioned for the long-term.
Data General's stock rose $1.50 yesterday, closing at $18 on the Big Board.
 
Unisys
The Unisys Corporation reported a first-quarter loss of $98.2 million, more than 30 times the company's first-quarter loss a year ago of $3.2 million.
First-quarter revenue declined 11 percent, to $2.06 billion, from $2.31 billion in the 1990 period.
"The weak economic environment in our major markets around the world continues and has resulted in a general slowdown in computer industry demand," said James A. Unruh, chairman and chief executive.
The company's orders and revenues remain depressed while customers continue to delay large technology investments, Mr. Unruh said.
Losses on a commercial microcomputer contract with the Government and the effect of price controls on Brazilian operations also contributed to the loss, Mr. Unruh said.
Unisys, based in Blue Hill, Pa., said it had reduced administrative and selling expenses to 1987 levels and had eliminated 3,000 jobs last quarter. Its work force was at 72,000 at the end of the quarter.
Shares of Unisys fell 37.5 cents yesterday, closing at $4.50 on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: $1.4 Trillion Budget Plan Is Approved by the Senate

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
The Senate approved a $1.4 trillion Government spending plan for the next fiscal year tonight after rejecting efforts by Democrats to shift money from the Pentagon to domestic health, education and welfare programs. Approval came by voice vote.
In a series of significant test votes throughout the day, the Senate repeatedly upheld the spending limits imposed in last year's bipartisan budget agreement between Congress and President Bush. Final approval of the Senate budget measure today came by voice vote. 
 The next step in the budget process is for senators to negotiate a compromise with the House of Representatives, which adopted a similar budget blueprint last week. Because it does not become law, the compromise measure, known as a budget resolution, is not subject to veto or approval by the President, but will provide guidance to Congressional committees writing appropriations bills and other legislation over the next five or six months.
 
Changes From Bush Plan
 The Senate and House would both provide more money than the President requested for education, child health and child nutrition programs in the fiscal year 1992, which begins Oct. 1. Both houses would provide less money than the President sought for space exploration. The Senate, like the House, summarily rejected Mr. Bush's proposal for further cutbacks in payments to hospitals under Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for 34 million elderly and disabled people.
In the Senate, as in the House, the budget debate was devoid of the passion and anguish that characterized last year's debates on the budget. Lawmakers are sticking closely to the fiscal framework they put together last fall.
The 1992 budget resolution "upholds the principles of the budget summit agreement of last year, and it upholds the discipline that was the fundamental underlying reason for the budget summit agreement -- the discipline to control spending," said Senator Jim Sasser, the chairman of the Budget Committee. Mr. Sasser, a Tennessee Democrat, adroitly beat back efforts by liberals eager to spend more on social welfare programs and conservatives eager to slow the growth of Federal spending.
Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, proposed to cut military spending by 2 percent a year for five years and use half the savings for education, health care and pollution control programs. The other half of the savings would have been used to reduce the Federal budget deficit, projected at $286 billion next year under the Senate plan.
 
Bid to Cut Arms Outlays Lost
 Mr. Bradley's proposal failed after Mr. Sasser raised a point of order, charging that the proposal violated rules established to enforce last year's budget agreement. Those rules generally prohibit the transfer of money from the military budget to domestic spending accounts in the next three years. Mr. Sasser said he sympathized with Mr. Bradley's objective, but could not vote for the proposal because it would "do violence to the budget summit agreement that we enacted into law last year."
"We are compelled today to carry out that agreement," Mr. Sasser said. "I wish it could be otherwise." Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the ranking Republican on the Budget Committee, warned his colleagues that they would be "plowing a big hole in the budget agreement" if they approved the Bradley proposal.
Echoing the frustration of many senators, Mr. Bradley complained that last year's budget agreement "locked everyone in concrete," severely limiting the Government's ability to respond to a measles epidemic, the recession and other national problems.
By a vote of 73 to 22, the Senate reaffirmed its support for the budget agreement and blocked Mr. Bradley's proposal.
The Senate later rejected, by a vote of 70 to 25, a proposal by Senator Paul Simon that would have cut the military budget by 2 percent, or nearly $6 billion, next year. All the savings would have been used to reduce the deficit, and the National Taxpayers Union endorsed the proposal by Mr. Simon, a liberal Democrat from Illinois.
 
Plea for Military Cutbacks
 "After the United States won World War II, we reduced defense spending by 90 percent in three years," Mr. Simon said. "Surely today, after winning the cold war, we can reduce defense spending by 2 percent."
Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, the Democrat who serves as chairman of the Armed Services Committee, joined many Republicans in opposing the Simon amendment. Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, said the military spending levels in the 1992 budget resolution and in last year's budget agreement were already too low. Senator Domenici said the Defense Department was shouldering 40 percent of all the savings achieve in last year's budget agreement.
The Senate budget resolution contains a surprisingly strong endorsement of the principle that the Government should trim benefits and subsidies provided to affluent people, as President Bush recommended. "Subsidies that are provided to the wealthiest segment of our society should be either redirected to provide more assistance to the poor and the underprivileged, or applied to further deficit reduction," the resolution says.
But the Senate did not specify how that commitment to fairness and equity should be put into practice. The Senate budget resolution observes that people from high-income families can receive Government assistance in the form of farm subsidies, school lunch subsidies, low-interest loans to pay college costs and subsidized health insurance under Medicare.
The House Budget Committee said that proposals to reduce Government subsidies for high-income people had "a great deal of merit," but, like the Senate, it did not explicitly demand any changes in such subsidies.
By a vote of 60 to 37, the Senate rejected a proposal by Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, to freeze Federal spending for 1992 at this year's levels. Despite the euphoria on Capitol Hill over last year's budget agreement, he said, the deficit will set a record of nearly $300 billion this year and will be almost as high next year.
"The deficit is very much like a lizard," Mr. Grassley said. "When Congress tries to catch the lizard, it grabs the tail and the tail comes off in our hand. The lizard goes on its merry way and grows a whole new tail, only bigger and longer."

HEADLINE: New Jersey Judge Rules Surgeon With AIDS Must Tell Patients

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 25

 BODY:
A Superior Court judge ruled today that a surgeon infected with the AIDS virus must inform patients before operating on them.
In what is believed to be the first court ruling in the nation to weigh the protection of a health-care worker's confidentiality against a patient's right to know, the judge, Philip S. Carchman, said, "If there is to be an ultimate arbiter of whether the patient is to be treated invasively by an AIDS-positive surgeon, the arbiter will be the fully informed patient. 
 "The ultimate risk to the patient is so absolute, so devastating, that it is untenable to argue against informed consent combined with a restriction on procedures which present 'any risk' to the patient," Judge Carchman wrote in a 75-page opinion.
The opinion appears to go farther than the draft guidelines being studied by the Federal Centers for Disease Control, which recommend that infected physicians voluntarily suspend performing procedures that carry a risk of transmission, or seek the approval of local committees.
The center began re-examining its recommendations that call for a case-by-case evaluation of how infected physicians and dentists should practice after a dentist in Stuart, Fla., who died of AIDS, was found to have infected three patients. Another Florida dentist gave up his practice this month after learning that he has AIDS and recommended his patients undergo testing.
 
Guidelines Differ
 In recent months, the American Medical Association and the American Dental Association have adopted policies recommending that infected physicians tell their patients or stop performing surgery.
But the New York State Health Department adopted an opposing view in guidelines issued in January that said health-care workers need not tell patients if they are infected and may continue to operate or perform other invasive procedures.
The case that brought the issue before Judge Carchman was filed in 1988 by Dr. William H. Behringer, an ear, nose and throat specialist who practiced in Princeton and performed surgery at the Medical Center at Princeton until he was found to have AIDS in 1987. Dr. Behringer was 42 years old when he died of AIDS on July 2, 1989, but his estate continued the suit, charging the medical center with breach of contract and violating state anti-discrimination laws.
The decision is expected to be appealed and eventually to reach the New Jersey Su preme Court, lawyers for the estate and the medical center said.
Judge Carchman ruled in favor of the physician in finding that the hospital breached its duty to protect the confidentiality of his diagnosis, which was made in June 1987 when he came to the hospital's emergency room.
The information on Dr. Behringer's medical chart became widely known throughout the hospital and was being discussed around town before he was his release d from the hospital two days later. In his suit Dr. Behringer said his friends shunned him, his patients left him and he suffered emotional and economic distress because of the disclosure.
 
'Whispers Became Roars'
 "All that was required was a glance at a chart, and the written words became whispers and the whispers became roars," Judge Carchman wrote. "And common sense told all that this would happen."
Judge Carchman ruled the physician's estate was entitled to damages from the medical center for failing to protect his confidentiality as a patient. The amount will be the subject of further hearings.
But his opinion upheld the action of the medical center and its president, Dennis Doody, in suspending Dr. Behringer's surgical privileges.
The hospital and its various boards and committees discussed how to deal with issues raised by Dr. Behringer's infection for weeks. At one point the executive committee of the medical and dental staff recommended that Dr. Behringer retain all his privileges, that he follow precautions recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and that he be subject to careful monitoring for competence.
 
Informed-Consent Form
 But Mr. Doody and the hospital's legal counsel said that despite the absence of a reported case of transmission of the AIDS virus from a health-care worker to a patient at that time, Dr. Behringer would be required to reveal his infection in an informed-consent form to be signed by his patients.
Judge Carchman said everyone realized this amounted to a "de facto prohibition" from surgical practice.
Nonetheless, in weighing this action against Dr. Behringer's assertion that the hospital was violating his rights under the state's anti-discrimination law, Judge Carchman ruled that the hospital acted properly.
"New Jersey's strong policy supporting patient rights, weighed against plaintiff's individual right to perform an invasive procedure as part of the practice of his profession, requires the conclusion that the patient's rights must prevail," Judge Carchman said.
Roger J. Bernstein, the lawyer for Dr. Behringer's estate, said he applauded the decision for recognizing a patient's right of confidentiality when receiving an AIDS diagnosis.
 
Fear of Death
 But he said the court too readily accepted the certainty of death from AIDS despite testimony during the trial in December 1989 that "there is a significant group of HIV-infected people who have lived for 10 years and longer without contracting a fatal disease."
He said "fear of death" played an excessively large role in the decision. "It gave credence to fears not founded on the real risks of AIDS transmission," he said, adding that it mirrored the hospital's view that "AIDS equals bad equals out."
John R. Heher, the lawyer for the medical center, said the case was precedent-setting on two counts: for requiring infected health-care workers to inform patients of their disease before performing an invasive procedure, and for requiring that hospitals sequester the health records of staff physicians who contract the AIDS virus.
Mr. Bernstein, the estate's lawyer, said, "There is a conflict in the law that has never been resolved between laws that protect confidentiality and those that require informed consent."

HEADLINE: It's Official: July Saw The Recession's Start

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
The committee of seven prominent economists that is the arbiter of when recessions officially begin and end, ruled today that the current one started nine months ago, in July. The panel made no attempt to guess when it might end.
The decision of the Business Cycle Dating Committee of the National Bureau of Economic Research, a private organization whose rulings go into numerous record books, means the American economy began to contract before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. But, committee members said, the initial contraction might never have evolved into a full-blown recession without the damage to the economy that resulted from the Persian Gulf crisis. 
 "The war plainly did not create the overall economic slowdown that was very evident even in June," said Robert Hall, a Stanford University economist and chairman of the committee. "However, the increase in oil prices that followed the invasion probably did play a role in the sharp contraction that occurred in the fall."
 
Characteristic Contraction
 That sharp contraction in the four areas that the committee watches most closely -- jobs, personal income, sales and industrial production -- is a phenomenon that is characteristic of nearly every recession, with or without a political crisis. Without that sharp contraction, concentrated this time in October and November, the slowdown might never have turned into a genuine recession, in the committee's view.
Today, the Labor Department said the number of people filing new claims for state unemployment insurance climbed by 47,000, to 498,000, in the week ended April 13. That reversed two weeks of decline. President Bush promptly chided the Federal Reserve for not doing more to push down interest rates. [Page D2.]
Mr. Hall said that the sharp contraction in the fall was " what the business press would call a free fall." Although the committee concerned itself today only with dating the recession's starting point, Mr. Hall and other members said the economy was still contracting.
"It will be a long time, I predict, before we meet again to date the trough -- the end of the recession," Mr. Hall said. The Bush Administration, the Federal Reserve and many private economic forecasters say that the Persian Gulf crisis, with its impact on oil prices and consumer confidence, caused the recession, and they say it is now coming to an end. The committee, in effect, steered clear of both contentions.
The committee members, by a unanimous vote, provided a starting date for the recession that will appear in thousands of Government documents and business publications. The record now lists eight other recessions since World War II with an average length of 12 months. If this one is average it would end in June.
Geoffry Moore, a committee member from Columbia University, said, "So far this one does look to me very much like an average recession, although it is hard to find evidence that it is ending."
 
The Popular Definition
 The National Bureau, a private organization that finances research, has pinpointed not only recession dates but also the beginnings and ends of booms. In that role, the ruling today served the additional function of defining the economic expansion that started in November 1982, at the end of the last recession, and lasted for 92 months, until last July.
Only one other expansion since 1854 was longer: The booming 1960's produced 105 months of constant growth, from early 1961 until the final months of the decade.
The popular definition of a recession is two quarters of contraction by the gross national product, which is the value of all goods and services produced in a given period. By that definition, the current recession started in last year's fourth quarter, when the G.N.P. declined by 1.6 percent at an annual rate, and this year's first quarter, when the G.N.P. decline was more than 2 percent and perhaps much more, according to most estimates. The Commerce Department will announce the first-quarter figure tomorrow.
The Dating Committee also prefers that a downturn last at least six months to qualify as a recession. But it frequently dates recessions as starting in the midst of a quarter -- in this case in the early weeks of last year's third quarter.
This time July became a sort of average for four key developments. The committee decided that job growth peaked in June, then jobs began to disappear as layoffs accelerated. Personal income, adjusted for inflation, grew to its highest level in July and has fallen ever since. Sales by manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers peaked in August and then declined, and industrial production went into decline in September.
The other committee members are Martin Feldstein of Harvard, president of the National Bureau; Robert J. Gordon of Northwestern University; Benjamin Friedman of Harvard; Victor Zarnowitz of the University of Chicago, and William Branson of Princeton.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
2-Day Gain by U.S. Issues Ends

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
The two-day advance in Treasury bond prices came to a halt yesterday as the market in long-term securities absorbed various economic factors.
The number of initial claims for unemployment insurance rose 47,000, to 498,000, in the week ended April 13, the latest period covered by the Government's survey. Bond prices rose slightly on the news, but an increase had been expected and was thus not taken as serious negative news by investors in fixed-income debt issues who count on negative economic reports to protect their holdings from inflation and higher interest rates on newer offerings. 
 Also weighing on the fixed-income market was the decision by BankAmerica on Wednesday to reverse an earlier reduction in its prime lending rate from 8 3/4 percent back to 9 percent.
 
Long Bond Off 7/32
 As a result, late trading found the Treasury's bellwether long bonds, the 7 7/8 percent issue maturing in February 2021, down 7/32, at 96. This raised its yield to 8.23 percent, from 8.20 percent the day before.
The long bonds had been up as much as 10/32, when prices began to sag in the final hour of trading at the Chicago bond futures market. That market closes at 3 P. M., Eastern time. The New York cash bond market has no fixed hours.
The late weakness in bonds caused the Treasury's long notes, the 7 3/4 percent issue due February 2001, to slip 6/32 in late dealings, to 97 28/32, causing its yield to rise to 8.06 percent, from 8.03 percent the day before.
 
Auction of 5-Year Notes
 Prices of intermediate Treasury debt, meanwhile, were bolstered by the successful auction of five-year notes, which followed the excellent reception of an auction of two-year notes a day earlier.
The sale of the five-year notes again drew a record amount of bids, $32.4 billion for the $9 billion offered. This exceeded the record $30.2 billion that was bid for $8.5 billion of the same maturity a month ago.
The five-year notes were auctioned at an average yield of 7.70 percent for an issue with a 7 5/8 percent coupon. At the last monthly sale of this maturity, the average yield was 7.81 percent and the coupon was 7 3/4 percent. The price of the two-year notes rose 3/32, to 100 6/32, which brought its yield down to 6.89 percent, from the average of 7 percent obtained at Wednesday's auction.
"About 30 minutes before the close of bidding, rumors swept the market that a few bidders acting on behalf of Middle East interests were planning to take most of the five-year notes," said Andrew J. Schnydrig, a Treasury bond trader at the New York branch of Bank Julius Baer of Zurich. "But the successful auction also had a negative tinge to it. Some in the Street think both sales this week could mean that there will be less aggressive bidding at the refunding auctions."
 
Refunding Auction in May
 On May 7, 8 and 9, the Treasury will hold its quarterly refunding auctions of notes and bonds. The total amount offered is expected to have a record face value of $35 billion or more.
Sentiment was also mixed at the short end of the Treasury maturity spectrum, as market participants tried to fathom the next move by the Federal Reserve. Yesterday, the Fed moved to drain reserves from the banking system for the fifth time in the last six sessions. After appearing at first to again have little impact on the key Federal funds rate, the rate finally moved from 5 13/15 percent to close at 6 percent.
The funds rate, which is what banks charge each other on overnight loans, is the only interest rate that the Fed has a large measure of control over. It is also the rate that banks, among other large financial institutions, charge each other for temporary loans. And it is also considered to be the bedrock cost of credit from which most other interest rates are scaled upward.
At any rate, the discount rate on the Treasury's 90-day bills, which are normally the most sensitive to the funds rate, fell 4 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.60 percent; six-month bills were unchanged at 5.70 percent, and the one-year bills declined 3 basis points, to 5.81 percent.
Following are the details of the Treasury's auction of five-year notes:

HEADLINE: Stocks Fall And the Dow Drops 28.46

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Wave after wave of computerized program selling, and widespread investor concern that interest-rate cuts may be out of the question for a while, toppled stock prices yesterday.
A forecast from Compaq Computer that second-quarter profits would be down this year also contributed to the decline. Compaq's stock price fell 9 3/8, to 52 1/2, and it was the most active stock on the Big Board, with 6.4 million shares changing hands. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 28.46, or almost a full percentage point, to 2,921.04.
Showing that the drop extended broadly across the market, the Standard & Poor's 500 index fell about the same. Over-the-counter stocks, as measured by the Nasdaq composite index, also fell, about half as much.
Trading was at about Wednesday's level, rising slightly to 166.9 million shares from 166.8 million. Sixty-nine stocks rose to 52-week highs, but declines led advances by almost 2 to 1.
 
Computerized Selling
 Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said heavy computerized selling near the beginning and end of the day clipped almost 29 points off the Dow. A 16-minute selling wave immediately after Compaq's forecast of weak profits accounted for more than half the decline.
"I think the market has to churn around for a while," said William S. Stack, chief investment officer for the Lexington Management Corporation. "We don't have any real incentive to push it one way or another. We either need important developments in earnings or movement in interest rates, and I don't think we have news on either one."
Wall Street investment people seemed almost entirely focused on either rates or profits or, in many instances, on both.
In Boston, Robert G. Freedman, chief portfolio manager for John Hancock mutual funds, said the market, which plunged 35 points in the first hour, began with "bad news from Compaq and that set the tone for the day -- which was down."
 
Many Issues Disappoint
 The market, he argued, is "reacting to disappointment in a lot of different stocks and is causing volatility in the marketplace."
As for interest rates, he noted that the Treasury auctioned $9 billion of five-year notes yesterday at an average yield of 7.7 percent, or less than the 7.81 percent in the prior auction last month.
"It's an indication that rates are coming down and that's usually positive for stocks, but it didn't help the market at all."
The conclusion, he said, is that "the market's in a period of consolidation over the next couple of weeks after a strong run and is still waiting for a cut in interest rates."
Even so, he said, "I haven't changed my feeling that the market is still headed higher."
Joseph H. Barthel, investment strategist for W. H. Newbold's Son, said: "The market's been locked in a 150-point trading range between 2,850 and 3,000 since early March. Since then the bullish newletter writers have stayed optimistic while the number of bears has slightly retrenched."
He said he had found in a review of consolidation periods over the last 25 years that the number of bulls typically drops an average of 27 percent while the number of bears climbs 34 percent.
"What that reflects," he said, "is that the market has been too optimistic."
He argued that declining rates have been "the catalyst for advancing stock prices" and "with this prop removed, the market's faced with an exhorbitant number of bulls who have been disappointed and this is prompting the selling."
Other technology stocks weakened. Digital Equipment fell 2 7/8, to 69; Honeywell 2 1/4, to 58 1/4; Intel 2, to 53; Apple Computer 2 1/4, to 58 1/2; Microsoft 2 1/4, to 100 3/4, and Hewlett-Packard 1 3/8, to 53 5/8.
An exception was Sun Microsystems, the most active stock on the Nasdaq list, with 5.6 million shares traded. It rose 4 3/4, to 38 1/4. It rose 1 1/4 on Wednesday after a sharp rise in profits.
UAL hit a 52-week high of 161 1/2 but closed at 159 1/4, down 1/8. The stock dropped almost immediately after its announcement early in the day that it had lost $157 million in the first quarter.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
MURDOCH SELLING 9 U.S. PUBLICATIONS FOR $600 MILLION

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
Rupert Murdoch, the Australian-born publisher whose wide holdings in the United States include New York magazine, 20th Century Fox and several television stations, agreed yesterday to sell most of his magazines in this country for more than $600 million, people involved in the talks said.
The buyer is a partnership controlled by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts, the New York buyout firm that was also involved in the recent purchase of the Bank of New England. 
 As head of the News Corporation, Mr. Murdoch, now a United States citizen, went on an acquisition binge in the 1980's, but the debt he took on along the way has proved a huge burden. In February he had reached agreement with bankers to change the terms on much of his $8.2 billion in debt.
 
TV Guide Is Not in Deal
 Although the agreement with the banks did not specify asset sales, analysts had always assumed that $800 million or more would have to be raised for him to be able to meet his obligations.
The partnership, called K-III Holdings, is buying nine publications, the most profitable of which is The Racing Form, a daily newspaper that has covered thoroughbred racing nationwide with no serious competition.
The other publications are Soap Opera Digest, Soap Opera Weekly, New York, Seventeen, Premiere, European Travel & Life, Automobile and New Woman. Mirabella, the fashion magazine, and TV Guide were not part of the sale, the people said.
 
Heavy Debt Incurred
 The price was fairly low compared with what the magazines might have fetched in the 1980's, but Peter Diamandis, former head of Diamandis Communications, said that given how treacherous the magazine market has been lately, Mr. Murdoch got a decent price.
But if the price was low, Mr. Murdoch had little choice. Like the heads of many other media companies, both domestic and foreign, Mr. Murdoch determined to expand his company internationally in the 1980's, presumably on the theory that only big global companies would prosper. Media executives justified that expansion on the theory that their properties generated so much cash that they could comfortably pay off part of the debt they had incurred, or, if neccessary, sell some properties at ever-rising prices to meet those obligations.
In the United States alone, Mr. Murdoch bought the 20th Century Fox Film Corporation, Metromedia's televison stations, TV Guide, a variety of magazines and book publishers.
But by this year Mr. Murdoch's cash flow was insufficient to meet debt payments and he was forced to sign the agreement with the banks to renegotiate his loans.
To some degree, the theory has proved true that diversification within media would pay off. Fox's movies "Home Alone" and "Edward Scissorhands" were both surprise hits. Because they were relatively low-budget films and were highly profitable, they took some of the pressure off the News Corporation. But not enough to avoid a substantial sale of assets.
And so last month, after much speculation, the magazines were put on the market. Mr. Murdoch, perhaps because he was so aware that in the current economy it would be hard to sell the unsuccessful properties, was determined to sell all the publications as a group.
 
Interest From Other Buyers
 A number of buyers were apparently interested, including Reed International, the British concern that has been expanding its American publishing business and whose properties include Variety, the entertainment trade paper.
But the sale was not easy because a number of Mr. Murdoch's magazines do not make money, according to proprietary data.
Of those that do, The Racing Form is by far the most profitable, having had cash flow last year of $25 million, according to industry estimates.
Soap Opera Digest is also considered a desirable property. Last year it had $15 million in cash flow on sales of $37 million.
 
Magazine Business Struggles
 Mr. Murdoch sold his publications for about 10 times their last year's cash flow, or the cash the magazines generated. That is a relatively low multiple compared with what the publications might have fetched in the 1980's. Mr. Diamandis said the going rate was about seven times cash flow. "In the late 1980's, the multiples were as high as 15 times cash flow," he said.
Soap Opera Weekly is a relatively new publication that is barely making money.
The data on New York magazine reflect not only how difficult the magazine business has become, but particularly how tough the New York market is. Last year the weekly publication had cash flow of $7 million on revenues of $47 million. Its cash flow was down from $9.7 million a year earlier, and its revenues were relatively flat.
On the other hand, some magazines, like Seventeen, have prospered despite new competition from publications like Sassy. The monthly magazine aimed at teen-age girls had cash flow of $9.6 million last year on net revenues of $47 million. That profit was up from $8.4 million a year earlier.
 
Losses for New Publications
 The data also indicate how difficult it is to start a new publication and how long it takes before that publication makes a profit. For example, Premiere, a magazine that covers the movie industry, lost $1.6 million last year on revenues of $14.5 million. Although it continues to lose money, the losses have declined. The previous year it had lost $5 million on sales of $11 million.
European Travel & Life also continues to lose money, having a negative cash flow last year of $984,000. Still, that figure is down sharply from the previous year's loss of $2.4 million, giving some indication that eventually it may become profitable.
Mr. Murdoch did not sell TV Guide, which many industry experts say was Mr. Murdoch's biggest acquisition error. The News Corporation paid $3 billion for a publication considered to have been worth $2 billion or less.
K-III Holdings was formed in February 1989 by Kohlberg, Kravis and several former executives at Macmillan Inc., the publishing and information services company. Since then it has been involved in various acquisitions or proposed acquisitions in publishing. In May 1990 it bought Ward's Communications, which puts out a highly regarded auto industry newsletter, and in December it bought the assets of Field Publications and Funk & Wagnalls.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Trade Bloc War? Concern Grows

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
IS the world economy headed for a split into three warring trade blocs -- Europe, North America and East Asia?
"Not if we succeed in the Uruguay Round," said Jacques Delors, president of the European Commission, during a discussion in New York this week. Named for the country where the current trade negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade began in 1986, the Uruguay Round broke down in December over Europe's refusal to yield to American demands for drastic cuts in farm subsidies. 
 Efforts to get the trade talks back on track are going on. But the most formidable obstacle to their success -- European resistance to lower subsidies -- has not been removed.
Mr. Delors seeks to blame the United States for this. He said he had told President Bush that if the United States continued its "negative" approach, in an attempt to paint the European Community as "the bad guy of the world," the talks would fail. "Bush understands that," Mr. Delors said. "We cannot negotiate under these circumstances."
The Bush Administration regards this as evasion. It denies that it has taken an antagonistic line toward Europe on trade. The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, "has said nothing mean," said her spokesman, Timothy O'Leary. He said Mr. Delors was "trying to divert attention from the real issue -- outrageously high European agricultural subsidies."
Do the American negotiators see any sign that the Europeans are willing to change their position? "There's nothing yet," Mr. O'Leary said. And what about the future? "It will depend on the mood," he said.
But Mr. Delors said he thought there was "a better mood" ahead for discussing agriculture. "I share the fears of many economists and politicians about a world divided into many blocs," he said.
This view represents a growing awareness that the United States is moving to establish its own regional trade bloc and is prepared to take unilateral action against countries that it deems to be discriminating against American exports.
Following the free-trade agreement with Canada, the Bush Administration is moving aggressively to negotiate a wide-ranging free-trade agreement with Mexico. The Administration faces opposition from labor and environmental groups but is being strongly supported by a coalition of business interests favoring the pact and supporting the Administration's request for "fast track" negotiating authority, which requires that trade agreements be voted up or down by Congress without amendment.
Two motions are now before Congress to end that fast-track authority. But President Bush intends to submit a plan to Congress within the next week to protect workers' rights and the environment to safeguard the Mexican agreement and fast-track bargaining authority. The Administration thinks it has too much at stake to let the Mexican agreement fail.
It believes that the deal is the key to stronger economic growth on both sides of the border. And if the Mexican deal goes through, the Administration means to negotiate a similar free-trade arrangement with Chile and later with other Latin American countries.
Skeptics wonder whether the effort to build an American regional bloc makes sense. Prof. Jagdish Bhagwati of Columbia University calls American regionalism "an empty threat" to the European Community.
In a forthcoming article in Foreign Affairs, he declares: "It is not credible that the United States would shoot itself in the foot, and indeed higher up, by sidetracking her energies and her trade to a region whose fragile democracies, inflations, debts and slow growth rates offer a far less attractive market than the burgeoning Far East and the European Community, both of which are even now more substantial markets for American exports. If the United States turns foolishly away from the world to her own backyard, the European Community's likely reaction would be: fine, get buried in it."
That may be an overstatement. There is full awareness, both here and abroad, how vital to the economic growth of every country expanding world trade has been, and what a threat to future growth would be posed by a splitting off of the United States, Europe and East Asia into hostile regional trading blocs.
If the Uruguay Round fails, the largest German bank, the Deutsche Bank, states in its Bulletin, "the current trend toward inward-looking trading blocs will probably accelerate, and trade conflicts will multiply."
No country wants that outcome, knowing that it could breed recession or depression. Regionalism, based on internal free-trade principles, can contribute to the welfare of the Americas, Europe and East Asia, but only if each region is open to other regions and nations.

HEADLINE: Slump in Air Travel Brings Losses at UAL and Delta

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The UAL Corporation and Delta Air Lines, two of the nation's largest airline companies, reported large losses for the first quarter yesterday, reflecting the sharp slide in air travel brought on by the Persian Gulf war and the recession.
UAL, which is based in Oak Grove Village, Ill., and is the parent of United Airlines, said it lost $156.9 million in the three months that ended on March 31. The Atlanta-based Delta said it had lost $84.1 million. 
 Such losses were "pretty much expected," said Thomas Canning, an analyst at the Standard & Poor's Corporation. "It's mostly a function of the weak traffic. People just weren't traveling in the first quarter."
The industry has been hit hard since the Persian Gulf crisis first began last August, inflating fuel prices. Airlines in the United States lost nearly $4 billion last year.
The airlines seem to be doing better now, with traffic picking up and fuel costs somewhat lower than at the peak of the gulf crisis. But much of the traffic was lured back by steep discounts.
The UAL loss is far greater than the $36.4 million the company lost in the first quarter of last year. UAL's revenues rose slightly, to $2.56 billion from $2.51 billion.
"Our dismal first-quarter results were due primarily to a very significant, industrywide reduction in travel following the outbreak of the Persian Gulf war," the chairman, Stephen M. Wolf, said.
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, UAL's stock fell 12.5 cents, to $159.25.
 
Delta's Traffic Growth
 At Delta, Thomas J. Roeck Jr., the chief financial officer, said traffic was up 8 percent in the quarter. The company's loss was in contrast to a profit of $31.3 million, or 48 cents a share, in the 1990 quarter.
He said a large portion of the traffic growth in the first two months of the year came from "discount fare promotions."
Delta, the third-largest United States carrier, after American Airlines and United, said its revenues totaled $2.29 billion, up slightly from $2.12 billion in the 1990 period.
The company's stock rose $1.125, to $71.875, on the Board Board.

HEADLINE: Disney's Quarterly Profits Fall 29%

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 25

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company said today that its earnings for the quarter ended March 31 fell 29 percent as a weak economy and the Persian Gulf war hurt attendance at its theme parks, and box-office flops depressed results from its film division.
Disney said its net income for the quarter, the second of its fiscal year, was $126.6 million, or 95 cents a share, compared with $178.5 million, or $1.29 a share, in the comparable period last year. Revenues for the quarter were $1.44 billion, an increase of 10.8 percent over the period a year earlier. 
 Operating income in the company's theme parks and resorts segment fell 33 percent, to $130.7 million. Revenues in the segment fell 6 percent, to $671.1 million. The company singled out lower attendance at Walt Disney World in Florida, lower occupancy rates at its resort hotels and the costs of expansion as reasons for the decline. Results in the segment were helped somewhat by higher per-capita guest spending, Disney said.
In the film entertainment segment, operating income fell 20 percent, to $46.2 million. Revenues in the segment rose 31 percent, to $613 million. Disney said the drop in income was primarily attributable to the weak box-office performance of two movies, "Scenes from a Mall," a comedy starring Woody Allen and Bette Midler, and "Run," a drama about a student trying to avoid local mobsters.
Disney released its earnings after the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange, where the company's shares closed at $115.125, down $2.875.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Give Vietnam $1 Million; Assistance Is First Since the War

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
The Bush Administration said today that it would provide financial assistance to Hanoi for the first time since the Vietnam War, approving a small but symbolically significant aid package for Vietnamese disabled during the fighting.
The announcement that $1 million would be made available for artificial limbs comes less than a week after the two nations agreed to open an office in Vietnam to resolve the cases of American soldiers missing since the war. It represents one more cautious step in a slow warming of relations that began two years ago.
 
Ties Hinge on Cooperation
 Administration officials reiterated that an initiation of full diplomatic relations or the lifting of a 15-year trade embargo would hinge on Hanoi's cooperation in accounting for all missing American soldiers and in reaching a diplomatic settlement to the civil war in Cambodia. 
 But in the statement announcing the aid, Richard H. Solomon, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, also pointedly expressed appreciation for Vietnam's program of economic reforms.
State Department officials said the Agency for International Development would funnel the $1 million in aid through private American humanitarian groups, which will produce the artificial limbs in Vietnam.
The limbs will go to people who suffered their wounds during the Vietnam War, including soldiers from the North and South Vietnamese armies, members of the Vietcong and civilians.
Officials said the program would be similar to efforts for the disabled in Afghanistan, Uganda and Mozambique. They said they could not estimate how many people would be treated.
"It's a sign of new cooperation," said a State Department official who monitors Vietnam. "But it is not a step toward resuming diplomatic relations." No Government officials will be sent to Vietnam to work on the aid program, he added.
Mr. Solomon told the Senate subcommittee on East Asian and Pacific affairs that the United States had conditionally pledged aid involving artificial limbs and child care in 1987, when Vietnamese and American officials first agreed to work together on accounting for the missing soldiers.
"We have found some improvements in cooperation, but limited results," Mr. Solomon said, "and Vietnam really needs to accelerate unilateral and joint efforts to achieve the results we are seeking."
 
Role of Office in Hanoi
 Referring to the temporary office on M.I.A.'s that will be opened in Hanoi, he said: "It will have no diplomatic or political responsibilities, and should not be seen as a first step in the normalization process. It can, however, help to accelerate normalization once a Cambodia settlement is signed."
The United States still lists some 2,276 Americans as missing or unaccounted for in the Vietnam War. Since August 1987, Vietnam has turned over more than 288 sets of remains, but only 117 have been identified as those of Americans. Most of the others were judged not to be the remains of Americans or could not be identified.
Ann Mills Griffiths, executive secretary of the National League of Families of American Prisoners and Missing in Southeast Asia, said the aid program was "a very positive move," adding: "We are hopeful the temporary office may facilitate greater results. But that is up to the Vietnamese."
Gen. John Vessey, the special envoy to Hanoi on prisoners of war and the missing, has focused on 119 "discrepancy cases" in which the United States believes that soldiers were seen alive after their planes were shot down or they were otherwise separated from their units.
 
Progress in 13 Cases
 Kenneth C. Quinn, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State who is working with General Vessey, told the Senate subcommittee that American-Vietnamese technical teams had made progress in 13 of those cases by digging up remains and retrieving other evidence.
Economic aid to Vietnam has long been a center of controversy. During negotiations with the Carter Administration in 1977, Vietnam insisted that the United States had an obligation to contribute billions of dollars toward the country's postwar recovery.
The Vietnamese based their claim on two documents. One was the Paris cease-fire agreement of 1973, which pledged American support for Vietnam's reconstruction. The second was a letter sent by President Nixon to Prime Minister Pham Van Dong after the cease-fire that reportedly pledged more than $4 billion in food and reconstruction aid.
Neither the Ford nor the Carter Administration accepted Hanoi's argument, maintaining that its invasion of South Vietnam in 1975 broke the cease-fire agreement.
The prospect of diplomatic ties vanished in December 1978, when Vietnam invaded Cambodia to overthrow the Khmer Rouge regime of Pol Pot. But relations slowly began to improve in 1989, when Hanoi removed the last of 140,000 Vietnamese combat troops from Cambodia.
Although Vietnam still provides a considerable number of military advisers to Phnom Penh, the Bush Administration moved to increase cooperation last July by opening talks with Hanoi on ways to make peace in Cambodia.
 
U.S. Licenses Aid Groups
 Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d went a step further that month when he said the Administration would encourage private American groups to offer humanitarian aid to Vietnam. The Administration has since licensed 36 organizations or individuals to provide $4.3 million in relief.
Administration policy drew a good deal of criticism today from both Republican and Democratic senators.
Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts, a Vietnam veteran and a Democratic critic of the Administration's Vietnam policy, welcomed the announcement. But the senator, who will travel to Hanoi next week, suggested that the Administration was "holding the people of Vietnam and our own relationship and our own benefits that we gain from it a prisoner -- not just to our feelings about the Vietnam War, but prisoner also to the Cambodian conflict."
He said the missing soldiers could be more rapidly accounted for if the Administration expanded its trade and communications with Hanoi.
Senator Robert C. Smith, Republican of New Hampshire, asserted in testimony before the subcommittee that United States intelligence agencies had not been aggressive enough in following up "live sighting reports" of American servicemen who could still be alive in Vietnam.
 
Talk of Sighting P.O.W.'s
 Mr. Smith complained that the agencies had "repeatedly denied" Congressional requests to review "first-hand accounts from refugees who say they have seen American P.O.W.'s in captivity in Southeast Asia, some as recently as January 1991."
Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, said he agreed with Mr. Smith. "I'm not criticizing Vietnam as much as I am our own Government," Mr. Helms said, referring to information on the missing servicemen. "I've never heard as much double-talk as I have gotten each time when you try to reason or learn something from our Government."

HEADLINE: Panel Asks Bush to Cite 3 Nations

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
A panel of Cabinet officials has recommended to President Bush that the United States officially cite China, India and Thailand on Friday for tolerating violations of American copyrights and patents, Congressional and Administration officials said today.
Such a move would require the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills to begin a formal investigation and negotiations with each country. It would also authorize, but not require, her to increase duties or introduce other restrictions on imports from these countries if no improvements were made by December or early next year. 
 The United States and American trade associations are concerned about reports that Chinese companies are copying American pharmaceuticals, agricultural chemicals and computer programs without paying any license fees to the inventors. They have also complained that India and Thailand do not protect American patents on pharmaceuticals and copyrights on records, books and movies.
 
Difficulty Seen in Citing China
 The recommendation of the Economic Policy Council, which includes President Bush's top advisers on economic issues, does not guarantee that China will be cited. A former Ambassador to China, the President has made American relations with China his personal responsibility and has resisted sanctions proposed in the past for Chinese human rights violations.
Victoria Clarke, a spokeswoman for the Office of the United States Trade Representative, declined to comment. "There's only one desk officer in this town on China, and that's George Bush," she said.
Wu Jianmin, a spokesman for the Chinese Foreign Ministry, warned the United States today that any punitive measures linked to intellectual property rights would hurt relations with China, The Associated Press reported from Beijing.
 
Decision Near on China's Status
 The decision on whether to cite China for failing to protect American intellectual property rights comes almost two years after the Tiananmen Square massacre and less than six weeks before the President must decide whether to renew China's most-favored-nation trading status. This status, granted in 1980, allows Chinese goods to enter the United States at the lowest tariff rates available for each product.
China's most-favored-nation status is subject to annual renewal by the President with the acquiescence of either house of Congress. When President Bush renewed the status last year, House members angry about Chinese human rights violations voted to cancel the move, but the Senate took no action before going into its summer recess.
President Bush is required to notify Congress by June 3 of any renewal this year. Opponents of most-favored-nation status for China, who have been led by Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, would then have until Sept. 3 to overturn this step.
 
Special 301 Measure
 The action recommended by the Economic Policy Council on Wednesday night would represent the first time that the United States has cited a country under the so-called Special 301 measure. This measure is a section of the nation's trade law that was amended by the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988 to toughen penalties for foreign countries that do not protect American intellectual property rights.
In 1989 and 1990, the United States put several countries -- including China, India and Thailand -- on a list of countries to be monitored for possible failures to protect American copyrights and patents.
The Trade Policy Group, an interagency committee of deputies to the members of the Economic Policy Council, recommended last week to the council that Indonesia also be cited, prompting an unusual burst of lobbying by representatives of the Indonesian Government, a Congressional official said today. Indonesia was not included in the final list of countries recommended by the Economic Policy Council, said the Administration officials, who spoke on condition that they not be identified.
 
Thai Official's Comment
 Indonesian and Indian officials declined to comment. A Thai official who insisted on anonymity said trade negotiations between Thai and American officials at the United States consulate in Amsterdam ended earlier this week without an agreement on intellectual property.
In its recently published annual review of foreign trade barriers, the Office of the United States Trade Representative found that China lacked a copyright law and that a planned law fell short of international standards. The Federal agency also cited industry reports that patented American pharmaceutical and oter chemical products were "being produced in China, without license, for both domestic and export markets."
The report added that "China, in copying these U.S. products, reaps the benefits without incurring the associated costs" of development.
The President's response is imminent because under the Special 301 measure, the United States trade representative, who is part of the President's Executive Office, must identify offending countries within 30 days after issuing its annual report on foreign trade barriers. The report was issued this year on March 29, meaning that the last business day before the deadline is Friday.
 
Discouraging to Investment
 Roger W. Sullivan, the president of the United States-China Business Council, a Washington-based association of American companies with investments in China, said the lack of protection for intellectual property rights there was discouraging investment.
Mr. Sullivan said American executives had told him, "We're not going to go forward with this investment because the guy who supplied us with the process software won't let us go in there."
The trade association has favored the citing of China under Special 301, while continuing to oppose any effort to take away China's most-favored-nation status. "Some of the companies, particularly the larger ones, feel that this is the way to address the real problems, and not the blockbuster approach" of removing most-favored-nation status, Mr. Sullivan said.
 
Wider Charges Against China
 China's image in Congress has declined further in recent months because of its ballooning trade surplus with the United States, allegations that it forces political prisoners to produce products for export markets and concerns about its exports of arms and nuclear technology.
Representative Pelosi plans to introduce a measure next week in the House that would link a renewal of China's most-favored-nation status to its performance on human rights, an aide said today.
The Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman also said today that linking trade ties to human rights would hurt American relations with China, The Associated Press reported.
