HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
U.S. IS SKEPTICAL ON AUTONOMY PACT FOR KURDS IN IRAQ

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
White House officials expressed skepticism today over President Saddam Hussein's accord with Iraqi Kurds and said the Bush Administration was committed to building camps for the Kurdish refugees in northern Iraq.
The American reaction to the Iraqi-Kurdish agreement, announced in Baghdad on Wednesday, paralleled that of the Kurdish refugees themselves. Since their flight to the mountains, the refugees have insisted that they will not return to Iraq until Mr. Hussein is out of power, and they repeated that insistence today. 
 The American skepticism of Mr. Hussein's intentions toward the Kurds became evident when the White House said it had ordered about 300 armed Iraqis to leave the vicinity of Zakho, a northern Iraq town near where coalition forces are setting up a safe haven to resettle Kurdish refugees.
 
Letter to U.N. Delegate
 The order came in a letter delivered on Wednesday to Iraq's delegate to the United Nations, Abdul Amir al-Anbari, by Thomas R. Pickering, the American representative at the United Nations.
Iraq has protested the decision by American, French and British troops to occupy a buffer zone for refugees along the Iraq-Turkey border. But Mr. Anbari told reporters late today that Iraq had agreed to comply with the American order and had removed all but 50 police officers from the town.
Administration officials said they could not confirm Mr. Anbari's statement, and reporters in Zakho said they had seen several hundred armed Iraqis in Zakho as of today. But Pentagon officials said today that some Iraqi police officers might be allowed to remain in Zakho to maintain civil order. Kurds in the area say that the police officers are Iraqi soldiers in disguise, a report that has kept the fearful refugees from leaving the squalor of the mountains.
 
Waiting for a Safe Return
 The Administration says the Kurds' fears for their safety were not allayed by Wednesday's agreement between Mr. Hussein and Kurdish leaders. The preliminary accord reportedly guarantees democratic rule and increased autonomy for Iraqi Kurdistan, and would allow the estimated one million Kurdish refugees to return home in peace.
But Mr. Hussein made similar promises in 1970, they recalled, only to follow them up with ferocious attacks on Kurdish cities during rebellions in 1974, 1988 and again this year.
In remarks to reporters today, a senior Administration official who develops policy on the Kurds said the United States intended to protect hundreds of thousands of Kurdish refugees on both sides of the Turkey-Iraq border until their safe return to their homes could be reasonably assured.
He added that the Administration had no clear idea how that safe return could be negotiated, much less when. In the worst case, he said, it cannot be ruled out that the camps now being built by American and European forces will become "something like the Palestinian refugee camps" operated for years in the West Bank territory occupied by Israel since the 1967 war.
 
Prime Minister Comments
 In Baghdad today, Iraq's new Prime Minister, Saadun Hamadi, insisted that his Government was determined to repair all breaches with its enemies at home and abroad. Mr. Hamadi said that Iraq would rapidly comply with all United Nations terms for the lifting of economic sanctions and that Mr. Hussein had dealt with Kurdish leaders "with sincerity and good intentions."
Asked about the accord between Mr. Hussein and Kurdish leaders, the senior American official expressed doubt that Mr. Hussein could be trusted for long to keep his promise of fair treatment for the Kurds.
"It is in our interest, in everyone's interest, to have the Kurds go back to their homes, but also to go back to some kind of assurance that they will not be persecuted," the official said. "And we're not there yet. If you were a Kurd and had the bitter experience over I don't know how many years, would you just be willing to take Saddam's word on a piece of paper and go home? I think that's questionable."
 
Doubtful of International Help
 The American official said that it appeared unlikely that involvement by the United Nations or neutral powers could be enlisted to enforce the accord between Mr. Hussein and the Kurds because outside involvement would violate Iraq's sovereignty.
Although the United States has fewer objections to international assistance, he said, the question of outside involvement in internal political issues is especially sensitive in other nations, Chief among them are the Soviet Union and China, two members of the United Nations Security Council who are coping with domestic unrest of their own.
The senior official said he was more optimistic that the camps being built near the Turkish border could eventually be turned over to United Nations troops or other non-American supervision, if only because the Soviets and other powers have no desire to see American troops in Iraq for years.
 
Complaints of Iran
 The Pentagon said today that an Air Force C-141 transport would leave Washington on Friday for Teheran, where it would deliver a 145,000-pound load of donated blankets for a million Kurdish refugees in Iranian camps.
The plane will deliver the first shipment of American aid to Iran since the Iran-contra affair of 1985 and 1986, when the Reagan Administration secretly sold weapons to Iran.
Iran has complained bitterly that it has shouldered the bulk of Iraq's refugee problem with little outside assistance, and it called on the Bush Administration Sunday to offer more direct aid to Iran, saying the Kurdish problem was largely the creation of the United States and the gulf war..
The senior official said that the Friday shipment was arranged after the Iranians "suggested some limited help" to the Americans for its Kurdish refugees, but that "the door is not wide open" for further discussions on the refugee situation or any other matter.
 
Cease-Fire Issue
 He also maintained that the United States was not prepared to offer American assistance to some 500,000 Kurds who are reportedly massed at the Iraq-Iran border waiting to enter Iran.
Although the United States has given such assistance to Kurds at the Turkish border, it lacks bases or other facilities close enough to make deliveries to the Iran-Iraq border.
Iraq's compliance with the terms of the cease-fire in the gulf war became an issue again today when the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna said that Baghdad had failed to disclose the locations of its stocks of nuclear-weapons material, one of several United Nations requirements for the lifting of sanctions.
The State Department also told Iraq today that it had no objection to Iraqi crop dusting south of the 36th parallel but insisted that such activities in the Kurdish region north of that line be done by contractors under the supervision of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization. Iraq has asked to dust the crops out of fear that crop failure could contribute to famine in the devastated region.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
New Iraqi Premier Is Asking Improved Ties With Ex-Foes

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 25

 BODY:
Iraq's new Prime Minister, Saadun Hamadi, struck a broadly conciliatory note today, saying the country is moving toward democracy, wants better relations with the coalition nations and will scrupulously meet the United Nations terms for lifting economic sanctions.
In a 90-minute news conference with Iraqi and foreign journalists, the 57-year-old American-trained agronomist seemed to go out of his way to offer an olive branch to his country's former enemies. But he continued to criticize deployment of American troops in northern Iraq to protect Kurdish refugees, saying it is unjustified now that the United Nations is ready to do the job. 
 Speaking in Arabic from the head of an immense conference table seating more than 60 in the Ministry of Information, the Prime Minister said Iraq wanted to restore diplomatic relations with the Persian Gulf war's coalition partners if they would reciprocate by reopening their embassies in Baghdad.
He rejected American complaints that Iraq may have under-reported its stocks of chemical and other weapons to the United Nations, saying Baghdad is determined to comply fully with the Security Council's plan for destroying those weapons, compensating Kuwait and lifting the economic blockade as laid down in Resolution 687.
Iraq, he said firmly, has "no biological weapons or nuclear weapons," and the inventory of weapons of mass destruction that was sent to the United Nations this month "is correct and precise."
"Our primary objective is to implement the Security Council's resolutions," he said.
 
No Information on Zakho
 Asked whether Iraq would comply with the Bush Administration's demand to withdraw its military from the northern town of Zakho, where American troops are establishing a safe haven for Kurdish refugees, Mr. Hamadi said, "I'm not in a position to know about such things, and I can't answer you." At the United Nations, Iraq's envoy said Baghdad would comply with the demand.
Asked if Iraq had abandoned its territorial claim on Kuwait, the Prime Minister took a conciliatory line, saying: "We are looking to the future and want to forget the past. Therefore, I don't like to raise issues that may disrupt the situation now."
He promised that their companies would be welcome to bid for postwar reconstruction contracts in Iraq once the United Nations-imposed trade sanctions have been lifted.
As Iraq is one of the few OPEC oil producers able to increase its output, he pledged that his nation would cooperate with Saudi Arabia in regulating production to insure that the cost of oil rises smoothly in line with inflation if demand picks up later this decade and to prevent an economically disruptive jump in prices.
 
Sanctions Are Assailed
 Only once did Mr. Hamadi appear to take issue with the gulf war allies. Asked whether Iraq can realistically hope for normal relations with the rest of the world while President Saddam Hussein remains in power, he accused the United States and its allies of delaying an end to sanctions to force political change because this suits their interests and not because they object to the Iraqi Government on principle.
The United States, he argued, is traditionally friendly with Israel despite the continued Israeli occupation of Arab lands in violation of the Security Council's resolution. It also works closely with Prime Minister Yitzak Shamir, whom he described as a "well-known terrorist," guilty of "massacres against Palestinians."
He also expressed strong personal loyalty to Mr. Hussein, saying at one point, "I know no one who keeps as firmly to his principles as President Saddam Hussein." He said Iraq's leader was popular and had many historic achievements, which the world would recognize once the crisis was over.
An ascetic-looking man, Mr. Hamadi was appointed to the post of Prime Minister, which the President had previously held, in the wake of Iraq's defeat in the gulf war.
 
Democratic Reform Seen
 The decision to split the two jobs and create a separate Prime Minister and Cabinet is presented by Iraqis as the first step in the country's planned move toward greater democracy and pluralism, which was proposed as early as the 1980's but postponed as a result of the Iran-Iraq war.
The choice of Mr. Hamadi, who is a Shiite Muslim in a country where power has been firmly held by the Sunni minority, is widely seen as an attempt to reassure the restless Shiites in the south.
Mr. Hamadi threw no new light on the emerging political agreement between Baghdad and Kurdish opposition leaders announced last night by Jalal Talabani, head of the Patriotic Union for Kurdistan.
"I'm going to confirm that Iraq is conducting this dialogue with sincerity and good intentions," he said. "The aim is to find an objective, patriotic national solution to the autonomy issue."
Woven through much of what Mr. Hamadi said at the news conference was a classic exposition of the process of political reform that the Government says is getting under way in postwar Iraq.
According to this view, the revolutionary institutions that the ruling Baath Party established after it took power in 1968 are now "evolving into democratic institutions, gradually and practically."

LENGTH: 1405 words

HEADLINE: Auctions

BYLINE: By Rita Reif

 BODY:
Whither Art Prices
Are the prices for contemporary art going up, down or holding firm? 
 That question is among many posed by auctioneers, dealers, collectors and investors who view next week's sales of contemporary art at Sotheby's and Christie's in Manhattan as a barometer of how the market is faring in the recession.
Other questions these experts are asking include: How will auctiongoers respond to next week's evening sessions at Sotheby's and Christie's in which more than half the postwar artworks date from as recently as the 1970's and 80's? And will the record sum of $6.3 million, paid at Sotheby's at the peak of the art boom in 1988 for Robert Rauschenberg's "Rebus," be matched or bettered when the 1955 painting is presented again Tuesday night at the same house?
The contemporary-art auctions are the first in the two-week spring marathon of major art sales, which is expected to bring in a combined total of $174.4 million to $234.7 million. This would be drastically down from a year ago, when the combined total for the May art sales was $924.7 million.
This year's contemporary-art auctions are to take place 12 months after the end of a six-year boom in sales in this field. In the downturn at both houses that began last May and deepened in November, the dollar totals realized at each contemporary-art sale dropped precipitously -- in a few cases to less than half what the auction houses projected these sales would bring. And for the first time since the mid-1980's, the number of unsold properties soared at contemporary-art sales to as much as 50 percent of the works offered.
Because of the poor results of these sales, the economy and the Persian Gulf war, there had been speculation that Sotheby's would move its contemporary-art sale to London. "We never planned to move the New York sale of contemporary art to London -- only the Impressionist art," said David Nash, who heads Sotheby's fine art sales internationally. He said that when the war in the Persian Gulf was well under way in mid-February, he had suggested to Christie's that both houses combine their New York and London sales of Impressionist and modern art, a plan Christie's rejected.
 Both Sotheby's and Christie's say the number of unsold works next week should be lower than at the sales held last May and November. To counter these setbacks, said Lucy Mitchell-Innes, who heads Sotheby's sales of contemporary art in New York, she has organized the house's sale along different lines: "We have taken very little dealer property in this sale. And more than 75 percent of the evening session, and much of the rest of the sale, is from private collectors."
At Christie's, Diane Upright, who heads contemporary-art sales in New York, said: "Substantially more than half the works are from private collectors and are fresh to the market. This was a sale assembled in the middle of the war, when no one knew what would happen in the economy. We sought artworks that were off the market for many years and could be offered with conservative estimates. It's conservative estimates that produce an atmosphere of enthusiastic bidding."
Although no one knows whether the mix of works in these sales will spur buying and stem the proliferation of unsold properties, one thing is certain: the price levels of the art offered is lower, with fewer works expected to sell at or above $1 million and many more properties expected to bring $100,000 or less. The overall totals projected by Sotheby's and Christie's reflect these changes. They are half or a third of what the auction houses estimated the 1990 sales would realize.
Sotheby's two-day auction of postwar art begins at 7 P.M. on Tuesday, offering 74 works that the house expects will total $23.7 million to $32.1 million. The sale, which ends Wednesday, includes 272 items estimated by the house to bring $31.3 million to $42.4 million.
The most-talked-about artwork in next week's sales, Mr. Rauschenberg's "Rebus," is back at Sotheby's, where it was sold for $6.3 million in November 1988 to the Swedish real estate investor Hans Thulin, a price that remains a record at auction for a work by the artist. This time the painting is being sold by order of a Swedish finance company that has not been identified, and was the last painting to be consigned to the sale after the catalogue closed in early March.
"We were asked by the creditor to sell this painting," Ms. Mitchell-Innes said. "Mr. Thulin used the painting as collateral for a loan." The Swedish collector, who paid record prices at auction in the late 1980's for several artworks and two cars, quickly resold a few of them, including a Bugatti Royale 1931 sports coupe that he bought for $9.8 million at Christie's in London in 1987. Last May, Mr. Thulin said he had sold the Bugatti to a Japanese syndicate of businessmen but would not disclose the price he had been paid. Mr. Thulin did not return phone calls placed this week to his offices in Stockholm and Brussels. Before "Rebus" was shipped to Sotheby's, Mr. Thulin sent a blitz of faxes to art dealers in many countries offering to sell the painting for an undisclosed price.
Sotheby's presale estimate on "Rebus," a curiously serene painting splashed with paint, plaster, varnish, graffiti, a torn poster, comics and photographs, is $4 million to $6 million.
The same sale is to offer 30 works from the collection of Charles Saatchi, the British advertising magnate, including Cy Twombly's untitled gray painting from 1969, which Sotheby's estimates will bring $1 million to $1.5 million. The Saatchi holdings are not identified in the catalogue, but Sotheby's has named a number of them and confirmed that many of the sale's 45 properties date to the 1970's and 80's. Among them is Philip Guston's "Edge" from 1976, depicting in black and red a row of sturdily shod feet marching across the 6-by-10-foot canvas. The presale estimate is $700,000 to $900,000.
Among the other Saatchi works that are expected to bring lower prices are two by Jeff Koons -- "Travelbar" from 1986" ($70,000 to $90,000) and an assemblage of Hoover and Shelton vacuum cleaners completed in 1986 ($100,000 to $150,000). In addition, there are two by Susan Rothenberg -- "Cabin Fever" from 1976 ($250,000 to $350,000) and "Squeeze" from 1978-79 ($150,000 to $200,000) -- and Elizabeth Murray's "Sleep" from 1983-84. The Murray is expected to bring $80,000 to $100,000.
At Christie's, most of the value of the two-day contemporary-art auction is in the first session, which is to be held at 7 P.M. on Wednesday. The 54 works, expected by the house to bring $14.8 million to $20.4 million, are part of a two-day sale of 371 artworks that is expected to total $20.9 million to $28.5 million.
Among Christie's most important works is Mr. Twombly's "Near Parnassus," a 1964 dialogue painting of a gray ground from his Rome series that is expected to bring $3 million to $4 million. There are two paintings by Ellsworth Kelly -- "Black Curve IX" from 1976 ($550,000 to $650,000) and "Green White" from 1959 ($300,000 to $500,000).
 
 
The Beatty Collection
 Impressionist and contemporary artworks from the collection of Sir Alfred Chester Beatty, the New York-born mining industrialist, and his son, the late Chester Beatty, is to be auctioned at Sotheby's in late June in London and in November in New York. The Beatty collection -- best known for van Gogh's "Sunflowers," which was auctioned at Christie's in London in 1957 for $39.9 million -- includes 33 works expected to bring more than $20 million. The collections is being sold by the Helen Gertrude Chester Beatty Trust of London, established by the heirs of Sir Alfred's daughter-in-law, who died in 1986.
Among the most important paintings are two by Toulouse Lautrec -- "Bed," from 1898, a bordello scene that may sell for more than $2.5 million, and an 1891 depiction of Mme. Fabre doing her makeup, which may bring more than $5.9 million.

HEADLINE: Judge Holland's Stunning Surprise

 BODY:
Since plea bargains are rarely overturned, the chances that a judge would reject a deal crafted by the Federal Government, the state of Alaska and the world's largest oil company seemed almost nil. On Wednesday, however, Judge H. Russel Holland bravely threw out the agreement ordering Exxon to pay $100 million to settle criminal charges arising from the Exxon Valdez oil spill.
He said the fines were "inadequate" and sent "the wrong message, suggesting that spills are a cost of business that can be absorbed." In effect, he told the Bush Administration to strike a tougher bargain -- which it now can. 
 The original agreement ordered Exxon to pay not only criminal penalties but as much as $1 billion more in civil damages to help restore Alaska's environment. Despite obvious flaws, the settlement was praised by environmentalists and by this page as preferable to a long and chancy trial.
What began to change many minds was the release on April 8 of summaries of 58 scientific studies conducted by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. These summaries suggested far greater environmental damage than originally suspected. The full studies have not been released. Nor have studies of the spill's economic costs -- which, according to some participating economists, could amount to $5 billion or more.
There's no justifiable reason to keep those reports secret. The Justice Department argues that releasing the data now would weaken its case in any future trial. That argument is vastly outweighed by the data's public value -- to inform any new settlement, gauge the fairness of that settlement and, not least, help guide the restoration of Prince William Sound.
The parties now have three choices: a trial, a new fine imposed by Judge Holland, which could cost Exxon as much as $600 million more, or a renegotiated plea bargain. Nobody wants a long trial. A bigger penalty would surely serve as a further, welcome deterrent to industry carelessness. But the best solution would be a tough new deal, embracing both criminal and civil penalties, that would require more up-front money than the leisurely payout provided for in the original bargain and approximate more closely the damages implied in the still-secret reports.

HEADLINE: China's Gulags Deserve No Favors

 BODY:
In the long run, American consumers and Chinese democrats both benefit from the freest possible economic exchanges between the two countries.
China's very low wages translate into cheap import prices for a wide range of toys, clothing and electrical appliances. Hard currency flowing back from the U.S. increases the political leverage of Chinese constituencies favorable to renewed economic and political reform in places like the special economic zones of China's southeast coast. 
 Yet China's hard-line Communist regime confounds this long-term logic with its arrogant contempt for human freedoms and fair economic play. Beijing seems to interpret past Bush Administration indulgence of its appalling human rights record as a license for fresh abuses.
The appropriate American response is for President Bush to strictly condition, or even suspend, China's privileged access to U.S. markets, formally known as "most favored nation" status, when it comes up for renewal later this spring.
The worst abuse is China's shameless exploitation of convict labor for export production. Senator Jesse Helms has been raising this issue for some time, always eliciting stiff denials from Chinese authorities. Now Asia Watch, a New York-based human rights organization, has uncovered official Chinese documents that call for intensified labor camp production, targeted especially at U.S., German and Japanese markets.
American law has long banned the importation of prison-made goods from anywhere. The ideals of free trade can scarcely be fulfilled when labor is in chains. China's vast gulags hold millions. Many of these labor camp inmates are being punished for political offenses, like participation in the 1989 democracy movement. All endure extremely harsh conditions. Extending trade privileges to a gulag economy offends the most basic American values.
As a Communist country that denies its citizens the right of free emigration, China can only qualify for U.S. trade privileges by receiving an annual waiver, initiated by the President and subject to review by Congress.
For the past decade, China has been granted waivers on the reasoning that growing trade relations will bring the Chinese people human rights gains as well as economic benefits. This year, such reasoning will be hard to sustain without gagging on the idea of gulag work gangs.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Fast Track on Trade Speeds Democracy's End;
Stimulus to Cleanup

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Border Boom's Dirty Residue Imperils U.S.-Mexico Trade" (front page, March 31) deserves clarification. You confuse my call for "free trade and a long-term plan for the environment" as supporting the conclusion that "most committed advocates of free trade insist that existing environmental problems should be addressed before free trade becomes a reality."
My position and that of the Border Trade Alliance, which promotes local economic development on both sides of the border, are clear. With the Environmental Protection Agency's assistance, Mexico's counterpart agency has drafted a strong set of environmental regulations. The problem is financial. The funds necessary for infrastructure development and the enforcement of environmental regulations are lacking throughout Mexico, not just in its northern border. The environment is not a trade issue to be included in free trade negotiations. 
 The Border Trade Alliance supports parallel, but separate, discussions of the financial problem. Where market access for United States technology, products, services and investments will improve environmental quality, we recommend that they be included in the free trade agreement. If you combine Mexico's environmental law with ready access for environmental products, services and investment, environmental quality under free trade will improve dramatically.
Contrary to your supposition, the compliance with environmental regulations by United States factories in Mexico, called maquiladoras, sets the standard among Mexico's domestic industries. Pollution did not begin with the maquiladoras.
It is unfortunate that critics of the free trade agreement confuse the problem with the means for a solution. The United States-Mexico border needs new, clean industries, skilled technicians, technology and investment, which generate a tax base from which to finance infrastructure. Free trade will be a significant catalyst for stimulating economic growth in Mexico, creating jobs for thousands of citizens.
In addition, Mexico needs political, social and economic reform, including tax restructuring, environmental consciousness and investment to take a developed nation position on the environment. Defeating free trade portends no solution for the overburdened, underfinanced infrastructure along the United States-Mexico border.
 
WILLIAM F. JOFFROY JR.
Chairman, Border Trade Alliance
Nogales, Ariz., April 9, 1991

HEADLINE: Business Failures Up

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Business failures increased by 53.3 percent in the first quarter, the biggest rise in seven years, the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation reported yesterday.
The business researh company said services and retail trade suffered the worst, a typical situation during a recession. The company said 20,811 businesses failed in the first quarter, compared with 13,577 in the first quarter of 1990. 
 "Every region and every major industry sector, with the exception of mining, posted a sizable increase in failures in the first quarter," said Joseph W. Duncan, the company's corporate economist.
Failures in the services sector jumped 58.7 percent, to 5,437, from 3,425 a year earlier. Retail trade failures increased 32.5 percent, to 4,109 from 3,101.
Many companies that serve businesses failed as large businesses cut back on their use of outside companies, Mr. Duncan said.
Financial services and real estate companies continued to fall victim to a depressed real estate economy. The category recorded 1,256 companies, a 43 percent rise from a year earlier.
Construction companies posted a 48 percent rise in failures, with 2,849 concerns going out of business in the quarter.
More than 1,300 businesses failed in New England, more than double the number in the 1990 quarter and the biggest rise in any region.

HEADLINE: New Stance on Car Sales

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 26

 BODY:
The president of the National Automobile Dealers Association urged auto makers today to increase cash rebates and offer lower financing rates to stimulate car sales.
Frank Anderson Jr., president of the association, said, "The time has come to jump-start car and truck sales, even if it takes short-term measures we don't like and have traditionally opposed, like consumer rebates and interest subvention programs." 
 Mr. Anderson's comments were in a speech delivered today to a group of Chevrolet dealers in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. A text of the speech was released by the association.
His statements today represent a shift in position for the association. The group has opposed rebates and low-interest loans offered by the car companies "because they take the dealer out of the merchandising process," Mr. Anderson told the dealers today.
The change comes as many dealers are in dire financial situations. Last year, 900 dealers went out of business, according to the association, which represents 25,000 dealerships. Sales of cars and light trucks in this year's first quarter were 11.4 percent below the level in the 1990 quarter.

 BODY:
America West Airlines said today that it lost $49.9 million in the first quarter because of the Persian Gulf war, the recession and high jet fuel prices.
Al Frei, America West's chief financial officer, called the quarter "the most severe operating environment in U.S. aviation history" and said the loss industrywide was about $4 billion over the last six months.

HEADLINE: Beauty Salon Magazine Fails

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Whittle Communications is suspending publication of its American Style magazine for beauty salons because of sluggish advertising demand, the company said yesterday.
The fourth issue of the magazine, which was started last fall and was published every other month, will be its last. It was distributed to 140,000 beauty salons nationwide. 
 "American Style was a big idea at the wrong time," said Peter Finn, publisher of American Style. "We gave it our best shot, but current economics and the national downturn in the print industry proved too much for us."
The decision represents a rare setback for Whittle, based in Knoxville, Tenn., but American Style is not the first media casualty in the beauty parlor market.
Murdoch Magazines called off a planned video service for beauty salons before it started last summer because of worries that advertising support might not be available. The publishers of Confetti magazine halted publication of their monthly beauty salon magazine in February after a major backer withdrew his support.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Moves Up Slightly on Mixed Economic Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar edged aimlessly higher yesterday as traders absorbed mixed messages about the United States economy and interest rates ahead of this weekend's meeting of world monetary officials.
Gold fell slightly in New York but was mixed overseas. On the Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $353.90 an ounce, down 10 cents from late Thursday. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $353.50, also off 10 cents from late Thursday. 
 Currency trading was extremely quiet in the absence of major factors.
The Commerce Department reported a second consecutive decline in gross national product; the decline was worse than some analysts had expected, but the currency market took the news in stride.
The report said the economy shrank at an annual rate of 2.8 percent in the quarter. The drop in gross national product, the total output of goods and services, outpaced the 1.6 percent rate of decline recorded from October through December.
Traders were also relatively unmoved by an apparent sign of higher inflation in the report's inflation gauges. One gauge, a price index that measures a fixed basket of goods, increased at an annual rate of 5.1 percent in the first quarter -- up from a 4.7 percent rise in the fourth quarter.
"The G.N.P. report was a classic mixed bag. For the dollar market, it very quickly was just thrown out the window," said Jerry Egan, chief dealer at the Bank of Boston.
Market participants largely focused on this weekend's meeting in Washington of monetary officials from seven leading economies. President Bush was scheduled to meet with the finance ministers and central bankers on Sunday.
Dollar traders were concerned by remarks made yesterday by Karl Otto Pohl, head of the German central bank, indicating he wanted to keep German monetary policy tight.
Stronger interest rates in overseas markets generally help currencies competing against the dollar.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a close of 137.83 yen, from 137.87 on Thursday. Later in London, it rose to 138.15 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 138.10 yen, up from late Thursday's 137.85 yen.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.6860, from $1.6935 late Thursday. Sterling also lost ground in New York, where a pound cost $1.6905, down from $1.6915 late Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.7510 German marks, up from 1.7490; 1.4766 Swiss francs, up from 1.4670; 5.9110 French francs, up from 5.8995; 1,294.00 Italian lire, up from 1,291.00, and 1.1523 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1532.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Lifted by Late Rise in Futures

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
A late rally lifted prices of long-term Treasury bonds yesterday, while the intermediate and shorter maturities remained narrowly mixed. Dealers attributed the late turnabout to an advance in prices of Treasury bond futures in Chicago in the last hour of trading there. The Chicago bond futures market closes at 3 P.M., Eastern time.
Earlier in the session, both cash and futures prices had been under pressure from the start of trading. At that time the Government had reported that the first-quarter gross national product had declined by 2.8 percent on an annual basis, following a decline of 1.6 percent in the last quarter of 1990.
 
Increase in Inflation
 Ordinarily, this latest sign of a weakening economy would have benefited the markets in bonds and other fixed-income debt issues because it would mean less upward pressure on inflation and interest rates. But the first-quarter data also showed that inflation, the bane of the fixed-income market, had increased to 5.1 percent at an annual rate, from 4.7 percent in the fourth quarter of 1990. 
 In late trading, the Treasury's benchmark 30-year long bonds were offered at 96 9/32, up 9/32, while the yield fell to 8.20 percent, from 8.23 percent the day before and 8.24 percent a week ago. Earlier, in Chicago, the spot June bond futures closed at 96.7, up 10/32 on the day and 17/32 for the week.
"As is often the case, the cash bond market followed the lead set by the Chicago bond futures," said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president and credit market specialist at Dean Witter Reynolds. "Significantly, much of the late buying in Chicago was short covering, which usually indicates a shift in market sentiment. Aside from the G.N.P. data, there was no other news of consequence."
One explanation for the change in sentiment, Mr. Sullivan continued, was the belief that some of the Group of Seven industrialized nations meeting in Washington this weekend will resist efforts to lower the value of the dollar. While a strong dollar often has a negative impact on exports, it does make dollar-denominated securities more attractive. The dollar closed the week on a firm note, which may also have contributed to the late rally.
"The late rally may have also reflected expectations of a sharp rise in unemployment when the April jobs data are released next Friday morning," Mr. Sullivan added.
The Federal Reserve, for its part, drained reserves from the banking system for the sixth time in the last seven sessions to prop up the key Federal funds rate, which banks charge one another for temporary loans. At the time of the draining, the funds were trading at 5 15/16 percent, or slightly below the Fed's perceived target of 6 percent. Later, the usual pre-weekend lessening of demand for funds caused the rate to slip down to 5 7/8 percent.
Among the shorter Treasury maturities, discount rates on bills were slightly higher. The Treasury said it would auction $11.75 billion of new one-year bills on Thursday.
In the note sector, prices rose from 1/32 for the two-year issue to as much as 3/32 for the 10-year issue.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%); 

CITY: CHICAGO, IL, USA (89%);

HEADLINE: Washington Presses Japan to Open Construction Jobs

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
After several years of diplomatic fencing, Japan and the United States traded harsher jabs today over American access to the Japanese construction market.
The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, began a legal process that could result in Japanese companies being barred from many Federal and federally funded construction projects in the United States, beginning on June 1. 
 A Japanese negotiator who insisted on anonymity said that if the sanctions go into effect, Japan will retaliate by suspending its current program of giving preferential treatment to foreign companies on 17 big public works projects. But he said considerable progress had been made recently in negotiations and insisted that the American sanctions would probably never go into effect.
 
3 Nations Cited

An American official who also insisted on anonymity agreed that some issues were being resolved. The Japanese Government offered today to expand the preferential treatment program to certain other projects, he said, while adding that the sanctions would go into effect if remaining differences were not addressed.
Mrs. Hills today also officially cited China, India and Thailand for tolerating violations of patents, trademarks and copyrights. This could result in duties or other restrictions on imports from all three countries.
She said President Bush approved of the decision to name China. The President, a former chief of the American liaison office in China, resisted sanctions after the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989.
Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, who led a push in Congress for citing the three countries, said he was "very pleased" with their designation.
 
A Hardening Stance

Mrs. Hills's moves reflect a hardening of the Administration's stance on trade and a new willingness to take unilateral action against countries perceived as treating American businesses unfairly.
The collapse of negotiations last winter in Brussels for a new global round of tariff reductions has cleared the way diplomatically and legally for the more aggressive stance. The American trade laws pertaining to economic sanctions permit less action to be taken when foreign countries are proceeding in good faith with bilateral or multilateral negotiations.
The move against Japanese construction companies comes five years of increasingly acrimonious disputes over the tiny share of Japanese public works contracts that are awarded to American companies.
The Japanese Government has maintained that the limited success of American firms reflects their lack of experience in the Japanese market. American trade negotiators have maintained that American firms are excluded deliberately.
Today's move was partly symbolic, because Japanese companies do little work on Federal and federally funded projects in the United States. In 1989, Japanese companies won contracts worth $2.8 billion in an American market worth $435 billion, said Elizabeth Dugan, a spokeswoman for the Commerce Department.
But Federal projects accounted for only $14 billion of the market, and Japanese companies won only $100 million worth of contracts for these projects, she said.
By comparison, the Japanese construction market is variously estimated at $300 billion to $550 billion, with American companies claiming only $300 million a year.
The proposed regulation would bar Japanese companies from public works projects that receive money from the Energy, Transportation and Defense departments and from the Bureau of Reclamation in the Interior Department. Appropriations for these projects amount to at least $21 billion this fiscal year, Mrs. Hills said.
 
 Problems in Europe

The procurement practices of the European Community and three of its members -- Germany, France and Italy -- are also causing concern and are now the subject of negotiations, Mrs. Hills said.
John R. Tucker, president of AEG Westinghouse Transportation Systems Inc., a Pittsburgh-based maker of mass transit equipment, said Japan had raised a series of obstacles to American construction companies. Japanese criticisms of American safety and tidiness practices, he said, are only the latest in a series of smokescreens thrown up to obscure a refusal to do business with American companies.

HEADLINE: Federated Will Offer a Reorganization Plan

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Fifteen months after entering bankruptcy, Federated Stores Inc. will ask a Federal judge on Monday to approve a reorganization plan that would offer cash and notes worth 100 cents on the dollar to the unsecured creditors of seven of its store groups, including Bloomingdale's, according to creditors and executives close to the company.
The plan also provides for an offer of Federated common stock to unsecured creditors of Abraham & Straus, another New York store division, and of the Lazarus stores in Ohio, they said. 
 All told, Federated has $7 billion in debt, and hopes to eliminate it all through these offers.
In effect, the offer to the unsecured creditors of the seven store subsidiaries represents a 100 percent payback over three to five years, these people said. The notes involved will be interest-bearing term notes. The offer will be made to the unsecured creditors of Bloomingdale's, New York; Burdines, Miami; Rich's Inc., Atlanta; Jordan Marsh, Boston; Maas Brothers, Tampa, Fla.; Bon Marche, Seattle, and Stern's, Paramus, N.J. The unsecured creditors are mostly suppliers and service companies like advertising agencies. It was not clear what the plan held out for Federated's secured creditors, primarily its banks.
The offer to the A.& S. and Lazarus creditors has an undetermined value at this time, because the approximately one million shares of Federated stock to be offered to them have no market value until the company emerges from its Chapter 11 bankruptcy and goes public. The one million such shares were authorized by Federated Stores, the American holding company for the Campeau Corporation, of Toronto, which owns the nine store groups in the United States. But those shares were never issued.
Carole Sanger, vice president for communications at Federated's headquarters in Cincinnati, said the company did not comment on speculation. Other unsecured creditors familiar with the plan said that industry reports of an arrangement of 50 percent cash and 50 percent notes for the seven subsidiaries was not correct because it had been changed from a week ago. However, the retail executives familiar with the plan's contents said yesterday that they had not been informed that the ratio had been changed.
The retail executives familiar with the plan said details were still being changed. But the basic framework, calling for cash and notes to certain creditors and equity to others, was expected to remain.
Creditors reacting yesterday to the present form of the reorganization plan expressed a variety of opinions. Some wanted to wait for a fully refined plan because the basic one they had seen had too many loopholes. Some said they were encouraged by it in general terms. One area of potential controversy was said to be the precise maturity period for the interest-bearing notes. Another would be some clarification of the value of the Federated equity to be offered to the A.& S.-Lazarus creditors. A third issue to be resolved was the ratio of the contemplated exchange of bonds to equity.
Federated Department Stores and the Allied Stores Corporation, which respectively own five and four of the store groups, went into Chapter 11 bankruptcy on Jan. 15, 1990, along with all the store divisions. Campeau had bought Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988. The Federated Stores Inc. name was created for the American holding company.
Although all subsidiaries and divisions were profitable, the high debt created by the takeover compelled the American stores to seek court protection from their debts.
The basic plan, if approved by the court in Cincinnati, is expected to be altered and refined for at least six months, the retailers said, with the reorganization beginning no sooner than the end of Federated's fiscal year on Jan. 31, 1992. Toward the end of the first quarter ending in April, they said, Federated would go public and the authorized shares would then assume some form of market value.
The differences in the proposed settlements to creditors of the seven store groups under Federated and Allied and the two divisions of Federated stem from the fact that the two groups had varying ownership and corporate affiliations with Campeau.
Federated's business plan, announced in October, has largely been scrapped, according to Kurt Barnard, a New York analyst and publisher of a retail marketing newsletter under his name. "The recession and consumer retrenchments have sobered Federated management into recognition that consumer buying and strengthening competition may be more damaging than first assumed," he said.

HEADLINE: MAGAZINES MURDOCH IS SELLING, AND ONE HE IS NOT;
New York Magazine Hurt by City's Slump

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
New York magazine, perhaps the best-known city magazine, has seen better days.
With the New York economy in a tailspin, the magazine's total advertising pages dropped from 3,126 in the 1989 fiscal year to 2,905 in the 1990 fiscal year. Indeed, it has only been through aggressive increases in the price charged per ad page that the magazine has stemmed some of the decline in ad revenues, and it is only through continued such increases that it expects to turn ad revenues around by the 1992 fiscal year. 
 "How has New York been doing over the last couple years?" asked Judith Price, president of rival Avenue magazine, referring to the city's economy. "Pretty lousy. That's the problem."
Financial documents that were circulated to potential buyers last year show the magazine produced $7 million in cash flow on revenues of $48 million in the 12 months that ended June 1990, for a 15 percent margin.
"That's very low for a local magazine," said Robert A. Cohen, president of a New York magazine consulting company that bears his name. Typical operating margins are 20 to 30 percent, he said.
"New York magazine, like all local regional magazines," he said, "is suffering from a near-collapse of the retail advertising market and I would imagine that it has lost tens of millions of dollars of value versus what it could have been sold for three years ago."
 
One's Loss, Another's Opportunity
 While the slippage at the magazine is a loss for Rupert Murdoch, its current owner, it represents a buying opportunity for Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, which on Thursday agreed to buy New York and eight other publications from Mr. Murdoch.
This year, the magazine's forecast calls for $9.8 million on revenues of $49.2 million, and next year $11.9 million on revenues of $54 million. Those snapshots appear to have been taken before charging the magazine for its share of the overhead costs borne by Mr. Murdoch's organization, like interest costs. Depending on the size of those costs, it is possible the magazine was even less profitable to Mr. Murdoch than the documents suggest.
Media experts also questioned whether the magazine would in fact see the projected recovery even with, as Mr. Murdoch's investment bankers suggest, the recent demise of 7 Days and Manhattan,inc.
"There are so many high-end books in New York; it's a crowded market, and then with the intrusion of VCR's, people don't have time to read a thick book each week," said Paul DuCharme, director of print media at Grey Advertising.
For all the bad news, media experts said the magazine had other lures for a potential owner, like the weekly window it offers into an affluent, mostly New York audience of 1.6 million readers. On the surface, its paid circulation has held steady at 430,000, but lately those figures have been helped by a costly increase in copies given away to airlines.
Ms. Price of Avenue magazine is highly respectful of the product and its longtime editor, Edward Kosner. "He's a trend surfer," she said. "He's able to smell and spot trends, and that's what made New York magazine."
Although people close to the buyer said the magazine was not for sale, there was talk of interest by other publishers.
One contender was squelching the rumors.
 "That's totally inaccurate," said Morton Zuckerman, the media executive who already owns U.S. News & World Report and The Atlantic. He acknowledged that he was part of a group that had sought to buy three publications -- New York, Premiere and Automobile -- from Mr. Murdoch.
Though his group lost out to a $650 million or so package proposed by the Kravis group, media experts were abuzz yesterday about whether Mr. Zuckerman might get a second shot should Henry R. Kravis choose to sell a few of his new purchases to reduce the cost of his acquisition or his debt.
Mr. Zuckerman was nonetheless skeptical yesterday that Mr. Kravis would part with the influential New York property. "They will remain the owner," he said.

HEADLINE: Corner of Connecticut Is Foundering as Its Lifeline, the Navy, Scales Back

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GROTON, Conn., April 24

 BODY:
Here in the self-proclaimed Submarine Capital of the World, home of the nation's largest submarine builder and the Navy's largest submarine base, the local economy is declining slowly and may soon reach levels not seen since the demobilization that followed World War II.
A combination of military-related plant closings, work force reductions and job transfers out of state are expected to shatter the economic base in southeastern Connecticut and neighboring Rhode Island. 
 Though many areas of the country are expected to be hit hard by base closings and weapons cutbacks, few are likely to suffer as much as Groton, New London and the 19 other towns in New London County, which depends more on military spending than almost any other area of the country.
"Catastrophe isn't too strong a word," said Barton W. Whitman, a vice president of Aquidneck Management Associates, a 40-employee consulting firm supported in large part by contracts from the Naval Underwater Systems Center.
"We're talking about an unemployment rate for the area that might run between 20 and 25 percent," he said.
Business and governmental officials fear not only Depression-era unemployment rates but quick drops in the area's real-estate market, banks and retail businesses.
The economic effects, which would only worsen the state government's chronic revenue shortfalls, might also force town governments to raise property taxes. "Electric Boat is 17 percent of our tax base," said C. Richard Foote, the town manager of Groton.
Military spending per capita is about $9,500. Sixty percent of the 110,000-person labor force is engaged in military-related work, and $1.6 billion of the county's $2.1 billion annual payroll comes from military spending. "The engine that runs the machine in this county is defense," said William D. Moore, president of the Southeastern Connecticut Chamber of Commerce.
Electric Boat, the largest employer in southeastern Connecticut and the state's second largest after United Technologies, another military contractor, is expecting to learn the fate of its bid for a $2 billion Seawolf submarine contract within the next two weeks. If the company loses, it may close. If it wins, it probably will still pare its work force from 22,000 to 11,000 by 1995, a response to the Navy's plans to cut its future submarine fleet by more than half.
Meanwhile, across the Thames River in New London, 800 to 1,100 of the 1,495 jobs at a Navy research laboratory, the Naval Underwater Systems Center, will probably be transferred to Newport, R.I. The reassignments, part of the plan proposed this month by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to close 31 military bases, will probably start in October and go on for five years.
Further darkening the economic outlook here are transfers and decommissionings at the Navy submarine base in Groton, where the number of personnel is expected to drop from 14,000 to 10,100 by 1996. And in nearby Montville, the Department of Energy is gradually shutting down the UNC Naval Products plant, which employs 1,060 people and makes reactors for submarines. In Rhode Island, Electric Boat has 4,000 workers at its Quonset Point shipyard.
 
'Going to Be a Ghost Town'
 Last month, a study conducted by Regional Economic Models of Amherst, Mass., projected that New London County, with a population of about 255,000, will lose between 13,000 and 27,000 jobs by 1996 because of military cuts. It also estimated that the population will decline by 24,000, the average annual wage will fall by $3,000 and up to half of the disposable income in the region will disappear.
"This is going to be a ghost town," said Emma Devlin, who for the last 27 years has owned Hughie's restaurant, two blocks from the Naval Underwater Systems Center in New London.
Electric Boat, a division of General Dynamics of St. Louis, is the region's economic linchpin. The company has experienced the boom-and-bust cycles associated with war and peace before, particularly in the late 1940's and early 1950's, before the development of the nuclear submarine. In those days, it was forced to diversify and created products like the device that automatically clears pins from bowling alleys.
 
Working on First Seawolf
 Neil D. Ruenzel, director of communications at Electric Boat, said the company's reductions stem from the Navy's decision to reduce the number of Tridents from 24 to 18 and the next generation of nuclear submarines, the $2 billion Seawolf, from 29 to 11. Electric Boat won all the Trident contracts and is now building the last. It is also working on the first Seawolf.
He noted that the Navy now plans to build only one Seawolf per year, not three. Electric Boat would have to seriously consider closing if it does not win the contract each year, he said, because the cost of retooling after a year without a contract would make the company unlikely to win future bids. Unlike its competitor in Newport News, Va., which also builds aircraft carriers, Electric Boat makes only submarines.
Newport News was expected to win the second Seawolf contract in March. But Navy officials, pressured by Connecticut's Congressional delegation and Electric Boat executives, delayed a decision last month to further study the effects of a stripped-down submarine fleet on the two shipyards and the competitive bidding process.
Business and civic leaders in the Groton-New London area worry that the Virginia Congressional delegation wields far more political clout than Connecticut's. The county's Representative, Sam Gejdenson, a Democrat from Bozrah, has also become a frequent target of local criticism because of his lack of support for the military build-up during the 1980s.
Mr. Gejdenson noted, though, that the unemployment rate for the New London area for February may have been the highest in nine years, but was the same as the national average, 6.5 percent. He also attributed the approaching crisis to the area's failure to diversify its industry.
Indeed, little local foresight is evident, particularly among the workers in places like the Sub Cafe in New London and the Nautilus Barber Shop in Groton. "I don't think anything is going to happen," said Kenneth H. Levine, an electrical mechanic for seven years at Electric Boat, which was founded 90 years ago as the nation's first submarine maker. "This place has been here forever."
Some diversification is underway. The Mashantucket Pequot Indian casino is slated to open this fall in Montville. Some think that's too little, too late. "You're replacing 1,500 engineers with 1,500 croupiers," said John C. Markowitz, president of Sonalysts, a sonar research concern in Waterford.
In the meantime, a coalition of county business leaders is trying to pressure the Navy into awarding the Seawolf contract to Electric Boat.
They are also airing public service announcements on local radio and television. The commercials, which have been criticized by some for their gloominess, show a field of tombstones, each carved with the name of local military contractor. In the background, a ship's bell faintly tolls.

HEADLINE: Apollo Theater Wins Reprieve on Repayments

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 26

 BODY:
The landmark Apollo Theater, which was scheduled to close on June 1 because of severe financial problems, won some breathing room today when its state and private lenders declared a six-month moratorium on loan repayments.
During that period, the lenders will try to renegotiate the Harlem theater's financing in an effort to protect the state's investment of $9 million and to save the stage where performers like Sarah Vaughan and Dionne Warwick began their careers. 
 Percy E. Sutton, the former Manhattan Borough President who is the largest investor in the group that operates the Apollo, said in a statement that he might convert the group into a nonprofit institution so the theater could receive tax-deductible contributions.
In exchange for declaring the loan moratorium, the state's Urban Development Corporation, which is the Apollo's largest lender, won the right to hire a consultant to study how the theater might be managed more effectively.
The $16.5 million renovation of the historic theater was plagued by cost overruns and management problems during its construction phase from 1983 to 1988. It now is troubled by insufficient bookings and high insurance and utility costs.
 
War of Words

A particular problem has been the financial performance of a new video studio that has produced less than half its anticipated revenue, said Vincent Tese, the state's Director of Economic Development and the chairman of the Urban Development Corporation.
In the last two days, the fight to save the Apollo has been accompanied by a war of words between state economic development officials and William Stern, Mr. Tese's predecessor as chairman of the Urban Development Corporation.
Mr. Stern was quoted in New York Newsday on Thursday as saying that the state's efforts to keep the Apollo afloat, including Mr. Tese's anticipated decisions to declare the moratorium and to cut the interest rate on the corporation's loans to 4 percent from 8 percent in 1986, were "a kind of welfare."
Mr. Stern, who left state government in 1986 and is now a private investor in New York City, said today that he was using the term generically to refer to government-financed economic development projects that make use of grants and low-interest loans rather than marketplace incentives like tax breaks.
 
Criticism of Remarks

Because the Apollo is in Harlem and because Mr. Sutton and his fellow investors are minorities, state officials and Apollo investors have portrayed his remarks as racist.
"The state's Economic Development Office looks for places to invest that will create jobs and economic opportunity," said Harold Holzer, a spokesman for the Urban Deveopment Corporation. "We do it in Buffalo. We do it in Albany. We do it in Harlem. It's peculiar, to say the least, that he would pick out a project in a minority community and call it welfare."
Mr. Stern fired back today that the economic development officials were battling him rather than addressing problems in the loan program.
"Welfare is a perfectly legitimate word," he said. "We can't get into this politically correct language. But the idea is that this was a hit, so they'll hit me back. That's the way they do it. I know, because I used to be on the inside."
The Apollo renovation was financed primarily by the corporation, by Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and by the Federal Government. The theater, which opened in 1934, reopened in 1988 after having been closed for 10 years.
In a complex lease-purchase arrangement, Mr. Sutton's Apollo Theater Investor Group leases the theater from a corporation subsidiary known as the Apollo Theater Redevelopment Corporation.
To allow the theater to establish financial stability, the state allowed the investor group to defer making lease payments until March 1, 1991.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 8.66; Loss for Week at 53.21

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
A depressing report on the state of the economy, although much as expected by Wall Street, brought the bond market down initially yesterday, and stocks followed.
For most of the day, stocks fell when bonds fell and rose when bonds rose, but by the end of the session bonds ended narrowly ahead while stocks closed narrowly lower. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell to 2,912.38, down 8.66 on the day and 53.21, or 1.8 percent, for the week.
Trading slowed from 166.9 million shares on Thursday to 153.9 million yesterday, the quietest in three weeks. Declines led advances by 859 to 672 but 62 stocks reached new highs. Four fell to new lows.
 
 Further Drop for Compaq
 Compaq Computer, which slid by 9 3/8 on Thursday after forecasting a drop in second-quarter profits, fell 1 5/8 more yesterday, to 50 7/8.
Michele Preston of Cowen & Company recommended that investors switch to Lotus Development, a producer of personal computer software. Lotus promptly rose 2 1/8, to 34 3/8.
Figures compiled by Birinyi Associates showed that even professional program trading had little effect on the market. Despite waves of computer-driven buying and selling, the activity raised the Dow less than 4 points.
Traders attributed the week's sluggishness to disappointments over earnings and signs that the economy was not weak enough to prompt the Fed to bring interest rates down.
Uncertainty over both has kept many investors on the sidelines, traders said.
Even yesterday's figures seemed inconclusive. They showed that the gross national product, the total output of goods and services, slid at an annual rate of 2.8 percent in the first quarter. Traders said the drop came fairly close to what many economists had expected and thus had only a minor impact on the market.
Greg A. Smith, chief investment officer at Prudential Securities, said in his current newsletter, published well before the G.N.P. data were released, that "a surprisingly weak economy is possible" and that "there are some indications of some slippage in consumer confidence."
He added, "About the only definite conclusion I can come to at this stage is that it doesn't appear very clear what kind of recovery we may or may not be experiencing."
 
'Back and Forth All Day'

"The market's been back and forth all day," said David S. Chao, head trader in New York for County NatWest Securities. "It took its cue from the bond market after the G.N.P. numbers came out."
Still, he added, "stocks have been pretty listless the last couple of days."
In his weekly newsletter, Charles I. Clough Jr., chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company, said he would be "reluctant to chase" groups that have done well but also have "questionable long-term fundamentals." He mentioned regional banks with heavy debt, textile and apparel companies, specialty stores and home builders. He singled out energy and utility stocks as "current values."

HEADLINE: Proposal to Link Airports by Rail Is Dealt Setback

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
A plan for a rail link to whisk passengers between La Guardia and Kennedy International Airports is unraveling because, transit officials say, a study has found that not enough passengers would use it to justify its more than $2 billion cost.
The study, commissioned by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, has led the various transportation agencies that had hoped to ease congestion around the airports to reconsider or withdraw their support of the plan, officials said yesterday. 
 The airports handle more than 54 million passengers and 1.5 million tons of cargo a year. But the panel that conducted the study estimated that only 1,200 passengers a day travel between La Guardia and Kennedy. In addition, they said private investors would be unlikely to offer financial support -- in return for development rights or tax abatements -- despite the easy access the rail link would create for sites along its route, such as Shea Stadium and Jamaica Center in Queens.
 
The Proposal Is Downgraded
 Officials of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which oversees the regional commuter railroads and the city subways and buses, said that as a result of the study's findings the project had become a lower priority for their agency.
And the New York City Department of Transportation said it would prefer concentrating on short-term solutions to reducing traffic congestion around the airports while considering other airport access routes.
"The fact is that this probably means that it slips in terms of priority on several investment agendas, including ours," said Gregory Johnson, the director of planning for the M.T.A. "But airport access of some sort does sit somewhere on the agenda because the two airports are gateways to the national and international markets and therefore critical to the region's taking a role in global competitiveness."
When the M.T.A. announced the rail-link proposal in March 1990, using the rights of way along the Van Wyck Expressway and Grand Central Parkway, it was touted as a tool to spur economic development along the route.
 
Panel Urges an Alternative
 But in the report commissioned by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which is responsible for the airports, a panel of experts on urban development concluded not only that there was little private interest in development along the route, but that an aiport link would have few riders and would be economically unfeasible.
Instead the panel, which was convened by the Urban Land Institute, a nonprofit research organization that studies land-use issues, recommended concentrating on separate links between Manhattan and the two airports.
According to the report, about 25,000 people a day travel between Manhattan and La Guardia and 17,000 between Manhattan and Kennedy.
Port Authority officials said the figure of 1,200 a day traveling between the airports was too low and stressed that the report was undergoing revisions. "There's not enough meat here to formulate any conclusions about feasibility yet," said David Z. Plavin, the director of aviation for the authority.
 
One Conclusion Anticipated
 Mr. Plavin also said the conclusions reached by the panel about potentially low ridership and the lack of interest from private investors were expected.
"Supporting the alignment with development rights, yes, that's something we would like to have happen," he said. "But I don't think any of us assumed that was going to be a significant contribution to the system."
But other transit officials said they were disappointed by the panel's findings on development potential.
The proposed line would tie the central terminals at Kennedy and La Guardia along the Van Wyck Expressway and Grand Central Parkway, and transit officials were hoping the prospect of reinvigorated development around stations at Shea Stadium, a stop on the No. 7 subway line, and Jamaica Center, where the Long Island Rail Road stops, would induce private investment.
The report said the Port Authority, as the agency charged with operating the airports, should assume the lead role in developing and financing public transport to the airports.
But Mr. Plavin said the region's transportation agencies must share the responsibility for financing such a system.

HEADLINE: Newspaper Executives Say It's Bad All Over

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
From the Times Mirror Company in Los Angeles to Knight-Ridder Inc. in Miami, executives from 15 newspaper companies who spoke at a two-day conference that ended here today told tales of lower advertising, revenues and earnings in the first quarter of 1991, after a dismal 1990.
For months, many executives had hoped that a boom in consumer confidence after the Persian Gulf war would end the advertising slump. 
 Several companies, most of which also own broadcast stations, cable television systems or other properties, said the advertising decline was encouraging them to experiment with new ways of appealing to consumers and advertisers.
 
 Concentrating Their Efforts

But for the most part, the executives who addressed financial analysts at the 20th annual Morton Media Conference said they were concentrating their efforts on two areas: replacing lost ad revenue with money from circulation, and cutting costs as much as they can.
"The rumors of better times are still ricocheting around out there," said James K. Batten, the chairman and chief executive of Knight-Ridder Inc., which publishes The Miami Herald, The Philadelphia Inquirer and 25 other papers. "But we still don't have any tangible evidence of it."
Knight-Ridder's revenues from newspapers declined 4.4 percent in the quarter from the period last year -- the first such first-quarter drop since the 1974 merger that created the company. Others fared far worse. At the Tribune Company in Chicago, revenues fell 31 percent in the newspaper division and 20 percent over all, figures that did not include results from The Daily News in New York, whose 1991 operating losses were reflected in the company's 1990 results.
Classified advertising was the primary culprit, plummeting at every company. At the Gannett Company, which publishes 82 daily newspapers, classified linage dropped 13 percent. John J. Curley, the chairman, said, "This is the worst year since I've been alive."
 
 War and Recession

The main culprit was the recession, but the war had a significant impact. Last month, several companies said they were detecting signs of a postwar pickup. Ad volume at The New York Times, while down 19 percent for the entire first quarter, declined only 12 percent in March. But Walter E. Mattson, the president and chief operating officer of The New York Times Company, said that this month the newspaper's ad volume was once again running 19 percent below levels of a year ago.
With few exceptions, the newspaper companies have tried to recapture the lost ad revenue by raising newsstand and subscription prices.
Affiliated Publications Inc., which owns The Boston Globe, said it expected to add $9 million in annual revenue by raising the home-delivery price of The Globe to $4 a week, from $3.50, and increasing the street price to 50 cents a copy, from 35 cents, in areas at least 30 miles outside Boston.
John L. Morton, the financial analyst who organizes the annual conference, cautioned that "circulation revenues are a touchy game, because you want to make sure you don't hurt your franchise." But he said the companies had little choice because "they did all the cost cutting they could last year."
Some companies are, however, still paring costs. This month, the Pulitzer Publishing Company negotiated new contracts that eliminate many work rules governing the pressmen and paper handlers at The St. Louis Post-Dispatch. Nicholas G. Penniman 4th, Pulitzer's senior vice president for newspaper operations, said he expected to cut 80 press room positions soon, saving $3.4 million annually.
 
 Going to School

But the companies are more concerned about finding new revenues. On Thursday, Dow Jones & Company said it would be bringing out a classroom edition of The Wall Street Journal, with distribution starting in September.
Other companies, among them Multimedia Inc., Knight-Ridder and Pulitzer, plan to create computer data bases, using their subscriber lists as the foundations, to help advertisers locate specific customers for their products.
And several companies, including Tribune, Multimedia, Pulitzer and the E. W. Scripps Company, said they were considering starting cable television channels.
The Tribune Company described its Chicagoland Channel, which it plans to start later this year in partnership with Continental Cable, as a 24-hour news and entertainment channel.
