HEADLINE: Recession Grew Worse in Quarter As Economy Shrank at 2.8% Rate

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
The economy contracted more rapidly in the first three months of the year than it did at the end of 1990, as national output recorded its first consecutive quarters of decline since the recession of 1981-82, the Commerce Department reported today.
Most analysts had come to expect in recent weeks that the decline would exceed the fourth quarter's 1.6 percent annual pace, and today's report, which showed a 2.8 percent rate of decline in the January-March period, was not seen as significantly worsening prospects for pulling out of recession. Some analysts still say recovery will begin by midyear.
 
Officially in Recession
 The data on the output of goods and services were accompanied by what appeared to be worrisome figures on inflation -- various gauges rising to annual rates above 5 percent -- but close examination suggested that these were aberrations related to imported oil. 
 Still, the decline in the gross national product reflected broad weakness in the economy, which is now officially in recession, and there are few signs of recovery other than in residential real estate.
"It's not clear you're yet approaching the trough," observed M. Kathryn Eickhoff, a New York consultant and former economist for the Office of Management and Budget. She said it was difficult to see how G.N.P. could expand in the current quarter.
But the Bush Administration clung to its forecast of a spring upturn, with Michael R. Darby, Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, declaring that "a small positive number is certainly within the realm of probability."
But Mr. Darby cautioned, "We are moving into a transition stage, so expect crosscurrents in various aspects of economic activity for several months yet."
The contraction was officially designated a recession on Thursday by the National Bureau of Economic Research, which said July was the starting point even though G.N.P. advanced at a 1.4 percent rate in the third quarter. Today's report of a second straight quarterly decline in gross national product fulfills the popular definition of a recession.
Nearly every sector contributed to the first-quarter decline. Spending on personal consumption, which accounts for 65 percent of the economy, fell at an annual rate of $9.5 billion, or 1.4 percent, after a 3.4 percent rate of decline in the fourth quarter. This was the first time since the first half of 1989 that consumer spending fell for two straight quarters.
An even bigger drag was an annualized drop of $19.8 billion, or 14.4 percent, in business investment, mainly reflecting cutbacks in orders for durable equipment. Mr. Darby said this might reflect temporary deferrals during the Persian Gulf war, and he cited more recent reports showing that investment intentions had steadied.
But the National Association of Manufacturers said business investment, which had been relatively buoyant because of increases for computers and other office automation equipment, was now "following its normal cyclical pattern of falling sharply during recessions."
 
 Government Spending Down
 Purchases of goods and services by all levels of government also fell, an infrequent occurrence. Despite the war, Federal spending was $3.1 billion lower, with $500 million of that accounted for by the military.
Department officials said that the war had only a negligible effect on the economy and that they could not even tell whether the effect was to raise or lower G.N.P. The war was largely fought from inventories, specialists have noted, providing no gain to gross national product until the stockpiles are replenished.
Businesses continued to liquidate stocks of automobiles and other goods at a rapid rate of $20.7 billion in the quarter, the report also showed. This had the effect of raising G.N.P. somewhat since the drawdown, at $26.4 billion, was even higher in the October-December quarter.
Inventories are now so lean, said Edward Guay, an economist for the Cigna Corporation, that even a small amount of fresh demand would force factories to raise production almost immediately. He said a surge of inventory rebuilding could push second-quarter G.N.P. growth to a rate of perhaps 2.5 percent.
Mr. Darby said the department estimated that inventories fell sharply in March but for purposes of calculating the G.N.P. this was roughly offset by an improvement in the trade deficit.
 
 Concerns Over Exports
 For the quarter, exports fell at a $700 million pace, following a sharp fourth-quarter increase, a development that raised concern among some analysts that export growth might not be strong enough to be an important engine of recovery.
Real final sales fell at a 3.3 percent pace in the first quarter, in contrast to a 1.4 percent increase in the fourth, the report also showed.
As for inflation, the fixed-weighted price index climbed to 5.1 percent, from 4.7 percent in the fourth quarter, while the implicit price deflator jumped to 5.5 percent, from 2.8 percent.
This, several analysts said, was mainly a result of a decline in the price of imported oil, which in a statistical quirk produces a temporary increase in the reported inflation rate that is subsequently reversed.
 
 Another Gauge of Prices
 The inflation rate for gross domestic purchases, Mr. Darby noted, slowed to 3.6 percent in the first quarter, from 6.3 percent in the fourth quarter, and was only 3.1 percent when a Federal pay increase is excluded.
The first-quarter price data included increases in excise taxes and in postal rates.
Today's report also showed that the nation's savings rate -- personal savings as a percentage of disposable personal income -- edged down to 4.1 percent from 4.2 percent.
G.N.P. measured in current dollars instead of in constant 1982 dollars rose at a rate of $35 billion, or 2.6 percent, in the first quarter, after rising $12.7 billion, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, in the fourth quarter.
In a revision of some fourth-quarter data, the department said corporate profits from current production were weaker than initially reported for that period, falling $11.8 billion, instead of the $5 billion calculated a month ago.
Real G.N.P. ran at a rate of $4.12 trillion in the first quarter, down from a $4.15 trillion pace in the fourth quarter. Current-dollar G.N.P. totaled $5.56 trillion.

HEADLINE: MAGAZINES MURDOCH IS SELLING, AND ONE HE IS NOT;
Publishers Find Profit in Soaps

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Soap Opera Digest and Soap Opera Weekly look to be two of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company's more valuable acquisitions in the magazine package. The publications expect to have 40 cents of cash flow, essentially profit, for every dollar of revenue this year, according to financial papers prepared for potential buyers. But will the magazines continue to prosper? Stay tuned.
The two magazines, available at supermarkets nationwide, provide news and plot synopses of daytime serial dramas. They dominate their market, with Rupert Murdoch's investment bankers likening them to the Time and Newsweek of their field. 
 One reason for the magazines' glowing financial health is that soap fans are so avid that the magazines have to spend little to attract them. Soap Opera Digest, for example, spends just 14 cents in marketing expenses to attract one dollar of circulation revenue. Soap Opera Weekly, still a relatively new publication, spends only 36 cents.
By contrast, larger mass-market publications, like Time and Newsweek, spend up to 75 cents, mainly for discount subscriptions, gifts like telephones and desk planners and third-party sales operations.
The soap-opera publications' are doing especially well given how the recession has hurt larger magazines aimed at more affluent readers. The soap-opera magazines' readers' incomes average less than $24,000.
The companion publications are also inexpensive to produce, with a staff of about 60 to bring in $60 million in annual revenue. They have loyal, predominantly female readers who live mostly in the Midwest and South and are in their early 30's. The magazines have such strong supermarket sales that they would prosper without advertising.
That picture emerges from a 136-page review document. While the documents are basically marketing tools, they offer an unusually detailed look at the magazines.
In the year ending June 30, Soap Opera Digest expects to have revenue of about $45 million, up nearly 19 percent from $38 million a year earlier. The profit contribution this year is expected to total $22 million, up from $15.7 million the year before.
Soap Opera Digest has the equivalent of 40 editorial, advertising and production employees, or less than one person for every million dollars of revenue.
Many of the most successful magazines in recent years have been smaller specialized publications, which can attract both fervent readers and advertisers.
This is especially true with Soap Opera Digest, a twice-monthly publication costing $1.95. Its sells about 1.5 million copies, nearly 70 percent at newsstands.
Founded in 1975 and acquired by Mr. Murdoch in 1989, Soap Opera Digest was meant to appeal to fans who missed episodes of soap operas, it but later expanded to include news and celebrity profiles. The synopses appealed especially to working women.
 
 Soap Opera Star Salaries
 Some of Soap Opera Digest's best-selling cover articles in 1990 were "How Much Do Soap Stars Make?" (single copy sales: 1,137,200) and "TV's Sexiest Men" (1,109,923).
Soap Opera Weekly was founded in November 1989, shortly after the acquisition of Soap Opera Digest. The weekly is a tabloid-sized publication costing 99 cents.
The weekly expects to post $16.3 million in revenue in this fiscal year, nearly triple the $6.2 milliona year earlier. It expects to earn $4.2 million this year, up from only $79,000 the year before. Start-up publications rarely break even, let alone make a profit so quickly. It has a staff of only 19.
Competition is minor for both publications, according to the Murdoch bankers. There is Soap Opera Update, a biweekly with an unaudited circulation of 200,000 and Episodes, which Mr. Murdoch's people described as a promotion for ABC-TV soap operas.
But buried deep within the mountain of glowing statistics are some cautionary numbers. For one thing, Soap Opera Digest's subscriptions for the 1992 fiscal year are projected to be flat at 475,000 and single-copy sales, the ones at the newstand, are projected to decline to 1,019,000 from 1,033,654.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Many more banks are effectively bankrupt than regulators had recognized and the program that insures bank depositors is "nearly insolvent," said Charles Bowsher, the Comptroller General. He suggested that a quick way to fix the fund would be to raise $15 billion through industry contributions. [Page 1.] 
 The economy contracted more rapidly in the first three months of the year than it did at the end of 1990, as national output recorded its first consecutive quarters of decline since 1981-82. [1.]
Newspaper executives at a conference told tales of lower advertising, revenues and earnings in the first quarter. [43.]
Lawmakers left Detroit vowing to give the auto industry more consideration on regulations and competition. [8.]
 
 Companies
General Cinema said it had ended its effort to acquire Harcourt after failing to come to terms with Harcourt's bondholders. [37.]
K-III Holdings' agreement to pay $650 million for nine Murdoch publications, including New York magazine, Seventeen and The Racing Form, was the talk of the publishing industry. [37.]
Financial data on four Murdoch magazines highlight the profits -- and perils -- in the business. New York magazine has seen better days; ads, like the city's economy, are in the dumps. Seventeen magazine, with a huge and growing market, is one of the most profitable Murdoch publications. Mirabella, the youngest family member, appears to be the rejected child. Soap Opera Digest and Soap Opera Weekly dominate their market and seem to be two of the more valuable items in the package. [40.]
Federated Stores will reportedly ask a Federal judge to approve a reorganization plan that would offer cash and notes worth 100 cents on the dollar to some unsecured creditors. [37.]
I.B.M. has agreed to allow Mitsubishi Electric to sell an I.B.M. mainframe, the first time I.B.M. has allowed another computer company to resell one of its most powerful machines. [37.]
A small distributor plans to sell an expensive drug treatment that could help psychotic patients for a price 30 percent below that set by Sandoz, the drug's maker. [37.]
Amil Gargano is leaving as chairman of Ally & Gargano to start his own small agency. The new venture will operate autonomously but rely on Ally & Gargano for various services. [37.]
Shell Oil reported a 38.4 percent drop in earnings, citing weak natural gas prices and slumping sales for refined products. [38.]
The New York Times Co. and The Washington Post Co. acquired the one-third interest in The International Herald Tribune that had been owned by Whitcom Investment. [43.]
Visa said it had agreed to pay for legal advice for restaurant owners who revolted against American Express fees. [39.]
Procter & Gamble agreed to drop the word "fresh" from Citrus Hill orange juice, giving the F.D.A. a victory. [1.]
 
International
Japan and the U.S. traded harsher jabs over American access to the Japanese construction market. [38.]
 
Markets
Stocks fell after a depressing report on the economy. The Dow closed at 2,912.38, down 8.66 on the day, 53.21 for the week. [42.]
A late rally lifted prices of long-term Treasury bonds, while the intermediate and shorter maturities were mixed. [42.]
Prices of pork belly futures jumped as speculators positioned themselves for a possible rally. [47.] The dollar rose. [47.]

A product said to be able to relieve the urban problem of potholes was patented by two New York engineers. Patents. [38.]

HEADLINE: Lawmakers Leave Detroit With Vows to Help Auto Makers

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 26

 BODY:
Facing record losses, a raft of new regulations from Washington and increased competition from abroad, the American auto industry has spent two days wooing one of the largest delegations of members of Congress ever to descend on Detroit.
The lawmakers left town today with many members vowing to give the industry more consideration. 
 "I never realized what effect the economy has been having," said Representative Benjamin L. Cardin, Democrat of Maryland. "We have to be more aggressive in trade negotiations. Imports are still a problem."
The impressions of the 41 members of Congress who toured factories and executive offices of the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation, as well as the headquarters of the United Automobile Workers union, could have an important impact on coming debates about proposed legislation on trade and clean air.
 
Some Temper Their Concerns
 Naturally, kind words about the automobile industry, which paid for the visit, from lawmakers who represent other areas may have simply reflected a desire to be polite in front of their colleagues from Michigan and their hosts. But some seemed to be truly impressed.
"After seeing Detroit up close, I'm going to be more inclined to temper the environmental concerns of my constituents with the need to revitalize the auto industry and the nation's manufacturing base," said Representative Frank Riggs, Republican of California.
Mr. Riggs said his constituents in Sonoma County were worried about expanded offshore oil drilling. Energy legislation before Congress that would regulate such wells is also expected to impose tougher fuel-efficiency regulations on the automobile industry. Manufacturers are clearly hoping that Mr. Riggs may now be less willing to accept stricter fuel-efficiency measures to get the prohibition of drilling his constituents want.
As regular participants in Washington's legislative horse trading, United States automobile makers have historically opposed stricter standards on safety, fuel efficiency and automobile emissions. In many debates the automobile companies issue the same dark warning: A law like this could sink the United States auto industry.
Ater the law passes,the Big Three usually find a way to comply. The script is as old as the seatbelt, which Detroit once opposed as ineffective and too expensive. In the longer term, the industry's credibility has been damaged in the eyes of lawmakers who regard its opposition as reflexive and lacking regard for social policy.
 
Many Without Industry Ties
 Detroit, of course, has its traditional defenders in Congress, including the Michigan delegation. Among those defenders on the tour were Representative John D. Dingell, a Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, and Representative Marcy Kaptur, an Ohio Democrat who is co-chairwoman of the Congressional Competitiveness Caucus. But more than half the group have no automobile plant in their districts.
"More than half the members weren't even in Congress for the debates of the 1970's, and they don't know anything about the auto industry," Ms. Kaptur said. They also are not aware, she said, of the industry's far-reaching economic impact, including its use of half the nation's production of carpet and 20 percent of the semiconductors. Her remarks were delivered at the conclusion of a tour through G.M.'s Hamtramck Assembly Plant, where Cadillacs are built.
What the delegation learned in its 24 hours in Detroit was that the manufacturers have been spending billions of dollars to comply with Federal legislation that has brought airbags, doubled fuel efficiency and improved the safety of vehicles. "People were amazed to learn that the large Buick had better fuel efficiency than Toyota's luxury car," said Sander M. Levin, Democrat of Michigan.
But the spending exacted a price in competitiveness, the companies said. And if automobile makers have cried wolf once too often, the industry's problems now appear to be all too real. Losses since last December have been about $5 billion, and Chrysler has been scrambling to solve short-term financial problems.
Thursday afternoon, the delegation heard Owen F. Bieber, president of the automobile workers union, say that a bill before Congress could open free trade with Mexico could cause the loss of union jobs. The companies support the bill, in one of many examples of the conflicting interests of the union and the manufacturers over legislation.
The bus trip from the union's headquarters to a new $1 billion Chrysler assembly plant, which is scheduled to open later this year, passed through blighted east side neighborhoods and crumbling, abandoned factories. A spokesman for the union said the route was chosen intentionally. "There's no way to go through the east side without some eye-openers."
At Ford's proving grounds, the former racing driver Jackie Stewart drove members on high-speed circuits of the test track. But the highlight, all seemed to agree, was a buffet dinner at Chrysler headquarters with Lee Iacocca, the corporation's chairman. According to reports from the dinner, which was closed to the press, Mr. Iacocca eloquently urged members to press for restrictions on Japanese imports.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A Congressional delegation arrived in Detroit on Thursday to check the state of the auto industry. Owen F. Bieber, president of the United Automobile Workers, escorted Representative Helen Delich Bentley of Maryland after she arrived at Detroit Metropolitan Airport. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BANK DEPOSIT FUND NEARLY INSOLVENT, U.S. AUDITOR SAYS

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26

 BODY:
The nation's top auditor said today that many more banks were effectively bankrupt than regulators had recognized, and that therefore the program that insures depositors was "nearly insolvent."
The official, Charles A. Bowsher, the Comptroller General, suggested that a quick way to fix the fund, which is financed through premiums paid by banks, would be to raise $15 billion through additional contributions from the banking industry. 
 "The bank insurance fund is nearly insolvent, and I cannot overemphasize how important it is to restore it as quickly as possible," Mr. Bowsher told the Senate Banking Committee. "If you don't get on top of this soon enough, then the taxpayers will eventually lose."
 
40 Cents for Every $100
 To raise $15 billion quickly, Mr. Bowsher urged Congress to consider an immediate special assessment on banks of 40 cents for every $100 in deposits. He said that if the lawmakers found this would unduly restrict lending by the banks, Congress might consider levying an assessment of 20 cents in 1991 and again in 1992.
In either event, he strongly urged the Senators not to put a cap on existing annual premiums at 30 cents for every $100, as the Bush Administration has proposed.
The $15 billion increase could be used by the fund both to bail out insolvent banks and to borrow against, thus further strengthening the insurance program. Existing law permits the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which operates the fund, to borrow up to nine times its net worth. The law also gives the agency a credit line of $5 billion with the Treasury.
 
Audit Used Regulators' Files
 Economists for the White House and for Congress have relied upon economic models to determine the net worth of the bank insurance fund, and their findings have predicted that the program may run out of money within a year or two. But the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress that Mr. Bowsher heads, conducted an audit that was based on information from the regulators' own files. The results of the audit, presented at the hearing today, showed that the fund and the banking industry were in far weaker condition than previously calculated.
Mr. Bowsher's testimony was the most dire of any Government official in a long series of hearings over the last year. In the hearings, a progressively worse picture of the plight of the insurance fund has emerged.
Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., the chairman of the Banking Committee, said the G.A.O. had found that "the bank insurance fund is essentially out of money."
"We're in a position of some real vulnerability," said Mr. Riegle, Democrat of Michigan.
But the proposal made by Mr. Bowsher today provoked only criticism in Congress and from the industry and appears to have little chance of approval. The Administration and bank regulators have proposed a different way to recapitalize the fund.
They have recommended repairing the fund by increasing its authority to borrow by $70 billion. On Thursday, Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the House Banking Committee, introduced a measure to increase the fund's borrowing authority by just $25 billion, but Treasury officials have criticized that measure because it does not include most of the proposals they have put forward to overhaul the entire banking system.
 
 On Top of Current Premiums
 Mr. Bowsher's suggestion that the fund be buttressed by an immediate special assessment was immediately challenged by banking groups, who said a bite of 40 cents for every $100 in deposits would be too much for the industry to bear. The assessment would be on top of existing premiums, which are scheduled to increase this summer to 23 cents for each $100, from 19.5 cents.
The $15 billion sought by Mr. Bowsher to bolster the fund is slightly less than the entire industry's earnings last year. It also represents less than one-tenth of American banks' existing capital -- the owners' stake in the banks that is crucial as a cushion to absorb large losses.
Mr. Bowsher said preliminary results of the audit of the bank fund put its net worth at the end of last year at $2 billion to $5 billion. The actual amount depends upon how dozens of large banks that are effectively insolvent, but have not yet been seized by the Government, are classified.
Unaudited results put the fund's net worth at $8.4 billion as of Dec. 31. L. William Seidman, the chairman of the F.D.I.C., disclosed on Tuesday that his agency was disputing the G.A.O.'s audit, but the accounting office declined to comment before presenting its conclusions to lawmakers today.
Mr. Seidman has said the fund is weak and needs additional borrowing authority. But he has said it would not be insolvent if, as many economists and Government officials have predicted, the economy began to turn around by summer.
Both Mr. Seidman and Mr. Bowsher acknowledge that a large part of their dispute centers on timing -- whether to recognize losses in 1990 or 1991 for a fund that virtually all officials now concede is headed toward insolvency if Congress and the Administration are unable to agree on a solution.
The findings of the audit have a far-reaching effect, though, because the F.D.I.C.'s authority to borrow from the Government is largely tied to its net worth. This week, officials said they had begun to draw on their borrowing authority to help finance the failure of the Bank of New England and two affiliated banks, whose cost had already been subtracted by the F.D.I.C. in its calculation of the bank fund's net worth of $8.4 billion. That collapse requires an initial outlay of at least $5 billion. It is estimated that the failure will cost as much as $2.5 billion ultimately, after the banks' bad assets are sold.
Mr. Bowsher and Mr. Seidman have said they hope to work out their differences soon. But if they are unable to reconcile the different financial figures, Mr. Bowsher said the accounting office would have to give a qualified, or adverse, auditor's opinion that the F.D.I.C. balance sheets are not based on generally accepted accounting principles. Those principles require that all contingent liabilities be included in the audit.
Bank deposits of up to $100,000 are protected by the F.D.I.C., and depositors holding up to that amount would continue to be protected even if the fund became insolvent. If that occurred, the fund, which was created in 1934 after many banks collapsed in the Great Depression, would have to be bailed out by taxpayer funds, since it is backed by the full faith and credit of the United States.
Mr. Bowsher told reporters after the hearing that the existing difficulties could put the bank fund in the same position as the now-depleted fund that protected depositors at savings associations.
"It's somewhat similar to the savings and loan situation of 1988," Mr. Bowsher said. "You don't have money to resolve problems now, so you start parking your problems and then it costs even more."
 
 Examination of 368 Banks
 Mr. Bowsher said the G.A.O. figures reflected an examination of the financial condition of 368 banks. Those banks were on the regulators' list of troubled institutions. Many had assets of more than $100 million.
He said that 71 of those institutions were "already insolvent, or nearly so" and would cost the fund $7 billion to $11 billion. Of those banks, he said the problems of at least 40 were so grave that they had to be calculated in the net worth of the fund at the end of last year.
"The remaining 31 banks, more likely than not, will fail without recapitalization, but do not meet the criteria of insolvency and therefore present accounting rules do not require the fund to reserve for these banks," he said.
 
 Banks See 'Alarming Proposal'
 Banking groups and some Senators on the banking committee criticized Mr. Bowsher's idea of a special premium, saying it could further tighten credit at a time when there were already complaints that banks had refused loans to credit-worthy customers.
"It is an alarming proposal that would strike extremely hard at many institutions," said Charlotte LeGates of the National Council of Savings Institutions, a Washington-based trade group of banks and savings associations. "To lead the American public to the idea that bankers can go into the vault, spin the dial and pull out vast hoards of cash is something that is simply not true."
Richard A. Kirk, the president of the American Bankers Association, said the G.A.O.'s proposal "clearly would be economically and financially counterproductive."
"If you really want to see a credit crunch, this is the way to get one," he said.

HEADLINE: Baker Says Israel Fails to Provide Needed Responses

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, April 26

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that Israel had failed to give all the responses he needed to continue trying to put together an Arab-Israeli peace conference and that as a result he and President Bush would have to reappraise their next steps in Middle East peacemaking.
Mr. Baker had to leave Israel abruptly because of the death of his mother in Houston today, but he had largely completed his daylong talks with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Foreign Minister David Levy. 
 On Mr. Baker's departure from Israel, his spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, issued a statement dictated by the Secretary that left the unmistakable impression that he was highly unsatisfied with Mr. Shamir's position on how to arrange a peace conference that Palestinians could attend.
The statement also left the clear impression, which American officials pointedly would not deny, that the Bush Administration now believes that primarily because of Israel's obstinacy it is going to have to reconsider how, and even whether, it will continue trying to put together an Arab-Israeli peace conference.
 
Israelis Give Their Side
 Israeli officials hurriedly briefed reporters traveling with Mr. Baker before they left Jerusalem, giving them a list of responses that Mr. Levy had given Mr. Baker, which they insisted demonstrated flexibility on Israel's part. The responses involved some concessions on procedural issues, but not on any key points dividing them from the Arabs, who, up to now, have not publicly shown any more flexibility than the Israelis.
As Mr. Baker left the Prime Minister's office, after being called by his wife, Susan, and informed of the death of his 96-year-old mother, Bonner Means Baker, the Secretary was asked by reporters whether he was returning for another peacemaking swing, as his aides had hinted on Thursday.
"Well, we don't know yet whether we will be coming back," he said. Then, referring to the Israelis, he added, "We have got some answers, but there are still some questions that we have asked to which we do not have answers."
As Mr. Baker's plane was about to take off, Miss Tutwiler elaborated in a statement she said was personally cleared by the Secretary.
"The President called the Secretary in his suite at the King David Hotel," she said. "After the President expressed his condolences on the death of the Secretary's mother, the Secretary gave the President a brief sense of where things stood. The only characterizations I am going to be able to give you concerning today's meetings here in Israel is the following:
"Obviously, the meeting with the Prime Minister, even though it ran over, was abruptly concluded. Questions remain here in Israel. We still need some answers from the Israeli Government relating primarily to modalities before we can move this process forward. The Secretary intends to see the President when he returns from Houston to determine appropriate next steps in the search for Middle East peace. That is it."
 
No Further Elaboration
 The statement was significant not only for what it said, but also for what it did not say. Asked if the Secretary still was waiting for responses from the Arab side to move the process forward, or whether the Arabs were being just as obstinate, Miss Tutwiler said that Mr. Baker wanted to leave the statement exactly as it was.
These remarks contrasted sharply to those that Mr. Baker made at the end of his previous stops, when he always tended to accentuate the positive. Even after talks on Tuesday with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, which made no apparent progress either, Mr. Baker called the discussions "useful."
While no American official would explicitly say so, it was apparent that Mr. Baker felt that after his four visits to Israel in the last seven weeks, the Israeli Government was still refusing to give him what he believes are the minimum acceptable answers to some key questions. Mr. Baker had vowed that he would not allow any of the parties to string him along.
Without explicitly saying so, American officials left the impression that the Secretary was trying to administer some diplomatic shock therapy to the Israelis, much the way President Ford and Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger did in April 1975, when they announced a "reassessment" of American policy toward Israel after the Israelis had not gone along with American ideas for a deal with Egypt..
When Mr. Baker was in Israel a week ago, on his third Middle East swing since the gulf war ended, he left Mr. Shamir with a series of compromise proposals on how a peace conference might be organized that Palestinians could attend. The Israelis want a ceremonial opening conference that would usher in direct talks with Arab neighbors. The Syrians want a full-fledged conference with United Nations involvement and with the parties being able to refer deadlocks to conference sponsors.
The Israelis refused to have any Palestinians from Israeli-annexed East Jerusalem attend, because it might suggest that Jerusalem's status is negotiable, and they want American asurances that any Palestinians who do take part will not claim allegiance to the Palestine Liberation Organization. The Palestinians want more flexibility in choosing their own representatives.
When Israeli officials gave reporters the text of the official responses to Mr. Baker, even as he was still meeting with Mr. Shamir, it seemed to be a pre-emptive move that may have influenced Mr. Baker's blunt statement.
 
The Israelis' Responses
 In the responses, the Israelis said they had agreed that the Soviets and the Europeans could take part in the peace conference in some way -- provided they accepted Israel's terms. There would be no role for the United Nations, which the Syrians demand.
Second, Israel agreed to a conference provided that it is an opening to direct talks and that the superpower sponsors will have no authority to impose a solution or have any other operational role in the negotiations. To help satisfy Arab demands for an ongoing conference though, Israeli officials said they would agree that after six months of talks the Arabs and the Israelis can "inform" the co-sponsors about their progress -- provided that both sides agree to do so.
Third, the conference would be called the Conference for the Opening of Direct Negotiations for Peace in the Middle East.
Fourth, in Israel's view, the task of such a conference would be to lead to direct talks and cover issues like water problems, economic development and arms reductions. There was no Israeli mention of trading land for peace.
Fifth, Israel is ready to talk to a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation, provided that it is not connected to the P.L.O.
 
Clarification Offered
 Later, Israel clarified its position, saying it would not allow Soviet co-sponsorship of the conference until the Soviet Union renewed diplomatic relations with Israel.
But even with that, the Government's answers stirred the beginnings of a possible political storm. Right-wing ministers said the Government had gone too far. Science Minister Yuval Neeman of the far-right Tehiya party threatened to leave the coalition unless Mr. Shamir reconsidered.
Even Defense Minister Moshe Arens and Deputy Foreign Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, both allies of Mr. Shamir, were reported to be unhappy, particularly with the provision that the talks might be reconvened if the direct negotiations ran into difficulties. All this is to be debated at an Israeli Cabinet meeting on Sunday.

HEADLINE: Cambodia Ruler Shrugs As Plan for Peace Stalls

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, April 25

 BODY:
Wide anticipation of an imminent settlement of the Cambodian war now seems to have been premature.
Western governments have generally assumed that Phnom Penh's Vietnamese-backed Government can not last more than a few years without a peace treaty ending Chinese military aid to the Cambodian rebel alliance. 
 But a draft treaty carefully negotiated by the United States and other key members of the United Nations Security Council, with little reference to Phnom Penh's goals, has stirred nervousness here and in Hanoi. And the Cambodian Government, however shaky, seems to think it can hold on.
It is politically impossible for any Cambodian faction to reject the United Nations draft outright. But the Phnom Penh Government, concerned about sovereignty, disarmament and a possible return of the Khmer Rouge guerrillas to power, has proposed enough "amendments" to the plan to block it for some time or even derail it.
From the perspective of Phnom Penh, the challenge from the rebel coalition is far from dire, Cambodian officials and Eastern European diplomats say. They say the Government may have much to gain from delaying a plan that would strip it of much of its power and then hold elections that the regime is likely to lose.
"Many predicted doom for us when the Vietnamese troops withdrew" in September 1989, nearly 11 years after their invasion to unseat the Khmer Rouge, a senior Cambodian official said. "But almost two years later, we're still here, and we're managing pretty well."
Phnom Penh does not feel enough pressure to sign a risky peace. "Everyone is tired of the war," a Soviet diplomat said. "But there is no hurry. This is not a collapsible economy, and there isn't that much fighting."
Officially, the Government of Prime Minister Hun Sen and the chairman of the National Assembly, Chea Sim, have accepted the United Nations plan as a treaty "framework" and "a good basis" for negotiations.
But little talk has transpired since December between Phnom Penh and the United Nations or among the Cambodians. A new meeting of the Supreme National Council, which includes members of the Government and the three opposition factions, has been expected since mid-April; now diplomats say it may not happen before June.
All sides have agreed to abide by United Nations calls for a cease-fire until the meeting is held, but the rainy season brings a kind of truce anyway.
A sharp decrease this year in aid from the Soviet Union and other countries in Eastern Europe has resulted in higher inflation, power cuts and a general worsening in living conditions. But the Government has coped.
Militarily, the Khmer Rouge rebels have gained some ground in the dry season, extending routes of communications and supplies.
But they have avoided big battles with the Government army, which is said to have a "backstop" of at least several thousand Vietnamese troops.
 
Phnom Penh's Stake
 "It's not a wonderful army," the Vietnamese Ambassador, Ngo Dien, said. "But it seems enough to face the other side.
"The problem for the regime is not whether the solution is Communist or non-Communist," he said, "but what happens to them and what they've built and acquired in the last 10 years."
Vietnam maintains that its influence on Phnom Penh is waning, despite Western pressure on Hanoi to push the Cambodians to settle. Conservatives in Hanoi, including the army, are unhappy at the prospect of multiparty elections next door.

HEADLINE: Taiwan Belongs in GATT

 BODY:
Even as politics divided the world after World War II, trade united it. Now, Communism's collapse and the third world's disenchantment with protectionism makes possible a truly global market -- one world, united in trade.
The framework for trade advances has been the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Under its auspices nearly 100 diverse nations have agreed to uniform, equitable rules of international commerce. Yet GATT ought to be even more universal than it now is. Politics still divides.
Western deference to China now keeps Taiwan, the world's 13th-largest trading nation, outside GATT. Beijing objects that admitting Taiwan would undermine the principle that there can be only one China. 
 That argument doesn't stand up. Taiwan has deliberately skirted the one-China issue by applying to GATT as the "Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu." Its admission under this name would follow the precedent of Hong Kong, a GATT member since 1986. Ideological hostility, not China's integrity, seems Beijing's true concern.
Taiwan's open-market economy meets normal GATT entrance criteria, while Beijing's half-reformed, half-centralized system falls short. And despite the mainland's huge edge in territory and population, Taiwan is a weightier player in the world economy by almost every measure: industrialization, trade flows, capital exports and international reserves.
Taiwan is now America's sixth-largest trading partner, accounting for this country's second-largest bilateral trade deficit. With the Bush Administration's stated commitment to GATT, Washington might be expected to support Taiwan's application strongly. But thus far it has not.
The Administration would best serve American political and economic interests by supporting Taiwan's entrance into GATT.

HEADLINE: Murdoch Gets a Generous Price

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
Publishing executives were abuzz yesterday over K-III Holdings' agreement to pay $650 million for nine of the News Corporation's publications, including New York magazine, Seventeen and The Racing Form. The general consensus is that K-III is paying a hefty, but not exorbitant, price when the future of advertising spending is uncertain.
"In this market, it is very hard to evaluate values because advertising revenues are falling so fast," said one publishing executive. "That multiple is going up every day," he said, referring to the price, which is 11 times cash flow, a term used in the industry to describe profitability.
 
 The Biggest Step Yet

This purchase would represent the biggest step yet by K-III Holdings, a two-year-old publishing venture run by three former Macmillan executives with backing from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the buyout firm with the very deep pockets. Beginning in February 1989, William F. Reilly, K-III's chief, has bought a variety of smaller publishing properties, including the Weekly Reader, trade magazines, encyclopedias and specialized directories. The more visible publications would represent a new direction for him and the company. 
 Both K-III and Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, which is selling the magazines, had more than the usual problems in arriving at appropriate prices in the slumping market. Several people with knowledge of the negotiations, said the News Corporation had to reduce its 1991 advertising estimates for various publications after results for April and May came in below its earlier projections.
And K-III's bid left room for further deterioration. According to one person with knowledge of the talks, the final price that K-III pays for the magazines will depend on what the actual cash flows for the various publications are through June 30, the end of the New Coporation's fiscal year. If they fall below projections, K-III will pay less than the $650 million price the two sides agreed on.
While there are some highly profitable publications in the group -- like The Racing Form and Seventeen -- industry executives questioned how much room there was for these established properties to grow. And the newer publications, like Premiere and European Travel & Life, do have room to grow, but are not seen having as much potential for significant profit.
There was much speculation in the publishing world yesterday that K-III will sell off some of its magazines, perhaps relatively quickly after the deal closes to recover some of their investment as soon as possible. Among the names most often mentioned were "Seventeen," and "New Woman."
But people close to K-III said earlier this week that they would keep the publications intact.
One magazine that was said to hold special appeal for Henry Kravis, the Kohlberg, Kravis partner, was New York magazine. According to one executive with knowledge of the talks, Mr. Kravis has no intention of selling it and was particularly involved in its purchase.
Mr. Kravis and his wife, the fashion designer Carolyne Roehm, have led a highly visible life that has been widely chronicled in the last decade. She was featured on the cover of the Nov. 24, 1986, issue of New York, in an article called "The Working Rich." Like other executives who have made money in other businesses, such as Laurence A. Tisch, Mr. Kravis is now investing in a prominent media company.
Nor is Mr. Kravis considered likely to sell The Racing Form, because it is such a cash cow. Even if K-III wanted to sell it, finding a buyer willing to pay $200 million or so might prove difficult, despite its profitability. The paper, published seven days a week, has about 110,000 circulation and a newsstand price of $2.50 a copy.
Until recently it has had a virtual monopoly on the business, but that may be about to disappear. Robert Maxwell, the British-based entrepreneur and longtime Murdoch rival, is set to introduce another racing paper in the United States in the next several weeks. Publishing experts say that could lead to a price war, cutting into profits for The Racing Form. Some race tracks have also begun to offer their own publications, and these are already crimping profits. And race track attendance is down.
The paper's current cash flow, or the actual cash the business generates, is about $25 million, which is below the $35 million cash flow the paper is said to have had when Walter Annenberg sold it to Mr. Murdoch .
K-III Holdings is also considered likely to hold on to Soap Opera Digest, in part because it, too, generates so much cash. It had $15 million in cash flow on revenues of $37 million in 1990. Finding a buyer who would pay a sufficiently high price for a single publication would be very difficult.
What that means is that if K-III were to sell any of the publications, Seventeen may well be a likely target. Hearst and Conde Nast are both considered likely buyers.
Whatever it keeps, K-III will have its hands full, particularly if the economy -- and advertising -- do not bounce back soon. And a number of industry executives said privately yesterday that they are beginning to think there may not be a recovery until 1993. That would mean magazines could languish for the two and a half years -- proving even the most conservative projections overly optimistic.
"Every publisher is looking at a year that is much softer than they anticipated in their original budgets for the year," said Reginald Brack, the chairman of Time Warner Publishing.
 
 Upbeat Projections
 But the projections in the financial documents for the magazines are generally upbeat. The offering prospectus on New York, for instance, assumes that advertising revenue will grow in 1992 to $41 million, from $36 million in 1990.
Furthermore, most industry executives agree that the Murdoch magazines are unusually well run, so that there is little room for cost cutting as a way of increasing profit margins.
K-III brings some clear management expertise: Mr Reilly refashioned Macmillan into a larger and more profitable company, which was so attractive that he then lost it in a takeover battle. In forming K-III, he brought with him Charles G. McCurdy and Beverly C. Chell, Macmillan's former chief financial officer and general counsel, But the textbooks at Macmillan are a far cry from popular magazines.
There was some talk yesterday that K-III might bring in some new management, depending on how many magazines it retains.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 29, 1991, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Saturday about Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company's purchase of some publications from Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation misstated the status of The Racing Times, a newspaper owned by Robert Maxwell. The Racing Times began publication this month.

HEADLINE: FILM;
Hollywood Keeps Striking Out On Real-Life Baseball

BYLINE: By ALLEN BARRA; Allen Barra, a contributing writer for The Village Voice and Entertainment Weekly, has written about film and sports for American Film, Premiere and Inside Sports.

 BODY:
Baseball movies are older than the World Series, and as Casey Stengel used to say, you can look it up. The first World Series was played in 1903, and according to Prentice Hall's handy reference book, "Everything Baseball," (the book you can look it up in), the first feature-length baseball movie, "The Ball Game," was cranked out in 1902. There's an old Hollywood adage that baseball movies don't sell tickets, but during the last 89 years more than 150 of them have been made, so somebody must be going to see them.
As a new season begins, a quick trip to a videocassette store reveals an amazing range of baseball subjects covered by Hollywood over the years. Buster Keaton's "College" (1927) contains perhaps the funniest baseball scenes ever filmed, as the hero tries to make the university baseball team. John Badham's "Bingo Long Traveling All-Stars and Motor Kings" (1976), a film which was all but ignored upon its release but now rates near the top of most critics' list of best baseball movies, features James Earl Jones, Billy Dee Williams and Richard Pryor as post-World War II Negro League barnstormers. 
 The Little Leagues were covered in the series of "Bad News Bears" films that began in 1976. And in recent years, the minor leagues have made it to the screen in "Bull Durham," one of the most popular of all baseball movies, and the cable television movie "Long Gone," which starred William Petersen and Virginia Madsen.
Currently several films with baseball themes are in production or the planning stage, including the tale of an American ex-big leaguer in Japan, a former major league manager who helps put together a Russian national team, a minor leaguer scout and even the story of the first female professionals. When it comes to baseball, it seems that Hollywood has all the bases covered.
All the bases except one: home, as in reality -- the lives and work of contemporary big league ballplayers. This is all the more surprising when you consider that professional baseball has never been more popular in terms of attendance and television viewership and that several baseball movies in the last few years have been substantial hits. Yet Hollywood and the major leagues avoid each other the way the Chicago Cubs avoid the World Series.
Hollywood might insist otherwise, pointing at such earlier films as the biographies of Lou Gehrig, Jim Piersall and Grover Cleveland Alexander and such recent films as "Major League" and "Eight Men Out."
"Fear Strikes Out" (1957) is, in fact, a film whose reputation has grown in recent years, a harrowing account of how the pressures of big league play (and the pressures imposed by a pushy father) contributed to the nervous breakdown of the star outfielder Jim Piersall. And "Eight Men Out," John Sayles's revisionist account (taken from Eliot Asinof's book) of the 1919 Black Sox scandal, may be the first movie ever to factor problems of economics and class conflict into a sports movie.
But others are either sentimental ("The Pride of the Yankees," 1942, about the great Yankees first baseman Lou Gehrig), maudlin ("Bang the Drum Slowly," 1973, about a hayseed catcher played by Robert De Niro who is dying of leukemia) or bowdlerized ("The Winning Team," 1952, about the Hall of Fame pitcher Grover Cleveland Alexander, played by a former sports announcer, Ronald Reagan, who portrayed Alexander not as an alcoholic but as an epileptic. He was both).
As for "Major League" (1989), it tells the story of an ex-Las Vegas showgirl (played by Margaret Whitton) who wins a pennant by assembling a team composed of misfits and castoffs. (Anyone who has ever observed the precision and balance of a winning major league team knows that the chance of a randomly selected bunch of also-rans finishing in first place at the end of a 162-game season are about the same as a room full of monkeys armed with word processors being able to produce "The Baseball Encyclopedia.")
Films like "Major League" are Hollywood's version of baseball realism; most of the others sound as if they could fit more easily under the category of science fiction.
"Rhubarb" (1955) went "Major League" one better (or maybe one worse) by having a cat become the owner of a big league team. The supernatural looms large in baseball movies. Pennants have been won with the aid of angels ("Angels in the Outfield," 1951) and the devil ("Damn Yankees," 1958). And lest these plots sound silly to modern fans, remember that the hero of "The Natural" (1984) has a special bat that seems to be charged with the power of a lightning bolt that felled the tree the bat was cut from. How silly will the story of an Iowa farmer who builds a ballpark to lure the ghost of Shoeless Joe Jackson (the 1988 hit "Field of Dreams") seem 20 or 30 years from now?
 Hollywood scriptwriters are so removed from the realities of big league ball that one of them concocted "It Happens Every Spring" (1949), about an egghead scientist (in baseball movies anyone who reads the sports pages without moving his lips is an egghead) who invents a chemical for making a baseball avoid a bat. Apparently the screenwriter was unaware that baseball pitchers had found such a chemical nearly 100 years earlier and that it had been outlawed. It's called spit.
Why can't baseball movies reflect the big league game as the players play it and as the writers and fans see it? Tim Braine, an independent producer who is currently working on "Comrades of Summer," the first baseball movie set in the Soviet Union, finds the prospect of doing realistic baseball movies "too expensive and too difficult."
"For one thing," he said, "you need the approval of Major League Baseball, and that is an extremely protective group of people. You have to fictionalize and soften your material in order to avoid difficulty." Mr. Braine offers an example involving the principal owner of the Yankees: "If you wanted to make a movie about George Steinbrenner's fall from power, you might find that whatever baseball people thought of Steinbrenner in private, you couldn't get them to approve a script which made Steinbrenner a villain because it would make owners in general look bad. By the time you got done compromising your original material, you wouldn't recognize it."
Another reason movies avoid contemporary stories of big league players, Mr. Braine suggests, is that "it isn't so easy for fans to identify with ballplayers as they once did -- or at least that's what conventional wisdom says."
"In some cases," he said, "actors would be portraying athletes who make more money than they do. The average producer would say, 'So where's the conflict? Where's the tragedy?' I'm not saying I agree; I'm just saying that the ballplayers' current prosperity makes it more difficult to get the audience to sympathize with them."
The man most responsible for that prosperity is Marvin Miller, the former executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, the players' union, and the chief architect of free agency, which allowed players to sell their services to the highest bidder. Mr. Miller definitely does not agree that modern baseball is devoid of interest for moviegoers. "Fans are always interested in the nuts and bolts of the game -- there's as much drama in baseball now as there ever was," he says. "If there wasn't, there wouldn't be so much fan interest."
Besides, Mr. Miller says, "Just because players make more money now doesn't make them less interesting or less human." Mr. Miller cites several modern players whose stories he thinks would make good films: Tony Conigliaro, the Red Sox slugger whose career was ruined by a single pitch that nearly blinded him; J. R. Richard, the fireballing Houston ace who couldn't convince the team's brass that he was having heart trouble, and Curt Flood, the Cardinals outfielder who risked his career by challenging the reserve clause, which bound a player to one team.
"How about Roberto Clemente?" says Mr. Miller, referring to the Hall of Fame Pittsburgh Pirates outfielder, who died in a 1972 plane crash while on a mercy mission. "A batting champion, a World Series hero, a man who dies a tragic death, a national hero in Puerto Rico. Isn't that a natural movie story? And there are plenty of stories with happy endings, like Hank Aaron and his pursuit of Babe Ruth's home run record.
"For that matter," says Mr. Miller, "the story of how the players finally stood up to the owners and struck to preserve their hard-fought right to free agency would make a terrific movie." But echoing Mr. Braine, Mr. Miller adds, "I wouldn't expect the owners to cooperate with that one."
Stories about contemporary players are never produced, Mr. Miller notes: "They always go back to the past when they do a factual movie about baseball, because then they can get nostalgic about the subject. Hollywood people know baseball from the sports press, and sportswriters are often like overgrown boys nostalgic for a past that never was."(Note: "The Babe," the story of Babe Ruth, has just begun production in Chicago with John Goodman in the lead.)
At least one former ballplayer thinks a realistic movie about baseball can be made -- in fact, he claims to have already made it. Jim Bouton, the former New York Yankees pitching star and author of the controversial best seller "Ball Four," directed a short documentary last year called "Bus League," about life with the Birmingham Barons minor-league team. Even though the film is currently the property of Kingworld, a major distributor of television programming, "Bus League" still hasn't been shown.
"The mentality of the people who do TV and movies amazes me," says Mr. Bouton. "They think people aren't interested in real life. The truth is, if you made movies, and I mean either documentaries or fiction, that showed everything that really goes on in baseball, people would never stop watching. If you followed the players around with a camera, you'd see much stranger and more interesting things than you see in baseball movies. How could you miss? You'd be combining the two great American pastimes, baseball and soap opera.
"You know what would happen? They'd end up showing two-hour movies about the player's lives and broadcast only the highlights of the games."
 
DOUBLE PLAYERS
 Ballplayers don't just perform for the fans in the stadiums. Sometimes they put on a show for moviegoers.
* The New York Yankees' slugging outfield duo of the early 1960's, Mickey Mantle and Roger Maris, appeared in not one but two feature films: "That Touch of Mink" (1961), which starred Cary Grant and Doris Day, and "Safe at Home" (1962). Debate over which film features the pair's finest work has spawned numerous critical feuds, most notably the one between Andrew Sarris and Pauline Kael (see Ms. Kael's landmark essay "Circle, Squares and Diamonds").
* The Pittsburgh Pirates' late, great outfielder Roberto Clemente was supposed to make his film debut in "The Odd Couple" (1968) but backed out when he found out that his role would be to hit into a triple play against the New York Mets in a game attended by the sportswriter Oscar Madison (Walter Matthau). Clemente was too proud to be seen hitting into a triple play, and the Pirate second baseman Bill Mazeroski was asked to pinch hit.
* The comic actor Joe E. Brown starred in two baseball films made from stories by Ring Lardner, "Alibi Ike" (1935) and "Elmer the Great" (1933). Brown chose show business as a career over baseball when the Pirates dropped him in favor of another promising young third baseman, Pie Traynor, who went on to a Hall of Fame career. -- Allen Barra

SECTION: Section 7; Page 30; Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 375 words

HEADLINE: 'Illiberal Education'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Nancy S. Dye offers a surprisingly simplistic and misleading reading of Dinesh D'Souza's "Illiberal Education: The Politics of Race and Sex on Campus" (March 31), one of the year's most important books.
Instead of responding to Mr. D'Souza's analysis, Ms. Dye constructs frail straw men easily devastated by her merciless blows. "Like other conservative critics," she writes, "he believes that if only professors would stop assigning texts conservatives deem subversive and start showing slides of the Parthenon, disaffected young Americans of every background would rally around a core of shared values and traditions." Actually, in "Illiberal Education," Mr. D'Souza says very little about "the great books" and nothing about the Parthenon. What he does do is show that race relations are souring on campus and postulate that policies designed to combat the problem actually exacerbate it. His proposed solutions include new affirmative action policies based on economic need rather than race, but not slides of the Parthenon -- or greater adherence to the traditional curriculum, for that matter.
Mr. D'Souza marshals a great deal of evidence to make the case that under the banners of multiculturalism and diversity, campus leaders are redrawing the ugly lines of racial segregation. But rather than deal with the central thesis of Mr. D'Souza's book or challenge his proposed solutions, Ms. Dye chooses to reassure us with a statement irrelevant to the book she is reviewing: "The great books are alive and well on college campuses." She may be right. At Vassar College (of which Ms. Dye is dean of the faculty and from which I graduated last spring), I read Plato, Shakespeare and Melville, but I also witnessed the persistent harassment of conservative black students, intolerant and divisive protest over an invitation to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan to speak on campus and a general souring of race relations.
Ms. Dye could have addressed the threats to racial integration, equality of opportunity and academic freedom that Mr. D'Souza brings to light, but instead she chose to ignore his book and continue a polemical attack against Allan Bloom's "Closing of the American Mind."
 
JONATHAN D. KARL
Washington

HEADLINE: Postings: For First-Timers;
Home Loans

 BODY:
The drop in interest rates and a moderation of housing prices throughout the New York region has opened a window of opportunity for many people who wanted to buy a home during most of the 80's but could not afford one.
Now the State of New York Mortgage Agency, also known as Sonyma, has opened that window a bit wider. The agency introduced a new fixed-rate mortgage last month with down payments as low as 2 percent. Other Sonyma-sponsored mortgages require a minimum of 5 percent down on the purchase price. The new loans, which are for first-time buyers, are available for amounts up to $191,250 on one-family houses, cooperatives and condominiums. The loan limits for buyers of multi-family residences range from $244,650 for two-family houses to $367,500 for four-family houses.
Income limits for borrowers vary according to the location of the property. They range from $58,685 for a household of three or more in most of the state to $85,560 for such families in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. The mortgages, which will be available through Jan. 31, carry origination fees of 2.5 percent. For more information call the Sonyma mortgage line at (800) 382-HOME.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 4; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1907 words

HEADLINE: Summertime, and the Prices Are Easy

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
WITH recession gripping the Northeastern states, clouds are hanging over the region's summer resorts.
The Hamptons, Fire Island, Martha's Vineyard, Cape Cod, the Berkshires, the Catskills and the resort communities of the New Jersey Shore are all struggling through mini-slumps. 
 These summer havens also have been jolted by changing demographics and shifting vacation preferences. Families that once would have rented a house for a month or more are now taking shorter but more frequent vacations, and the large groups of single people in their 20's who once seized on house-sharing arrangements are now shrinking as the Baby Boom generation grows older.
In many cases, the shifts have prompted new and different rental arrangements. Brokers say extremely short-term rentals -- for a week or even less -- are growing more commonplace. So, too, are house shares by single people over 40, couples and even families with young children.
Whatever the causes, owners and brokers report that demand for summer houses is off, prices are down as much as 20 percent and more second homes are being offered for rent.
"The exuberance has left the market," said Tina S. Fredericks, a broker in East Hampton who handles rentals in the Hamptons, Montauk and other communities at the east end of Long Island. "We certainly don't get a sense that people are hot to spend a lot of money."
Those in the market for a summer house, she added, "are looking for less-expensive, shorter-term rentals."
The downturn began with the summer of 1989, experts say, when the huge weekend migrations to the region's beaches and mountain areas began to wane.
While this has provided some relief for crowd-weary sun worshipers, hikers and motorists, it has also thrown the region's resort real estate markets into disarray. In communities where large numbers of homes have traditionally been rented out for the summer, and where demand seemed all but insatiable during most of the 80's, summer renters are now being courted more aggressively than any time in memory.
As always, the rentals are being packaged in many forms -- large groups of unrelated single people sharing beach houses, families leasing mountain cabins for two weeks or a month and wealthy people taking country estates at rents as high as $100,000 for the three-month season from Memorial Day to Labor Day.
Real estate executives in some of the most popular Northeastern resorts -- including the Hamptons and Cape Cod -- say that last year was the weakest in more than a decade, with hundreds of houses sitting empty for part or all of the summer season.
And the summer of 1991 promises large numbers of vacation houses at rents that are highly negotiable, and in most cases well below the lofty levels reached in the mid-80's.
The slump has been aggravated by the growing number of properties offered for rent, just as demand has slackened. Resort community brokers say the inventory has expanded because so many second homes that owners normally would use themselves for most or all of the summer are being listed. Plagued by job worries, reduced incomes and other recessionary woes, many owners are electing to economize by renting out their summer houses for the first time, or for longer periods than they had in the past.
"IT seems like everybody who owns a house is suddenly offering it for rent," said Harriet Haynes, a Manhattan real estate executive who is seeking tenants for two houses she owns in in Otis, Mass., a resort community in the Berkshires. "Maybe the people who bought second homes just can't afford them."
Mrs. Haynes and her husband, Charles, a professor at New York University, have been investing in Berkshire houses and renting them out since the early 80's. Renters, she said, "have just become a lot more cautious."
"We've reached a point where people want to rent by the week, and they also want to look at the house before they commit," she said. In contrast, more summer renters in the mid-80's took houses for a month or more, and did so simply on the basis of photographs and verbal descriptions of the property.
Some owners of vacation homes and officials of the resort communities say the bottom of the slump may have passed. They point to a rebound in economic optimism since the end of the Persian Gulf War, and a tendency of many families, still nervous about the international travel in the aftermath of the war, to vacation closer to home.
"Our calls for summer rentals have been the highest in four years," said Pat Padula, director of the Department of Tourism for Monmouth County in New Jersey, which includes Belmar, Ocean Grove, Point Pleasant and other beachfront resorts. She estimated that brokers in the resort communities had signed on 30 percent more summer tenants so far this year than they had at the same time last year.
Though rents have eased, leasing a house in the more popular beach and mountain resort areas still can be expensive. Simple three-bedroom houses close to the beach in the Hamptons begin at around $20,000 for the three-month summer season. On Fire Island, Cape Cod and along the New Jersey Shore, season prices range from $10,000 to $15,000, and even in the less costly mountain communities of upstate New York and western Massachusetts, cabins fetch $5,000 or more.
Those who share houses, known in the resort communities as "groupers," have refined their arrangments into a complex ritual. The groups are brought together at open houses, cocktail parties and through classified advertising and typically include at least 12 people sharing a three-bedroom house.
In such an arrangement, known as a "half-share," each renter is entitled to use the house only on alternate weekends, and shares a bedroom. On Fire Island and in some communities in the Hamptons, where house shares are most common, rates for a half-share begin at $1,000 for the summer, and exceed $1,500 for many houses.
Homeowners and experienced renters say prices have declined 10 percent to 20 percent since they reached a peak in 1987 and 1988.
"The idea is simply to pay the mortgage and stay above water," said Alan Freeman, a Manhattan producer of educational films who is seeking 19 more single people for half shares this summer in an eight-bedroom house he owns in Ocean Beach, on Fire Island. He attended a recent house-share promotion at a Manhattan hotel at which homeowners sought tenants with photographs and videotapes of happy weekenders frolicking in the surf.
Mr. Freeman already has nine half-share tenants who have signed, five of whom took advantage of a special discount offered to those who committed themselves before April 15. They are paying $1,000 for the summer. Now, he said, he is asking $1,350.
His experience in some ways reflects those of others who bought resort properties during the giddy real estate boom of the 80's and are now in a financial squeeze. He said that when he bought the Fire Island house in 1986 he had planned to rent part of it out, but to smaller groups. He also hoped to use the beach and oceanfront vista as a setting for environmental and drug- prevention films. But after failing to win funds for his film production projects from the Federal Government or private sources, he said his income has been less expected, and he has no choice but to fill the house with summer renters.
The summer rental slump, while clearly tied to the region's deep economic problems, also reflects shifts in demographics and the preferences of young families. Many are no longer able or willing to take long vacations. Indeed, veterans of the resort rental industry say a major shift in the market began to emerge in the 70's with the growing number of women in the workplace.
FOR decades, thousands of families in the Northeast had rented cottages or houses for the summer and organized their schedules so that mothers and children would use the use the rentals all summer and working fathers would join them on weekends. But for women with full-time jobs, that option disappeared.
Now, some analysts say, families are being tempted by a range of travel options throughout the year that reduce the amount of vacation time they can devote to a summer rental.
"The recession has hurt, but for a lot of people it has become a question of whether they want to take a whole month and rent a house," said Barbara Nevin, a broker on Martha's Vineyard, Mass. She added that the island's summer rental market, although "picking up a bit this year," had been "very weak during the last two seasons."
"We are seeing a pattern," Mrs. Nevin said. "The same kind of families that used to rent a house for a month are now deciding maybe to rent for two weeks and spend the other two weeks at Disney World or someplace else."
Another shift affecting most of the resort areas, particularly those where sharing houses has been commonplace, is the aging of the Baby Boom. As the population bulge that moved during the 1980's from its 20's to its 30's now moves into its 40's, veteran "groupers" say the character of house sharing has changed.
"There was a wildness in the 70's and 80's that has just about disappeared," said Mike Turitto, a New York City sales representative who has been organizing co-ed groups to share houses on Fire Island for 15 years and is now looking for 10 more people, ages 28 to 40, to fill a house in Ocean Beach. Ten have already signed on.
"People have gotten older and much more conservative," he said, adding that there are now many more "subcultures of house shares."
For many, the appeal of summer house sharing has not diminished with age, marriage or even children. Increasingly, married couples and families with children are getting together to share.
"We share the kitchen, the children play together and it usually works out smoothly for everybody," said Barbara Rothchild, a Manhattan pre-kindergarten teacher who, with her husband, Norman, a sales manager, owns a seven-bedroom house in Southhampton.
The Rothchilds, who have a 7-year-old daughter, share the house with other families during the summer. She said the house mates have included friends -- they met one of the couples in a Lamaze class -- but most have been strangers who responded to their newspaper "house-share" advertisements. This year, the ad has been placed, but house mates have yet to sign on. The price for a family in the Rothchild's house is $3,500 for a half-share.
"We are getting a lot of phone inquiries," she said. "People are shopping around."
Elsewhere in the mountain and beach communities of the Northeast, real estate experts say summer renters are approaching the market with caution and with economies in mind.
On Fire Island, Lee Mehlig, a broker based in Saltaire who deals in summer rentals, said one clear sign of the slump last year was among hundreds of summer houses on the island that are rented out by the month. These monthly rentals have always been in highest demand for August, he said, and August rents have almost always been committed to tenants by April or May. But last year, he said many houses were still available for August in June and July, and some even remained empty during the peak of the August vacation period.
The market for house shares has also been weak, he added.
"It used to be that if you had six slots to fill you could count on 8 or 10 applications," Mr. Mehlig said. "Now maybe you will get 4."
