HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Manhattan Hotels;
Redoing the Sheratons for the Convention and After

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
WHEN the Sheraton Centre asks guests to pardon its appearance during renovation, it means more than indulging a change in wallpaper.
A construction hoist has been lashed to the side of the 50-story tower. A sidewalk shed runs around the base. The lobby, being completely reoriented, has been greatly truncated. And that powerful pounding guests hear is the sound of four new elevator shafts being driven through the building. 
 What is going on, in short, is almost as much a re-creation as a remodeling. In the end, the 29-year-old hotel on Seventh Avenue, between 52d and 53d Streets, will court a new clientele, charge higher prices and get a new name: the Sheraton New York Hotel. Much the same process is under way at the Sheraton City Squire, cater-corner from the Centre, which is to emerge from a remodeling and partial refacing as the Sheraton Manhattan Hotel. Both projects were designed by Brennan Beer Gorman of Manhattan.
Given the current slow state of the hotel market, it might seem surprising that ITT Sheraton would commit $142.6 million to renovate the 1,800-room skyscraper and $47.2 million to redo its 650-room neighbor.
But the hotels are being rebuilt for what the company, based in Boston, hopes will be a better market, and for the 1992 Democratic National Convention, for which the Sheraton Centre, along with the nearby New York Hilton, will serve as headquarters.
Moreover, a period of lower occupancy would seem to be ideal for a renovation. At the moment, eight floors, representing nearly 300 rooms, are out of service.
"We couldn't have picked a better time to do this," said Karl Franck, vice president and managing director of Sheraton's two Seventh Avenue properties. "There is a downturn in business and there was a war -- which, incidentally, did not figure in our planning. But it happened to be good timing all around. By next year, we'll have the right product and the overall economic situation is expected to reverse itself to a degree. We intend to go after the overseas market. And away we'll go. It will be a new game."
For now, not only is occupancy down at the two Sheraton hotels, so are the rates, although Mr. Franck declined to be specific.
Overall, the occupancy rate in New York City was 53.3 percent in January, according to the most recent figures compiled by Pannell Kerr Forster, certified public accountants, a national concern with headquarters in Manhattan. That is in contrast to a rate of 59.7 percent in January 1990.
Averaged annually, New York City had an occupancy rate of 72.6 percent for 1990, a drop from 74.6 percent in 1989 and 76.7 percent in 1988 and 1987. "An occupancy in the low 70's is still very healthy and may be one of the highest in the country," said John A. Fox, a principal in Pannell Kerr Forster. "Things have softened but by no means is it the death knell of the industry."
"I don't have figures for the postwar period but, anecdotally, things seem to be coming back," Mr. Fox said. "But they're still not booming."
"I don't think we're going to recapture what we lost," said Stephen W. Brener, an industry consultant whose Manhattan firm bears his name. "We're going to have trouble holding on to what we had. I don't think the hotel industry is going to come out of this recession until way into the next year."
Another vital sign that has dropped in recent months is the average daily room rate, which was $139.62 in January, contrasted to $142.36 in January 1990.
"It's not a substantial drop but it's unique to New York," Mr. Fox said. "New York's rates, at least in the last 20-year period, have increased in excess of inflation. As for the near future, he said, "the consensus is that rates will be either flat or slightly up but still significantly below inflation rates."
The room rates compiled by Pannell Kerr Forster reflect what a hotel takes in, not what a guest pays. To that $139.62 average rate, for example, would be added $11.52 in sales tax (at 8.25 percent), $8.38 in the city's occupancy tax (at 6 percent), $6.98 in the newly imposed New York State occupancy tax (at 5 percent) and a $2 city hotel tax (for rooms costing more than $40) -- bringing the total to $168.50.
"THE newest room tax hurt us badly," Mr. Fox said. "It makes it much tougher for New York City to be competitive with other major destinations, particularly as it relates to groups and convention business, which is very attuned to rates."
One big project that has suffered in the current market is the hotel planned at the southernmost end of Battery Park City. Having sent out a request for proposals, the Battery Park City Authority began talking with a development and operating team. However, David Emil, the president of the authority, noted last week that "the market for hotel development is much weaker than a year ago and there are substantial problems in our current negotiations."
Some of the projects that are still going forward are the Regent Hotel, on 57th Street, between Madison and Park Avenues; the Ramada Renaissance Hotel, on Broadway, between 47th and 48th Streets and Sheraton's remodeling of the St. Regis, Fifth Avenue and 55th Street, which is to reopen this fall.
Remodeling was long overdue at both the Sheraton Centre and City Squire, which were built by Laurence A. Tisch and Preston Robert Tisch. The Sheraton Centre opened in 1962 as the Americana and claimed the distinction of being the tallest hotel in the world. It was also about the closest Manhattan ever got to a Miami Beach hotel, with its abstract geometric shapes and vivid yellow color.
On the day the Americana opened, the Tisch brothers began the City Squire, a high-rise motel with its base given over to parking. It also had -- and still has -- a swimming pool, a rarity in a Manhattan hotel.
Both were taken over by a partnership between Sheraton and the Equitable Life Assurance Society in 1979. Sheraton bought out Equitable's interest last year, at which time it was at liberty to begin the renovation.
WHILE the Sheraton Centre served as a Democratic headquarters for the 1976 and 1980 conventions, it has been showing its age and design defects. The lobby was remarkably small and cramped, traffic patterns were confusing, elevator service was inadequate and the rooms, guests complained, were much too noisy.
"The way the hotels have been in recent times has not measured up to Sheraton's own standards in other parts of the world," Mr. Franck said. "This was not a secret."
At the Sheraton Centre, the lobby is being expanded to 8,740 from 3,520 square feet; three new passenger elevators are being added to serve floors 21 through 28, easing the load on the six existing high-rise cabs; a new service elevator is being installed running the height of the building; dark-tinted, double-glazed windows are being added throughout, which ought to cut down noise in the rooms and will also change the appearance of the hotel's facade.
The more luxurious "Towers" portion of the hotel, which now takes up the 46th through 50th floors, will be expanded two floors and get an expanded lounge and a new four-bedroom, duplex suite. A new entrance for the convention business is to be built on 53d Street and new escalators will serve the ballroom- and meeting-room floors. Public rooms and guest rooms will be renovated.
Across the avenue, the base of the City Square -- which is now covered in a heavy metal grille that makes the structure look exactly like the parking garage it is -- will be reclad with bays of reflective glass and panels of acrylic cement and plaster. Guest rooms will be renovated and get new windows like those at the Sheraton Centre.

HEADLINE: Perspectives: The Federal Buildings;
A Spur to Slow Construction

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
FOR New York City, the proper word for two major Federal building projects that are going forward in lower Manhattan is opportune.
Over $500 million in new construction will be "going into the ground," in the lingo of the construction trade, late this year or early next with the award of two contracts by the General Services Administration last month. 
 One project is a new Federal Court House, the largest in the country, to supplement the existing court building serving the Southern District. The other is an office building. They will start at a time when all indications are that private construction work in the city is sliding toward its lowest levels since the 70's, dragging construction employment down.
"The situation is bad and could potentially get us back to where we were in the 1973-74 period," said Louis Coletti, president of the New York Building Congress, an association of businesses involved in construction. Current unemployment in the construction trades is about 25 percent, he said. In lower Manhattan, the vacancy rate in office buildings is 17.5 percent, says Cushman & Wakefield, the commercial real estate firm.
Figures from F.W. Dodge Corporation, the McGraw-Hill affiliate that tracks construction activity, show a 64 percent decline in starts in residential and nonresidential construction in the first quarter of this year compared with the first quarter of 1990. The number was 2.3 million square feet this quarter and 6.4 million a year ago.
Historically, public projects have helped take up slack under these circumstances. For the Government, the slack means more competitive prices and lower costs than could have been achieved in the 80's. And the Federal Government prefers to own rather than lease the space it occupies long-term.
ACCORDINGLY, all parties involved in these projects are congratulating themselves that they are starting a countercyclical effort in New York City development. They also are bringing two institutional quality buildings to lower Manhattan that will undoubtedly add stature to the urban environment long beyond this cycle and the next.
They are also focusing attention on the Federal Government's space needs, which have grown in Manhattan even as employment regionally has fallen in the last 10 years. The reason is the big rise in activities related to criminal justice and environmental protection.
The new buildings bear description.
The beige-stone courthouse completes the Foley Square ensemble of court buildings. It is a 27-story tower rising above a broad nine-story base on a site of almost two acres east of the New York County Courthouse and across Pearl Street from the existing Federal court building. The $241 million contract was awarded to BPT Properties, a partnership of Bechtel Investments Realty and the Park Tower Group.
It will have 43 courtrooms and one ceremonial courtroom in a structure of 921,000 gross square feet. Courtrooms come in varied sizes. There will be 23 "typical" courtrooms (2,100 square feet, 12-foot ceilings); six large courtrooms (2,800 square feet, 16-foot ceilings); and 14 smaller magistrates' courts (1,500 square feet, 15-foot ceilings, usually). Then there is a ceremonial court (5,000 square feet, 20-foot ceilings).
A courthouse also needs space for juries and lawyers and judges' chambers and libraries and staff functions. Add it all up and it comes to 547,000 square feet of occupiable space. The term "occupiable" in Federal parlance means the space inside the walls where people work. It is a smaller fraction of the gross floor area than what the private market calls rentable square feet in an office building.
The architects are the firms of Kohn Pederson Fox Associates and Simmons Architects, a participating minority firm. Lehrer McGovern Bovis, with Don Todd Associates, another minority firm, is the general contractor and Structure Tone is construction manager for the interior. The ground breaking is scheduled for the end of this year and initial occupancy should start in early 1994, says Daniel MacEachron, senior vice president of BPT Properties.
The office project is on a 70,000-square-foot site east of Broadway between Duane and Reade Streets. It will be a 34-story building with 974,000 gross square feet (687,000 occupiable above street level), with the main entrance at 290 Broadway on the Duane Street corner. A four-story arcade 25 feet wide will run along Duane Street facing 26 Federal Plaza, the nation's largest Federal office building aside from the Pentagon. The design also includes a three-story rotunda and a low pavilion at the eastern side of the site for a daycare center, auditorium and health club.
The $276 million contract was won by the Linpro Company, a national developer based in Berwyn, Pa., through its New York office, where Christopher F. McGratty and John T. Livingston are the partners in charge. The architect is the firm of Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum. Raquel Ramati Associates was the design consultant and Tishman Construction Corporation is the general contractor.
Excavation can be expected to start in five or six months, Linpro said. In one sense the new office building seems to come at a peculiar time. Any entity other than the Federal Government would be tempted to move into the rental market during the soft downtown market and find bargain-priced space. New York City is doing just that, putting aside its original intention to take half the space in the new Federal office building. That lease probably would have cost over $50 per occupiable square foot.
BUT the Federal Government considers it advantageous in the long run to own its space, which it can produce economically because of its low borrowing costs. And contractor prices are likely to be lower when activity is slow.
"Put it this way," said Donald R. Knab, chairman of BPT Properties. "If the need exists, this is precisely the time to do it."
The need exists, says William J. Diamond, regional administrator of the General Services Administration. At 26 Federal Plaza, "not a square foot is available," he said. "We can't even put in a physical fitness unit."
The big growers have been the Environmental Protection Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The E.P.A. is aleady a 175,000-square-foot tenant at 26 Federal Plaza and in the new building will have 250,000 square feet, its total allotment. The F.B.I. will take the rest of the space in 290 Broadway but will keep some of its space across the street.
Federal employment in Manhattan has risen over the last 10 years to 27,200, officials said, from 23,800 in 1981. The Government has had to take more leased space than it prefers, said Mr. Diamond. The regional counsel of the I.R.S. moved into 39,000 square feet at 7 World Trade Center; the General Accounting Office took 24,600 square feet there. The Security Exchange Commission took 38,600 at 75 Park Place.
The development projects are moving forward as soon as they are because of New York City's willingness to let the Government have the sites in a "friendly condemnation" after design negotiations with the City Planning Commission. The Government paid $104 million for the sites. Had a public review process been required, which residents of nearby residential buildings would have preferred, the projects might well have been delayed beyond 1992.
As it is, a construction start early in 1992 would come more than four years after Senate authorization of funds for both projects, in December 1987. Even then, court clerks were sitting at desks in hallways.

HEADLINE: Talking: Insurance;
Meeting Mortgage Payments

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
A TERRIFYING prospect for any homeowner with a large monthly mortgage payment is a long period of unemployment. The rise in foreclosures over the last year is a direct reflection of how easily such a calamity can occur during a recession.
 But the specter of default is as much a problem for bankers as borrowers. Thus it is hardly surprising that lenders look for ways to encourage borrowers to protect their payments from such a hazard through a private insurance policy. Known as mortgage unemployment insurance, the idea was conceived by Richard T. Harris, president of Morgard, a St. David's, Pa., agency that supplies support services to insurance companies. The policy is not for everybody, for the premiums can be quite high under some circumstances.I 
 Last November, the first homeowners were solicited -- the 280,000 carrying mortgage loans from Chase Mortgage Corporation of Tampa, Fla. The opportunity has since spread to other lenders; the insurance can be bought only if the lender is participating in such a program.
 New borrowers are being offered an even better opportunity. Increasingly, the real estate broker, builder or banker supplying either the property or the loan has been offering to pay the premiums for the first year or so. "All the opinion polls were showing that one of the main reasons people weren't buying was because they were concerned about their jobs," said Mr. Harris.
 Offering to pay the premiums for a trial period became an obvious marketing tool. "If it can give our buyers the peace of mind they need to buy a home, it's probably well worth it," said Tim Good, president of Mortgage Access Corporation of Morris Plains, N.J., an affiliate of Weichert Realtors that has been exploring the idea.
 This form of unemployment insurance adds another layer of security to the more traditional protection, known as mortgage life insurance, that pays off a mortgage entirely if the borrower dies.
 The key question for borrowers is whether the enemployment insurance is worth the cost. That question also arises for mortgage life insurance.
 Unemployment protection covers the borrower's mortgage payments while he or she is out of work. Coverage is normally limited to a year, although a shorter term -- say, six months -- may occasionally be obtained for lower premimums. Almost all policies will cover payments of up to $2,500 a month, enough to cover most borrowers' needs. Payments are defined as principal, interest, taxes and insurance, all of which are normally paid to the lender in one monthly check.
 The premium is based on the size of monthly payments, the risk rating of the borrower's job category and the geographical area. For instance, a borrower who is a salesman in Middlesex County, N.J., carrying monthly payments of $1,000 would pay a premium of $39 a month under the policy being considered by another Weichert affiliate, the Weichert Insurance Agency.
 Borrowers with an adjustable-rate loan could find their premiums automatically adjusted up or down with their monthly payments as interest rates fluctuate. Premiums are added to the regular amount payable to the lender each month.
 If two people, such as a married couple, are on the mortgage note, both will be covered for the same premium as a single individual, but the rating will be based on a blend of both job category ratings. If one loses a job, benefits will be based on the unemployed spouse's prior portion of total household income. For example, if the wife lost her job and her income represented 40 percent of household income, then 40 percent of the mortgage payments would be covered.
THERE is normally a waiting period of 30 to 60 days after a layoff before coverage begins. Being dismissed for cause or having prior knowledge of a pending layoff before the policy was issued are grounds for automatic disqualification.
Anyone who is self-employed or has a checkered employment history or even a job considered extremely insecure, such as a truck driver, assembler or construction worker, may not even be accepted. However, situations that involve only a temporary layoff may be covered.
 Patricia Mungenast, assistant treasurer with Chase Mortgage, said about 250 people had signed up so far. Based on initial reponses, she said that far more will be enrolled as soon as the remaining states approve the plan. About 35 states have approved so far; in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut approval is still pending.
Borrowers seeking advice from their local independent insurance agent may not find much. Many are skeptical about the opportunity although they admit they do not yet know much about it. "You are normally better looking at your entire insurance needs in a more comprehensive way," said John Manougian, president of John Manougian Insurance Agency of Silver Spring, Md.
 But there are exceptions. If the borrower's job might indeed be in jeopardy within the next few years the investment could be worthwhile, especially if the job might prove difficult to replace without relocating, said Glenn Daily, an insurance consultant in New York City.
 Part of the skepticism may derive from the negative view independent agents have traditionally taken of mortgage life insurance -- a policy added to monthly payments that pays off the remaining principal if the borrower dies.
 Under such a policy, premiums remain stable for the life of the loan but the potential proceeds decrease as the outstanding balance shrinks. In most instances -- though there are exceptions -- the payoff goes directly to the lender, not the survivor or beneficiary. So the beneficiary cannot control the use of the money, if, for instance, he or she prefers not to have the loan paid off.
Mortgage life insurance offered through a lender does not normally require a physical examination and may be the best type of life insurance anyone with medical problems may be able to buy, agents concede.
 Further, said Mr. Manougian, "some of the policies allow the money to go to the beneficiary instead of the bank."
He added that this option is more likely to be available through a regular insurance agent than from a lender. The ones from the independent agent may also be cheaper.
 In other instances, a compromise might work. For example, Chase Mortgage now offers a payoff tied only to accidental death -- an alternative that sharply decreases premiums and might be particularly appropriate for the younger borrower.

HEADLINE: THE VIEW FROM: THOMASTON;
Opera House Revival Is Work in Progress

BYLINE: By CHARLOTTE LIBOV

 BODY:
IN 1958, a determined group in East Haddam mounted a campaign to rescue a dilapidated opera house that was slated for demolition. They succeeded, and the building became the Goodspeed Opera House, nationally renowned for its efforts to preserve the American musical.
Now, similar efforts are under way in Thomaston, with the goal of turning the town's formerly condemned opera house into a cultural beacon for northwestern Connecticut. But Sally Hassenfelt, the program director for the Thomaston Opera House Commission, said she doesn't like to carry comparisons to Goodspeed too far. Although she is an admirer of Goodspeed, she said, she wants the Thomaston hall to create its own tradition as a community resource with varied uses. 
 "The only way for us to succeed through the recession is to become a place for the performing arts through the whole area -- for the town, the county, the state and for neighboring states," Miss Hassenfelt said. "But we would have to be flexible, and that means offering children's theater, educational theater, concerts and special events."
Virtually since the Thomaston Opera House was shut in 1985, supporters have worked to revive it. The community is getting an opportunity to gauge their success at an "April Celebration Weekend" of theater and music, which began yesterday. These are the first public events at the opera house in six years.
Today's program, scheduled for 2:30 P.M., includes a performance by the Naugatuck Valley Youth Symphony and an organ solo by Wade Bray of Norwalk.
 
Work for Mops and Brooms
 A recent feasibility study concluded that total renovation of the opera house, which occupies the top two floors of the Town Hall, would cost about $1.2 million -- a daunting sum, Miss Hassenfelt acknowledged. So, the commission is going slowly, she said, holding performances before most of the restoration work has even begun.
"We feel the important thing now is to get it open, so people can see all the wonderful things we can do here," Miss Hassenfelt said recently, as she watched workers put the finishing touches on a new stage floor. Mops and brooms were in the corner, ready to tackle the hall's heavy coat of dust. By opening night, though, "the place will shine," promised Mary Reynolds, chairwoman of the Thomaston Opera House Commission.
Since its construction in 1884, the opera house has played a major role in Thomaston's history and legend. Built at a cost of $50,000, the 564-seat hall is listed on the state and national Registers of Historic Places. The formal European-style opera house sits atop the red-brick Victorian Town Hall. Town meetings, high school graduations and other civic functions were held in the opera house, as well as balls, vaudeville and even performances of opera.
Gene Martin, retired executive editor of The Waterbury American and treasurer of the opera house commission, recalled going to the opera house as a boy, when it was briefly used as a movie theater.
"Supposedly, Caruso sang there, and Ray Bolger danced there," he said. "But I'm a little skeptical, because I can't find a playbill or an article. But George Jessel appeared several times."
 
Classic Pipe Organ
 Legend holds that the opera house is haunted by the ghost of an old man who was caretaker at the town firehouse next door. "People have said they hear strange noises," Mr. Martin said. "But I don't put much stock in it."
As it fell into disuse in the 1960's, the town condemned the opera house and prepared to demoish it, but a group of local volunteers made enough repairs to meet fire and building codes, and it was reopened. In 1971, the Connecticut Valley Theater Organ Society installed a classic pipe organ in the hall, which was used for summer theater and occasional concerts.
"Over the past 40 years, there were other commissions which contributed money through cake sales and performances, and they collected sizable sums to get the opera house restored," Mrs. Reynolds said. "We would just get to the brink, and then something disastrous would come along."
In 1985, officials closed the opera house in the midst of a performance of "Our Town" by a New York theater troupe, citing fire code violations. Following a study of the Town Hall and the opera house, the town meeting voted to renovate the entire building to comply with safety codes.
"It's a wonderful building," said Mrs. Reynolds. "It would be a shame to see it destroyed."
Even with the renovations, the interior of the opera house seems unchanged from its original construction. That authenticity makes it such a treasure, said Craig Morrison, a Philadelphia architect who is a consultant for the League of Historic Theaters in Washington.
"In New England, there is quite a tradition of having these opera houses, but a lot of these have been torn down or renovated," said Mr. Morrison, who visited the opera house in February. "Once in a while, you find one like this, which has stayed intact and has stage and decoration and begs to be used. It's a real charmer."
Miss Hassenfelt, who has worked in the theater since 1972, said she learned about the opera house in 1989 while having lunch in Manhattan with an actor, James Brennan, who had performed there in summer stock. A onetime apprentice at Goodspeed, she went on to work as a stage manager for John Houseman at the Juilliard School in Manhattan and for New York productions of "Fiddler on the Roof," "Annie" and "42d Street."
 "The opera house is part of the history of our town," said Thomaston's First Selectman, Eugene McMahon. "In the old days, we had town meetings and dances there. It was the hub of the town. Because of its history, and because it could be one of the finest little theaters in northwestern Connecticut, I think it should be restored."
 The long-range plans for the theater include summer musical productions, a year-round concert series, plus new plays, theater workshops and educational programs for adults and children. But for now, the commission is trying to raise modest sums. A recent $10,000 grant from the Waterbury Foundation will pay for the new floor and stage lights. And the commission has applied for a grant from the State Commission on the Arts to mount a fall musical, Miss Hassenfelt said. The opera house has no air-conditioning, so plans for all-year use are on hold.
But even though the major renovation of the Thomaston Opera House still appears years off, enthusiasts are more hopeful than they've been in years, said Mrs. Reynolds.
"There is a whole new feeling about the opera house," she said. "Even though there are still water stains on the walls, everyone who comes in just senses the magic is here. The time is right."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1695 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: April 21-26

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:
COMPANIES
 
Lockheed's Side Gets a Big Boost From the Air Force
 

After five years of intense competition, the Air Force selected the Lockheed Corporation, the General Dynamics Corporation, the Boeing Company and Pratt & Whitney, a division of the United Technologies Corporation, to build its next-generation fighter, the F-22. The contract may also determine which companies remain in the military aviation business. The award is one of the largest in history -- it may total $95 billion if a full 650 planes are built -- and one of the only remaining large-scale military-aviation projects. With the end of the cold war and the sharp declines in spending, the losing team, headed by the Northrop Corporation, must now decide if has a future making planes.
 
The Exxon Deal Sours
 
They danced around the negotiating table for more than a year. And until last week, the Exxon Corporation, the State of Alaska and the Justice Department thought they had a deal. Exxon would pay as much as $1.1 billion in civil penalties over 10 years and an additional $100 million in criminal fines for damages caused by the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill. But Federal District Judge H. Russell Holland told the parties to call back their lawyers. He said $100 million was not enough money to deter a company the size of Exxon, from future wrongdoings. "I'm afraid these fines send the wrong message, suggesting that oil spills are a cost of business that can be absorbed." Absorbed they can be. Last week Exxon announced record first-quarter earnings of $2.24 billion.
 
A Fumble in the T.W.A. Plan
 
Kirk Kerkorian, the wily Beverly Hills investor, wanted to buy troubled Trans World Airlines from Carl C. Icahn. T.W.A. has $2.7 billion in debt and has missed several of its payments. Mr. Kerkorian was willing to kick in $250 million from his Tracinda Corporation and he had the unions, which were committed to $441 million in givebacks, on his side. But he did not have Transportation Secretary Samuel B. Skinner on his side. Mr. Kerkorian asked the Transportation Department to stop the sale of T.W.A.'s trans-Atlantic routes to American Airlines. Those routes were part of Mr. Kerkorian's restructuring strategy. Last week, Mr. Skinner said the sale could go through. Mr. Icahn will get cash -- the exact amount still to be negotiated -- but cash may not be enough for the airline to survive.
 
Trump's Empire Comes Unglued
 
To Donald Trump, they were trophies. Now he must give the trophies back. In a tentative agreement with his creditors, Mr. Trump -- who owes $2 billion -- would sell the Trump Shuttle to NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines.. Banker's Trust would get Mr. Trump's 50 percent interest in New York's Grand Hyatt Hotel, Citicorp would get his 27 percent share of Alexander's, the department store. The Regency Hotel in Atlantic City would be put on the block. And his yacht -- with its legacy of bestowing bad luck on each of its owners -- would go to a unit of American Express.
 
KKR on a Leash
 
The regulators must be leery. . They placed so so many restrictions on Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company that the buyout firm can only be called a "passive investor." Even though it is putting up $283 million in the deal, led by Fleet/Norstar Financial Group Inc., to take over the Bank of New England the buyout firm will not gain voting rights until after three years. There are more safeguards as well. To prevent KKR from dominating the bank, and possibly lending to itself and friends at favorable rates, the Federal Reserve is not allowing the buyout firm to control its own shares. They must remain in the hands of the firm's 75 investors. Nor will KKR get any seats on the board for three years. Even with these restrictions, analysts expect the deal to set a precedent. Permitting companies to buy banks, after all, is part of the Administration's banking reform plan.
 
Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher, owes his creditors $8.2 billion and is having trouble raising the cash. For Kohlberg Kravis & Roberts, it is another opportunity to do another deal, and last week it put up $600 million to buy most of Mr. Murdoch's magazines. The titles include The Racing Form, Soap Opera Digest, Soap Opera Weekly, New York, Seventeen, Premier, European Travel & Life, Autombile and New Woman.
 
Retrenching at Rolls
 
In the 1980's, when yuppies reigned, Rolls-Royce Motor Cars Ltd., a unit of Britain's Vickers P.L.C., often oversold its production runs. The waiting period for exotic beasts like the $250,000 Bentley Turbo S could be years. But with the yuppies gone, the luxury auto maker too must retrench. It is cutting production by about 18 percent, from 3,333 units in 1990 to 2,760 this year.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
A C-Minus Recession
 
What kind of a report card does this recession get? "Below average for most recessions," said Sam Kahan of Fuji Securities Inc., in Chicago. That's too bad. According to the Commerce Department, the gross national product contracted by 2.8 percent in the first quarter. But what is worse, "consumer spending was also down, for the second quarter in a row." That has not happened since 1980. For an economy that is traditionally pulled along by the consumer, that is a gloomy sign.
 
Big-Ticket Letdown
 
As if the figures for gross national product were not bad enough, orders for durable goods, the big-ticket items that are expected to last at least three years but often don't, have taken another big plunge. They were down 6.2 percent last month, according to the Commerce Department, the fourth decline in the last five months and the biggest decline since last November's 11.2 percent drop. "The magnitude of the drop-off is usually associated with the beginning of a recession rather than the end." said Douglas P. Handler, an economist at Dun & Bradstreet.
 
Home Sales Improve, a Bit
 
At least sales of existing homes rose last month. But don't get your hopes up, the increase was minuscule, just 0.6 percent, according to the National Association of Realtors. Still, they did move in the right direction. But the "market is still soft," said Richard Peach, an economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association. "People are concerned about whether they will have jobs."
 
Detroit's Dismal Showing
 
Sales of automobiles continue to shrivel, only more so for the domestic makers than the Japanese and the transplants. In mid-April, Detroit's sales were down 14.1 percent, compared the same period last year. The transplants were up 3.2 percent. Hardest hit was the Ford Motor Company, prompting rumors -- denied -- of further plant closings. Ford lost 30.2 percent in sales while the General Motors Corporation was down by 14.1 percent. Only Chrysler showed an increase, a slim 1.1 percent gain. Some of the Japanese transplants did very well: Mazda was up 434.5 percent, Mitsubishi increased sales by 105.5 percent and Nissan climbed by 62.9 percent. Only Toyota took an American-style plunge: its sales fell by 22.8 percent.
 
Why the Worries on Inflation?
 
So how does Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, view the economic news? He is more worried about price stability than economic contraction. "The issue of inflation," Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee last week, "is that it never surfaces visibly until it is well advanced." Is inflation really such a pressing concern? "Even in this recession, the economy is running at 79 percent of capacity," said Robert P. Prince, head of research at Bridgewater Associates Inc., in Wilton, Conn. "Inflation kicks in at about 80 percent and getting there from here doesn't take that much growth."
 
Pickens Attacks Japanese
 
T. Boone Pickens is an unlikely defender of the nation's industrial heartland. But that's what the corporate raider and Texas oilman sounded like last week when he testified before Congress. He said Japan's big auto makers, when they set up shop in America, brought their suppliers with them. Transplanted Japanese companies supplied other transplanted Japanese companies in a manner verging on collusion. He is supported in his claims by a number of unions and a Midwestern think tank. Does Mr. Pickens have an ax to grind? Yes. After buying 26 percent of the Koito Manufacturing Company, one of Toyota's suppliers, he was denied a seat on its board even though he was its biggest shareholder. In the battle over the seat, Toyota, with only 19 percent of the shares, voted against him. He vowed to continue the fight.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Cutting a Deal, New Soviet Style
 
The Soviet Union's leaders are behaving more like politicians, less like commissars. Last week, in a dacha near Moscow, President Mikhail Gorbachev and 9 the 15 leaders of the republics hammered out a deal. They forced Mr. Gorbachev to agree to repeal some of the price rises and tax hikes he enacted last month and to change the constitution. Ultimately, "he acknowledges independence for the Baltics, Moldavia and Armenia," said Vladimir Kvint, U.S.S.R. Professor of Political Economy. What does President Gorbachev get? Popularity. That would be a plus, given his dismal ratings of late.
 
Japan's Art Crackdown
 
In Japan, companies buy art not just for esthetic reasons, but also as bribes. That's why police raided Itoman & Company in Osaka, and 50 other sites. Since the Japanese are such big buyers of high-priced art, the crackdowns could affect world auction markets. "Very wealthy persons might not want to be connected with large public purchases right now." said Bonnie Barrett Stretch, editor of Artnewsletter, a trade publication.
 
Germany: Only Inflation Counts
 
Karl Otto Pohl, head of Germany's central bank, has one thing on his mind: inflation. To keep it low, he said, in spite of pressure from Washington German interest rates will not come down. "Mr. Pohl is concerned with the growing money supply and with capacity constraints which lead to inflation," said Carl Weinberg, of High Frequency Economics in New York. Washington will not get its way.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Tough Time for a Promotion

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
On Jan. 1, Edwin M. Cooperman and G. Richard Thoman became co-chairmen and co-chief executives of the American Express Company's biggest money-maker, the Travel Related Services division. They couldn't have picked a worse time.
War soon erupted in the Persian Gulf, the economy fell deeper into recession, personal bankruptcies began to climb and Americans began to move more toward saving than spending. The division, which oversees the company's charge-card operations and has been the engine of American Express's meteoric growth, recorded its first quarterly loss in 25 years. 
 "There has never been a quarter like that," said Mr. Thoman, 46. "We have never seen a recession hitting the affluent consumer, as well as a slowdown in the travel business."
Because of the troubles, executives say they are becoming more conservative in accepting new card holders.
"We intentionally slowed down our card growth," Mr. Cooperman said. "But we still have the engine pumping away."
Indeed, even with the troubles, Mr. Thoman and Mr. Cooperman, who is 47, have been able to bring a number of long-planned initiatives to fruition. Last week, American Express reached an agreement with Sumitomo Bank to form a joint venture to issue personal charge cards and offer consumer loans in Japan. The company also began an effort to cut the comparatively high commissions it charges merchants who accept its card.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
The Dow Looks Even Mightier From Abroad

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
A Dow at 3,000? To Americans who think in dollar terms, that was an extraordinary event. But the strength of the dollar has meant that to foreign investors, American stocks have zoomed much further.
For an investor who thinks in German marks, the Dow Jones industrial average hit its high last Monday, when it was up 31 percent since the beginning of the year. That was the equivalent of the Dow at 3,453, indexing for currency changes from Dec. 31. For an American investor, the Dow had risen but 14 percent when it peaked at 3,004.46 on April 17. 
 The difference, of course, has been the dollar's strong rally, which began in early February, when it was at 1.45 marks, and which has pushed it up to 1.75 marks. The buck's boom owes some of its strength to hopes that the American economy will rally and interest rates will stop falling. But much of the move can be seen as the fall from grace of the mark as Germany's Government struggles with the aftermath of the monetary unification with the former East Germany.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Tracking Environmental Risk

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
When the closing bell clanged at the New York Stock Exchange last June 26, the shares of PPG Industries of Pittsburgh weighed in at $49.25 each. By the next day's close, those shares had skidded nearly $3 -- thanks to fresh news reports about the company's potential role in cleaning up chromium-tainted land in Jersey City.
Curiously, public officials in New Jersey had announced as early as December 1988 their plans to seek cleanup contributions from PPG and several other companies. But as this case illustrates, in the absence of a reliable disclosure process, stocks are enormously vulnerable to the vagaries of sudden reports on possible environmental liabilities. 
 What noxious residue has been found on a company's land? What is being stored on the site next door? What liabilities did the company purchase with its latest acquisition? It is not difficult to imagine the questions that can keep investors awake at night. But finally, it is starting to get a little easier to assemble some answers, too.
One reason is that a regulatory initiative begun two years ago is starting to bear fruit in the current crop of annual reports. The Securities and Exchange Commission warned companies in 1989 to disclose any potential environmental cleanup liabilities they might face under the Federal Superfund law. As a result, many of the current crop of 1990 annual reports provide a bit more information about environmental liabilities than they did in the past, said Michael Silverstein, president of Environmental Economics, a research firm in Philadelphia.
"It's not that the 10-K liability disclosures are totally and completely adequate," Mr. Silverstein said. But the numbers are so compelling that "incomplete as they are, they merit the attention of investors."
Add to that the services of entrepreneurs who are applying computer record-keeping and sorting techniques to the vast numbers of documents that have been filed with state and Federal environmental agencies in the past decade. The result is a host of electronic data bases that can be searched far more quickly and comprehensively than would be possible by hand.
Since 1988, at least a half-dozen new national data bases have been formed, and smaller regional services are springing up almost weekly. There is no exhaustive roster, but industry specialists identified the leading companies as Ensite, based in Denver; Environmental Audits, in Lyonville, Pa.; the Environmental Risk Information Center, in Alexandria, Va.; the Petroleum Information Corporation, in Littleton, Colo.; Toxicheck, in Birmingham, Mich.; Vista Environmental Information in San Diego, and, as the newest entry, Environmental Data Resources in Southport, Conn.
The intensifying competition does not worry Ronald D. Miller, president of Vista, one of the earliest entrants in the field. "The industry is really still in the infancy stage," he said. "The challenge right now is to create a market for our product; once that market is created, we can fight over market share."
Anthony J. Buonicore and Peter Cashman, two former environmental consultants who own the newly hatched Environmental Data Resources, are somewhat less altruistic. Emphasizing their environmental experience, Mr. Cashman said, "We are confident we will take market share."
Mr. Buonicore sees electronic record-searching services as a critical addition to corporate S.E.C. reports. "The S.E.C. action in 1989 is the strongest they've taken about what you have to disclose for environmental liability," he said. "But they rely strongly on the company's own opinion of materiality. So most of the 10-K's do not disclose very much."
Securities lawyers researching potential acquisitions, accountants doing corporate audits, potential investors, lenders and creditors contemplating foreclosure -- all need as complete a picture as possible, he explained. A thorough review of what is already available in the public records of various government agencies is a critical starting point for their examinations.
If it has become easier to find an environmental data base, it is still hard to choose one whose searches will not only provide answers to investors but also satisfy the legal and regulatory criteria that are emerging in the field of environmental assessment. But progress is also being made on that front.
Michael L. Italiano, an environmental lawyer with Gardner, Carton & Douglas in Washington, is the chairman of a multi-industry committee working under the auspices of the American Society for Testing and Materials to develop professional standards for those who do environmental assessments. And when Mr. Italiano's panel offers its proposed standard to the society for adoption later this year, it will almost certainly include some standards for the records' search that those audits entail, he said.
In the meantime, one data-base user has taken matters into his own hands. Robert V. Colangelo is president of the Green Corporation, an environmental services concern in Chicago. He has reviewed most of the leading data bases now available and plans to publish his conclusions later this year, he said.
Among his preliminary findings: Few of the existing companies are insured for errors or omissions in their research, and both product prices and the scope of the search can vary sharply from company to company. While users must shop carefully, he added, the data bases are obviously becoming an important piece of the industry.
Mr. Italiano, the lawyer, also has some reservations about some of today's electronic archives. "My personal view is that it will be a long time before there is a data base that will give you everything you need, because there is just too much land and too much history you need to cover," he said. "But tremendous improvements are being made almost weekly, so their role in the future will probably be much greater than it is now."

HEADLINE: Keep Trade Out of the Deficit Debate

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Mr. Kearns falls victim to his own accusations as he lowers the veil of economics over the United States trade deficit with Japan.
Building factories in the United States is not a result of trade balance manipulation but of good business. The United States realizes gains from the sale of land, supplies, construction and operations associated with the output of such a plant. The Japanese gain the use of a superior work force. The components used by Japanese factories in the United States come from all over the world, just as they do in United States factories and in German factories.
Japan is not the only nation to produce in one foreign country for export to another. This is simply the execution of a long-term business strategy. Take Texas Instruments, which is a major producer of memory chips in Japan. More than one-half of this output returns to the United States in the form of imports from Singapore. Would Mr. Kearns count this as an export of Japan, Singapore or the United States?
 
LAKSHMAN ACHUTHAN
Wainscott, N.Y., April 18
 
The author is an associate at the Center for International Business Cycle Research, Columbia University.

HEADLINE: Congressman Assails Safety of 'Walk-In' Medicine

BYLINE: By Philip J. Hilts, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
While offering hope for new forms of fast and economical medical service, the rapid growth of walk-in clinics and surgical centers is also providing "the last refuge for the medical buccaneer," a Congressman asserts in an opening statement prepared for a hearing on Monday.
"This is a largely unregulated arena of health care," Representative Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, said in his statement prepared for the hearing of the House Small Business Subcommittee on Regulation. 
 Mr. Wyden, the chairman of the panel, put his opinions this way: "Literally millions of procedures are performed each year with little or no quality review of the doctor's expertise, the training of his assisting personnel or the kind and suitability of live-saving equipment which may, or may not, be on hand.
"It is the view of the chair that ambulatory care provides a fertile environment for medical entrepreneurs who are undertrained, unscrupulous or unethical. In the words of one physician interviewed by the subcommittee staff, outpatient services is an area of care that is the last refuge of 'the medical buccaneer.' " m
 
Fast and Inexpensive Care
 The hearing will review the explosive growth of non-hospital clinics and surgical centers, which increased in the 1980's to more than 5,000 from only a handful at the start of the decade. The clinics have proliferated because they offer inexpensive care without long waits over a long period, often staying open late at night.
If centers that provide services like diagnosis, X-rays, drug treatment and mental health care are included, the number registered with states has risen to 23,000 from near zero in the 1970's.
Mr. Wyden provided several illustrations of clinic shortcomings:
*A Southern California doctor allowed his bookkeeper to administer a general anesthetic; the patient died during the operation.
*A diagnostic center in Texas allowed a radiological technician to give a 5-year-old a sedative; the amount given was an overdose and the child died.
*In Virginia, a child choking on a piece of candy nearly died when his mother took him to a clinic where the sign read, "Immediate Care." The clinic turned the child away because no doctor was present. Passing policemen resuscitated the boy on the sidewalk in front of the clinic.
 
Proposed Rules Are Expected

The extent of the problems in such clinics is not known, Mr. Wyden said, adding that that in itself is a problem resulting from the lack of regulation.
The one-day hearing on Monday is expected to help shape regulating legislation that Mr. Wyden is expected to introduce in the current session.
Doctors and medical associations have resisted regulation of the clinics. One reason is that doctors are already regulated by licensing and insurance rules. They say it would be difficult to distinguish, for regulatory purposes, between the clinics and an ordinary doctor's office and the procedures carried out there. Private doctors' offices operate under minimal government regulation.
Dr. Michael D. Bishop, an emergency-room physician who owns five walk-in clinics in Indiana, called the planned hearing "just sensationalistic." He said in a telephone interview that he opposed additional regulations, though they would bring some other clinics up to the standard that he said he applied in his own.
Dr. Bishop said his clinics, called "Immediate Care Centers" on their signs, offer more services than a doctor's office, including the ability to handle emergency cases like heart failures, with special expensive equipment. But he said his clinics discouraged patients from coming for emergency care.
 
Voluntary Guidelines Available

Arthur E. Auer, the secretary of the National Association for Ambulatory Care, which represents several hundred clinics, said his association offers guidelines that the clinics can follow voluntarily. He said no additional regulations were necessary because problems at the clinics were rare, at least among the members of his association
"They are really no different than doctor's offices, unless they advertise certain additional advantages, which they then must live up to," Mr. Auer said. "We don't believe they should advertise a physician on duty or essential equipment if they don't have it."
Frank Papineau, an investigator for the General Accounting Office, who is working with Mr. Wyden's staff, says in testimony prepared for the hearing that there are "some common and continuing problems for the consumer" in the clinics.
 
A $40 Billion 'Fraud' Bill
 Mr. Papineau, whose office is the auditing and investigative arm of Congress, said these include "inapproprate use of, or lack of credentials, no minimum standards for treatment and false and deceptive advertising,"
He said "medical hucksters" are responsible for "a large measure of the $40 billion medical fraud bill paid annually by American consumers and taxpayers." The $40 billion is what Mr. Papineau estimated is spent on unnecessary medical care and procedures annually out of the nation's total medical bill of $700 billion.

HEADLINE: SANDINISTAS SEEK NEW ROLE TO PLAY

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua

 BODY:
A year after going down to electoral defeat, the Sandinista Front is searching for identity in a world without a powerful Soviet Union to arm and defend it, and in a country without right-wing dictators to fight.
The Sandinistas, who rode to power in 1979 at the head of a popular insurrection against the Somoza family dictatorship, lost last year's presidential elections to an opposition coalition led by Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. 
 Now it is debating the creation of a democratic political party, and its leaders say Marxism-Leninism and the idea of taking power by military means have been ruled out. But they seem uncertain, or divided, about what kind of political definition to take. Working documents for a party congress scheduled for July speak of "humanistic socialism," but some rank-and-file members wonder what that means, and others say it sounds too mild.
 
Next Election in 1996
 Former Vice President Sergio Ramirez Mercado, probably the leading theorist of the Sandinista Front, said it was "premature" to try to define the party more clearly now.
Mr. Ramirez said he thought that by the next elections, in 1996, "this neo-liberal enthusiasm in the world will wane, and people will begin to think of alternative models for societies."
"On the other hand," he continued, "we have to see what happens in Nicaragua, whether with Mrs. Chamorro's economic program the country can achieve stability, increase production, grow and create jobs. In that case, an opposition party has to think about what it can offer."
On the personal level, the Sandinista leaders have developed in different directions. For some, who had passed their adult lives underground or in power, this is the first taste of anything like ordinary life.
Former President Daniel Ortega Saavedra spent several months traveling in the Middle East and the Persian Gulf in an ostensible peace effort after Iraq invaded Kuwait. Mr. Ramirez gives speeches abroad and writes, in his first vocation.
Former Interior Minister Tomas Borge, at age 61 the elder in the Sandinista leadership, is trying to establish a career as a celebrity interviewer for foreign newspapers and magazines. He is said to ask $10,000 to do articles on such figures as Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya and Fidel Castro of Cuba.
Luis Carrion Cruz, at 38 the youngest member of what is now a seven-man Sandinista directorate, plans to enroll in the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard in September to work toward a master's degree in public administration.
Mexican-born Victor Tirado, who had a significant role in guerrilla days but a less significant government role, said he was hoping that some group in the United States would invite him for an expenses-paid visit.
Others are more oriented inside Nicaragua. Bayardo Arce, who once combined journalism with guerrilla activities, now oversees the substantial press and broadcasting empire the Sandinistas have managed to retain. Jaime Wheelock Roman, former Agriculture Minister, is in charge of drafting the documents for the coming party congress.
"The country has changed, and we have also changed," said Mr. Carrion, explaining why the Sandinista Front has to "modify and reorganize itself in the form of a democratic political party."
He said the idea of an armed movement led by an all-powerful "vanguard" -- the national directorate -- had been appropriate during the years of fighting the authoritarian Somoza dynasty, but had been "debatable" in the years after 1979, and "definitively, in the present circumstances, it is inappropriate, incorrect and unnecessary."
 
Party Congress in July
 The debate and discussions now under way at all levels of the Sandinista Front, which will culminate in the congress in July, encompasses its past performance as well as its future shape. At the highest levels of the party, the debate is thought to be quite intense, even though it seldom comes into the open. In recent interviews, several members of the leadership gave only mild hints of the differences.
"Any defeat brings trauma to a political party," Mr. Ramirez said, "but especially in a party like the Sandinista Front that didn't have defeat in its perspective in 1990."
He said the Sandinista Front remained a political group "with strength, but one that didn't have the strength to win the elections." As a result, he said that in the next five years the Sandinista Front would have to present "a moderate program of consensus that will allow us to improve our standing with sectors of the population where we lost."
Mr. Ortega said the Sandinista Front, with more than 40 percent of the vote last year, had withstood the tide of change better than most Communist parties in Eastern Europe.
"It's because we, at the time of the triumph of the revolution, had the vision to follow a different route, a plan with a mixed economy, political pluralism and Christian participation, different from that of Eastern Europe or Cuba," he said.
Mr. Ortega said he did not want to think about 1996 yet. He said the Sandinistas needed to help Nicaragua achieve stability this year while at the same time defending their position in what he called "a new fight for property occurring in Nicaragua."

HEADLINE: Crux of Debate by Group of 7: Interest Rates

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
The Finance Ministers and Central Bank presidents of the seven leading industrial nations, meeting here this weekend, are arguing over whether to reduce interest rates to prevent recession from spreading through the world. But woven into the discussion is another question that will shape their final decision: Does the world have enough savings for all its needs?
The Germans insist there is not enough, and interest rates must stay high to ration it. The Americans agree that over the long run, the world might lack enough spare money to modernize Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union and also to finance new factories, homes, roads, power stations and the like elsewhere. But short term, the Bush Administration says, capital -- essentially savings available for investment -- is sufficient for interest rates to come down, encouraging people to borrow and spend. 
 The conflicting views showed up in briefings, interviews and speeches in advance of the meeting of the Group of Seven countries: the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Italy, Britain and Canada. President Bush is likely to repeat a request for lower rates at a White House breakfast on Sunday.
"We must accept for a period of time high real interest rates as a logical result of a shortage of capital," said Karl Otto Pohl, president of the German Bundesbank. He referred in particular to the more than $230 billion that he said the West Germans were transferring to East Germany.
But if high rates ration scarce capital properly, as the Germans contend, they also discourage the borrowing that is necessary for the spending needed to bring the United States out of recession and to revive sluggish European economies. That is the Bush Administration view, prompted in part by concern that a decline in European purchases of American products might prolong the recession.
Reflecting those concerns, David Mulford, the Treasury's Under Secretary for International Affairs, argued that in these hard times there was not much demand for capital. Quite the contrary, he said, "liquidity is piling up in the banks."
The communique that the ministers are to issue Sunday night is not likely to be stated in terms of the capital shortage, officials of several countries said.
They said the communique was more likely to consider whether "a brief detour" is needed to reduce rates for a while to insure that many countries do not go into recession, or whether rates must stay up to avoid inflation. Inflation can come if there is too much borrowing and too much demand, but not enough goods to go around.
Whatever the short-term considerations, the capital-shortage issue is likely to remain at the heart of the debate, now and at future Group of Seven meetings, experts say. That is because the traditional sources of surplus capital -- Germany, Japan and the Middle East oil countries -- are increasingly spending their extra money on themselves. They are doing so just as new demands for capital arise for Eastern Europe, the Soviet Union and to repair Middle East war damage.
But if managing capital, or savings, is to be the new focus, then the Group of Seven must determine the total of world savings, economists say. That might be difficult, particularly in the 1990's, given that savings fluctuate in ways that make them hard to measure.
David W. Mullins Jr., a Federal Reserve Board governor, argues, for example, that investing in new Eastern European factories or repairing damaged Middle East oil wells creates sources of new income, which is then available to repay debt. New savings, in effect, are created to repay the borrowed money, postponing a capital shortage and holding down interest rates in the process.
"There might be some crowding out of other investments initially, but these investments in the long run are good for growth," Mr. Mullins said.
Similarly, Robert Hormats, a vice president for international investment at Goldman Sachs, says that investment in the 1990's is likely to be more productive than in the 1980's, when a lot of borrowed money went for consumption rather than for factories or other wealth-producing investments.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Jobless Issue Proves Puzzle to Democrats

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
For all the fragmentation of the Democrats over the last three decades, the one issue that has always pulled the party together is the one that created its coalition in the Great Depression: unemployment.
Now, in the midst of the first recession in a decade, its impact underlined by the report on Friday of a sharp drop in national output earlier this year, the Congressional Democrats have an issue and they do not seem to know what to do with it. 
 The issue, simply put, is that in this recession far fewer of the jobless are covered by unemployment compensation than in past recessions. Moreover, the trust fund that is supposed to pay for benefits beyond the regular 26 weeks is actually getting fatter because its rules often require a very high unemployment rate in a state before the fund kicks in.
A couple of weeks ago Speaker Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, said the House Ways and Means Committee was about to move ahead with legislation extending benefits, but nothing has happened.
Last week Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who chairs the Finance Committee, held a hearing on the issue and said Democrats would have to do something about extending benefits. "The problem," he said, "is trying to figure out how to pay for it."
Then the Senate passed a budget resolution with a provision that would make it still harder to raise taxes to pay for any extension, and no one challenged that clause.
The simplest and the most prominent of the ideas is Representative Thomas J. Downey's. The Suffolk Democrat proposes paying for expanded unemployment benefits by raising the wage base on which employers pay Federal taxes for unemployment benefits. Employers now pay taxes on wages up to $7,000. Mr. Downey would raise that to $53,400, but at the same time reduce the tax rate. This would limit the effect on small businesses paying lower wages, but produce a considerable gain in Federal revenue.
Under his plan the Federal tax for an employee earning $30,000 would go to $90 from $56. For those earning $18,667 or less, the tax would actually decrease.
Mr. Downey would use the money raised for a new, entirely federally financed program of extended benefits, which would be based on the national unemployment rate, not state figures, and, in the most politically unassailable section of his plan, would raise to 26 weeks, from 13, the basic benefits military veterans would get. Civilians now get 26 weeks. His bill would also curtail the rights of states to disqualify claimants.
Mr. Downey estimates that the total cost of his plan would be $26 billion. It is legal under last year's budget agreement because it includes the taxes to pay for itself.
 
Vulnerable to G.O.P. Attacks
 But the tax increase is substantial, at a time when Democrats hate to make themselves vulnerable to Republican attacks that their party likes to tax. Mr. Foley said Friday that at the tax level proposed by Mr. Downey the bill would be "extremely difficult to pass," though he hoped for some action in this session.
Mr. Downey acknowledged that a "dramatically less ambitious" bill could get through. He is delaying action on the bill in the Ways and Means subcommittee he chairs, while seeking votes on the full committee, trying to trim as little as possible to get them.
In the Senate the leading advocate of change is Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, the Maryland Democrat who heads the Congressional Joint Economic Committee. He testified before Mr. Bentsen's panel that the recession was "much more serious" than acknowledged and that the committee should vote to extend benefits.
He was particularly distressed because the trust fund that pays for extended benefits was expected to take in five times as much in taxes this year than it will pay out. And after Labor Secretary Lynn Martin defended that fund's "ample resources" as a evidence of solvency, Mr. Sarbanes compared her comment with a librarian claiming her library was functioning well because every book was on the shelf.
But the most dramatic figures are the ones Mr. Bentsen cited in opening the hearing -- the estimate that while as many as 75 percent of the unemployed drew benefits in past recessions only half that many were getting them now. The 75 percent figure came from 1975, but previous high totals included 64 percent in 1961, 60 percent in 1958 and 67 percent in 1976.
Isaac Shapiro, a senior research analyst at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities here, derived those percentages from Labor Department statistics. He calculated that 37 percent of the unemployed in 1990 drew benefits, and said data from the first three months of 1991 indicated that only 42 percent of the unemployed would draw unemployment insurance benefits this year. He noted that as any recession continues and deepens the percentage getting insurance benefits increases because more workers with long job histories and insurance coverage are laid off.
 
'The Gap Is Normal'
 Ms. Martin seized on this point to dismiss concern about the difference between the total of the unemployed and the number receiving benefits. "This gap is normal," she testified.
She cited a Congressional Research Service study that identified the unemployed not receiving benefits as typically young, not the heads of families or their families' primary source of income.
"The Administration," she said, "believes that the unemployment insurance program is continuing to effectively perform its prescribed and targeted mission of providing temporary, partial wage replacement to experienced workers who become unemployed through no fault of their own, and encouraging an early return to work."
Her opposition to any change in the law was different, and far less partisan, than the scorn that Representaive Newt Gingrich, the House Republican whip, heaped on the Downey proposal.
Mr. Gingrich, of Georgia, said: "If liberals voted for tax cuts that would create jobs, we wouldn't need this kind of proposal. It's sad to see liberal Democrats create unemployment and then call for more spending to try to fix it."
Mr. Gingrich saw this issue, as he sees almost everything, as a political issue.
Not many Democrats talk that with that kind of partisan edge. The words "Republican recession" are never heard. The discussions are dry, not intense.
Even Mr. Downey speaks more with frustration than a strong political blood lust, saying of his fellow Democrats, "If the party can't deliver for these people, who are our people, then what are we doing here?"
 
In the Past, Passion
 It was not always that way. Democrats used to be to get pretty passionate over the unemployed.
Consider the intensity of an earlier Congressional debate over extending unemployment insurance benefits. In 1958 the unemployment rate was 6.8 percent, as it was in March of this year, and Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, was telling the Senate, "We cannot adjourn this summer without having taken some constructive step to help nearly six million unemployed."
Senator Harry F. Byrd, the conservative Virginia Democrat, saw budget problems and Federal domination of the states in Mr. Kennedy's proposal. Senator Wayne Morse, Democrat of Oregon, disagreed and insisted, "Congress should enact measures which will do something about filling the empty stomachs of the growing hundreds of thousands of hungry persons in our country who have exhausted their unemployment insurance benefits or will soon do so."
Mr. Byrd and the Republicans won the vote in the Senate, but liberal Democrats swept that fall's elections, and Mr. Kennedy was heard from again.
Today the Democrats must deal with budget constraints and uncertainty about what they stand for, reflected in Mr. Downey's account of his failure to get a colleague to back his bill. Mr. Downey said the other Democrat told him that his bill made sense, but that he would not support it. After all, the other Democrat said, he was already committed to supporting three controversial measures: the civil rights bill, a bill guaranteeing parental leave and a bill prohibiting employers from giving permanent jobs to replacements for strikers.
Those bills all have active organizations actively lobbying for them. The Democrats used to be the lobbyists for the unemployed.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Murk of Politics Obscures Baker's Path to Peace in the Middle East

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d briefly interrupted his Middle East diplomacy last week to meet with the Soviet Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh in the Caucasus Mountains. Before their talks, Mr. Baker toured the area, and while standing on a hill, with the giant Mount Elbrus hidden in fog in the distance, he was asked whether from this perch he could see his way to peace in the Middle East.
In a brief flash of candor, Mr. Baker answered, "About as clearly as I can see Mount Elbrus." 
 After Mr. Baker's three trips around the Middle East in seven weeks, it is apparent that, while the road to peace may remain obscure, several other things should be crystal clear.
The first is that his entire effort to engineer a diplomatic breakthrough between Arabs and Israelis may be based on a false premise: that the defeat of Iraq in the Persian Gulf war has opened a new "window of opportunity" to settle this age-old conflict.
To begin with, as long as President Saddam Hussein of Iraq remains in power, the war is not over in the eyes of the Arabs or Israelis, and both still have their eyes more on him than each other.
 
No Mood for Concessions
 Neither the Israeli Government nor the Israeli public is in the mood to make any serious concessions to the Palestinians, who supported Mr. Hussein during the gulf war while he launched repeated Scud missile attacks against Israel.
The Saudis, Kuwaitis and other Arab gulf states, who winked at Israel during the war and hinted that after Iraq is defeated they might adopt a new stand toward Israel, have shown no such inclination. They already alienated their Muslim religious communities by siding with the Americans against Iraq, and they do not need to court more trouble by warming up to the Israelis, or by giving President Hussein a propaganda tool with which to attack them.
Throughout his travels, Mr. Baker tried to get the Jordanians, Syrians and Saudis to make positive statements toward Israel to help induce Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to be more forthcoming. What did he get? When King Hussein of Jordan was asked what confidence-building gestures he might be prepared to make toward Israel to lessen tensions, he cited only the fact that Jordan had not joined Iraq in attacking Israel -- not exactly something that will induce Israelis to trade land for peace.
Mr. Baker left Israel on Friday saying he did not know whether he would be coming back, and making clear that the Israelis had not given him the answers he needed to convene a peace conference. In the morning he had met with Foreign Minister David Levy, who offered several concessions to help make a peace conference possible; then Mr. Baker went to see Mr. Shamir, who took almost all of them back, officials said.
That episode illustrates the second revelation of Mr. Baker's travels -- that neither the Arabs nor the Israelis have shown a commitment to making a realistic peace conference possible. That would mean adopting flexible positions to make it easy for the adversaries to come to the peace table rather than impossible.
The Israelis want the Palestinians to come on the condition that they abandon their most cherished political positions first: that is, agree to never mention the Palestine Liberation Organization and agree that Palestinians who are residents of Israeli-annexed East Jerusalem be barred from the talks, because otherwise it might imply that Jerusalem is negotiable.
Mr. Shamir also insists on continuing to build Jewish settlements in the West Bank, as Mr. Baker is trying to woo the Arabs.
The Arabs want Israel to agree before the conference starts to trade land for peace, but are unwilling to even hint at what peace might consist of. Before Mr. Baker met with Saudi Arabia's King Fahd, the Saudi monarch was asked a simple question: Since the Saudis do not want to come to the peace conference with Israel, would they be prepared to enter into direct talks with the Israelis on the side, dealing with regional issues like water use, arms control and economic development?
 
No Peace Without Political Pain
 King Fahd answered: "Our ardent hope is that peace is achieved in this region. This is the important thing. It is important that we not move ahead of ourselves in these things."
This leads to the third point made clear by Mr. Baker's travels: There is no such thing as a politically painless peace process.
"So far the United States has been trying to make peace in a politically low-cost fashion," said Stephen P. Cohen, president of the Montreal-based Center for Middle East Peace and Economic Cooperation and an expert on the peace process. "They have tried to coax the Saudis and other Arabs instead of saying, 'Look, we saved you against Iraq. We invested enormous assets to do so and now we expect something in return vis-a-vis Israel.' "
On the Israeli side, added Mr. Cohen, it means being willing to state publicly when, where and why the Shamir Government is not being serious or reasonable in meeting even the minimum Arab conditions for a peace conference, even if that means a tough public debate with American Jewish leaders and within Israel. Administration officials insist that if Israelis and American Jews understood how little was being asked of Mr. Shamir's Government to make a peace conference possible, they would be shocked.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d during a visit to Jerusalem. (Associated Press)
