HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Henderson, Back in Lineup, Fails to Get to First Base

BYLINE: By LEONARD KOPPETT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., April 27

 BODY:
Rickey Henderson got back into action today after missing 13 games with a leg injury, but he remained one stolen base short of Lou Brock's major league record of 938 steals.
Henderson failed to reach first base in four trips to the plate as the Oakland Athletics defeated the California Angels, 4-3, at the Oakland Coliseum. 
 He made three fine plays in left field before leaving the game after making the final out of the seventh inning. There was no new difficulty with his left calf and he was expected to play again Sunday.
"My leg responded well to running in the outfield, and I feel a lot of confidence in it," Henderson said. "As for stealing bases, you can't steal first base so I have to get back into the swing of hitting."
 
'No Sense in Pushing It'
 "No new problems," said Manager Tony La Russa. "He was getting a little stiff, maybe, and there was no sense in pushing it."
"He did fine," said Barry Weinberg, Oakland's trainer. "He got a little fatigued. This is like a first spring training game for him now."
Henderson was injured in the fourth game of the season, on April 12, while running out a grounder. In his first game, he had stolen base No. 937, then was thrown out twice in subsequent games. The injury, a muscle strain, turned out to be more serious and slower healing than first believed. When Henderson was still unable to play after a few days, he was placed on the 15-day disabled list retroactive to the day of the injury. This was the first day he was eligible to return.
 
Brock Present, Hoopla Absent
 Brock, who had come to Oakland to be part of any record-breaking ceremony in the season's first series, had teased Henderson then about giving him "48 hours" to do the job. Today, he was on hand again, without issuing time limits.
However, the hoopla that marked Henderson's attempt to break the record at the beginning of the season was pretty much absent now.
Facing Mark Langston today, Henderson flied to center, struck out, rolled to short and popped up to second. But he ran well enough in flagging down a long drive to left in the fourth and a foul in the bullpen area in the fifth and in making a catch against the left-field wall in the seventh.
 
No Echoes of Controversy
 Henderson's return had no echoes of the controversy that surrounded him in spring training, when he reported late and spoke publicly about his desire to have his $3 million contract renegotiated to match this year's salary inflation. When he signed the pact before the 1990 season, he became baseball's highest-paid player; now the leaders are in the $5 million class and he wanted an adjustment.
Henderson was accused of being selfish and was booed loudly in spring training appearances. But on opening night here, he received a warm reception from the Oakland crowd and was loudly cheered as he contributed to a victory. Since then, his contract status -- still not finally resolved -- has receded as a public issue in the local media and in clubhouse conversation. It seemed no factor at all today.
What was a factor, however, was the return of an important regular to the Athletics lineup. The team has had many injuries, including one to shortstop Walt Weiss, and lost six of its last seven games on a recent road trip. In Henderson's absence, five different players filled the lead-off role: Weiss, Lance Blankenship, Mike Gallego, Willie Wilson and Fred Manrique, the shortstop filling in for Weiss.
 
Third Victory for Moore
 Oakland raised its record to 11-7, after a stretch of five losses in six games at Seattle and Minnesota. Mike Moore, pitching into the seventh, scored his third victory, the first 3-0 start of his career. When he needed help, La Russa provided it by calling on three different pitchers to get one out each in a one-run situation in the seventh and eighth, then had Dennis Eckersley come on for a one-two-three ninth.
Moore yielded two runs in the first inning. But with two out in their half of the first, the Athletics got three on a walk to Jose Canseco, Dave Henderson's single, Terry Steinbach's two-run double and Mark McGwire's scoring single. Dave Henderson went on to have a four-hit day that raised his average to .406. Rickey Henderson is hitting .200.
Steinbach's scoring fly in the sixth made the score 4-2, and that was enough to withstand California's run in the seventh.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
The Rain in Barcelona Wakes Up the Organizers

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BARCELONA, Spain

 BODY:
As King Juan Carlos officially reopened Montjuic Stadium for the World Cup of track and field on Sept. 8, 1989, he heard whistles, jeers and protests from several thousand Catalan nationists, calling attention to themselves as an "oppressed nation." This was no big deal. The King had been razzed on other occasions, and Catalonians often use public events to express their feelings.
 But it was that 90-minute thunderstorm two days later as the World Cup was ending that got people wondering.
 
Water Everywhere
 For nearly three years, citizens of Barcelona had been gearing up to stage the summer Olympics in 1992. Montjuic Stadium, a majestic 62-year-old edifice atop the hills overlooking the city, was being fixed up, built up and spruced up to become the crown jewel of the Games as the site for opening and closing ceremonies and the track and field competition. 
 But under torrential downpours, it became evident that the stadium had not been fixed, built or spruced enough. Water collected everywhere. Interiors thought to be sealed from the outside were flooded. The infield became a pond. The stadium steps turned into waterfalls. The place was a mess, and suddenly, the stadium had become a symbol of the Olympics, less than three years away.
In the minds of more than a few people here, the cascades of water washed away a veneer of ability. Now, the depth of problems confronting organizers all along, which were previously little known to the general public -- political infighting, lagging construction, lack of enough hotel rooms -- had taken on a new profundity and urgency. It hardly mattered that the Olympic organizing committee had had nothing to do with the World Cup, which was staged by the International Amateur Athletic Federation. Under sheets of rain, few were willing to make the distinction.
 
Now at Halfway Point
 The next morning, one local newspaper declared that Barcelona "failed the only big test before 1992."
 It is now about midway between the rainy past and the opening ceremonies of July 24, 1992, and few Barcelonese appreciate the role of the rain more than Pasqual Maragall, the 50-year-old Mayor of Barcelona and president of the 1992 organizing committee, known commonly as C.O.O.B., the initials of its formal name in Spanish.
 "In a graphic way, the rain helped," he said in a recent interview at the Palauet Albeniz, a small but opulent government building just down the hill from Montjuic. "It had a positive effect, in the sense that it made things a bit dramatic when there was still time enough to recover and provide a new dynamic."
 Unlike many others who serve as president of an organizing committee and leave the operations to an executive director, Maragall is fully involved in the Olympic effort. Once a student at the New School in New York and a professor of economics at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, he saw the Olympics as an opportunity to revitalize Barcelona, expanding its position as Spain's leading economic force by making it a tourist destination and cultural center as well.
 
Other Improvements Made
 Refurbishing old sports buildings was only one of the possibilities. The Olympic bid would also lead to better roads, subway extensions, a modernized airport and desperately needed luxury hotels to attract business leaders and upscale visitors.
 But like so many civic projects, Olympic efforts were bogged down in politics shaped by pressures and demands from the three major players: the city government, the regional government known as the Generalitat of Catalonia, which is housed just across a plaza from city offices, and the federal government in Madrid.
 "The climate around C.O.O.B. was very stormy and difficult," Josep Miquel Abad, the chief executive officer of the organizing committee, said in a separate interview at his office. "Every day was something different. Now, the situation has changed a lot. Relations are much closer."
 By exposing the inadequacies of the stadium, the thunderstorms embarrassed the infighters and shocked them into realizing how their differences and mistrust were jeopardizing the Games. As if by magic, when the skies cleared, their behavior changed. Within six months, Maragall formed a working group of representatives from the three political entities, the public works agencies and the organizing committee to monitor progress. He also brought in an independent auditor, the California-based Bechtel Corporation. Among 300 projects under way, they focused their main concerns on roads, subways and hotels.
 
Traffic Often a Nightmare
 Barcelona is a vibrant city of 1.7 million people and 700,000 cars and trucks, an unusually high ratio that often makes traffic a nightmare. While the subway system is vast, modern, clean and safe, and nearly all the Olympic venues lie within the metropolitan area, organizers knew from the beginning that getting people around and finding them suitable accommodations would be their biggest problems. They also knew that the solutions would shape the future of the region, far beyond the 17 days of the Olympics.
 But rather than maintain an overly ambitious campaign to have everything finished by the end of 1991, Maragall's working group scaled back the efforts, focusing on a more realistic schedule of completing a freeway known as the outer ring road; a subway line to Montjuic, where a 15,000-seat indoor arena and a swimming complex sit adjacent to the stadium; and eight luxury hotels.
 In time, the group discovered that even those expectations were a bit grandiose. So plans were modified again, with the emphasis on finishing the ring road by early next year and completing construction on four hotels. Work on the subway line would continue but with no expectations that it could be finished in time for the Olympics, making it, perhaps, the biggest victim of the earlier squabbles.
 "We knew it would be very difficult, very delicate," Maragall said of the 4.3-mile extension. "It was always possible until the end of last summer, but the politics were so difficult to overcome, we knew it was probably impossible."
 Adequate and affordable hotel space remains a concern. Soon after Barcelona won the Games, in October 1986, the organizing committee booked 80 percent of the available rooms during the period of the Olympics and rates were fixed, tied to a projected consumer price index. Today, with the Spanish peseta much stronger against the dollar than it was five years ago, the rates seem expensive, about $160 a night for a room in a two-star hotel. And there's not much room to bargain. Hotel owners are complaining that the rates are too low and have vowed to charge even more for the rooms the organizing committee did not reserve.
 To charges of price gouging, Abad and his colleagues say don't blame them, blame the hotel owners.
 Security is another issue that worries organizers. Spain's proximity to north Africa and the Middle East and Barcelona's long coastline along the Mediterranean Sea make the region particularly vulnerable to terrorist attack. Officials also fear problems from the Basque separatist group, known by its Spanish initials, E.T.A., and from the Palestine Liberation Organization, which has formal representation in Spain.
 Abad remembered discussing security concerns with a member of a visiting Soviet delegation, who suggested it would be easy to control the problem by building a large fence around the city. Abad said he laughed and told him, "In a democratic society, you cannot do such things."
 Maragall sees none of the difficulties ahead as impediments to successful Games, not even a mayoral election May 26, in which he is seeking a third term. He said he would be shocked to lose, but even if he did, projects would be completed on time, the Olympics would go forward as planned. The country, the region, the city and the organizing committee had come too far for anything less, he said, as if the shimmering, late afternoon sun peeking through the windows of his office didn't make the point as well.

HEADLINE: Squeeze Play;
Hussein's Ouster Is U.S. Goal, But at What Cost to the Iraqis?

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE United States intelligence community this month completed its first full assessment of war damage in Iraq, and the numbers were sobering: $30 billion to rebuild the infrastructure of roads, bridges, power plants and oil installations; five years to repair the electrical grid; months to get water purification plants working; shortages of chlorine and grain, depleted livestock and acute shortages of medicine.
 The question for the Bush Administration is what should Saddam Hussein be allowed to do about it? 
 After nine months of trade sanctions and economic blockade, the United States and its allies still exert absolute control over the levers of Iraq's economy. Two months after the shooting stopped, Mr. Hussein has not been allowed to sell a single barrel of oil, his principal source of national income.
 While a long and meticulous inspection program goes ahead to verify that Iraq has destroyed its weapons of mass destruction, Washington and its allies will retain enormous power over Iraq's 18 million people, many of whom are refugees in their own land, many of whom are hungry, sick or traumatized by war.
 Therein lies the quandary for the Bush Administration -- how tightly to squeeze Iraq, and when to let up. This next step may determine the long-term survival of the man Mr. Bush has been able to defeat in every way except one: Mr. Hussein remains in power in Baghdad. If not victory, as Milton's dark angel said, it is yet revenge.
 By all accounts, the initial inclination in the White House is to tighten the screws, using as justification Mr. Hussein's repression of the Kurds in northern Iraq and his disingenuous accounting of the ballistic missiles, chemical weapons and nuclear materials he is hiding.
 President Bush reaffirmed on Friday his central postwar policy goal. "There will not be normal relations with this man as long as I'm President of the United States," he declared, adding that "it's only terror that's keeping him in power" and "we want him out of there."
 
Tighter or Looser?
 The critical question for United States policy will be whether to undertake a controlled strangulation of Iraq's economy as part of a strategy to topple Mr. Hussein, or a loosening of the noose that allows Mr. Hussein to rescue his people from the deprivation and destruction of the war. Strangulation inevitably brings more human suffering and will prevent Iraq from making a down payment on reparations to Kuwait, whose civilian and oil economies suffered untold billions in damage from the Iraqi occupation. Strangulation would also prolong the damage being done to the economies of Jordan and Turkey, which had strong trading ties with Baghdad before the war.
 But allowing Iraq to open the valves of its formidable oil industry would only strengthen Mr. Hussein as the leader who can still deliver at home. It would also allow him to fulfill his obligation to pay war damages in Kuwait and perhaps launch him once again into the Arab political arena he still aspires to dominate.
There were strong indications at week's end that Mr. Bush and his senior advisers were getting ready to calibrate their postwar campaign. "My impression is that they are at the thinking stage and not at the clear formulation stage," said one senior analyst who participates in the interagency groups that feed options to Mr. Bush and his senior national security aides.
 In another indication, a senior Administration official was asked whether the United States would look favorably on Iraqi requests to export oil. The official said that would depend upon a lot of things, "Such as first of all, there will be a big difference in approach to it whether Saddam Hussein is in power or not."
 Whatever course Mr. Bush takes, constructing and then managing a postwar strategy for Iraq will be complicated and full of risks.
 "It's not clear to me how long this population can hold out with these sanctions," said one government specialist on Iraq. "They still seem to be eating, but we need to get electricity going for water purification, they need chlorine and simple things you could give them." He added that because of the threat of cholera and other diseases, "They need vaccines and medicines massively and immediately."
 Without elaborating on where Administration policy was going, one senior adviser said, "Oh, we're not going to let Iraqis starve."
 Still, no one in the Administration foresaw the scale or intensity of the Kurdish crisis, which has left thousands dead.
Even if the ropes were taken off Iraq's economy, intelligence estimates say the country's oil revenues would not be able to cover the reconstruction bills or pay down the $80 billion in foreign debts piled up over the last decade. By the end of the current decade, Baghdad's shortfall is forecast at between $100 billion and $170 billion. Just to pay the interest on its debt this year, Iraq needs $8 billion.
One Central Intelligence Agency estimate says that with minimal investment, Iraq could be exporting 1 million barrels a day within three months. And, the study adds, with a $1.5 billion investment to repair bomb-damaged pumps, Iraq could be shipping 2.7 million barrels a day of crude oil to the world markets by the end of 1992, assuming the West cooperates by selling Baghdad the oil-sector equipment and spare parts it desperately needs.
 
Diagnosing His Strength
 In contemplating a long-term pressure campaign to drive Mr. Hussein from power, one part of Mr. Bush's calculus must be whether any amount of pressure can dislodge the Iraqi leader from his seat as absolute ruler in a totalitarian police state.
Last month, a special intelligence assessment suggested that Mr. Hussein's regime was "diseased" and he was not likely to last more than 6 to 12 months. But in the ensuing weeks the intelligence community has altered its view, based on the observation that the Iraqi Army has remained loyal to Mr. Hussein and that violent insurrection that flared in the north and south never made it to the capital.
In an important respect, the spontaneous uprising in the predominantly Shiite Muslim south and the northern Kurdish provinces may have only served to reinforce Mr. Hussein's appeal as a strong central figure able to prevent ethnic and regional pressures from splitting the nation apart. To the Sunni Muslim minority that has run Iraq in this century, Mr. Hussein still is the only thing standing between them and the anarchy of disintegration; the only thing holding together the unruly ethnic and religious warren on the fertile and oil-rich land of Mesopotamia.
To be sure, many Iraqis would prefer a change at the top, but taking on Mr. Hussein's security apparatus has long been regarded as a suicidal proposition.
From the moment the war ended and Mr. Bush opposed an initial Iraqi request to sell oil to buy food and medicine, there was every indication that Mr. Hussein sensed Washington's pressure game and has maneuvered to counter it. After five days of secret negotiations in Baghdad last week, Mr. Hussein struck a tentative accord with Kurdish guerrilla leaders to end the state of war in the north and to cooperate in bringing 2 million Kurdish refugees back from the borders with Iran and Turkey under new security guarantees.
Whether the pact survives the scrutiny of the Kurdish community, it demonstrated Mr. Hussein's focus on dividing his internal opposition as the first step in his political recovery at home. His next step will be to divide the international coalition that effectively controls his economy.
Iraq's export pipelines through Saudi Arabia and Turkey are the key to his economic recovery. Saudi Arabia, whose ruling family has dedicated itself to Mr. Hussein's downfall, has the least interest in rushing to reopen the valves on the oil terminal it allowed Iraq to establish on its Red Sea coast in 1989.
But Turkey continues to suffer the effects of lost trade with Iraq. Aside from the hefty pipeline fees it once earned, Turkey misses the lucrative market Iraq provided for its exports and the barter payments that arrived in the form of 4,000 tanker trucks carrying Iraqi crude oil for Eastern Turkey's refineries.
Jordan also would suffer from an extended embargo against Iraq. Bereft of friends among the oil-rich Arab gulf states that fought Iraq while Jordan stayed on the fence, King Hussein's severe economic problems will only intensify in coming months.
The Bush Administration, having decided that the Jordanian monarch was too important a strategic player in the region to abandon during the war, could end up contributing to Jordan's economic collapse by insisting on keeping Iraq's borders sealed against trade. Without the trade revenue, Baghdad cannot make payments to Jordan on the pile of debts left over from the Iran-Iraq war, nor will Jordanian farmers and exporters be able to ship goods to their traditional overland markets in Iraq.
 Mr. Hussein will focus his diplomatic energies at the United Nations Security Council, where China, the Soviet Union and many non-aligned nations may balk at an economic campaign that smacks too heavily of retribution or nation tampering.
 Most Iraq specialists who have watched Mr. Bush over the last nine months instinctively believe that a harsh pressure campaign is ahead and they are gearing up to be alert for the telltale signs of human catastrophe, such as epidemics and starvation, that will require what one analyst called "humanitarian adjustments" along the way.
But for now, from Baghdad to Basra and from Mosul to Kirkuk, it seems clear that it will be a long time before Iraq's war-weary population returns to the living standard to which it was accustomed -- at least as long as Mr. Hussein rules.

HEADLINE: The World;
The Dauntingly Expensive Task of Imposing Arms Control

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
THE incomplete inventory of weapons of mass destruction that Iraq delivered to Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar earlier this month has opened a Pandora's box of problems for the United Nations, which must now set out to locate and destroy the weapons and find the money to do it.
Under its sweeping cease-fire agreement with Iraq, the Security Council gave itself an extraordinarily ambitious task: to get rid of Iraq's chemical and biological weapons, its weapons-grade nuclear material, its ballistic missiles with ranges of more than 95 miles and any research and production sites and equipment to develop them. 
 Iraq's limited cooperation is only the first illustration of just how difficult, time-consuming and costly the ground-breaking exercise will be. And it raises the question of whether arms control can be imposed from the outside when the target country may not possess the political will to help.
If it is so difficult to dismantle an arsenal of weapons of mass destruction in a country that has just suffered a devastating military defeat, how would it ever be possible to disarm other regimes -- North Korea, for example, or South Africa -- if they were unwilling to cooperate?
"When the United States and the Soviet Union decide to eliminate weapons, it involves years of planning and every single detail and legal nicety is spelled out in thick briefing books," said Janne E. Nolan, a fellow at the Brookings Institution in Washington, and the author of a book on ballistic missiles. "This time, we're just winging it."
The process of organizing an administration to conduct the inspection and destruction is daunting. Mr. Perez de Cuellar named a Swede and an American to head a commission that will oversee hundreds, perhaps thousands, of technical experts from around the world in a project expected to take years. Hans Blix, the director general of the Vienna-based International Atomic Energy Agency, which will take responsibility for inspecting and destroying the Iraqi stocks that could be used to make nuclear arms, told the Bush Administration last week that he will need more than 400 experts.
Iraq has denied -- falsely, American intelligence officials say -- that it has biological weapons, or research operations to develop them. It has argued that since its weapons-grade nuclear material is subject to international inspection, there is no reason to deal with that issue. American intelligence officials believe that Iraq has substantially more than the 38 launchers and the 52 Scud missiles it listed. Last Monday, the I.A.E.A. told Iraq to disclose the location of its nuclear fuel within a week; so far, the Iraqis have not responded. The special commission will work with the I.A.E.A. not only to inspect and dispose of the 48 pounds of highly enriched uranium fuel it already inspects; for the first time, it is supposed to hunt for uranium-enrichment operations and equipment, as well as laboratories where a nuclear device might be designed.
But Iraq is a country where diplomats must apply in writing days in advance to take a trip outside of Baghdad and where foreign delegations are never allowed to roam unescorted. Even after the experts are in Iraq, will Saddam Hussein's Government allow them free access to the sites they want to inspect? Or will their arrival give the Iraqis sufficient time to hide any questionable material or weapons at alternate sites?
"We have to assume that no matter what access the Iraqis give us that they will be looking over our shoulders and that everything we do will have to be negotiated with Saddam," said Gary Milhollin, director of the Washington-based Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control. "To do a complete inspection, we would have to search every cave and building in Iraq."
If Iraq does not comply, the Security Council can do little but enforce a tough set of economic sanctions against Iraq, including a ban on oil exports, Bush Administration officials admit. "All we can do is say that their response falls far short of what's expected of them and to try to make their lives as difficult as possible," said one senior Administration official.
The United Nations has not yet figured out a way to destroy or dispose of these weapons. Nuclear material can be relatively easy to seal and ship, and missiles and launchers can be disposed of with little difficulty. But the destruction of chemical and biological weapons is a different matter altogether, and the United Nations is grappling with a range of options -- from crude battlefield destruction, in which an area would be sealed off and the weapons burned, to the construction of a site where the weapons could be destroyed according to strict environmental standards; such construction might cost billions.
Even if the United Nations exercise is successful, the next question is who will pay for it. Members might be required to contribute to a special fund, a burden many would not welcome; or, a senior Administration official suggested, the Security Council could try to pass a resolution demanding that Iraq finance the operation from oil revenues.
For arms control experts, the operation illustrates the limits of current international controls. "Inspection routines do not define most of the proliferation in the world," said the military analyst and author Anthony H. Cordesman. "If we let Iraq get away with this, it will make our efforts to impose any regime over weapons of mass destructions impossible. If the U.N. fails, who in the region is going to sign any non-proliferation agreement and stick by it?"
The exercise also raises a more fundamental question: whether weapons of mass destruction and the means to build them -- the West German chemical weapons plants, the Soviet missiles, the French-designed "vaccine" factories, the natural uranium from Brazil, Portugal, Niger and Italy, for example -- should be sold in the first place.
Mr. Cordesman estimates that the global cost of the war to liberate Kuwait could be more than $500 billion, more than 10 times the cost of all the arms transfers to Iraq in the last decade.

HEADLINE: The Region;
Can a City Numbed By False Apocalypses Scare Itself Into Action?

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
IN the annals of public posturing, the three biggest threats by New York City government are: we're closing your neighborhood firehouse; we're cutting subway service; we're not hiring the police officers we promised. And the leading nominee from private industry: we're moving to New Jersey.
Only this month New York City transit officials retreated, for the time being, from their threat to shutter token booths at night, shrink or scrap some bus routes and curtail other services. The Dinkins administration, which warned last fall that as many as 15,000 New York City employees might have to be dismissed, now estimates that only 1,100 will actually have been fired before the fiscal year ends June 30. Apocalyptic visions are not, of course, limited to New York. In Connecticut this month, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker rescinded threatened layoffs after state employees agreed to contract concessions. 
 Who's kidding whom? Were the officials bluffing? Were their scare tactics expected from the start to collapse of their own weight? Were they trial balloons leaked to generate public protest? Were the threats designed to dramatize the dimensions of budget gaps that local governments are confronting, to spur negotiations with organized labor and special interest groups or to make the eventual economies, however onerous, seem acceptable by comparison?
"All of the above," says Mortimer L. Downey, executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, whose new chairman, Peter E. Stangl, is reconsidering the proposed service reductions that some people fear would drive riders away without appreciably bridging a projected deficit. "It's a public bargaining process," Mr. Downey said. "Getting out in public with one approach sometimes brings people to the table to discuss other approaches. It gets people focused."
Barry Feinstein, an M.T.A. board member and leader of the Teamsters local that represents city employees, agreed. "It's part of how government does business," said Mr. Feinstein, an acknowledged grand-stander himself. "It's meant to create a fear or to draw fire, to have an idea tested and then to be followed up with something less stringent. Those things are all legitimate parts of trying to accomplish a legitimate government end. If you take the view that the end justifies the means, you can be comfortable with that."
 
Crying Wolf
 The price of crying wolf repeatedly, though, is that it can breed cynicism. The practice has evolved into a periodic theatrical production -- a participatory one in which the players improvise to avoid the script's draconian denouement. These latter-day versions of the original fable are spontaneously choreographed. Rather than ending with one of the protagonists being eaten alive, if all goes well the prospective victim survives to dance with sheep in wolves' clothing.
<> <> City Budget Director Philip R. Michael and other officials insist that the dimensions of the problems are usually real even if proposed solutions sometimes represent the worst case rather than wishful thinking. The prophecies are rarely supposed to be self-fulfilling.
"I don't think you make every proposal with the expectation that it's engraved in stone," Mr. Michael said. "Often, for the purposes of credibility, you have to make a plan that is within your control. If you put out a plan that is your fondest hope, which preserves the greatest number of services and inflicts the smallest amount of pain but you need a bunch of partners to accomplish, then everyone will say, correctly, that you can't deliver and you're just daydreaming."
One shortcoming of the Dinkins administration has been its inability to bluff effectively. Earlier this year, New York City Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez persuaded the teachers' union to defer some of the wage increases it had just won rather than subject its members to thousands of layoffs. Mayor David N. Dinkins has yet to get municipal employee unions to agree to deferrals, furloughs or other concessions -- in part because he has not given labor leaders a dramatically worse alternative, like layoffs, from which they could then bargain to save their members' jobs. Arguably, Mr. Dinkins's apparent lack of guile contributed to higher labor costs in the first place. Fearing a strike and refusing to engage in political gamesmanship, he announced a contract with the teachers last September before reaching agreement with other municipal unions that probably would have settled for less. Mr. Michael's seemingly contradictory warning later that week that as many as 15,000 city employees might have to be dismissed because of declining revenues was released as much to pre-empt a similar alarm by Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman and to reassure the bond market of the city's resolve as it was to frighten the other unions.
No less a figure than Victor Gotbaum, former leader of District Council 37, the largest municipal employee union, argued that, if anything, the administration has been too reticent, or inconsistent, in portraying the problem. "In the old days," Mr. Gotbaum recalled, "we regarded it as crying wolf because if John Lindsay said he had a $300 million deficit, he was right but he borrowed it. Today it's not a question of crying wolf. Phil Michael was murdered because of his timing -- he talked of 15,000 layoffs after the teachers contract, so people asked: 'Why are you crying wolf now?' Not even the unions deny there are real tough times ahead. If anything, there's a lack of definition, which is indicative of a lack of leadership on all levels."
Harrison J. Goldin, the former city comptroller, largely agreed. "When the Mayor warned last fall about dire things that needed to be done he was accurate," he said. "The impression the public got thereafter that maybe those things didn't need to be done, in the face of an underlyng situation that, in fact, is getting worse, has made it all the more difficult to mobilize the support and get the concurrence you need to accomplish the solutions. Union leaders are, after all, politicians, and they find it very difficult to bring along members who have not been conditioned to accept how serious the situation is."
 
No Spirit of Sacrifice
 Mr. Goldin recalled that under Mayor Edward I. Koch, anticipated deficits evaporated with the improving economy, but "that helped to create a situation in which people were skeptical." Moreover, said Robert F. Wagner Jr., a member of the M.T.A. board, "it's been done over and over again and the dimension of the problem is so great that traditional approaches to getting the attention of the public, the Legislature, the City Council and others are not working. Instead of making people pay attention, it ends up making the agencies involved, like the M.T.A. or the city government, look foolish."
Henry J. Stern, the president of Citizens Union, a government monitoring group, agreed that comparisons with the city's 1975 fiscal crisis and recurring false crises since then have numbed the public. "The doomsday scenarios of bankruptcy and default are refreshingly absent from Fiscal Crisis II," he said, "but regrettably absent is the spirit of sacrifice."
And, regardless of how much bluffing went on before, this time a wolf is most definitely pacing impatiently at the door. Mr. Dinkins has already shut two firehouses (of as many as 41 that were targeted for closing). And while he has so far spared promised police expansion from the cleaver, he is reluctantly beginning to explore deeper cuts and other economies in a number of departments and categories that were considered sacrosanct only a few months ago including the administration of the Police Department. Meanwhile, transit officials are still juggling alternatives to close their own budget gap. "The service cuts and fare increase are still pending," said Mr. Downey of the M.T.A. "The one thing that hasn't gone away is the deficit."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
In Bush Presidency, The Regulators Ride Again

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
TEN years after President Reagan announced a systematic campaign to cut away the thicket of Federal regulation, the garden of Government is once again teeming with an abundant growth of new regulations.
The Bush Administration disclosed last week that it was preparing a record number of new rules, covering everything from clean air to child care to savings and loan associations. 
 The "unified agenda of Federal regulations," published twice a year, shows that the number being developed by Federal agencies has grown about 17 percent, to 4,675, since Mr. Bush became President in January 1989. From 1983 through 1988, the number held steady at around 4,000.
White House officials say President Bush is distressed by the increase. As Vice President, he coordinated the Reagan Administration's "deregulation" campaign, one of the cornerstones of Mr. Reagan's economic program. Mr. Bush led the Reagan Task Force on Regulatory Relief, which mowed down hundreds of rules deemed burdensome to business, consumers, universities or local governments.
Federal officials and former officials give two reasons for the resurgence of rule-making activity: President Bush has not made deregulation a political priority, and Congress has passed many laws that require the executive branch to formulate new rules.
Cornelius M. Kerwin, dean of the School of Public Affairs at American University, said, "The volume of rule-making in this country is a reflection of the demands made on our political system by the American people, and they now want the Government to take an active role in solving a broad swath of problems."
 
Reregulation?
 Professor Kerwin said that President Bush, preoccupied with foreign affairs, had been "less than aggressive in his attack on Federal regulation."
Bush Administration officials said that new rules were proliferating because they were required by new laws dealing with, among other things, immigration, Federal grants to child care centers, restrictions on lobbying, food product labeling, aircraft noise and the rights of disabled people.
Christopher C. DeMuth, president of the American Enterprise Institute, who was executive director of Mr. Bush's Task Force on Regulatory Relief from 1981 to 1984, said: "There is a great growth in regulation these days all over the Federal Government. It is being led by Bush appointees."
In part, he said, the current trend reflects a perception that "maybe we went too far" in reducing regulation of financial institutions, airlines and other industries. Mr. DeMuth said he emphatically disagreed with that view.
James C. Miller 3d, director of the Office of Management and Budget from October 1985 to October 1988, said that the effort to curtail Federal regulation "definitely gets less emphasis now than in the 1980's." Mr. Miller, a former chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, said that Mr. Bush should "put more of his political capital into the effort to avoid excessive regulation."
The costs of Federal regulation were one of President Reagan's favorite themes. "American society experienced a virtual explosion in Government regulation" in the 1970's, he said in 1981. Excessive, inefficient regulations "limit job opportunities, raise prices and reduce the incomes of all Americans," he said. His Vice President, Mr. Bush, declared that "we have regulated ourselves to death."
By May 1982, Mr. Reagan was boasting, "We acted quickly and effectively to cut away the thicket of Federal regulations -- a thicket that was stifling business and industrial growth."
Heather J. Gradison, who served as head of the Interstate Commerce Commission from 1985 to 1990, said she was disappointed to see a diminished commitment to deregulation these days. "The Reagan Administration appointed people who had strong ideological inclinations to move forward with deregulation," she said. "We have not seen anything like that mandate from the Bush people."
But Robert Pitofsky, a law professor at Georgetown University who served on the Federal Trade Commission from 1978 to 1981, said the political pendulum was just swinging back toward the center. "Regulation during the Reagan years, when enforcers were ideologically committed to an extreme free-market approach, was uncharacteristically low, compared with the previous 30 years," he said. "What we are seeing now is a more centrist trend, a move back toward the historic average."
The agenda of regulatory activities planned by Federal agencies in the next 12 months includes such diverse items as peanut marketing quotas, tobacco price supports, restrictions on imports of honeybees and zebra mussels, auto emission standards, child labor rules, restrictions on fishing for black rockfish off the coast of Washington and rules for disposing of tissue from dead whales.
Vice President Dan Quayle is trying to carve a role for himself monitoring Federal regulation to insure that the benefits of new rules outweigh the burdens imposed on American business. As head of a new interagency group called the Council on Competitiveness, Mr. Quayle has advised all Federal agencies that he intends to supervise the review of proposed regulations, just as Mr. Bush did in the last Administration. Already the council has demanded changes in several environmental rules, including one that would set air pollution standards for municipal waste incinerators.
The Quayle panel would seem to be acting in line with the philosophy Mr. Bush expressed when he signed the clean air bill last year. He said the Government should rely less on regulation and more on the marketplace, offering "incentives, choice and flexibility for industry to find the best solutions."
But the growth in the volume and detail of Federal regulation seems likely to continue unless President Bush makes a stronger personal effort to curtail it.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Over Steep Turkish Passes, the Kurds Start Back to Iraq

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ON THE TURKISH-IRAQI BORDER, April 27

 BODY:
The movement of Kurdish refugees back to Iraq from their grisly camps in the mountains of southern Turkey appears to be starting in earnest.
United States Army helicopters today flew 325 Kurdish men from Isikveren, one of Turkey's biggest and most desolate refugee centers, to help build the resettlement encampment of blue and white tents in the river valley outside Zakho, in northern Iraq. 
 Special Forces officers running the airlift plan to bring in at least 250 more Kurds from other border encampments each day for the next three days, in an effort to build enthusiasm for the move among the refugees.
There were about 6,000 volunteers for the pick-and-shovel jobs in the Zakho camp this morning, said Dayton Maxwell, the United States Agency for International Development's specialist in charge of disaster relief here.
 
Some Now Return Voluntarily
 Perhaps more significantly, in the nameless valleys and gorges scattered along the Iraqi side of the mountains, people were coming back on their own today, in groups of tens and twenties, building into the hundreds. They climbed over high passes and ridges from Turkey onto footpaths that turned into dirt tracks and finally, roads.
The returning refugees had little to carry -- perhaps a blanket, a transistor radio, a few belongings bundled into a makeshift pack. Mostly they walked, but on some roads there were donkeys carrying bundles or refugees packed into a truck bumping down the road.
The mass flight of Iraqi Kurds for the Turkish and Iranian frontiers began when Iraq's forces crushed a Kurdish rebellion last month in the aftermath of its defeat in the Persian Gulf war. The United Nations estimates there are 416,000 refugees at this border and farther within Turkey, while 200,000 to 400,000 are reported on the Iraqi side of the border. More than a million people have fled to Iran, the United Nations says; on Friday, it doubled its estimate of the daily death toll among the refugees, from 1,000 to 2,000.
American military and aid officials hope that once movement of the Kurds and other refugees back to their homes in Iraq begins, it will become a mass flow, as their exodus was.
About 200 families returned to their homes in Zakho last night, Mr. Maxwell said. That number would surely have swelled today.
A major factor in the growing movement appeared to be the removal of several hundred armed Iraqis described as policemen, but widely believed to be soldiers or security agents.
But on a number of roads, Kurdish guerrillas known as Pesh Merga (those who face death) kept some refugees back, saying the streets were still unsafe, in an apparent effort to assert their authority. A local commander said about 3,000 of the guerrillas have gathered on the outskirts of the zone protected by Western forces, where half a dozen refugee camps are planned.
Mr. Maxwell, explaining the airlift of the Kurdish refugee workers, which has been worked out over the last week with traditional clan chiefs, said:
 
Momentum Needed
 "The important thing is to break the ice and get some momentum going. They are very anxious to come, and now that the flow has started, we will get supplies in place and start moving people through."
At Zakho today, First Lieut. Joel Baker of the Marine Corps, whose combat engineering platoon hammered together the 1,000-tent camp at Zakho in a hurry, watched refugee families coming back to town along the main highway. They were packed into carts pulled by tractors.
"The marines put up this place to give the Kurds their freedom," he said. "It makes you feel good to see how hard work can change people's lives."
The roads on the Iraqi side showed the haste with which the refugees moved out, taking off in every vehicle that moved, including fire trucks, garbage trucks, buses, ambulances and taxicabs.
High in a mountain valley, more than an hour's drive from the last visible population center at the village of Darkar, a group of 17 refugees paused to rest in the shade of a tree before passing two abandoned municipal fire trucks on their way back to Zakho.
"I want to go home," said Hayam Haji, a 12-year-old girl. "Zakho is better to live in. I am not happy because Saddam is still in power. When Saddam is gone, I will be happy."
 
Taking Precautions
 A man going back to the town said: "I'm going back to Zakho to look at the house and see if everything is all right. If the Pesh Merga are in the town and everything is all right, I will go back."
But the bright day, in which British marines and fresh paratroopers manned positions hard by the roadblocks of the Kurdish guerrillas, barely concealed the Mideast tribal blood feuds that could spell trouble for the coalition forces committed to keeping the peace here.
"The situation is not stable now," said a guerrilla leader named Mohammed Shafik, at a roadblock only a few miles from the last roadblock set up this morning on the main highway by American and British marines. "Due to this instability, we will keep our weapons."
"We have many reservations about Saddam Hussein," he said, referring to the agreement reportedly reached between the Iraqi President and some Kurdish leaders. "We have to be alert in our minds. We have had many bad experiences."
At another roadblock, a guerrilla leader who gave his names as Abu Zira put the score-settling to come bluntly: "We don't want anybody who was appointed by Saddam Hussein.
"I think the British, Americans and French will remain as long as it is in their interest," he said. "When it is not in their interest they will leave. And when the allied forces leave the place, the Pesh Merga will start fighting again."

EUROPEANS PRESS U.N. ROLE
 MONDORF-LES-BAINS, Luxembourg, April 27 (AP) -- Officials from France and Britain proposed today that the United Nations encourage hundreds of thousands of Iraqi Kurdish refugees to return home by assuring their safety.
"The Kurds demand more security," France's Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, said after an informal meeting here of European Community foreign ministers. "The United Nations must be involved in returning the Kurds."
Mr. Dumas proposed that the Security Council meet to examine conditions in Iraq. French officials said such a guarantee would force President Hussein to respect his accord in principle with Kurdish leaders. The British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, suggested a United Nations police force to protect the Kurds.

HEADLINE: School Choice, Without Harm

 BODY:
President Bush wholeheartedly supports "parental choice" as a way to improve America's public schools. In announcing his new education plan, he said that giving parents more flexibility to choose schools "will create the competitive climate that stimulates excellence in our private and parochial schools as well."
This is a revolutionary change from the tradition of assigning pupils to public schools based on where they live. But thus far Mr. Bush has been remarkably vague about how he envisions such "choice" plans in practice. The idea is outlined sketchily in three sentences in a strategy document, amplified by five sentences in a fact sheet. 
 There one learns that the President would provide $230 million for demonstrations and incentive grants and would incorporate choice into the largest Federal school aid program -- the $6 billion Chapter 1 program providing desperately needed remedial education to disadvantaged children.
The choice approach has some attractions. It would provide a way out for bright or ambitious students currently trapped in inferior neighborhood schools, who might well blossom if allowed to choose a better school. And, if applied successfully, it might force weak schools to improve lest they lose their students to better schools.
But the Administration ought not embark on such radical change unless it can insure that the neediest students won't be left even worse off than before, in disintegrating schools that have been stripped of their best and brightest.
Since 1965, Washington has tried to provide equal opportunity for students who are economically and educationally at risk through the Chapter 1 program. Money is given to schools that serve a high proportion of poor students. It is generally spent on the lowest achievers, who receive remedial help in subjects like reading and math.
Recently, Federal rules have allowed any school where poor children constitute 75 percent of enrollment to use Chapter 1 funds for schoolwide services, like lowering class sizes in all grades, hiring reading teachers or guidance counselors. Thus, many schools, particularly in low-income urban areas, now rely on Chapter 1 funds to improve instruction for all students.
Mr. Bush now proposes to convert Chapter 1, allowing eligible students to choose any school they wish to attend, whether public, private or parochial, and their pro-rated share of the program's funds would follow.
Giving bright, highly motivated low-income students more educational options is not only desirable, but imperative. Too many of these students are trapped in public schools that continue to operate despite poor performance.
But what about the less motivated, most troubled students, who are ill equipped to exercise choice and might be rejected if they did? Washington's emphasis ought to be on improving the weak public schools for them, or on attaching enough money to each student so that better schools would want to compete for even the dullest and most poorly behaved. Unless the Administration is willing to promote quality education for all students, its plan will be little more than a publicly funded scholarship program for the bright and restless.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Kuwaitis, Having Survived Hussein, Now Find Their Environment Toxic

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KUWAIT CITY, April 27

 BODY:
With many Kuwaitis remaining out of their country two months after the end of the Iraqi occupation, this country seems in little hurry to measure the long-term health peril resulting from the hundreds of oil-well fires left by the retreating Iraqi forces.
The nation seems to have a divided view of the environment; pointing to the blazing wells is a way to vilify President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, but pointing too hard at the smoke might slow down the return of Kuwaitis, about half of whom are not yet back. 
 "We don't want people to flee the country," said Dr. Walid Daud, head of the preventive medicine department of the Kuwait Oil Company.
Yet the health hazard is such that doctors are advising anyone with chronic respiratory problems not to return yet, and some are advising families with children to wait as well.
 
 No Special Risks, At Least Not Now
 From what they know now, Kuwaiti and American scientists say, the environment poses no special risks to healthy people. Yet, the burning oil has become a pervasive blight, and there is much the scientists do not know about the long-term effects of the huge spills and fires, and their resulting pollution.
Kuwait has not put much emphasis on re-establishing a testing laboratory plundered by the Iraqis that could measure what was going into the air, and has declined to pay the United States Environmental Protection Agency to do the job.
Hospitals have andecdotal evidence that emergency-room visits and admissions are up because of air pollution, but are not able to keep track of how much. A house-to-house survey is under way to measure the smoke's health effects, and how people's daily practices make them vulnerable to pollution. But the survey is being done privately, not by the Government.
Some Americans also appear to be taking a complacent view of the problem. For example, on Monday, Col. Eliot J. Pearlman, a physician who specializes in industrial and preventive medicine and who is based in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, tried to reassure 60 soldiers here that they faced no danger. After a series of questions about the long-term effect on human lungs, one soldier asked if anyone had performed autopsies on sheep's lungs to see the effect of the smoke.
No, said Dr. Pearlman. But Kuwaiti scientists say those lungs show black spots.
 
 A Land That Lives in a State of Denial
 A Kuwaiti reluctance to confront environmental threats is not surprising, a foreign-educated Ph.D. said. "We don't admit to having any problem, political, economic or environmental, until it explodes," he said.
The wells are emitting all the garden-variety industrial pollutants present in the United States, including sulfur dioxide, carbon monoxide and other ingredients of smog. But they also produce a class of chemicals called polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons that are proven carcinogens.
Dr. Daud and other Kuwaiti officials said these are dangerous only with chronic exposure, and argued that all the fires set by the Iraqis should be out within months.
But as the fires continue to burn, Kuwaiti and foreign specialists say, the release of oil into the environment is producing pervasive, troubling symptoms. Among the questions about these is whether the polycyclic chemicals will remain in the air, and if they break down, whether the resulting chemicals will be less hazardous, or more.
Oil, which this country once drew from reservoirs a mile below the surface, is spitting over everything. Raw or as ash, it is in plants and animals, water and soil, on windshields and clothing, in lungs and even stomachs.
"We eat oil all the time now," said Fatima al-Awadi, a chemist, tracing the chain from well to soil to grass to animal. "It's in the meat."
Dr. Jassim M. al-Hassan, chairman of the biochemistry department of Kuwait University, stood on an island in the Sabriya oilfield north of here and remarked, "I don't think this area will ever recover."
The island is inside a river about a mile and a half long. But Kuwait has no rivers of water; this was oil. And it is flowing in the lowest-lying part of the surrounding desert -- the only fertile part, where the soil washed from the stony hills gradually collects, and where a stingy Nature provides just enough water to allow seeds to germinate.
Oil can be seen flowing in many places, cutting channels in the sand and forming black pools.
From a distance, most of the desert still looks pristine. But up close, the flowers that bloomed before the war -- daisies, milkweed, geraniums and others -- are spotted with oil and soot.
The same smoke that irritates eyes and throats in the city is attacking the sand itself in the desert. Once the sand was dry and granular; now it is being melded into a crust by the ash and the black rain that falls from unnaturally overcast skies.
 
Perilous for People, Deadly for Animals
 Herds of grazing sheep and goats look gray, too. The people who herd them, often children, now walk in front instead of behind, to try to protect the flocks from mines.
But the shepherds are leading their animals to oil-covered grass, where the animals appear to be poisoning themselves. Many show respiratory congestion, stop eating and die quickly. And in each flock, at least one or two sheep are nearly bare of wool and totter weakly. The tanker trucks that used to bring water for the animals now carry it only to people.
Where the sheep do find water, it is worse yet. The soot in the black clouds attaches itself to whatever moisture is in the air and produces the black rain.
The content of these rain puddles has not been scientifically analyzed, but Mohammed Abel, a biologist at the Environmental Policy Council, inadvertently performed an experiment. He has two kid goats at his home. After a rain, one drank from a puddle while the other did not. The latter goat has grown; the one that drank has lost weight and looks weak, Mr. Abel said. Fodder is contaminated, as well.
Dr. Hassan of Kuwait University fears for the camels. Some are domesticated and some run loose. The scientist crouched near a plant that grows in clumps in the desert, one often eaten by camels, and points to the spots of oil on each delicate yellow blossom.
Insects have been affected, too. In some places, pools of oil are like flypaper to the butterflies. But not, unfortunately, for the flies, of which there are far more than usual, including two varieties not seen here before. The reason may be as simple as the uncollected garbage, or the relatively cool, wet weather brought on by the smoke. And there are almost no bees; no one is sure why. Birds can be seen migrating through the area of burning oil, and specialists fear for them.
Then there is the question of the fish in the Persian Gulf, which in normal times is a major food source. The issue has been rendered partly moot by the Iraqis' destruction of Kuwait's fleet of dhows. But noncommercial fishermen still throw lines from jetties on the beach, even though ribbons of oil are visible a few yards offshore.
 
A Survey Obscured by Its Own Sludge
 To try to determine how bad the effects are, this week a group of 17 Kuwaiti scientists set out to survey residents, asking what symptoms they suffered and whether they drank tap water or ate locally grown food. In the evening, after the first day of knocking on doors, they looked over the survey forms and realized that the medium was the message -- the forms themselves were splattered with oil.
Scientists, American and Kuwaiti, acknowledge two fundamental problems: The level of soot and gases is highly variable, from place to place and from minute to minute in a given spot, and Kuwait is no longer able to measure the pollution.
Before the war, there were three permanent monitoring stations, situated to measure pollution from an industrial area, a sewage plant and other usual sources, and there were two mobile laboratories. The Iraqis disabled one of the fixed monitoring stations and took both the mobile ones, and the war drove away the lab technicians.
Some of the questions posed by the environnmental degradation here will in time yield to better analysis. Early in May, the United States Army's Environmental Hygiene Agency is to bring an advanced laboratory to Dhahran, Saudi Arabia. Field teams are to perform two weeks of sampling, but no public report is expected until fall.
 
Kuwait's Scientists Are Slow to Return
 Kuwait's own scientific establishment, heavy with Ph.D.'s trained in the United States and Britain, is near a standstill. Dr. Mustafa al-Desuki, chief technical adviser to the Kuwaiti Environmental Protection Department, said 80 percent of his staff was still abroad.
Postwar Kuwait has resolved to be less dependent on foreigners, but for years the country relied almost exclusively on foreign technicians. Many of these do not want to come back, and some, like Palestinians and Iraqis, are unwelcome.
Nonetheless, after two months of living amid burning oil wells, many Kuwaitis still do not see all this primarily as an environmental problem, but an economic one.
"This is cash," a businessman said of the oil. "If the fire was out and the oil underground, and the country needed to borrow, that would be our collateral. If the firefighters say it will take $500 million and seven months, I'd say give them $1 billion and three months."
While the firefighting goes on, some scientists minimize the environmental damage. Colonel Pearlman said oil will not hurt the gastrointestinal tract "unless you drink a good cup of crude," and for most people, skin irritation is "pretty much a nonevent unless you bathe in the stuff." The particles are too big to enter the lungs, he said, and will lodge instead in the upper respiratory tract, where they can cause irritation.
"Coughing up black soot is a protective mechanism by our bodies," Dr. Pearlman said. "That doesn't mean it's a health hazard. That means it's a nuisance."

HEADLINE: Racial Quotas Are a Fact of Economic Life

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Tossing Around the 'Quota' Bomb" (editorial, April 7), you claim to doubt that proposed revisions to the civil rights laws would drive employers to hire according to quotas to avoid lawsuits. The Bush Administration in making this argument, you say, "cites no evidence." You then provide ample evidence yourself. 
 The case involving the Daniel Lamp Company, which you discuss, and which was described on "60 Minutes" and received a good deal of attention in Chicago, makes the point. The lamp company employs fewer than 30 production workers; the employees are mostly Hispanic, but at various times several blacks have been employed as well.
After a black woman who had been rejected for a job complained, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission claimed that a nondiscriminatory employer would have had more black employees (8.45 blacks, to be precise). It proposed that the company spend $10,000 advertising to discover blacks who felt they had been discriminated against and further that the company pay $124,000 into a fund out of which several rejected black applicants, and any blacks responding to the advertising, could seek damages. If the employer did not agree, a lawsuit would follow (the commission filed suit on Jan. 16).
How did the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission conclude that Daniel Lamp should have had 8.45 black employees? Because that number was approximately 30 percent of Daniel's work force, and the commission claims that is the percentage of blacks employed by companies within a three-mile radius of the Daniel plant.
This is the study to which you refer, and it proves nothing. The lamp company was in an entirely Hispanic neighborhood, paid the minimum wage and was not likely to elicit large numbers of applicants who lived at a distance from the plant. All of the employees who worked at the plant were from the neighborhood.
An employer observing the situation of the Daniel Lamp Company, whether or not the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission ultimately prevails, can be forgiven for thinking that the better part of discretion is to hire a specified number of minority workers to avoid trouble. To paraphrase your words, if you refuse to recognize the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission's demand as a quota, it will be hard to conduct any cogent debate.
Anyone who has lived in the United States and worked for an employer in the last 20 years knows, despite the absence of evidence cited, that employers engage in race-conscious preferential treatment to avoid litigation. Not all of this behavior is undesirable, but until the civil rights establishment, and the Democratic Party, are willing to be candid about the facts of life, a constructive discussion of the pros and cons cannot begin. They'll just have to stand there and take it when the quota epithet is hurled at them.
 
MAYER G. FREED
Professor of Law and Associate Dean, Northwestern U.
Chicago, April 18, 1991

SECTION: Section 7; Page 23; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: Goo Galore

BYLINE: By Timothy Egan; Timothy Egan is the Seattle correspondent for The New York Times and the author of "The Good Rain: Across Time and Terrain in the Pacific Northwest."

 BODY:

OUT OF THE CHANNEL
The Exxon Valdez Oil Spill in Prince William Sound.
By John Keeble.
290 pp. New York:
HarperCollins Publishers. $22.95.  
 Few things in Alaska ever happen on a small scale. The Klondike gold rush of 1897 set off a stampede of hyperbole matched only by the greed of the prospectors. The Good Friday earthquake of 1964 not only buried whole towns, including the old port of Valdez, under a seismic wave of water, but created a new shoreline for much of the state. The Trans-Alaska Pipeline, built in the 1970's after a vast oil field was discovered beneath the North Slope, was the biggest private construction project in history, hooking the state on a potentially destructive treasure.
So when the Exxon Valdez, one of the world's most technologically advanced tankers, was ruptured on a shallow reef two years ago, it was not just any old accident but the nation's largest oil spill, a gusher of nearly 11 million gallons. And when Exxon settled with the United States Government and the State of Alaska last month, the claim made history. Exxon agreed to pay $1.1 billion, the largest sum ever paid for an environmental catastrophe.
As John Keeble shows in "Out of the Channel," the spill was all the more dramatic because it was a clash of two extremes: the industrial world, in the form of the Texas-based Exxon Corporation, versus primordial nature, Prince William Sound with its sea otters and its villages inhabited by people who live off whatever they bring in from the sea.
At the height of the cleanup effort, when an army of 11,000 workers slopped around Prince William Sound in orange rubber suits, hand-scrubbing rocks and hosing down beaches with hot water, there was a rollicking, black-humor, typically Alaskan quality to the whole mess.
Mr. Keeble, the author of four books of fiction, tells the story of the great spill in a style and tone that is more impressionistic than the scolding narrative it could have been. His approach, while a bit meandering in some sections, serves him well, because nothing about the saga of the Exxon Valdez was ever as black-and-white as it appeared.
For example, even though the Coast Guard made the ship's skipper, Capt. Joseph Hazelwood, give up his license to operate a ship for nine months after he pleaded no contest, in July 1990, to charges of negligence and consuming alcohol within four hours of sailing, no jury and no investigative reporter has been able to show conclusively that he was drunk when he went below deck a few minutes before the spill and gave up command of his ship during the most treacherous part of the journey from Valdez to Long Beach, Calif. (Indeed, he was acquitted in Alaska of charges of intoxication and reckless endangerment.) Mr. Keeble adds nothing new to the file on Captain Hazelwood, who is the youngest skipper in Exxon history, a voracious reader, a bit of a rebel and a conscientious man with a well-documented drinking problem.
Instead, the author gives him the now familiar revisionist treatment, describing him as the fall guy for a stereotype of a corporation. Mr. Keeble concludes that the truth about Captain Hazelwood will probably never be known, or at least understood, because he has become an icon. "The nation," the author writes, "could fix its sense of outrage and guilt upon him."
Mr. Keeble, who covered the spill for The Village Voice, spent enough time in Prince William Sound to bring back an engaging story. He talked with the "spillionaires" of Valdez, who lambasted Exxon while getting rich off boat rental fees to the company's cleanup fleet; with the confused and troubled villagers, and with the corporate spin doctors prowling around press conferences in fresh-pressed Eddie Bauer togs. The problem is the book's structure. The narrative moves from late-night chats aboard fishing boats to dissertation-style explanations of oil chemistry, without conveying a sense of the overall story or a developing theme.
Mr. Keeble finds the fishermen most interesting, with their advanced degrees and their homes cut off from the world; he calls them "the quintessential Alaskans of the moment." They opposed the pipeline from the start, because they feared that a spill of any significance could harm one of the world's last great salmon fisheries. And in the first hectic days after the accident, while Exxon dithered, the fishermen took charge, starting their own cleanup in an effort to save their salmon hatcheries. Aside from these eco-fishermen, though, Mr. Keeble finds few people worth romanticizing.
"Alaska," he writes, "is a resource colony, or economic territory." That may be true, but most of the "exploited" residents receive enough in oil dividends -- roughly $1000 per person -- to be willing co-conspirators. Until a few years ago, trying to find somebody who opposed the oil industry in the 49th state was like looking for a real cowboy in midtown Manhattan.
Mr. Keeble concludes, as other observers have, that the cleanup effort was by and large a public relations campaign -- one that cost more than $2 billion, employed more Alaskans than any project since the pipeline was built and took very little oil out of the the water -- perhaps no more than 20 percent. The technology that has gone into bringing oil from beneath the ground and transporting it to fuel-hungry consumers in the lower 48 states may be plenty advanced, but the methods used to clean up the muck after an accident are in the Stone Age.
There are sharp passages in this book about what a flood of oil does to an unspoiled landscape and its inhabitants -- descriptions of otters scratching their eyes out, birds gagging on the toxic sludge and villagers discovering the capitalistic impulse to gouge their customers. And such sights, we are now learning, are just a hint of the destruction; this month, biologists hired by the Federal Government announced that the damage was far worse than originally reported and that its effects may linger much longer than had been anticipated.
While there is nothing funny about the spill, the tone of this book is bit too grim, occasionally even preachy, and misses the raucous humor that Alaskans themselves found in an oil giant humbled by the accidental release of its prized cargo.
"Through their use of oil," Mr. Keeble writes, "humans have entered into an exchange with their own natural history that extends back through the millennia." But, he observes, we may be "consuming our natural history faster than it can replenish itself." Such things were seldom mentioned by the lawyers and accountants who dealt with the fallout from the nation's worst spill. Mr. Keeble's ability to find ironies in catastrophe may be his greatest contribution to the tanker of words spilled over the Exxon Valdez.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 28, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A review on page 23 of The Times Book Review today, about "Out of the Channel: The Exxon Valdez Oil Spill in Prince William Sound" by John Keeble, briefly summarizes the settlement reached by the oil company in March with the United States Government and the State of Alaska by saying Exxon had agreed to pay $1.1 billion. On Wednesday, after The Book Review had gone to press, a Federal judge overturned part of the settlement, saying the criminal portion of the penalty, $100 million, was too small, and leaving the entire settlement in doubt.
