HEADLINE: FILM;
'Truly, Madly' Favors Ghosts Without Gimmicks

BYLINE: By MATT WOLF; Matt Wolf is an American theater critic and journalist based in London.

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Anthony Minghella's first film, "Truly, Madly, Deeply," features among its characters a ghost who returns to be with the grief-stricken woman he loved. But any similarities to "Ghost," insists the British writer-director, are merely coincidental.
"It's such a different kind of film," Mr. Minghella, who is 37 years old, was saying over breakfast one morning in a Covent Garden brasserie. He said the specter of the American blockbuster constituted both "a blessing and a curse." 
 "It's a blessing that 'Ghost' did well," he said. "If it had been a disaster, then it probably would have inhibited this film from being released. It also suggested there's an appetite, happily, for films which have an anti-naturalist quality to them." On the other hand, he added, " 'Ghost' is there. I can't drive around it; I have to drive through it."
Not that audiences are likely to confuse the two movies. Whereas "Ghost" vaunts its Hollywood slickness from the outset, "Truly, Madly, Deeply," which opens Friday in New York City, looks like the low-budget English feature that, in fact, it is (the film cost about $1.8 million). Its opening scenes, showing Juliet Stevenson as the bereaved Nina in therapy, hint at a Bergman-like austerity. Only gradually does the film's quirkiness emerge in its celebration of human idiosyncrasy and in its rebuttal of all the trademarks of ghost-ridden movies. No walking through walls or otherworldly bluish lights here; the director's interests lie in "those strange ricocheting emotional dynamics" that have always marked his earlier work, as a dramatist, in theater and television. Like his new film, one of his early plays, "A Little Like Drowning," dealt with loss and grief without gimmickry.
"Is he really there?" Mr. Minghella said, discussing the film's plot, in which Alan Rickman as Nina's lover, Jamie, appears from the dead at her flat to offer solace and eventual release. "Who can see him? Is he really dead? I felt instinctually that those questions weren't at all appropriate." The film dispenses with the expected barrage of special effects, which, said Mr. Minghella, its producers could not have afforded anyway. "It's a wonderful thing when the economies of film making determine the style," he said. "We simply wouldn't have been able to do any of those things even if we collectively thought we must."
More important, he felt, was to honor his script's "shifting realities." "The movie's not about death, particularly," said Mr. Minghella. "It's about all forms of loss -- about all forms of hanging on to versions of the past which actually impede any sort of progress in relationships." In the film's final scene, Jamie and his other ghostly friends wave farewell to Nina through the window of her flat in what amounts to a gesture of letting go. Said the director: "In many ways, the movie is a meditation on the circumstances of women like Juliet in contemporary London: how you make your way, what sort of community you establish, how that community operates, how you move on."
"Truly, Madly, Deeply" marks the seventh collaboration between Mr. Minghella and Miss Stevenson, whom he first met when she appeared in several episodes of the BBC dramatic series "Maybury," for which he wrote a decade ago. The two have worked together on and off since in television and in radio, although never in the medium -- theater -- in which both remain best known. Mr. Minghella says he believes in fostering working relationships over time and points out that Bill Paterson, who plays Nina's boss at the agency that employs her as an interpreter, is the only one of the film's principals with whom he had not worked before.
"I would hope it was a sign of creative loyalty and also of seeing the possibility of the shorthand in relationships," said the director, whose wife, the Hong Kong-born dancer Carolyn Choa, has a small role in the movie. "You don't waste time in a creative relationship; there's a mutual vocabulary. You can get right to the heart of the matter."
Mr. Minghella said he owes the style of "Truly, Madly, Deeply" to yet another collaboration -- his partnership with the late Jim Henson. For Mr. Henson, he wrote nine episodes of the television series "The Storyteller," as well as a 1989 television film "Living With Dinosaurs," which starred Miss Stevenson.
"Before my Henson period," Mr. Minghella said, "all my narrative solutions were extremely naturalistic, extremely in the realm of what is possible. Then I worked on 'Storyteller' and spent two years really reading folk tales and myths and fantastical pieces of literature." The result was liberating.
"It opened me consciously or otherwise to the possibility of marrying two distinct styles: one which accommodates rather bold devices like the laws of fairy tales and at the same time marrying that with a much more apparently authentic style of language," Mr. Minghella said.
 A dramatist who first came to attention in the theater in the early 1980's with various plays on London's equivalent of Off Broadway, Mr. Minghella hasn't written for the stage since 1986, when he made his West End debut with "Made in Bangkok," about a British tour group on vacation in Thailand. The play arrived with impeccable credentials -- a major producer (Michael Codron), director (Michael Blakemore) and star (Felicity Kendal) -- and yet still lost money. Five years later, Mr. Minghella finds the very genre of theater puzzling.
"I don't know what constitutes the sort of material that's best expressed in the theater anymore," said the director, who was a drama lecturer at his alma mater, the University of Hull in northern England, until 1981.
For now, Mr. Minghella was sounding like a man hooked on the screen. On tap are three separate projects -- "The Seven Deadly Sins" for Henson Productions, about a man who is visited by the seven vices; a script for the director Randa Haines ("Children of a Lesser God"), set partly in Italy and in the United States; and another directing job, "Mr. Wonderful," about a group of Italians working for Con Edison in Manhattan. A movie of "Made in Bangkok" is possible, too.
The second of five children born to southern Italian emigrants, Mr. Minghella pointed to a link between his childhood on Britain's Isle of Wight and the process of film directing, a link he is only now discovering. Having grown up above his parents' seaside cafe, where life revolved around the kitchen, the director looks back on "an impossible domestic situation" of endless bustle and activity.
"I found myself going to university as far away from that kitchen as possible into a career and a job that couldn't be more of an antithesis, quietly writing in a room," he said -- antithetical, that is, until he started to direct. "I looked up and realized there were 70 people shouting and trying to get gear into place," he said, remembering the precise epiphany. "For one blinding moment, I'd gone back into the kitchen again. It felt great."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Anthony Minghella, the writer-director of "Truly, Madly, Deeply"--a taste for strange, ricocheting emotional dynamics (Jonathan Player for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Texas Governor Is Elusive on Taxes

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., April 24

 BODY:
One hundred days after becoming Governor of Texas, Ann Richards still seems to be campaigning for the job, except now she looks as if she is having fun.
Crisscrossing the state last year, Ms. Richards proclaimed her intentions to create a "new Texas." And now, as she dashes around the state Capitol, the slogan remains her rallying cry. Just as she did in the campaign, she offers specific policies on only a few carefully chosen issues, all the while avoiding any commitments on tax matters. 
 Instead of enjoying the honeymoon usually afforded newly elected officials, Ms. Richards, a Democrat, has been courting and cajoling the State Legislature and the executive bureaucracy, trying to establish her spheres of influence. Rather than expending political capital, she has been trying to create it.
"She stepped into this job at the worst possible time, given the condition of the state," said George Christian, an Austin lobbyist, "and she has not tried to shake everything up from top to bottom because that could have been a disaster for her."
 
Some Unfinished Business
 Appointing women and members of minorities to state jobs has been one of Governor Richards's major preoccupations. She has also pressed for legislation tightening the regulation of the insurance industry and the disposal of hazardous waste, and she has joined other politicians in promoting a new government ethics law. So far, however, none of her major legislative projects have been enacted.
"Her strategy seems to be to fire a few well-aimed rifle shots, not broadsides," said Mr. Christian, a former press secretary to President Lyndon B. Johnson. "Meanwhile, she is doing everything she can to prepare for the big crisis ahead."
In midsummer the Governor and the Legislature are planning to contend with a deficit last estimated at $4.6 billion in a two-year budget of about $53 billion. Unlike other states facing a temporary shortage of revenue because of the recession, the financial problems in Texas are more permanent.
For nearly a decade, low prices and declining production in the oil and gas industry have robbed the state of once-abundant revenue. At the same time, state and Federal courts have required Texas to increase spending on public schools, prisons, welfare and the care of the mentally ill.
After a briefing on the budget by fiscal experts early this year, Gib Lewis, the Speaker of the State House of Representatives, said, "I move we recess and go throw up somewhere."
A reaction of that sort has become a common sentiment among Texas politicians. But Governor Richards, who often seems to be grinning under her crown of white hair, is an exception.
"We look at this mess and we see all the valuable things we can do with it," said Mary Beth Rogers, the Governor's chief of staff. "Actually, this is a wonderful time to be an activist Governor of Texas."
So far, Ms. Richards has made only one foray into fiscal matters, and it failed when her proposal for a state lottery was rejected by the Legislature. Otherwise, she has postponed any action on the budget, insisting that all decisions on financial policy should wait until a special legislative session she plans to call sometime after July 1.
On that date she is scheduled to receive a special audit of state agencies that is intended to show how up to $1 billion can be saved by streamlining the state government and eliminating waste. On the same day a special commission headed by former Gov. John B. Connally is supposed to report on alternatives for raising new revenue.
But the options are limited. Texas is one of only five states with neither a personal nor a corporate income tax. Relying on sales and property taxes to make up for lost oil revenue has already driven those tax rates to some of the highest levels in the nation.
As a result Texas may have the most regressive tax structure in the United States. One recent study showed that a family of four earning $10,000 a year paid about 7.1 percent of its income in state and local taxes, while the rate for a family the same size earning $100,000 was about 4.4 percent.
Throughout the primary and general election campaigns last year, Ms. Richards shied from taking firm stands for or against changes in the tax structure, much to the frustration of her opponents. She has been equally elusive since her inauguration, but her reticence matters less now because others have taken the lead on the tax issue.
 
A Redefined Political Agenda
 Three weeks ago Lieut. Gov. Bob Bullock, a Democrat, presented a plan calling for corporate and personal income taxes while reducing sales and property taxes. The plan instantly redefined the state's political agenda, and not only because Mr. Bullock, as chief officer of the State Senate, holds a powerful post in the state government.
"The tax question can be resolved, but only with a massive town meeting at which Texans decide who they are and what they want to be," said George Shipley, a Democratic political consultant and lobbyist.
"Bullock can put the deal together on the inside, but Ann is the one who is going to have to close the sale by going to the public," he said, referring to the Governor by her first name, a practice commonly used by her friends and foes alike.
As she bides her time and guards her options, Ms. Richards has taken a position on the importance of the issue, but not on how to resolve it.
Earlier this month she told the Connally committee: "We cling to the pretense that we are living in the 1940's with the lowest fees, the lowest taxes and the best business climate. As we prepare to enter the 21st century, we can no longer trade in pretense and myth."
So far she has given no signs of whether she is willing to join forces with Mr. Bullock, who is both a political ally and a rival. But Ms. Rogers, the Governor's chief of staff, said, "People are all assuming that its an income tax or nothing, and I am not sure we are there yet."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Ann Richards of Texas with Speaker Gib Lewis earlier this month in Austin. Three months in office, Ms. Richards is courting and cajoling as she tries to establish her spheres of influence. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: High Medical Costs Hurt Growing Numbers in U.S.

SERIES: The Price of Health/First of five articles.

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
Long a gnawing worry of the poor, medical expenses and health insurance are now a source of mounting anxiety for millions of middle-class Americans -- healthy or sick, insured or not.
 For a growing number of people, insurance status has become the pivotal factor in important personal decisions, trapping some people in jobs they do not want and forcing others to forgo needed medical care. 
One spreading phenomenon is known as "job-lock" -- fear of changing jobs because of a medical history that, in today's more stringent insurance market, would probably prevent a worker's acceptance by a new health plan. Cancer patients or those with chronic diseases are most vulnerable.
 Anna Wu Work, a 36-year-old molecular biologist, says it is only her health coverage that keeps her working full time as a researcher at the City of Hope National Medical Center in Duarte, Calif., when she would rather spend more time with her daughters, Elizabeth, 4, and Kelsey, almost 1. She is afraid to leave her job or ask for part-time work, because she was treated for an early stage of breast cancer three years ago, and needs health insurance in the unlikely event of a recurrence.
 
Shaping the Health System
 "It's a special time," Dr. Work said, "and I want to be with my children, especially since I know I might not be there forever. But the one thing I can't do now is quit, because I have insurance here and I'm uninsurable if I leave."
 Most Americans still have health insurance. But as the nation's medical costs soar, more and more people are being squeezed financially or abandoned altogether by insurers. Their fears, and the vaguer disquiet of many well-insured people who see awesomely high bills for common medical procedures, are becoming important new forces for change in the nation's health system.
 "We've gotten to the point where everybody is scared," said Robert J. Blendon, a professor at the Harvard School of Public Health who is an expert on public opinion and health policy. "Everyone has heard these terrible stories about some middle-class working person they can identify with who had no insurance and got into an awful situation."
 
One Nightmarish Story
 If concerns about health insurance are an emerging obsession for America's middle class, it is stories like Brent McRae's that shape the worst nightmares.
 Mr. McRae was 27 years old and only two months into the new sales job that made him move to California from Texas in 1988 when he began to lose weight and feel ill. After five weeks of testing and finally surgery, he was found to have colon cancer.
 The bills were more than $100,000. But after his release from the hospital, he found out that the insurance he was still paying for through his former employer in Texas had been canceled because the employer had not sent his premiums to the insurer.
 "To this day, I have no idea who kept the premiums," Mr. McRae said, "but that was just the beginning."
 During his time in the hospital, Mr. McRae passed his new employer's 90-day waiting period and became eligible under the company's insurance for coverage of the six months of chemotherapy that he faced, at $700 a week -- or so he thought.
 "Five weeks into the chemotherapy," Mr. McRae said, "with a catheter imbedded in my chest, I walk into my oncologist's office, and he sits me down, puts his hand on my knee and tells me there's been no payment because John Hancock is denying coverage, saying the cancer was a pre-existing condition, even though it hadn't been diagnosed when the coverage began. Then he said he could no longer bankroll my treatment."
 Mr. McRae went without chemotherapy until he got new insurance, and last year had further surgery because the cancer had spread to a new part of the colon.
 "At one point in the middle of the whole thing, I hit bottom, between having cancer and being told I had no insurance, and I tried to commit suicide," he said.
 But his story has a happy ending: for the last year he has been cancer-free, and last month, in an out-of-court settlement, the former employer and the two insurance companies paid his medical debts and legal fees.
 
The Uninsured: Overview

 33 Million Lack Basic Protection
 Most Americans still have health insurance coverage, either through their jobs or, if they are elderly or poor, through Medicare or Medicaid.
 But some 33 million Americans, 13 percent of the population, most of them lower-income workers or their families, live without this basic necessity of modern American life. And tens of millions more have such limited policies that they are at risk of financial devastation.
 Even those numbers underestimate how many people are at risk and the scale of public insecurity. In a recent 28-month period, a Census Bureau study found that more than one in four Americans went at least a month without coverage. The proportion was higher still among black and Hispanic Americans.
 Dr. Blendon said several polls have shown that most Americans worry about their insurance coverage, especially in the future.
 "If you ask people about their coverage, 30 percent say they're not sure their current insurance would cover a major bill, but if you ask about the future, 60 percent say they're not confident about their insurance," Dr. Blendon said. "Insurance costs are doubling every seven years, and what employers are doing to contain costs, principally, is cutting back benefits. Working people are already paying more for less coverage, and they know that in the next negotiation, the company will take back more benefits."
 The American health insurance system is based primarily on group coverage provided by employers. But as the costs of insurance policies have risen, to keep pace with medical bills, employers have tried to shift more of the burden to employees, forcing them to pay larger deductibles, higher co-payments and in many cases an ever-larger portion of their own premiums.
 And an increasing number of working families work for companies that offer no health insurance at all. Small businesses and service businesses are especially likely to not provide insurance, and even large companies are hiring more part-time and per-day workers who are not eligible for benefits like insurance.
 "Our health insurance system is based on the idea that employers provide insurance, but more than three out of four uninsured Americans are either workers or dependents of workers," said Nancy Barrand, a senior program officer at the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation of Princeton, N.J.
 Insurers, faced with the ever-higher costs of medical technology, are trying to limit their risks by seeking to exclude people most likely to need expensive medical care. In the process they are undermining the very notion of insurance as a strategy for spreading risk.
 Insurance fears press especially hard on those who have already suffered a serious health problem like cancer or a heart attack and find themselves unable to get any insurance to cover the condition. Cancer patients, even those who have long been free of the disease, may face waiting periods as long as 20 years after applying before their insurance will cover a recurrence. Other people who are deemed health risks may be forced to consider policies with deductibles as high as $20,000.
 
The Part-Time Worker

 Staying Healthy Is a Daily Worry
 Maintaining adequate health insurance has become a worry even for many workers who have never spent a day in a hospital and have always taken for granted that health insurance would be there, free, as a fringe benefit of their employment.
 Hope Chasin, 44, says she never thought twice about insurance in all the years it came with her job, but now that she works on a per-day basis at a New York record company and has no employer-paid benefits, she is obsessed with the topic.
 "Not a day goes by that I don't worry about insurance," Ms. Chasin said. "When I start thinking about it in any way, shape or form, I get too scared. It seems very bleak. I'm saving my money for a mammogram, and this sounds ridiculous, but I'm praying, please, let me not need root canal work right now."'
 Ms. Chasin, who earns less than $25,000 a year, said she researched every possible insurance policy for which she was eligible when her former job at Time-Life Inc. was moved to Cincinnati.
 But the comprehensive coverage she wanted cost about $2,500 a year, more than she could afford, so she bought only a Blue Cross-Blue Shield hospitalization plan, for which she pays $250 a quarter and which does not pay any of her regular doctor bills.
 That was the approach most families used to take, until the advent of employer-paid health insurance in the 1950's.
 But the affordable hospitalization insurance that used to provide genuine protection to so many families is not much of a buffer against the price of medical care these days, when bills for one visit to a specialist's office, together with fees for tests and procedures, can be many hundreds of dollars.
 Even as the insurance system's gaps widen, the medical system's prices all but assume that an insurer is paying bills. And Ms. Chasin, who says she cannot afford to see a specialist about a pain in her arm that has bothered her for months, knows it.
 "As you get older, you realize all the things that can happen, that tomorrow morning you could wake up with some serious illness and enormous medical bills," she said. "I never thought I'd be in this situation, and now that I am, I'm noticing how many of the people around me have no insurance at all. I'm also noticing that whenever I talk about it, people get all heated up."
 
The Single Mother

 No Coverage for the Children
 Dr. Blendon and most other experts believe that the number of uninsured workers is likely to continue rising.
 "The small businesses that are the fastest growing part of the economy universally don't offer fringe benefits," he said. "So you leave your job at Apple and go work for Apple Lookalike, and you lose your insurance."
 Medicaid provides insurance for the poorest families, but covers less than half of those below the poverty line nationwide. In all but a handful of states, a family of three must have a yearly income less than $7,000 to qualify for the state-Federal program. (Pregnant women, infants and those with special medical needs can often qualify for Medicaid with a somewhat higher income.)
 Children are especially likely to be uninsured. Indeed, about half of all uninsured Americans are under 25, and about a third are under 18.
 "In the same period that the number of uninsured over all rose 24 percent, it was 40 percent for kids, almost all among working families," Dr. Blendon said.
 Dana Van Putten, a New York theatrical wardrobe worker, is insured through her union. But her month-old son, David, and her 5-year-old daughter, Dina, have no coverage at all because Ms. Van Putten, a single mother, cannot afford the extra $400 a month it would cost to convert to a family policy.
 Ms. Van Putten, 30, who is diabetic and had a difficult pregnancy, has been living on a $280-a-week unemployment check since January. She says she has been worried about insurance ever since she found out in November that her union coverage would not pay for the baby's hospital costs.
 David's bills turned out to be particularly steep, because he was in intensive care for five days.
 "I just got the bill, which was $16,195, and I clutched my hand on my heart when I saw it," Ms. Van Putten said. "I'll never get that paid off, and I'll never be able to save money to buy a house. What are you supposed to do, go bankrupt?"
 
The Job-Locked

 Insurance Governs Career Choices
 The rising number of uninsured families sends ripples through the health-care system.
 "As the number of uninsured people goes up," Ms. Barrand said, "it affects everybody else because people without coverage still need health care, so they go to the hospital and end up getting uncompensated care, which forces the hospital to shift those costs onto those who have coverage."
 In a telephone poll of 1,005 adults nationwide last December, more than 15 percent of those contacted said they or a family member had changed jobs or remained in a job because of health benefits. (The poll, conducted by International Communications Research for The Associated Press, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.)
 Workers with a history of cancer, diabetes or heart disease, or those whose spouses or children need expensive longterm treatment, often find themselves locked into job and insurance they had when the medical condition began because any new insurer will reject coverage for a pre-existing condition, either for several years or indefinitely.
 Counselors at cancer support groups tell of a Hollywood executive who turned down a tantalizing job at another studio without telling his wife, who had cancer, after he realized that the insurance at the new job would not cover her treatment.
 Similarly, a New York social worker recounts the story of an unhappy corporate vice president who raised capital for a new venture of his own, but gave it up after realizing that he could not get insurance to cover his 4-year-old son's treatment for a heart defect.
 And Dr. Work, the California researcher afraid to leave her job at the City of Hope, originally thought she could get around the insurance issue by getting coverage under the policy covering her husband, a cardiologist who joined a private group practice after her cancer treatment. When he joined the practice, the group policy covered cancer recurrence costs two years after the original cancer treatment ended. But when the two years was up, and they applied, Dr. Work and her husband found that it had been extended to five years.
 "I did everything right, I found the lump early, I had it taken care of, but I'm still being penalized," Dr. Work said. "Insurance is supposed to about sharing the risk, but nobody wants to share with the people who need sharing with."
 
The Job-Seeking

 When Past Ills Get in the Way
 Others with a history of medical problems find that insurance concerns make it difficult to find employment.
 Betty Moore, 60, of Alpharetta, Ga., said she was unable to find a job in 1970 after her first round of heart surgery to replace a valve weakened years earlier by rheumatic fever.
 "Everybody said they couldn't put me on their insurance because of my record and they said I couldn't work without insurance, so I finally got a small business loan and bought a florist shop," she said.
 At the time, Mrs. Moore was still covered under the insurance policy provided by her husband's job at the Lockheed Corporation, which paid for a second round of heart surgery in 1979.
 But when Mr. Moore left the job because of a disability, Mrs. Moore was left without insurance and the medical debts began to pile up.
 "We have $1,000 on the credit card from when I had to go to the hospital for a kidney problem for 11 days, and we're paying that off by the month," Mrs. Moore said. "We owe our doctor $1,600, and I still owe $400 from when I fell off a ladder in November. And then my husband owes some, too. We've gotten so far behind on the doctor bills, it's going to be a while to get caught up."
 After calling 10 insurance companies, Mrs. Moore finally found a $179-a-month policy for herself last November, but it will not pay for any heart-related problems for the first year.
 So Mrs. Moore is hoping with a quiet desperation that she will not need further heart surgery any time soon.
 "It can happen any time that a hole in the valve gets too big and it has to be fixed," she said. "I'm just hoping that it doesn't get bad soon. I don't know what would happen if it does. You can't be sure there will be a surgeon who will take you if you can't pay."
 Mrs. Moore said she would not really rest easy until she reached 65 and the safe harbor of Medicare.
 
The Family

 Juggling Ailments and the Bills
 But it does not take the threat of heart surgery to worry the uninsured. Even minor illnesses or injuries can pose huge problems.
 Last month, when William Price hurt his ankle playing basketball, he and his wife, Paula, went through the informal process of family triage that is becoming all too common in their Mebane, N.C., household.
 The Prices have no health insurance for themselves and their two sons because Mr. Price is self-employed and they have decided they cannot afford the available policies. So with each new medical problem, they juggle their priorities and their budget. Over the winter, they spent $35 or $40 every two weeks for their son Ben, 7, to see a doctor about his allergies.
 More recently, the Prices had to decide whether it was more pressing to take Ben to the dentist to get a cavity filled, to get Mrs. Price an ultrasound scan that might help diagnose her abdominal pains and fertility problems, or, as they decided after overnight ice packs left Mr. Price still unable to walk, to get an X-ray of the hurt ankle.
 "My wife said I had to see a doctor, so we tried to figure out whether it would be cheaper to go to the doctor, and pay $50 right away, and then probably get sent to the hospital for an X-ray, and have to pay another bill, or just to go to the emergency room and do it all in one visit," Mr. Price said. "That's what I did, and I think it was the cheapest alternative, but the bill was $140."
 The Prices already have more than $1,000 in medical debt to pay off, but their real worry is how they could afford treatment for an emergency. Indeed, concern about being uninsured caused a good part of Mr. Price's hesitation earlier this year, when he left the job he had held for five years and went out on his own selling satellite dishes.
 "I really wanted insurance in case something major happened," Mr. Price said. "I looked into buying my own insurance a while ago, but it was $350 a month for a family, and that's more than we can manage. I'm hoping that the place where my wife works will get a group policy, which they're trying to do. Until then, we just have to hope the family stays healthy."

Tuesday: How Canada provides equal care to all - with compromises. Subsequent articles will look at the economic costs and benefits of employment-based health insurance, and the choices and prospects for overhauling the health system.

But her son, David, and daughter, Dina, have no health coverage because she cannot afford the extra $400 a month it would cost (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times); Dr. Anna Wu Work, who was treated for an early stage of breast cancer, would rather spend more time with daughters Elizabeth, left, and Kelsey, but is afraid to leave her job because she needs health insurance (Bart Bartholomew for The New York Times) (pg. 28); "Everybody said they couldn't put me on their insurance because of my record, and they said I couldn't work without insurance," said Betty Moore of Alpharetta, Ga., who couldn't find a job after heart surgery. Weiner/The New York Times) (pg. 29) Graphs: "A Bigger Drain on Income," tracks health spending as a percentage of gross domestic product, 1960-1989 (Source: Health Care Financing Administraton) (pg. 1)
"THE AILING HEALTH SYSTEM: A QUESTION OF ACCESS ..."
Two issues, access and cost, dominate the debate over America's health care system.
Most Americans have health insurance and receive excellent care. Except among the poor, expecially in inner cities, Americans are healthier than ever.
All the elderly are covered by Medicare but less than half of those living below the poverty line are insured by Medicaid. Yet about 33 million people live without the basic security of health insurance, and tens of millions more have inadequate coverage.
Contrary to popular belief, most of the uninsured are jobholders or their family members - the working poor.
Insurance rates have climbed faster for small businesses than large ones, and more companies, especially those that are small or have many low-wage employees, do not offer health benefits.
Whether employed or not, young people, and black and Hispanic people, are most likely to lack health insurance. Also, more Americans with chronic diseases or a history of serious illness are having trouble obtaining affordable insurance.
Figures on the number of uninsured people understate the extent of vulnerability; over a recent 28-month period, one in four Americans spent at least a month without health insurance.
In polls, most Americans say they are generally pleased with their doctors and hospitals. But there is widespread anxiety about the future of health insurance, especially as the price of medical care continues to soar.
"How Americans Are Covered," shows a breakdown of Americans' primary source of health insurance in 1989 (Source: Department of Health and Human Services); "An Index of Insecurity, tracks Americans' health insurance status -- no coverage, covered for 1-27 months, covered for all 28 months -- over a period of 28 months, with a breakdown white, black and hispanic as well as overall total, from a Census Bureau study that ended August 1987; "The Uninsured": "By Age," tracks those uninsured by age -- under 16, 16-24, 25-34, 35-44, 45-54, 55-64, and over 65 -- monthly average for last quarter of 1988; "By Race," shows percentage of uninsured people by race: Hispanic: 26.5%, Black: 20.2% and White: 11.7%, as a monthly average for last quarter of 1988; "By Job Status," shows a breakdown of employment status of the head of household, for 1988, excluding the elderly, indicating unemployed: 14.8%,employed part-time: 23.2% and employed full-time: 62.0% (Sources: Census Bureau, Employee Benefit Research Institute) (pg. 28)
"... AND SOARING COSTS"
Health care now absorbs 12 percent of national income, and the share continues to climb relentlessly. Many economists fear that if the trend is not checked, health spending will erode national prosperity.
The price of health is a direct and growing worry for Federal, state and local governments, which must devote a rising share of their strained budgets to paying for health care. More than 40 percent of the nation's health bills are now covered by government programs.
Concern about cost is also mounting among companies and workers, which face steeply rising health insurance premiums that can eat into profits and wages.
Among the causes of the rise: unchecked use of ever more expensive technologies and a system that gives neither doctors nor patients much incentive to control cost, since insurers are paying the bills.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 8; Column 5; Arts & Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: Why a Dance-World Veteran Decided to Pack It All In

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
THE STUDIO HAD GROWN PROgressively barer over the past few weeks. One day a giddy display case of worn toe shoes and performance photographs hung on the wall. A few days later it was gone. So were a bushy green plant and one packing box. And now the studio is closed and empty.
 "Cartwheel on the Gangplank" was the name Senta Driver had given to a new piece performed last month, on a program that marked her farewell as a choreographer and the end of her 16-year-old dance troupe, Harry. But this departure was more a slow, inexorable trudge than a jaunty cartwheel. It has been even harder than she expected. 
 "The thing is I love dance very much," Ms. Driver said in a recent interview in her studio in the SoHo section of Manhattan., tucked into a battered couch at the edge of the dance floor that she had stained to look like earth. "It's awful to leave it. I'm not sure if people know -- this was not voluntary. It wasn't a choice."
 Ms. Driver, 48, is one of the most imposing figures on the modern dance scene today. Both her manner and her dances are threaded through with a steely, vein of intelligence and tenacity -- qualities that have brought her both praise and controversy. But there were moments during the conversation when her eyes suddenly welled up with tears.
 Ms. Driver had been through bad times before, with financial crises occurring about every three years. But things never got so bad that she thought seriously about retiring. Now, she has decided to become a nurse, working with the critically ill newborn babies she has cared for during four years as a volunteer at the Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan.
 Ms. Driver came to the decision to leave dance chiefly because of financial problems. But she is also fearful about the immediate future for artists in this country. In the past year or so, a number of major American dance companies have faced serious financial problems, among them American Ballet Theater, the Dance Theater of Harlem, the Martha Graham Dance Company, the Joffrey Ballet and the Pennsylvania Ballet. Smaller troupes have suffered similarly. But Ms. Driver is one of the last choreographers who might have been expected to leave modern dance. A woman of fierce intellect and passion about her work and the world around her, she made dances that authoritatively probed ideas about dance and the human body, yet were filled with a futsy physicality. "Senta Driver's choreography is both analytical and intensely physical," Anna Kisselgoff, senior dance critic of The New York Times, wrote in 1985. "One wonders how two such disparate aspects can be fused so creatively and brilliantly.
 "The hallmark of a Driver dance is its striking originality -- in the shapes and rhythms produced by moving bodies." the review continued. "Inescapably, the conclusion is that this result stems from the very marriage of Ms. Driver's cerebral approach to virtuosity requiring huge amounts of stamina and skill."
 It also required formidable concentration, according to Jeffrey Gribler, a principal dancer with the Pennsylvania Ballet who starred in Ms. Driver's 1981 "Resettings," a dance based on the August Bournonville classic "La Sylphide."
 "She stretched and modified and altered ballet technique," he said. "It was fascinating. The exercises on point were done in bare feet. Women lifted men. I found it an incredibly challenging and interesting experience.
 "There was some resistance from the dancers. She persevered. I think she expected resistance. She was patient. We had many, many sit-down rehearsals with discussions, and not just about the piece but about how we felt, why it was odd for us and important for her." Two years later, Mr. Gribler found himself dancing the lead in "La Sylphide."
 "I thought a lot about what I did with Senta," he recalled. "I think it helped me experience the character."
 Persistence was a hallmark of Ms. Driver's career. For over two decades, she had worked steadily, first as a performer with the Paul Taylor Dance Company for six years and then as the founder and director of Harry, generally considered one of the best managed companies in the field. She had named the company after Princess Mud of England, nicknamed Harry because she was courageous as a child. The company lived up to that premise of innate gutsiness, filled with dancers chosen for their "warmth, great hearts and valor," as Ms. Driver put it.
 As a consultant to the New York State Council on the Arts and the National Endowment for the Arts and as an official of Dance/USA, a national service organization, she was able to view dance from an unusually wide perspective. Over the years, she had performed in major theaters and dance festivals in 25 states and in Germany and Austria.
 But last June, Ms. Driver decided that it was time to end her artistic career. There were no bookings for the following 12 months. Though Harry's $200,000 annual budget was met by a strong mix of earned income and support from foundations, corporations and the Government, the company experienced a steady drop in public and private support since the mid-1980's. At the sametime, the demise of the National Endowment's Dance Touring Program made it harder to get engagements.
 One of Ms. Driver's best and most cherished dancers, Randy Wickstrom, was dying of AIDS. As bookings dwindled, other favorite dancers left the company, as did Dominick Balletta, the manager who had helped make 1989 one of the best years in Harry's history. Ms. Driver was increasingly alone.
 Suddenly, her work and her company seemed not to meet any of the increasingly complex, sometimes peculiar and contradictory demands of dance producers around the country. Ms. Driver had begun dipping into personal savings to buy time.
 "I found the idea of stopping so terrifying I couldn't face it," she recalled. "But that was the money I lived on." The money she would have needed to continue for another year -- about $50,000 -- was not really so much. But it simply was not forthcoming.
 "In dance, you always think if you just stay in business a little bit longer something will happen," Ms. Driver said. "You're always living on the edge of saying goodbye. Something always tears down what you're building. Something always takes away from what you need to be building. In the same mail that brings you the prize comes the crisis. But you get kind of used to all the routine miseries. If Dominick can't pull this off, I'd think, we'll find a way. And then there was no way."
 
Starting Out: The Dance Bug Bit in College
 Senta Driver grew up in Greenwich, Conn., and suburban Boston, in a middle-class family whose love of music was its only involvement in the arts. She had expected to become a historian. Then, in college, she discovered dance. Compactly built and never particularly good at sports, she fit into no popular stereotypes of a dancer. But a friend got her interested in the field, and at 18 she "got the bug." "I fought it off," she said. "Then I saw Paul's work at Connecticut College. It was an electrifying shock to my body. It was beautiful. And I wanted to do it. It was like discovering the sensation of taste."
 A Latin and philosophy major at Bryn Mawr, she often thought of quitting college to dance. "And then I graduated," Ms. Driver said. "It felt like a defeat." She went on to study dance at Ohio State University, obtaining a master's degree in physical education in 1966, then headed for New York City to absorb all she could of Mr. Taylor's teaching and choreography.
 Some critics felt that she made a mark on the Taylor dances she performed, as an implacable presence with a distinctive blend of detachment and feeling. But Mr. Taylor, who describes her in his autobiography, "Private Domain," as a determined rebel resisted what she terms her "fearsome devotion" to his work. By the time she decided to leave the Taylor company, in 1973, there was a distance between them.
 "When I left, he said to me: 'You're not going to be a choreographer. You're not going to even try.' I told him that he was certainly entitled to wait and see."
 That granite obduracy might be attributed to her New England upbringing. Ms. Driver talked of the influence of summers spent with her parents and four siblings on Naushon Island, off Cape Cod, a sheep farm owned by family friends. "It shaped my thinking, heavily." she said. "Something about plain work, hard work. You do it. You harness the horse. You learn competence."
 She had quit the Taylor company because she felt underutilized as a dancer. "I left to do my own work. I spent about six months working alone, trying to figure out what was not being done. Trying to get Paul's work out of my bones. The first thing I did was to walk around the room. Talk to myself. I made a rule not to sleep. I was reading dance history. I began to say the names I'd read. I had myself coached in accents."
 Out of these first experiments came one of Ms. Driver's most resonant dances, "Memorandum," a signature work created in 1975, in which the performer circles the room, calling out the names of great ballerinas of the past. She soon discovered the concept of movement along a diagonal and began the fascination with body mass and weight and their manipulation that would become a hallmark of her choreography.
 "I decided I would be strong enough if I trained myself to carry my 6-year-old nephew on my back," she said. "He had a look as if he were thinking about something unusual. He rode around strapped to me in a harness, his hands folded, doing his multiplication tables in his head so he had something to think about." The result was "Melodrama."
 Gradually, Ms. Driver developed a group of dances that she once descibed as portraits of herself thinking -- about traditional gender roles, about who partners whom in dance, and about how dance can be made to be seen from more than one direction.
 Despite her reputation for creating mostly "quirky" and "cerebral" dances -- terms that Ms. Driver loathes -- the pieces she feels to be key works have dealt with a variety of themes. Death and mourning were examined in "Missing Persons." Courtship was examined cheerfuly in "Avner, Rena, Bud and Roxie, Lillian and Sam." In "Video 5000" Ms. Driver played with filmed and live figures.
 
Daunting Issues: AIDS Began To Take Its Toll
 Ms. Driver is haunted by a sense that issues she raised in dance were never seriously addressed by reviewers. "My work is very controversial, including whether I should do it at all," she said, noting that a critic once described one of her pieces as resembling hippopotamuses wallowing in mud. What, she wonders, would those who never saw her work make of it based on such reviews? Will she have any place in the history dance?
 There were other concerns. Looking for strong, large dancers with "a great heart and moral presence and courage" for her five-member company, Ms. Driver increasingly began to find young performers demoralized by their drive to "do it the right way" rather than take the kinds of physical and emotional risks she demanded. She saw more and more fine dancers dying of AIDS. 'I lost a whole future with Randy." she said of Mr. Wickstrom, who died in October at age 38. "Where we would have gone, I can't go." She pointed to the spot on the studio floor where Mr. Wickstrom, trained as a gymnast, taught her new ways of moving. "My studio has a human presence," she said. "It's like a wonderful person, a sturdy person I could sit here and feel my history on the walls."
 
The Arts in a Bind: Problems Are Not Hers Alone
 But most troubling to Ms. Driver is her sense that the problems she faced are not hers alone. And the difficulties dance faces today do not spring, she believes, from a lack of public appreciation for the art.
 "There are smaller audiences and harder times. But I think dance has actually moved into the fabric of the culture in a lot of ways we don't realize. What's less popular is live performing. Not dance. People still want to see dance. They're taking aerobics all day long from the peole who urged to dance."
 Still, in an age of easily accessible home video entertainment, she added, audiences want to see performances when and where it is most convenient.
 Ms. Driver is troubled, she said, by what she sees as a drastic narrowing of both support and expectations among producers of dance and those who give money to it. "General support is eroding," she said, adding that there is growing interest in supporting or commissioning specific works rather than the day-to-day operations of a company. "The funding of projects is emphasized. I think it becomes a way to sift through the overload of applicants. But a great number of restrictions have all come together. Presenters say, 'I really like you, but the dance is too long or too short. Your budget is too small or too big. You're too old to be "emerging." You're not multicultural enough."
 "Even dealing with the good presenters who do give you commissions is daunting. One told me I had too many dancers and that there wasn't enough room for the audience. There were so many reasons I couldn't have a booking, a grant, a this or a that, that eventually I had to stop.
 "There is a strong tendency, among enemies and friends, to tell the artist in all kinds of ways to stop doing what they want to do and do something different. It won't work. If Lucinda Childs says she needs mice, then get her the money to get mice."
 Ms. Driver said that she is frightened by proposed cuts in the budget of the New York State Council on the Arts, which would reduce it by $24.8 million to $21.9 million, and what she sees as the continuing dismantling of the National Endowment for the Arts. "Forget what's happening to me," she said. "You're going to see a devastating sweep if the state cuts go through.
 "All the state councils are going down. They're all in trouble. But when New York's goes down, it will take with it a very large proportion of all kinds of artists who came here to work." And it is hard, she conceded, to lobby to save arts support, knowing that the money might come from allotments designed to deal with social problems like homelessness.
 "We're being forced into the image of these people who use the money for the homeless to create art that will frighten and offend. I have found it tremendously discouraging to see how artists are hated by the general population."
 Ms. Driver sees the recent controversey over pornography and Federal financing of the arts as indications of this feeling.
 "The artists have no friends any more, except each other," she said. "I'm not saying we can't do it without riches. People keep starting out. Choreographers will always most intimately rely on the allegiance of dancers."
 But in the end, the cumulative weight of it all became too much for Ms. Driver.
 "I would have taken any punishment to stay in this field," she said. "I had valuable help. I had some resources. I could take the punishment. I hung on until all fingers were gone. If you can stop me, then there's some real trouble."

 Senta Driver grew up in Greenwich, Conn., and suburban Boston, in a middle-class family whose love of music was its only involvement in the arts. She had expected to become a historian. Then, in college, she discovered dance. Compactly built and never particularly good at sports, she fit into no popular stereotypes of a dancer. But a friend got her interested in the field, and at 18 she "got the bug." "I fought it off," she said. "Then I saw Paul's work at Connecticut College. It was an electrifying shock to my body. It was beautiful. And I wanted to do it. It was like discovering the sensation of taste."
 A Latin and philosophy major at Bryn Mawr, she often thought of quitting college to dance. "And then I graduated," Ms. Driver said. "It felt like a defeat." She went on to study dance at Ohio State University, obtaining a master's degree in physical education in 1966, then headed for New York City to absorb all she could of Mr. Taylor's teaching and choreography.
 Some critics felt that she made a mark on the Taylor dances she performed, as an implacable presence with a distinctive blend of detachment and feeling. But Mr. Taylor, who describes her in his autobiography, "Private Domain," as a determined rebel resisted what she terms her "fearsome devotion" to his work. By the time she decided to leave the Taylor company, in 1973, there was a distance between them.
 "When I left, he said to me: 'You're not going to be a choreographer. You're not going to even try.' I told him that he was certainly entitled to wait and see."
 That granite obduracy might be attributed to her New England upbringing. Ms. Driver talked of the influence of summers spent with her parents and four siblings on Naushon Island, off Cape Cod, a sheep farm owned by family friends. "It shaped my thinking, heavily." she said. "Something about plain work, hard work. You do it. You harness the horse. You learn competence."
 She had quit the Taylor company because she felt underutilized as a dancer. "I left to do my own work. I spent about six months working alone, trying to figure out what was not being done. Trying to get Paul's work out of my bones. The first thing I did was to walk around the room. Talk to myself. I made a rule not to sleep. I was reading dance history. I began to say the names I'd read. I had myself coached in accents."
 Out of these first experiments came one of Ms. Driver's most resonant dances, "Memorandum," a signature work created in 1975, in which the performer circles the room, calling out the names of great ballerinas of the past. She soon discovered the concept of movement along a diagonal and began the fascination with body mass and weight and their manipulation that would become a hallmark of her choreography.
 "I decided I would be strong enough if I trained myself to carry my 6-year-old nephew on my back," she said. "He had a look as if he were thinking about something unusual. He rode around strapped to me in a harness, his hands folded, doing his multiplication tables in his head so he had something to think about." The result was "Melodrama."
 Gradually, Ms. Driver developed a group of dances that she once descibed as portraits of herself thinking -- about traditional gender roles, about who partners whom in dance, and about how dance can be made to be seen from more than one direction.
 Despite her reputation for creating mostly "quirky" and "cerebral" dances -- terms that Ms. Driver loathes -- the pieces she feels to be key works have dealt with a variety of themes. Death and mourning were examined in "Missing Persons." Courtship was examined cheerfuly in "Avner, Rena, Bud and Roxie, Lillian and Sam." In "Video 5000" Ms. Driver played with filmed and live figures.
 
Daunting Issues: AIDS Began To Take Its Toll
 Ms. Driver is haunted by a sense that issues she raised in dance were never seriously addressed by reviewers. "My work is very controversial, including whether I should do it at all," she said, noting that a critic once described one of her pieces as resembling hippopotamuses wallowing in mud. What, she wonders, would those who never saw her work make of it based on such reviews? Will she have any place in the history dance?
 There were other concerns. Looking for strong, large dancers with "a great heart and moral presence and courage" for her five-member company, Ms. Driver increasingly began to find young performers demoralized by their drive to "do it the right way" rather than take the kinds of physical and emotional risks she demanded. She saw more and more fine dancers dying of AIDS. 'I lost a whole future with Randy." she said of Mr. Wickstrom, who died in October at age 38. "Where we would have gone, I can't go." She pointed to the spot on the studio floor where Mr. Wickstrom, trained as a gymnast, taught her new ways of moving. "My studio has a human presence," she said. "It's like a wonderful person, a sturdy person I could sit here and feel my history on the walls."
 
The Arts in a Bind: Problems Are Not Hers Alone
 But most troubling to Ms. Driver is her sense that the problems she faced are not hers alone. And the difficulties dance faces today do not spring, she believes, from a lack of public appreciation for the art.
 "There are smaller audiences and harder times. But I think dance has actually moved into the fabric of the culture in a lot of ways we don't realize. What's less popular is live performing. Not dance. People still want to see dance. They're taking aerobics all day long from the peole who urged to dance."
 Still, in an age of easily accessible home video entertainment, she added, audiences want to see performances when and where it is most convenient.
 Ms. Driver is troubled, she said, by what she sees as a drastic narrowing of both support and expectations among producers of dance and those who give money to it. "General support is eroding," she said, adding that there is growing interest in supporting or commissioning specific works rather than the day-to-day operations of a company. "The funding of projects is emphasized. I think it becomes a way to sift through the overload of applicants. But a great number of restrictions have all come together. Presenters say, 'I really like you, but the dance is too long or too short. Your budget is too small or too big. You're too old to be "emerging." You're not multicultural enough."
 "Even dealing with the good presenters who do give you commissions is daunting. One told me I had too many dancers and that there wasn't enough room for the audience. There were so many reasons I couldn't have a booking, a grant, a this or a that, that eventually I had to stop.
 "There is a strong tendency, among enemies and friends, to tell the artist in all kinds of ways to stop doing what they want to do and do something different. It won't work. If Lucinda Childs says she needs mice, then get her the money to get mice."
 Ms. Driver said that she is frightened by proposed cuts in the budget of the New York State Council on the Arts, which would reduce it by $24.8 million to $21.9 million, and what she sees as the continuing dismantling of the National Endowment for the Arts. "Forget what's happening to me," she said. "You're going to see a devastating sweep if the state cuts go through.
 "All the state councils are going down. They're all in trouble. But when New York's goes down, it will take with it a very large proportion of all kinds of artists who came here to work." And it is hard, she conceded, to lobby to save arts support, knowing that the money might come from allotments designed to deal with social problems like homelessness.
 "We're being forced into the image of these people who use the money for the homeless to create art that will frighten and offend. I have found it tremendously discouraging to see how artists are hated by the general population."
 Ms. Driver sees the recent controversey over pornography and Federal financing of the arts as indications of this feeling.
 "The artists have no friends any more, except each other," she said. "I'm not saying we can't do it without riches. People keep starting out. Choreographers will always most intimately rely on the allegiance of dancers."
 But in the end, the cumulative weight of it all became too much for Ms. Driver.
 "I would have taken any punishment to stay in this field," she said. "I had valuable help. I had some resources. I could take the punishment. I hung on until all fingers were gone. If you can stop me, then there's some real trouble."

HEADLINE: Family Tends Neighbors' Heads and Hearts

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
ON a Saturday afternoon at Ashe's Barber Shop in New Haven, Chuck Ashe Jr. and his blue-smocked crew were clipping, trimming and shaving one head after another to the sound of popping soda cans and music from the movie "New Jack City." The most-requested styles included fades, slopes, boxes, twists and Gumbies, and Afros appeared to be making a comeback. Waiting time was about one hour.
"This is one of the few places these kids can go without someone approaching them to sell drugs," said Mr. Ashe, who stood with a hair pick in one hand and a razor in the other, sculpturing the hair of 18-year-old Terry McClain into a high fade and box cut. 
 "Take Terry here," the barber said, brushing the hair off the Mr. McClain's face. "Here's someone who's determined to bypass the system that has turned so many of our young people into barbarians."
Starting below the "No Smoking, Drinking or Cursing" sign, the queue of young customers curved along a mirrored wall covered with pictures of basketball stars and posters on teen-age pregnancy that advised, "Think Before You Act."
 
'Next Day, They're Gone'
 Large bay windows framed the scene on Shelton Avenue, where children danced on the sidewalk under a blue sky, and teen-age boys with fluorescent-colored sunglasses varoomed by on dirt bikes. A steady stream of cars pulled up to the curb to drop off or pick up customers.
Legendary for its social atmosphere, good music and trend-setting barbers who double as confidantes, Ashe's Barber Shop, is a rare safe haven for young people in a neighborhood rife with crime and unemployment, patrons said. Outside, drug dealers prowl for recruits and gunshots echo routinely through the streets. Inside, the barbers said, they try to persuade teen-agers not to succumb to the lure of fast money and instant status associated with the drug trade. Nevertheless, they admitted, it's an uphill battle.
"One day I'm standing here cutting their hair, and the next day, they're gone," said Mr. Ashe referring to at least 15 of his customers who have been shot and killed in drug-related incidents in the last couple of years.
"I got shot by an Uzi," said 16-year-old Darius Ferreria, who shimmied into the barber's chair and asked Mr. Ashe to give him a totally new look. "I was standing on a sidewalk, and the bullet went in one side of my thigh, then out the other. Clean through."
Three blocks down from Ashe's lies the infamous Mudhole, at the corner of Shelton Avenue and Hazel Street, a large sales outlet for drug dealers. The spread encompasses an empty lot on one side of the street and a windowless social club on the other that neighbors said was used for gambling.
 
Drugs Drive the Economy
 On this day, dozens of people, including many children and teen-agers, mingled freely on the corners. One local resident said a well-known denizen of the Mudhole was a young dealer who was shot and paralyzed a few years back and now sells drugs from his wheelchair.
Poverty and the lack of recreation or job opportunities has created an economy propelled by drug money, said Mr. Ashe, whose angry discourse on this topic easily rose above M. C. Hammer's rap lyrics.
"The lawyers, the politicians, the car dealers -- everybody's getting rich off the drug business except the black community," he said.
Behind a partition near the coffee maker, Audrey Ashe, the proprietor's sister, shaved a toothpick-thin V into Dexter Butler's left eyebrow. Her long fuchsia fingernails rested on the horizontal lines she had carved near his temple. The lines are called Kane parts, after Big Daddy Kane, a rapper, she said, and the shop was one of the first in the city to offer them.
Ashe's also set the trend for the designer signs that are shaved into the sides or backs of heads, Ms. Ashe said. Although their popularity has waned somewhat, she said, she and her colleagues get plenty of requests for Mercedes-Benz insignias, dollar signs and the silhouette of Michael Jackson.
Ms. Ashe said she much preferred working in barber shops to women's hair salons. "It's in my blood," she said. "It seems like I've been cutting hair all my life."
 
'True Success Story'
 Moments later, her father, Charles Ashe 3d, stepped through the front door for a brief visit. A tall distinguished man in a gray pinstripe suit, he owns a barber shop on Whalley Avenue that caters to older customers. As he stood next to his son, customers came up to shake his hand while small children wrapped their arms around his legs.
The elder Mr. Ashe began cutting hair 37 years ago at a place called Red's Barber Shop in New Haven, he said. He later taught all four of his children the craft. Two years after he started the shop on Shelton Avenue in 1981, he said, he turned it over to his children.
"The true success story is right here," Charles Ashe said, nodding to Chuck, who also owns a four-barber shop on Ferry Street. Charles Ashe's two other children, Eric and Karen, operate a barber shop on Kimberly Avenue.
"With four barber shops in the family, sibling rivalry is a plus," said Audrey Ashe. "The competition keeps us all on our toes."
Her father, who is also a Pentecostal minister, founded the First Pentecostal Church last year in a tidy concrete-block building two blocks from the Shelton Avenue shop. The opening of their church was a pivotal point for the family, he said.
For nearly 20 years, Charles Ashe lived with episodes of alcohol abuse and unemployment that threatened to destroy his family, he said, and the cycle repeated with his children, who also abused drugs.
 
Home From College
 "We, too, were products of our environment," said Chuck Ashe, the father of two young sons. "The thing that turned us around was discovering our spirituality, and that gave us an inner strength that enabled us to rise above the temptations in the streets."
The senior Mr. Ashe chatted with customers for a few more moments then headed back to his own shop as Lamont Young climbed into a chair. Mr. Young, a football player at a junior college in Massachusetts, was home for the weekend.
"If it weren't for sports, I'd be on the streets selling drugs," he told Chuck Ashe, who frowned and shook his head.
"This is another thing," Mr. Ashe said. "These colleges come into the community and take all of our best children. They spend the next four years filling their heads with dreams, teaching them how to shoot baskets or throw footballs, while the white children are learning how to run corporations. Then our kids come back to the community with no job skills, just shattered hopes. They come in here, look at me and say, 'Hey Chuck, where are all the jobs?' Before I know it, they're out there selling drugs."
Mr. Young asked for a box cut with Kane parts.
"That's not going to happen to me, Chuck," he said. "Football's O.K., but it's temporary. Academics come first." Mr. Ashe smiled.
 
Stop the Music
 Mr. Young, who is majoring in criminal justice, recalled that when he was a youngster, he often talked to Chuck Ashe about personal problems and school work. "Chuck probably knows more about my life than anybody," he said.
At 3 o'clock, the line of customers began to dwindle, and Darrell Barnes, one of the barbers, turned off the stereo, a signal that the shop was about to close. A young woman in a lime-green jumpsuit came in looking for her boyfriend. Wallace Coleman, a building contractor and old friend of the Ashes, brought his 11-year-old son, Jason, in for a haircut.
Mr. Coleman and Mr. Ashe talked about how cutbacks in the city's Parks and Recreation Department budget may affect the neighborhood's chances of organizing a Little League team this year.
"I bet the suburban kids don't have to worry about this," said Mr. Coleman.
Outside, street musicians gathered with bongos and began sounding a Caribbean beat. A half-moon of onlookers swelled around them. Others sat on the curb or leaned out windows. People drove by and waved and honked. Everybody seemed to know everybody.
That kind of community vitality cannot be duplicated in the suburbs, Mr. Ashe said, which is why he and his wife, Denise, a postal worker, decided to remain in the neighborhood. Resting his hands on the shoulder of one of his last customers, he paused and stared out the window.
"There's really two sides to this community," he said. "And it's this one, out there, that people tend to overlook.
"Like most people in this neighborhood, I'd like to see that inner beauty flourish. But to do that, we've got to make our young people understand that what they do today could haunt them for the rest of their lives. And that's one of the main things that Ashe's Barber Shop is all about -- changing those attitudes and changing those lives."

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Nonstop Gaiety in 'Merry Widow'

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

DATELINE: MILLBURN

 BODY:
IF audiences crave excess and frivolity when the economy is in crisis, then the Paper Mill Playhouse production of "The Merry Widow" is just the flaming antidote for a current malaise that has been described as fiscal anemia.
In a new $1.4 million production that substitutes Broadway pizazz and generic vulgarism for old-style Viennese charm, Franz Lehar's infinitely melodious confection, circa 1905, survives a shamelessly campy and outrageously ornate going-over. It does so as heartily as it has outlived innumerable variations, from the ballet stage to the ice skating rink, not to mention several screen versions. And none of those were sparked by the ineffable Judy Kaye in the title role. 
 She plays the wealthy widow who is being wooed by every Frenchman in sight. But Marsovia, the mythical French-ruled kingdom where she lives, is in hock, and if her millions are spent in Paris, that's it for Marsovia. So the powers of Marsovia must be on the lookout for a local lover for the widow, and, for a touch of decadence, their wives divert the outsiders.
In Robert Johanson's adaptation, Marsovia, as in other English retellings, remains the name for the original Pontevedrinia, but the widow, Hanna, usually renamed Sonia, is still Hanna. No matter. Cafe Maxim's and the "girls, girls, girls, girls, girls" are, as ever, Lolo, Cloclo, Froufrou, Dodo and Joujou -- though they are unidentified in the Paper Mill program.
As adapter and director, Mr. Johanson takes an approach that uses a little from here, a little from there, but brings no originality or distinctiveness to any of it. A duet composed for a pair of secondary lovers (the unfaithful Valencienne and de Rosillion) has been transferred, most sensibly, to the primary ones (Hanna and Count Danilo, played by Richard White). A couple of vintage Lehar arias (from "Giuditta" and "The Land of Smiles") infiltrate the score, most agreeably, but then so does Offenbach in an all-out third-act cancan.
If Mr. Johanson's innovative powers were in line with the Paper Mill budget, what a fresh, entrancing, not just expensive "Merry Widow" this might have been. Instead, the crusty cliches of old-style operetta are supplanted by the cliches of old-hat musical comedy, with crass so-called comic relief thrown in.
For nonstop gaiety, every scene is a soiree. With cherubs, tassels and blue velvet curtains enframing the proscenium, Michael Anania's settings range from sumptuous to garish. Witness an elegant first-act embassy, with its revolving staircase; a gorgeous second-act villa, with a flower-filled garden and a revolving bridge, and a scarlet Maxim's in the third act, flanked by sequined lamps and backed by a gargantuan stained glass Art Nouveau disk that moves upward, landing overhead, as dancers in their swings descend.
In an enormous cast, those clandestine lovers, rapturously played and sung by Hallie Neill and Mark Janicello, have a more romantic thing going than the stars. Presumably because of an indisposition that caused him to miss several shows two weeks ago, Richard White's resplendent baritone sounded restrained -- more mellow than usual but unfailingly pleasing -- at the performance attended. His understudy, Joseph Mahowald, is scheduled to go on in all remaining matinees.
As Danilo, Mr. White is at his most ardent when he is dancing across the stage by himself. The Count, once in love with Hanna, is supposed to be resistant this time around, but here's a Danilo who appears so deliriously accustomed to his face that one imagines he is searching for its reflection when he gazes into Hanna's eyes. A clownish turn near the finale, when he blurts out the passion he has been holding in, hardly supports a performance so steeped in self-adulation.
It remains for Ms. Kaye's dramatic conviction to make us believe that Mr. White cares. Besides, she's a grand diva and a funny lady. It's hard to envision a more insouciant widow. The line "I'm just a simple country girl who married well" could have been written with Ms. Kaye's down-to-earth comic manner in mind.
Although the theater's overly zealous sound engineers may be imparting an unnecessary edge to the soprano's high register, her musicianship and phrasing are impeccable, and her rich middle voice and dark chest tones produce a heady effect.
If only the audience would refrain from applauding in the middle of her astonishing last note -- a meticulously shaded pianissimo that swells and softens sublimely -- in "Vilia," her second-act display pieces. The aria isn't over until it's over, folks.
When, finally, Ms. Kaye joins the dancers and negotiates a series of splits, each on a high C, in the can-can, you know that the search for a more complete musical performer is pointless. For all the vagaries of an overloaded production, it is Ms. Kaye who keeps the show rolling along, with her own sly perspective, and very merrily indeed.
"The Merry Widow" at the Paper Mill Playhouse, Brookside Drive in Millburn. Performances are Wednesday through Sunday at 8 P.M., Thursday at 2 P.M. and Saturday and Sunday at 3 P.M., through May 12. Box office: (201) 376-4343.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hallie Neill, left, with Mark Janicello, second from left, Richard White and Judy Kaye in "The Merry Widow."
(Paper Mill Playhouse)

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Las Vegas;
Still Growing, But Not as Fast

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN SHARP

 BODY:
WHILE the influx of new residents continues to be strong in this casino city, the pace of new home sales and construction has faltered.
Candle Creek, a half-finished complex of 350 one-family homes beside a large grassy mesa, is one of many projects in the city's outskirts to feel the slowdown. 
 "Although we are still leading the country in terms of sales activity, it feels like we slammed on the brakes," is how Lawrence D. Canarelli, a Candle Creek official described the regional slowdown. "There's still tremendous growth, but it's not as brisk as it was last year." Mr. Canarelli is president of American West Development, the Las Vegas company that owns Candle Creek.
Across Clark County, which includes Las Vegas, new home sales in the first quarter of 1991 are running about a third below last year's, Mr. Canarelli said. Last year, new housing permits in the county were up 9 percent over 1989, to 27,100 one-family and multifamily units, he said.
Although 5,000 new residents a month still come in, housing permits are expected to slow substantially this year, said Keith Schwer, an economist with the University of Nevada, Las Vegas. Demand and supply are starting to meet after two years of brisk residential building.
Part of the slowdown results from a slower state economy. Job growth here, 9 percent last year, is projected to fall to 6 percent this year, according to the 1990 Las Vegas Perspective Survey by the University of Nevada at Las Vegas Center for Business and Economic Research.
More than 800,000 people live in Clark County, and its population is expected to reach 1 million by the year 2000, making Las Vegas one of the nation's fastest-growing cities.
But this rapid growth has strained the region's water supply, which has halted the approval of building permits. Las Vegas takes most of its water from the Colorado River system, which is already overallocated. The Las Vegas Valley Water District is considering tapping more water supplies from beneath the region's verdant valleys.
Candle Creek lies in such a valley in the Green Valley district, considered part of the Las Vegas metropolitan area. Houses in this affordable-housing project range in size from 2,000 to 3,600 square feet, with prices of $140,000 to $188,000.
Sales of existing one-family units were up 30 percent last year, to 3,500, and the median price in the county increased 7 percent, to $90,500.

HEADLINE: U.N. Needs a Supernational Supermanager

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Start the U.N. Search Now" (editorial, April 15) is a good analysis of the type of person the United Nations needs as the next Secretary General. 
 May I emphasize that the quality that will be most important in future Secretaries General is the ability to manage an organization that has developed over the last four-and-a-half decades into a maze of disparate elements, dominated by regional rivalries and virtually torn asunder by the polarization of the cold war.
A new world order is envisioned. East and West are no longer polarized but tend to cooperate with each other. The nonaligned are less and less relevant. The organization needs radical reform to deal with the emerging realities of the last decade of the 20th century.
Needed on the international scene today is a proven and respected manager, capable not only of understanding global development needs but, more important, of feeling the urgency for economic development without showing either a Western or an Eastern bias. Such a management expert must also be free from a neocolonialist mind-set.
I do not mean to imply that an American business executive or a Soviet manager should get the job, but it does seem to me that if a person who is a global corporate statesman and has genuine wide-ranging humanitarian concerns emerges as a candidate, such a person would be a superlative choice. The tide of ideological divisions is fast ebbing, while the economic inequalities are increasing at a geometric rate.
The United Nations has to develop the capacity to manage not only its own house, but also vast problems of third world poverty, environmental degradation, East European economic development, massive displacement of refugees -- all matters that require talent, energy and the dynamism of accomplished leadership.
There are qualified and visionary corporate leaders who fulfill these requirements, particularly from the Scandinavian countries, the neutrality of which would not violate the residue of sensitivity about United States or Soviet political hegemony.
One of these men or women would be an ideal choice as we near the 21st century.
 
ANGIER BIDDLE DUKE
New York, April 17, 1991
 
The writer served as a United States ambassador between 1949 and 1980.
