HEADLINE: MARKET PLACE;
Beazer's Growing U.S. Following

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
IF they love you abroad, but not at home, why not move? That, in essence, is the idea that seems to have occurred to Brian Beazer, the 56-year-old chairman of Beazer P.L.C., a British home-building company.
Having gone deeply in debt in the 1980's to buy American companies that make construction materials -- Gifford Hill and Koppers -- Beazer has found itself out of favor at home, but with a growing American following among investors. 
 Mr. Beazer's solution, disclosed last week, is for the company to separate its European operations, and sell nearly half of that company's shares to investors. Beazer already gets about half its revenues from this country, and the sale of the stake in its European operations would leave it more American than ever. Mr. Beazer says the company may then decide to move its headquarters to the United States.
Details of the transaction will not be available for a few months, but it appears that the move will at least temporarily dilute Beazer's earnings by 5 to 10 percent. It will also enable the company to cut its debt. The company hopes the sale of the shares will bring in as much as £250 million ($422 million).
The hopes for cutting the debt aided the shares the day the idea was announced, but the warm market reaction faded.
In London, Beazer ordinary shares, at £1.81 before the announcement, jumped to a high of £1.89, but then began to settle back, and ended the week at £1.72. In New York trading, where Beazer American depository receipts trade, each including four ordinary shares, the price was $12.375 before the offer, but fell to $12 by the week's end.
Arguably, it is the American market reaction that is now the most important for Beazer. The company estimates that half its shares are now held by American institutions, up from little more than zero before the company went after Koppers in a 1988 hostile takeover that led to Congressional hearings focused on the decision by Shearson Lehman Brothers, Beazer's investment banker, to help with financing of the bid.
It is not hard to understand why the British are disenchanted, or why the Americans seem to like Beazer. The British investors have been disenchanted by the rapid growth of the company in this country, and by the poor performance of the shares, which were trading at £2.05 back in 1988, just before the Koppers bid was begun. But some Americans find the shares inexpensive at around 10 times last year's earnings.
In an interview, Mr. Beazer said the performance of the stock since his company undertook the Koppers takeover had been only slightly worse than that of the average British home-building company, but he conceded that British holders were not happy. "Our United Kingdom shareholders have made it very clear that they would like to see the debt substantially lower," he said.
For longtime British holders of the company founded by Mr. Beazer's father, the differences are striking. In 1983, the year that Mr. Beazer took over as chairman, the home builder had sales of £71 million, or $108 million at the exchange rate current at that time, and profits were £5.1 million ($7.7 million). For the 1990 fiscal year, ended last June, sales were £2.3 billion ($3.8 billion) and profits £38.9 million ($63.4 million). Then, the company made its money from British home building. Now, that is less than a fourth of the business.
Nearly all of the company's $1.3 billion in debt as of last June 30 was denominated in dollars, and stemmed from the American takeovers. That debt has come down some since then as the company has sold some operations and entered into joint ventures on others, principally concrete plants.
The most important American operations that Beazer has are in the aggregates business, producing crushed rocks used in construction. "There is a shortage of aggregates shares in the U.S.," said Mr. Beazer, explaining the apparent attraction of his stock to American investors.
The shares also have seemed cheap to some American analysts, among them Barbara Allen of Kidder, Peabody. In an interview she said she hoped the company would change its domicile to the United States, and thus adopt American accounting standards that would be more comfortable to investors here.
The standards are vastly different. The British rules would show higher reported profits, and thus a lower price-earnings ratio, but even under the American rules, the company is trading at only 10 times last year's earnings.
Those earnings could be slipping, however, as the recession and the fiscal problems confronting state governments cut into construction, especially of roads and bridges, where aggregates are heavily used. Nonetheless, many investors accept the argument that the need to fix up the nation's public works will eventually force the spending, and that Beazer will benefit.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Job Data Are Not Expected To Affect Fed Rein on Rates

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Ordinarily, most of the focus of the credit markets this week would be on the Government's report on April employment for a sign of the nation's economic condition. The report is scheduled to be released Friday morning.
But this is no ordinary period because no matter how many more nonfarm jobs vanished this month, the Federal Reserve last week repeatedly signaled that it had no intention of lowering interest rates in the foreseeable future. 
 The signals were sent when the Fed intervened six times in seven business days to drain reserves from the banking system in an effort to prop up the Federal funds rate. Not only is the funds rate the only one that the Fed controls with any degree of certainty, but it is also the rate that banks charge each other for temporary loans and is the rate from which most other interest rates are scaled upward.
 
Banks Amply Supplied
 Specifically, the consensus among money market analysts is that the Fed wants the funds rate to be 6 percent. That would make it the same as its discount rate, which is what the Fed charges banks for loans. But commercial banks have indirectly been sending their own signals -- that they are amply supplied with lendable reserves. Indeed, the Federal funds rate traded as low as 5.5 percent last week while the Fed was draining bank reserves. Last Friday, the funds rate traded at 5 7/8 percent for most of the day before briefly touching 6 percent at the close.
As for the employment data due out before the markets open on Friday, consulting economists at McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei Inc. believe that the figures will show another drop of 200,000 nonfarm jobs and that the nation's unemployment rate will thus rise by two-tenths of a percentage point, to 7 percent.
 
A More Narrow Focus
 But investors and traders in Treasury and other fixed-income debt issues tend to have a more narrow focus. Late last week, many credit market participants were speculating over what effect, if any, yesterday's meeting in Washington of the Group of Seven industrialized nations would have on interest rates and the value of the dollar and, by extension, values of Treasury and other fixed-income debt issues.
The next tests of the fixed-income market are due on May 7, 8 and 9, when the Treasury will auction what is expected to be a record amount of notes and bonds. The Treasury will announce the size of the auction on Wednesday afternoon.
In the Treasury securities market last week, two successful auctions were completed. One consisted of $12 billion of two-year notes and the other was $9 billion of five-year notes.
 
Rise in Price of Long Bonds
 One measure of the market's satisfaction was seen in the rise in price of the Treasury's benchmark long bonds. The offered price of the 30-year bonds rose to 96 9/32 from 95 29/ 29 during the week, while its yield declined to 8.20 percent from 8.24 percent.
"Perhaps the Bank of America sent the clearest signal when it reversed an earlier cut in its prime lending rate to 8.75 percent and lifted it back to 9 percent," said John G. Lonski, senior economist at Moody's Investors Service. "Perhaps the big West Coast bank acted on the expectation that a near-term easing of Fed policy was significantly less likely than originally thought when it cut its prime earlier in the week."
Major commercial banks have asserted that they have to rebuild their profit margins and become more prudent in their lending practices. Still, Mr. Lonski summed up the view of many money market analysts last week, saying, "Until banks seek out loan customers more aggressively by way of narrower spreads between their prime rates and their basic cost of funds, this recession may be far from over."
 
A More Optimistic View
 A somewhat more optimistic view was offered by Eugene J. Sherman, senior vice president and chief economist at the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York. "On one hand, the monetary policy has been, and is likely to continue to be, mildly restrictive," he said. "For example, the growth of the money supply since 1987 has been half the rate of growth that prevailed in the prior 17 years. Looking ahead, we believe that the Fed will not squander the investment in conservative money management it has made over the last four years by easing excessively in the months ahead."
But Mr. Sherman said he did expect an economic pickup to put some upward pressure on interest rates in the second half of 1991. The Federal funds rate, which has been ranging from 5.75 percent to 6 percent so far in the first half, may be allowed to go as high as 6.25 percent in the second half of the year, he said. He also expects the discount rate on 90-day bills to range from 5.85 percent to 6.20 percent in the second half. In recent weeks, the bill rate has moved from 5.90 percent to 5.65 percent.
Mr. Sherman said he also expected long-term Treasury bond yields, as measured by the 30-year bond, to decline to 8 percent or 7.5 percent in the second half from the current level of 8.20 percent.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Cuomo Strategy: Spare the Rich To Help the Poor

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Both selectively quote Franklin D. Roosevelt and Kevin Phillips's "The Politics of Rich and Poor." They agree that the Federal Government has abandoned urban America. And they express deep concern about the impact of New York State's budget on the poor. Then they part company.
Tomorrow marks the next round in their Dennis and Goliath oratorical battle of the ages. This is not a sanctioned championship bout. It will merely test crowd reaction, rather than officially crown the state's political heavyweight (although Goliath -- Gov. Mario M. Cuomo -- no longer reigns as the 800-pound gorilla former Mayor Edward I. Koch once called him; now in his third term, he is perceived more widely as a less dominant, but still imposing, 500-pound lame duck). 
 Dennis Rivera, a slight 40-year-old, heads Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Employees Union. His union was instrumental in electing Mr. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins. His members are mostly poor black and Hispanic women.
His philosophy is vintage New Deal. His politics is also traditional, which means he can generate a crowd -- as he intends to do tomorrow afternoon with other unions and social-service groups for a rally in lower Manhattan against the Governor's proposed budget.
Like any good politician, Mr. Rivera naturally abhors a vacuum. He is resourcefully filling a void created by less aggressive figureheads in the Democratic Party and organized labor, including most of the unions that represent mu nicipal employees.
Supplementing $250,000 in television advertising, his union has distributed posters promoting tomorrow's "rally to save New York."
Superimposed over a picture of an AIDS patient at St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan and a health-care worker is the caption: "Victims of New York's Budget Cuts."
 Below, the poster urges: "Stop the cuts. Tax the rich."
Mr. Rivera has framed the debate narrowly. But the reality is more complex.
The Governor is grappling with a projected $6 billion gap in his budget for the fiscal year that began four weeks ago. He proposes more economies than tax increases because he fears too many taxpayers would sail away to tax havens in other states, leaving Mr. Rivera's membership and other poor people haplessly waiting on the levee.
"If the quality of life deteriorates further, they will leave anyway," Mr. Rivera says of Mr. Cuomo's wealthier constituents. "What's going to happen in New York is a repeat of Detroit -- those who can escape will."
The Governor argues that income taxes should be raised, but by the Federal Government, not by states, which compete with one another.
"Dennis is confused," Mr. Cuomo says. "He says if that is your position for Washington, why don't you raise the state income tax? Because if you do it in Washington, you don't chase business to Canada and Mexico.
"What the Federal Government has done by reducing its income taxes is to push the burden of taxation to the states. That tears us apart as a nation when the rest of the world is learning the lesson of coalescence."
By shifting the state's burden to localities, Mr. Cuomo, perhaps by necessity, has jeopardized his own political coalition.
"They're saying they want to be preserved from the inconvenience of the recession, and I don't blame them," Mr. Cuomo says.
But an income-tax increase of $3 billion or more, he says, "would punish most of all the people they claim to represent."
"My budget is not going to affect education in one year," he said. "But you raise the income tax at this critical moment, with companies lining up to leave, and it would drive the remaining businesses out of New York City.
"There's no logic to their position unless you believe that business is not vulnerable, that Larry Tisch won't move, that we didn't have to pay $100 million to keep the commodities exchanges, and that Morgan Stanley is a cinch to stay.
"The union leaders are saying, 'Tax the rich.' It fits the sign; you need something that's short enough to be carried on a stick. But you don't make policy to deal with the toughest fiscal crisis in our history with slogans. What Dennis is doing is best for his union membership. Mine is a more complicated agenda."
The Governor faces two challenges. He has to balance the budget and he hints, philosophically at least, compromise with those who favor some income-tax increase.
Even more challenging is achieving a political balance and persuading his constituents that he has done so in their interest. The Governor's goal is to demonstrate that by sparing the rich from more onerous taxes, he is really protecting the poor.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Networks in a Quandary With Earlier Reruns

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
Over the next four weeks, television viewers will see mostly original episodes of their favorite series, a kind of springtime treat offered by the three broadcast networks.
The problem is the networks may have already alienated quite a few viewers with a winter full of ice-cold repeats. 
 New episodes of many series will run through May because it is a ratings sweep month, when most of the nation's television markets are measured by ratings services. The stations then set advertising rates for the next quarter based on the ratings that they achieve during that month.
 
Erosion of Audiences
 But in order to save original episodes for May, the networks have increasingly loaded up on repeats in earlier months.
Steve Sternberg, the vice president of broadcast research for the Bozell advertising agency, contends that this strategy is contributing to the erosion of audiences for network television. He said that holding back new series episodes for the May sweep "has to be a factor" in the networks' losing viewers in December, January, March and April.
Mr. Sternberg said that the networks still attracted sizable audiences in May, but that they were playing their new episodes to a smaller house because of the warmer weather. "There are 9 percent fewer viewers available in May than there are in Feburary," he said.
Mr. Sternberg, who conducted a study of the network rerun patterns going back to the 1982-83 television season, said his research indicated that the networks were repeating more programs than ever in those months. (The networks rarely rerun programs in February, which is another sweep month.)
<HB'A Real Problem'
 Repeats have always attracted fewer viewers than original episodes. Comedies hold their audience better but they only average about 75 percent of the audience an episode attracted in its first run. A drama often falls off by more than 50 percent.
"Repeats are a real problem." said David F. Poltrack, the senior vice president of reserach for CBS. He acknowledged that more viewers than ever leave the three networks when they see a repeat and try out the multitude of programs now available on independent and cable channels.
"Five years ago, we used to just shift the audience around when we had repeats," Mr. Poltrack said. "The viewers went to ABC or NBC when we had a repeat and they had an original show; they came to us when one of them had a repeat. Now, a viewer watching our show often hates the shows on NBC and ABC, and when he sees a repeat he just goes on to one of those other channels."
Mr. Sternberg said the heavy use of repeats throughout a television season created an additional problem: "Using that many repeats interrupts viewing patterns." He said viewers get frustrated when they see a rerun the week after an original episode. As a result, they tune in to a cable channel and can lose some of their commitment to the network series.
Mr. Poltrack agreed that a program's continuity was affected by the use of reruns, especially for dramas like "L.A. Law" and ABC's "Thirtysomething," which follow continuing storylines through a season.
But he said the economics of the television business, as well as an increasing trend toward slower delivery of programs, compelled a network to "ration its product."
He acknowledged such a policy could hurt a series, citing the CBS show "The Flash," which was forced to repeat an episode in only its third week on the air. "The early repeats killed that show," Mr. Poltrack said.
Alan Wurtzel, the senior vice president of research for ABC, said the networks had to balance many objectives. One of those is satisfying their affiliated stations, which want a strong showing in every sweep month.
Though he said that keeping the affiliates happy was the biggest reason why May had become an oasis of original programs, Mr. Poltrack conceded that the networks did have another economic reason. "It is a premium value month for advertising," with many commercials tied to Mother's Day and graduations, he said.
"The ideal is a 52-week year of original programming," he said. "But we all know the economics of television won't support that."
Indeed, the networks rely on reruns for a substantial part of their profits. They always buy two runs of a program for a licenses fee that averages about $900,000 an hour. Advertising revenue usually meets or exceeds the cost of the license fee in the first run, so the second run of a show is more or less pure profit.
Networks generally order 22 to 26 episodes of a series. If they ordered more, they would not be able to get two runs of a program in a year.
 
Closed-for-Business Sign
 Mr. Sternberg contended that keeping more new episodes in December, January and March might help stem some of the decline in the network audience.
But Mr. Wurtzel argued that stretching out new programs through May was advantageous to the networks. "I would have a real concern about concentrating all the episodes earlier and then putting up a closed-for-business sign at the end of March." he said.
Still, the networks need to do all they can to keep the repeats from bunching together in the middle of the season, Mr. Poltrack said. "You don't want to see two repeats anywhere near each other," he said.
But, he acknowledged, the load of repeated episodes was growing heavier.
"Three years ago, you never saw repeats as close together as you see them now," he said.

HEADLINE: Chinese Pupils' Good Fortune Is Multiplied

SERIES: A Village in China - One of an occasional series.

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: YEJUAO, China

 BODY:
In June, Dai Manju will celebrate a personal triumph: a quiet, pint-sized 14-year-old who is an ace student, she will become the first person in her family ever to graduate from elementary school.
Perhaps her family will even celebrate by eating a bit of meat. There is the plump hog nosing around the corridor outside her mud-rick home, but the family thinks it would be a bit extravagant to eat the pork instead of selling it. 
 "Oh, we can't eat meat regularly," the girl's father, Dai Hanren, a small, 36-year-old peasant, exclaimed, shaking his head when asked if the family splurges on meat once a week or even once a month. "Our custom is to eat meat only on special festivals."
 
A $9,900 Mistake
 Miss Dai dropped out of elementary school several times in the past because of inability to pay the $13 annual school fees, including room and board. But now she and most of her classmates are planning to stay in school, thanks to a series of contributions from the United States -- and thanks also to a clerical error by Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the New York bank, which mistakenly sent the school $10,000. Ten thousand dollars is more than 100 years' income for the typical peasant in this region.
There has been much rejoicing in Yejuao over the contributions, and Miss Dai says she will now be able to afford not only to complete elementary school and enter junior high, but also to attend senior high and perhaps even go to college and fulfill her dream of becoming a teacher.
"I like school, because I want to increase my knowledge and learn about everything happening in the world," Miss Dai said. "I'd like to thank the friendly Americans who sent money to keep me in school."
The peasants of Yejuao are still shaking their heads at the generosity of Americans, who would read an article and send $10,000 just like that. As for the bank, John M. Morris, a spokesman for Morgan Guaranty, said that such mistakes were very rare and that the bank would not try to reclaim the extra $9,900 that it sent.
"Under the circumstances, we're happy to make a donation of the difference," Mr. Morris said.
The error came about when 11 New York Times readers sent checks ranging from $13 to $100 to help Miss Dai and her classmates after reading an article in December about their struggle to stay in Yejuao Elementary School. Morgan Guaranty, in preparing a bank draft for Chinese yuan on behalf of one of the donors, neglected the decimal point in the exchange rate and sent $10,000 worth of yuan instead of $100 worth.
The triumphs and traumas of education in this remote part of the Dabie Mountains in Hubei Province are a window into Chinese rural life. Some 800 million of China's 1.1 billion inhabitants live in the countryside, where the expression "higher education" may mean -- as it is sometimes used in this area -- grades four through six. Going to school in little villages like Yejuao (pronounced yeh-joo-WOW) is still often regarded as a treasured opportunity, partly because it is relatively expensive.
Children like Dai Manju possess nothing but a few clothes, and their dreams. Miss Dai's home is in a collection of mud-brick huts on a hillside, a two-hour hike over mountain trails from the elementary school village of Yejuao. The Dai home has no electricity, no watch or clock, no bicycle, and no furnishings aside from beds, chairs and a coffin that the family has made for Miss Dai's 57-year-old great-aunt. She is healthy now, the adults explain, but it is best to be prepared.
Neither of the parents of Dai Manju went to school beyond the third grade, and both are illiterate. Only about a dozen people from her hamlet and the surrounding ones, with a total population of 1,300 people, have ever graduated from senior high school, none of them girls.
With the donations from American readers, Yejuao Elementary School provided scholarships, mostly ranging from 50 cents to a few dollars, to 92 of the 174 pupils. The parents of these pupils signed a roster to confirm receipt of the scholarship, or, if they were illiterate, solemnly affixed their thumbprints to the document.
Despite the scholarships -- and despite family visits by teachers -- five students dropped out of the elementary school at the beginning of the new semester after spring vacation this year. But without the money, even more would have dropped out, Li Huachun, the principal, said.
While money is the major reason why parents pull their children out of school, it is not the only one. Parents often want their children to help around the house or in the fields, and particularly for daughters, who will be married soon into other households, an elementary school education is sometimes regarded as an unessential luxury.
 
New School Is Built
 In addition to providing the scholarships, the authorities say they used most of the $10,000 from Morgan Guaranty to help build a new elementary school in the next village, to replace the Yellow Mud Elementary School, which is crowded and falling apart. The old school, which is made out of mud bricks and leaks in the snow and rain, is already jammed but is getting more children all the time.
To build the new school, the Government and a large Chinese company provided $30,000 (the corporate donor is Stone Corporation, a national computer company that is in political trouble for supporting the 1989 democracy movement and that is now trying to impress the Government with its altruism). Local peasants and officials chipped in a total of $5,000 in tiny contributions.
Funds are still a bit short, so to cut expenses hundreds of local parents have turned out to help build the elementary school.
"One of my kids is at the Yellow Mud Elementary School, and so I wanted to pitch in to build the new school," said Zhou Qishui, a barefoot 48-year-old peasant who was working with several dozen other parents on the site of the new building. Mr. Zhou, who himself dropped out of school in the fourth grade when his father died, contributed $2 to the project and is also donating 20 days of his labor.
"The kids are suffering in the old school, especially when it rains and leaks on them, so they'll be much better off here," Mr. Zhou said with satisfaction.
 
Officials Are Wary
 While local peasants and school officials seem very grateful for the gifts from Americans, the Government in the county seat 70 miles away appears to be a bit uncomfortable with the attention. County officials refused two requests to revisit the school earlier this year. Under Chinese law, a foreign journalist can travel outside Beijing only with the permission of local authorities.
When they did finally allow a return visit to the school, officials refused to allow a reporter to spend the night in the village of Yejuao itself, saying that "conditions are too backward." The officials did permit a visit to Dai Manju's home village, but once there they banned taking of any photos and attempted to ban interviews with residents other than the Mayor and the Dai family.
"This is too poor," explained Deng Jiesan, the county's director of foreign affairs, who had huffed along the mountain trails with a few other official escorts. Mr. Deng apparently believed that accounts of poverty might embarrass his county.
In some respects, conditions at rural chools are indeed miserable. Classrooms are unheated, so that in winter pupils fingers are sometimes so cold that they can barely write. Many students live in dormitory rooms six nights a week, sharing a large bed with a half-dozen classmates, and spend only Sunday at their homes.
 
No Metal Detectors
 The dormitory rooms have no running water, and the outhouses -- Yejuao Elementary School's toilet consists of three holes in the ground, surrounded by a low wall -- are putrid and unlit at night. There are no bathing facilities, and in winter the students wear the same clothes all week.
Yet if the schools get by without hot water, they also manage without metal detectors. In some respects, the spirit in Yejuao Elementary School, and others visited in various parts of China, seems more upbeat than in many urban American schools. Crime and vandalism are almost unknown, teachers are honored -- the students stand at attention and utter a respectful greeting when the teacher enters the room -- and the most popular students are not the athletes or the trouble-makers but the most gifted academically.
Naughty students are universal, however, and Yejuao Elementary School has a few. The mischief-makers are not beaten, unless they do something that risks their lives, and normally teachers rely on discussions with the students and the parents -- teachers go to the homes of all their students at least once a year -- to resolve the problems.
The teachers can also send the students to Mr. Li, the principal, who has his own method of last resort.
"If we had a really bad student, I would put up a poster describing his misbehavior and calling on him to repent," Mr. Li said. "But that would be very rare. I've been at this school for more than a year and that hasn't happened yet."

HEADLINE: Fears on Cut In U.S. Arms;
Shrinking of Industry Is Called Dangerous

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
As Pentagon budgets decline sharply, every big weapons contract takes on added importance for military contractors. But few contracts define the stakes so starkly as the selection the Navy will make soon of a company to build its next attack submarine.
 Industry executives and Government officials say that what is at stake is the survival of one of the two remaining submarine-building shipyards -- the General Dynamics Corporation's Electric Boat division in Groton, Conn. 
 Electric Boat has said that unless it receives the next Seawolf contract, which could be awarded as soon as this week, it will probably not have enough business to stay open beyond the middle of the decade. A closing of Electric Boat would mean the loss of 22,000 jobs at the company and thousands more at its suppliers and subcontractors.
That would leave the Navy totally dependent for its submarines on a single source, Tenneco Inc.'s Newport News shipyard in Virginia.
While the Seawolf program would be "a matter of relative prosperity for Newport News, it now appears to be a matter of survival for Electric Boat and much of the submarine industrial supplier base in New England," James E. Turner Jr., Electric Boat's general manager, told a Congressional hearing last month.
The situation at Electric Boat is just one example of how declining military budgets and the resulting shrinkage of the contracting business are raising fears within the Government and the industry of a permanent erosion in the nation's ability to design and manufacture weapons.
The Air Force's selection last week of a team headed by the Lockheed Corporation to build a new generation of fighter planes gave Lockheed and its partners, General Dynamics and the Boeing Company, a solid base of military aircraft orders for the next two decades. And it left the losing team, the Northrop Corporation and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, seemingly dropped from the front ranks of the combat aircraft business, and in the long run, perhaps even being forced out of the field.
The Army is down to one tank manufacturer, General Dynamics, which is struggling to win enough domestic and foreign tank orders to keep its production line open after 1995. And the Army's selection earlier this month of Boeing and the United Technologies Corporation's Sikorsky division to build a new light attack helicopter seems to doom McDonnell Douglas's helicopter operations to a long period of retrenchment.
The Grumman Corporation, formerly the premier builder of Navy aircraft, is lobbying furiously in Congress to overturn a decision by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to end the F-14 fighter program. Mr. Cheney's decision would essentially force Grumman out of the aircraft-building business.
 
Only Moderately Concerned
 So far Pentagon officials say they are only moderately concerned about the industry's diminishing size and strength and its ability to provide military superiority to the nation's forces.
In announcing the selection of the Lockheed team last week, Air Force Secretary Donald B. Rice said concerns about the military contracting industry played no role in his decision. He added that the Air Force "will simply have to leave to market forces" the question of whether some companies leave the airplane business.
Some people argue that the shrinking of the industry is overdue, since it has been plagued for years with overcapacity, particularly in aircraft manufacturing. Many Government officials say it would be a mistake to start awarding weapons contracts on any basis other than merit and cost.
But as more companies approach the day when they must mothball their assembly lines, dismiss engineering and scientific staffs and cut back on research, there are growing warnings -- some, predictably, motivated by self-interest and pork-barrel politics -- that the Pentagon should slow the dismantling of the industrial base on which it has relied.
In a speech last month, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, said, "Our declining defense industrial base and the long-term consequences of decisions made today about the procurement of weapons systems" amount to a "serious problem that threatens to endanger the security of the United States." He urged the Navy to give the Seawolf contract to Electric Boat.
Many industry executives and analysts and Government officials stop short of calling for the Pentagon to take an active role in managing the shrinkage of the industry. But they say the military should do more to define what it needs to insure that the appropriate industrial abilities are retained.
"We still face the question of what is the minimum capability we require and what are the necessary inefficiencies we need to put up with in order to maintain it," said Gordon Adams, the director of the Defense Budget Project, a nonpartisan research group based in Washington. "Even if they are making the decisions without industrial base considerations, the decisions have industrial base implications."
 
$726 Million Contract
 The implications are clear on the Seawolf program. Electric Boat won a competition with Newport News several years ago to build the first Seawolf under a $726 million contract. The Navy originally planned to buy three or four Seawolfs a year and to split the business between Electric Boat and Newport News. The Navy thought the competition between the shipyards would bring down the program's costs.
But with the cold war apparently over and Pentagon budgets being slashed, the Navy now plans on buying no more than one Seawolf a year.
"We need to honestly face the fact that long-term procurement of one submarine per year will not sustain both submarine construction yards," H. Lawrence Garrett 3d, the Secretary of the Navy, told a Congressional committee several weeks ago.
The military aircraft business is also being forced to shrink. The Northrop-McDonnell Douglas team's loss on the new fighter program last week leaves Northrop's future almost totally dependent on the B-2 Stealth bomber program, which accounts for more than half the company's revenues. If the B-2 were to be canceled after the 15 planes the Air Force has already ordered -- a step many in Congress think is likely this year -- Northrop would be left as a producer of missiles and electronics systems and as a subcontractor on a few aircraft programs.
McDonnell Douglas has a large backlog of commercial and transport aircraft orders. But over the next several years, most of its biggest combat aircraft programs will end, including the F-15 and AV-8B fighters and the Apache helicopter. Earlier this year, the Navy canceled the company's other big hope for the future, the A-12 attack plane.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Seeks A Budget Talk With All Sides

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
After a grim weekend reviewing painful proposals to slash city services, Mayor David N. Dinkins last night asked labor leaders and city and state officials, including Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, to join him this week for what city leaders called a crucial meeting to discuss the city's worsening plight.
City officials said that at the meeting, Mr. Dinkins would lay out a plan that would include thousands of layoffs to close a budget gap of $3.5 billion for the fiscal year that begins on July 1 and would ask for immediate concessions from the state and from unions to head off the worst of the cuts. 
 "It is clear," said First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel, "if we are going to present a viable plan we are going to need help on at least those fronts."
One senior administration official said, "We are in the eighth inning now."
Behind the meeting call is a deep concern that the Dinkins administration's separate efforts to win concessions from its unions and get help from the state have been foundering, officials said. Such an appearance of continued disarray could undermine the confidence of the financial markets when city sells bonds next month, they said.
Union leaders have refused to consider cost-saving concessions until they see a complete long-term plan to solve the city's fiscal problems, including help from the state. Governor Cuomo and Felix G. Rohatyn, the financier who heads the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was set up during the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's to sell bonds for the city, have raised similar concerns about the need for long-term planning.
Mr. Steisel said that the meeting would be held later this week, the week before the May 10 scheduled release of Mr. Dinkins's budget. Officials said the budget would include the kind of service cuts -- including the closing of dozens of libraries and cuts in street sweeping and social services -- that Mr. Dinkins had been warning would be "awesome" and "painful."
"People will be shocked by the nature of the cuts," Mr. Steisel said. "There is a concern that whatever it looks like, people will believe it is a manageable plan, so there are no doubts in the financial marketplace that we are able to do it."
Stephen Villano, a spokesman for Governor Cuomo, said that Mr. Dinkins called the Governor yesterday to invite him to the meeting. He said that Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Dinkins agreed to meet separately this week to go over the city's plans and that the Governor "will have representatives" at the broader meeting.
Later, in a telephone interview, Mr. Cuomo said that he had long advocated bringing together government and labor and other constituent groups to address the city's problems and that he welcomed the Mayor's initiative. "At one point everybody must come together as we did in 1975," he said.
 
Cuomo Concerned About Cuts
 He said that the budget plan Mr. Dinkins was now drafting was crucial and had to show that the city had a "certain structural balance," with its spending plans matching its revenues for years to come. At the same time he said he was concerned that cuts in services not be too deep.
"A too-drastic cut in some services could do as much damage as any other mistake you could make," he said.
Over the weekend, Mr. Dinkins completed a review of reductions that made deep cuts in the city's capital spending, halving spending by many agencies -- including libraries, highways, cultural institutions and the Fire Department -- over the next four years to reduce the city's rapidly mounting debt-service costs.
These deep cuts, which would be needed even if the city fends off the worst of the cuts in services. would help the city reduce overall capital spending by 15 percent, to $16.2 billion. Some of the cuts would be offset by a plan to spend an extra $500 million to build more jails -- which will receive $1 out of every $10 in construction money. Deep cuts are also planned in the city's school construction program.
 
Last-Minute Reprieves
 In last-minute negotiations, Mr. Dinkins agreed to restore some planned cuts in the Parks Department -- which was preparing to eliminate most tree planting -- in economic development and in housing, in which Mr. Dinkins restored financing for a large rehabilitation program centered on Bradhurst Avenue in Harlem and Saratoga Square in Brooklyn.
Late yesterday, after a five-hour budget session in the library at Gracie Mansion, Mr. Dinkins began calling the Speaker of the Council, Peter F. Vallone, City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, Mr. Cuomo, Mr. Rohatyn and union leaders to invite them to attend.
On Saturday, Mr. Dinkins spent eight hours working through proposals sketched out by his budget officials. City commissioners will have a chance to appeal some of the proposed cuts in the next day or two.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor David N. Dinkins meeting with members of his staff at Gracie Mansion yesterday. Later, the Mayor asked for a meeting with union leaders and city and state officials, at which he will announce a plan calling for layoffs and concessions. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Plea by U.S. On Rate Cut Is Rejected

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 28

 BODY:
The world's largest industrial nations considered and rejected today a Bush Administration request that Europe, and in particular Germany, lower interest rates. But they agreed to consider the request in the future.
That, in effect, was the gist of an eight-paragraph communique issued after a nearly seven-hour meeting of finance ministers and central bank presidents from the so-called Group of Seven nations: the United States, Germany, Britain, France, Italy, Canada and Japan. 
 The communique recognized both the Bush Administration's pressure for lower interest rates as a means of ending the recession in the United States and avoiding one in Europe, and the German Government's refusal to force down rates and risk increasing inflation in that country.
 
Outcome Called a Standoff
 Various officials described the outcome as a standoff. "You come to a fight, and everything does not happen in the first round; what you saw today was the first round," said an executive of the International Monetary Fund, who insisted on anonymity. Most of the ministers will also attend the I.M.F.'s spring meeting, which starts on Monday.
United States Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, at a briefing after the Group of Seven meeting, acknowledged that he considered European interest rates, adjusted for inflation, to be too high. When asked about his differences with Germany on this point, he kept referring to a phrase in the communique that called for policies that provide "the basis for lower real interest rates and a sustained global economic recovery with price stability."
 
Both Views Recognized
 The phrasing recognized the Administration's request for lower rates, as well as the German insistence on price stability, which means minimum inflation -- a goal that central banks usually achieve by keeping rates relatively high.
Short-term rates in Germany today are roughly 9 percent, while American rates on short-term securities are around 6 percent.
The communique described the compromise as "a medium-term strategy." It added that the ministers had "agreed to monitor the situation closely and to take actions as needed within the coordination process with a view to achieving a sound recovery and a growing world economy."
While the United States struggles through a recession, most European economies are experiencing weaker economic growth this year. Mr. Brady suggested that if the recession failed to end this summer, as many economists have predicted, and Europe moves closer to a recession, then the dispute over interest rates was likely to resurface.
"We have to wait and see if economic growth returns in the summer," he said.
But the Bush Administration apparently could not get action now for a coordinated adjustment in the interest rates of the industrial countries. While the ministers did not disclose how the debate went, others said the United States probably had support from France and Britain, while concern over inflation apparently put Canada, Italy and perhaps Japan in the German camp.
The finance ministers and central bank chiefs spent 45 minutes with President Bush at a White House reception this morning, then crossed the street to Blair House, the Government's guest quarters, where their session was held.
Douglas Davidson, a White House spokesman, said the President's conversation with those at the reception was "private and personal."
Theo Waigel, the German Finance Minister, told reporters as he left the White House that Mr. Bush had spoken of the need to get interest rates down, in the United States and abroad, although he did so without reproaching the Germans for their refusal to lower rates.
The Bush Administration is concerned that the economic slowdown in Western Europe will reduce demand for American products. Exports to Europe have helped to offset the drop in sales at home, limiting the damage from the recession. If exports were to fall now, the recession might be harder to shake off, economists say.
The Administration, as a result, has urged the Europeans, and particularly Germany, which dominates the European economy, to lower interest rates as a means of stimulating growth. Lower rates would encourage people to borrow for spending.
But the Germans say they are already big importers. Karl Otto Pohl, president of the Bundesbank, the German central bank, said in a speech on Friday that German purchases of goods from other Western European countries had risen by 20 percent.
"Unfortunately, our imports from the United States have declined," he said. "I don't know the reason."
Mr. Pohl noted that western Germany was sending billions of dollars to eastern Germany to subsidize its transition to a market economy. The German Government argues that this investment will eventually pay off in rising east German demand for goods, including American goods. Meanwhile, the Germans argue that if their central bank pushed down interest rates, the extra incentive to borrow might be inflationary, creating too much demand at a time when resources are being channeled to eastern Germany.
"The answer is not to lower rates, but to accept for a period of time, high real rates," Mr. Pohl said last week. "This is the logical result of a shortage of capital."
The value of the dollar against the mark, the yen and the other major currencies, which had been such a central theme at previous Group of Seven meetings, took a back seat this time. Officials of the Bush Administration and the Federal Reserve say that while the dollar has risen in value in recent weeks, it is moving up from a very low level and is not an obstacle to exports.

HEADLINE: Orders for Machine Tools Fell in March

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 28

 BODY:
New orders for American-made machine tools fell sharply in March, according to a report scheduled to be released on Monday.
The report is yet another sign of the severity of the recession. On Friday, the Government reported that the nation's economy, as measured by the gross national product, declined 2.8 percent in the first three months of the year. 
 The Association for Manufacturing Technology, an industry trade group based in McLean, Va., said new tool orders in March fell 22.7 percent from the level of a year ago and 16.2 percent from February.
Machine tools cut or shape metal and are used in manufacturing.
 
Clues to Health of Economy
 Although the market for machine tools is relatively small, its level of activity can provide clues to the health of manufacturing and the economy in general.
The level fell sharply in March to $205.5 million, down from $265.9 million a year earlier and $245.2 million in February.
Despite the decline in orders, the association's president, Albert W. Moore, took an optimistic view, saying orders in the first three months of the year were still running close to last year's level.
In this year's first quarter, new machine tool orders totaled $650.5 million, compared with $661.7 million in the 1990 quarter.
"We think it illustrates the improving competitiveness of the U.S. machine tool industry," Mr. Moore said in a statement.
The quarterly decline of 1.7 percent percent comes "despite the strengthening U.S. dollar and uncertainty and weakness in many major foreign markets," Mr. Moore said.
In its monthly report, the trade group said March shipments of machine tools totaled $278.2 million, up 37.6 percent, from $202.2 million in February, and off 3.7 percent from $288.9 million a year earlier.
Foreign orders totaled $46.4 million in March, a 42 percent drop from $80.1 million in February, and down 39.2 percent from the $76.3 million posted in March 1990.
 
Foreign Shipments Up in March
 Foreign shipments totaled $42.1 million in March, up 24 percent from $33.9 million in February, but off slightly from $42.7 million a year earlier.
The trade group said metal-cutting orders fell 17.5 percent in March, to $153.6 million, from $186.3 million in February, and were down 22.5 percent from $198.2 million a year ago.
Metal-cutting shipments rose 30.8 percent, to $174.2 million, in March, from $133.2 million in February, but were down 18.7 percent from $214.2 million a year earlier.
Total March orders for metal-forming tools were down 12 percent, to $51.9 million, from February's $58.9 million, and down 23.4 percent from $67.7 million in March last year.
Metal-forming shipments jumped 50.8 percent, to $104.1 million, from February's $69 million and were up 39.2 percent from the $74.8 million of March 1990.
The association said the March backlog for orders was $1.45 billion, down from $1.53 billion in February. In 1990, the March backlog totaled $1.68 billion.

HEADLINE: Kohlberg, Kravis Rouses Itself

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
After almost two years of struggling with its previous investments as the "junk bond" market collapsed, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the giant buyout firm that became a corporate titan in the 1980's, appears to be back on a roll.
In one week, the firm, which has not made a large purchase in two years, began to snap up corporate properties again. It backed the bid that won Federal approval to buy the assets of the Bank of New England. And K-III Holdings, a company controlled by Kohlberg, Kravis, agreed to buy nine publications from Rupert Murdoch's debt-laden News Corporation for $650 million. 
 The deals are vastly different from the firm's well-worn leveraged buyout formula. Kohlberg, Kravis became known in the 80's for breakups -- selling pieces of a company to reduce the mountains of debt used in the purchase. But in the 90's, it is turning to "build-ups," in which it enlarges existing companies by acquiring assets.
 
A Consistent Philosophy
 In both the Bank of New England and Murdoch deals, Kohlberg, Kravis used its own capital to purchase the assets of troubled companies. The firm is injecting $283 million into the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group Inc., a financial services company, for the purchase of the Bank of New England assets. To support the Murdoch deal, it is expected to make another investment in K-III, a company formed by three former executives of the publisher Macmillan Inc. with backing from Kohlberg, Kravis.
"The two deals are very similar in philosophy," said one executive with ties to Kohlberg, Kravis. "It is an investment of their funds' capital in a program of building up a business."
The strategy is again putting Kohlberg, Kravis at the front of some high-profile deals. But even some investors with the firm say they do not believe the approach will enable the company to regain the fantastic returns on investments -- as much as 63 percent on an annualized basis on its first 16 deals -- it enjoyed in the mid-80's.
The new deals are far smaller than the firm's mega-transactions, like the $25 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco Inc. -- which, with financing expenses, ultimately cost Kohlberg, Kravis $32 billion -- negotiated in late 1988 and early 1989. But the deals signal that Kohlberg, Kravis is ready to start reaching into its deep pockets again. And the two new deals show that the firm is continuing to rely on borrowed money.
In large part, the switch from selling assets after a leveraged buyout to buying assets from troubled companies reflects the current condition of the economy, investment managers and Wall Street professionals say.
"I think building companies now makes extraordinary sense," said Scott Sperling, a partner at the Harvard Management Company, which runs the endowment fund for the university and is an investor with Kohlberg, Kravis. The buyout firm "has the ability to buy low," he said. "Backing a superior management team to acquire those sorts of pieces I think is a brilliant way of approaching the business."
 
Built From Scratch
 From its beginnings in 1976, Kohlberg, Kravis used leveraged buyouts to rise from next to nothing -- it had just $3 million to invest in 1976 -- to control an empire that includes RJR Nabisco, supermarket chains, like Stop and Shop and Safeway Inc., and Duracell International Inc. Since its inception, the firm has acquired 36 companies at a cost of about $65 billion.
The debt-driven buyout helped make the firm's founders extremely wealthy. Henry R. Kravis, George R. Roberts and their former partner, Jerome Kohlberg Jr., who left in 1987 over what partners said was his concern about the size of the firm's deals, are each estimated to be worth hundreds of millions of dollars. At the same time, Mr. Kravis assumed a prominent role in New York society, particularly since his marriage in 1985 to Carolyne Roehm, a fashion designer. Mr. Roberts, who is Mr. Kravis's cousin, works out of the firm's San Francisco office and tends to shun publicity.
In a leveraged buyout, a group of investors buys a company, often in cooperation with top managers, and pays for it mostly with borrowed money. In theory, the new owners begin cutting away at excess, dismissing unneeded employees and selling operations that have little to do with the core business. The company is then resold for a handsome profit.
 
Tapping Pools of Capital
 Kohlberg, Kravis raised the equity used in the buyouts by selling its investment skills to institutional investors and money managers. Since 1978, the firm has tapped its investors' capital pools six times for the formation of different buyout funds, and recently went back to investors to replenish the fund collected in 1987. The firm says it manages the money of more than 70 institutions.
In past years, when the firm put in only about 10 percent equity, it greatly increased the potential return for itself and its investors through the high degree of leverage. Now, with banks less willing to lend for highly leveraged transactions and the junk bond market essentially unavailable for raising large amounts of capital, Kohlberg, Kravis expects that the equity portion of deals could rise as high as 30 percent.
With more capital required for leveraged buyouts, the firm is exploring other investment strategies, company documents and Wall Street executives indicate.
 
Using a Minority Stake
 Kohlberg, Kravis has also adopted a so-called "toehold" approach to investing, in which it takes a minority stake in a publicly held company and uses its own investment as a signal of its confidence in the concern. The best known of those is its 9.9 percent holding in First Interstate Bancorp.
At the same time, Kohlberg, Kravis has been dipping into the capital markets to shore up the balance sheets of companies it bought in leveraged buyouts. Indeed, this month, Kohlberg, Kravis turned to the stock and bond markets six times, raising money for Safeway, Autozone Inc. and RJR Nabisco. A stock offering for Duracell International is awaiting approval from the Securities and Exchange Commission.
 
The Firm's High Fees
 The firm's investors are now wondering if the changes in investment strategy will be able to bring them returns close to those in the 80's, enough to justify paying the firm's high fees. Under the fee structure, Kohlberg, Kravis charges a 1.5 percent annual fee for managing the money invested with it, as well as investment banking fees, divestiture fees, consulting fees and a smattering of other charges.
On its four largest deals, the firm is estimated to have charged its limited partners $240 million up front. And on top of that, the firm gets to keep 20 percent of any capital gains from an investment.
Some limited partners in past Kohlberg, Kravis ventures voiced objections when the firm began seeking $1 billion to $2 billion to replenish the $5.6 billion buyout fund that the firm raised in 1987. The investors wanted Kohlberg, Kravis to cut its fees and change the method by which the firm treats gains and losses of companies in its portfolio.
 
Protected Profits
 Kohlberg, Kravis treats each company in its portfolio separately, giving itself 20 percent of the profits of every company that does well, while only taking 1 percent of the losses for the poor performers. The firm can profit even if the limited partners do not.
"They make a lot of money whether or not I as a limited partner make money," said Mr. Sperling of Harvard, who has not decided whether he will invest in the new Kohlberg, Kravis fund. "We want them to make money, but only after we make money."
Some institutional investors are finding that by using the asset-investing strategy by themselves they are able to produce returns equal to those from Kohlberg, Kravis when their costs of investing in the firm are considered. And that is leading them to stay out of this round of money raising.
But despite the grumbling, Kohlberg, Kravis's track record is still bringing in the institutional investors.
"I don't blame them for sticking to their guns on the fee issue," the manager of another fund that still invests with the firm said. "If I could get the money on those terms, I wouldn't change things either."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Saudi General Sees No Need For Big American Presence

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, April 28

 BODY:
A senior Saudi official says he does not think that Saudi Arabia would need or want a larger American military presence than it had before the Persian Gulf war. He also says no decision has been made about whether the United States would be permitted to store heavy military equipment in the kingdom.
In an interview Friday, Prince Khaled ibn Sultan, who commanded the Arab and Islamic forces in the coalition that ousted Iraq from Kuwait, said Saudi history, traditions and culture all weighed against a substantial American presence in his country. Any increase in American military personnel here should be limited to training functions, he said, adding that the number of new trainers would depend on the amount of new American arms purchased. 
 Speaking as American forces continue to pull out of Saudi Arabia in the aftermath of the gulf war, the Prince suggested that American military officials should not expect, as they apparently have, the Saudi Government's agreement that the most efficient way of deterring a future threat to this oil-rich kingdom of 7 million people would be to leave behind a stockpile of American weapons in the event American troops have to return here rapidly.
 
'Give Me Time'
 "It has not been talked about," Prince Khaled said. "I would say, if I were asked, give me time. I have to study it. And I have many questions that need to be answered: What is your threat? What is your future threat?"
After the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, hundreds of thousands of American troops were sent to Saudi Arabia to counter what was viewed as the imminent danger of an Iraqi attack on this kingdom. But the Prince, asked whether he thought Saudi Arabia was now so vulnerable given the destruction inflicted on Iraq, said, "I can't see that much of a threat now."
The Prince's skepticism about American plans to pre-position heavy equipment here is likely to surprise some American officials, since Prince Khaled is considered among the most pro-American of Saudi military officials, one who cooperated closely with Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the commander of the coalition's American and British forces.
A Western official who asked not to be identified confirmed Prince Khaled's assertion that the Saudi Government had not yet made a decision on the stockpiling issue. But he expressed confidence that King Fahd would eventually decide that storing some military equipment here and elsewhere in the gulf in event of a crisis made economic and military sense.
 
U.S. Stresses Stockpiling
 American officials have made stockpiling of weapons in the kingdom a key element in their strategy to improve security and defense in the gulf after the defeat of Iraq.
[In Washington, the Pentagon spokesman, Pete Williams, declined to characterize the Saudis' position. saying the issue of pre-positioning military equipment was still under discussion.]
A Western diplomat said an American general had arrived in the kingdom last week to begin a joint study with the Saudi military of the security threats to the kingdom and the region.
Prince Khaled said he expected that departing American units would take virtually all their weapons and equipment back to the United States with them and that very little equipment or arms would be stored here.
"I don't recall any storage of any equipment," he said when asked about reports that the United States military planned to stockpile some equipment here and leave American soldiers behind to guard it. "There has been no discussion about it. And I don't think it will be discussed."
The best way to avert future threats and to insure that the United States would not be called upon again to rush to the kingdom's defense, he said, was to support Saudi Arabia's plans to triple the size of its armed forces and enlarge and enhance its weapons arsenal. Therefore, he added, he hoped that Congress would respond favorably to Saudi bids to purchase advanced American weapons.
"I think Americans would appreciate it more if we increased the size of our armed forces and reduced the chance of sending them back here," he said.
When asked why such advanced weapons should be sold to the kingdom if, as he maintained, it now faced little military threat, Prince Khaled said he had no objection to limiting arms sales to Saudi Arabia provided such restraints were applied "equally throughout the region, including to Israel."
An initial $7.3 billion arms sale to Saudi Arabia passed Congress after the seizure of Kuwait and before the beginning of the gulf war. The rest of the $21 billion package proposed by the Administration, however, was deferred and has been mentioned recently in light of stiff opposition from Congress and budget constraints in the kingdom, which ran a $15 billion deficit in the first quarter of this year.
 
Equipment Training Favored
 Regarding the presence of American military personnel here, the Prince said: "In the future, I think we will take just the number needed to train on new equipment. It depends on how much new equipment we take."
Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, are both said to favor reversing American policy to allow some American ground forces to be permanently stationed in Saudi Arabia as part of any joint security arrangements in the region with Arab nations. Both are said to favor storing at least a division's worth of heavy equipment here -- tanks and other heavy arms -- to avoid the long delays in shipping such materiel to the peninsula in the event that Saudi Arabia is once again threatened.
But the issue of a large, visible or permanent American presence -- of men or American-controlled weapons -- continues to be politically delicate in the kingdom. After Iraq seized Kuwait in August, religious conservatives initially challenged American assistance here on grounds that it would lead to a permanent presence.
In the 1950's, the United States used an air force base in Dhahran. But the Americans left in the early 1960's because of protests by radical Arabs. Until the gulf war, Americans have only sent trainers here, and the kingdom has maintained a policy of refusing even joint ground exercises on Saudi soil.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
The Bush Administration will recommend a sharp increase in the supervision of the Government-sponsored companies that help to finance home purchases, higher education and agriculture. Officials say they are concerned that the enterprises have grown so large so quickly that their potential liabilities to taxpayers total more than $1 trillion. [Page A1.]
A family is on the verge of losing land in Kansas that it has owned for more than 50 years, in a tangled tale involving a failed bank, missing documents and a private investment partnership that a former F.D.I.C. official helped set up. [A1.] 
 The Group of Seven industrial nations rejected a U.S. request that Europe, and in particular Germany, lower interest rates as a means of ending the recession in the United States. But they agreed to reconsider the request in the future. [D1.]
Economic growth in the Boston area has been hurt by a Federal judge's order that prevents new customers from getting access to the metropolitan sewer system. [D1]
Few Pentagon contracts so starkly define the stakes in an era of declining budgets as the selection the Navy will soon make of the company to build its next attack submarine. News Analysis. [D1.]
The Army's program to incinerate chemical weapons is falling years behind schedule and costing much more than expected. [A1.] About 2,400 tons of contaminated soil is on its way to Utah for disposal after sitting in a CSX train yard for three days. [A12.]
New orders for American-made machine tools fell sharply in March, dropping 22.7 percent from a year earlier and 16.2 percent from February. The report is yet another sign of the severity of the recession. [D2.]
 
COMPANIES
Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts appears to be back on a roll after almost two years of struggling with its previous investments as the "junk bond" market collapsed. This time, however, the buyout firm, which had been known for breaking up some companies, is looking to build up some others. [D1.]
